webTitle: New rules will force cowboy agents into last-chance saloon

fields.headline: New rules will force cowboy agents into last-chance saloon
fields.trailText: If the game's reformers have their way regulations to enforce strict control of agents' activities will be in place next season.
fields.body:
The Wild West spanned a period of not much more than 25 years. Then the railroads brought some sort of civilisation and the fun was over. It is tempting to believe that the sharper-shooting football agents are also about to be driven out of the cowboy business. If the game's reformers have their way regulations to enforce strict control of agents' activities will be in place next season.

Central to the proposed new rules is the insistence that agents must not offer players to other clubs while they are still under contract. If they do the Football Association will be able to stop a transfer going through.

The FA and the Premier League are keen to clean up the buying and selling of players before the imminent changes in the whole transfer system, necessary to bring it into line with the European Union labour laws, produce an even more anarchic situation than at present.

David Dein, the Arsenal vice-chairman, is a leading advocate of regulating the agents' activities. Dein is still smarting from the way Nicolas Anelka's brothers - Claude and Didier by name, Frank and Jesse by nature - hawked their sibling around Europe while he was still an Arsenal player to the extent that the club eventually sold the disturbed Anelka to Real Madrid against the London club's wishes.

Dein has an important ally from the other side - Jon Holmes, an agent in a white hat, who is equally keen to curb the activities of the bandits. For a long time now Holmes, one of whose clients singlehandedly changed the nation's potato crisp-eating habits, has wanted the agents' trade put on a professionally regulated footing.

At present, as Holmes points out, all any person needs to become a Uefa-registered football agent is the deposit of 100,000 Swiss francs (£41,000). Well, that and a good head for figures, a telephone masquerading as a third ear, a great deal of verbal dexterity, more contacts than the instrument panel of an Apollo spacecraft and a limitless supply of chutzpah.

Agents are seen by some as parasitical wheeler-dealers and a disruptive influence on the game; by others as cynical manipulators of footballers' careers. It is, however, difficult to generalise. Some, like Holmes, are simply looking after their clients' best interests on and off the field and in this they are no different from the agents of authors, actors or TV personalities.

The cigar-chomping Eric Hall, with a background in pop music, may come across as a caricature of a football agent but if he was not good at his job players would no longer employ his services. For more than 10 years Mel Stein - an adviser, please note, not an agent - has supervised the playing career of Paul Gascoigne, which at least says something for Stein's staying power.

Then there is the king of the swingers, the football jungle's VIP, Dennis Roach by name and a logical product of the player's metamorphosis from modestly paid artisan to multimillionaire showbusiness property. Glenn Hoddle's business association with Dennis might have put some in mind of Wyatt Earp and Doc Holliday, but Roach, no less than any other agent, reflects the prime motivating force among footballers which is not so much greed as the need for financial security.

What critics of the considerable salaries commanded by the game's leading talents forget is that the period of a player's highest earning potential is not much more than six years. For a striker relying on pace it is often shorter and while goalkeepers and defenders can go on much longer all run the risk of seeing their careers ended by one tackle or even a fall at the wrong angle.

Players need agents and advisers to guide them through the labyrinthine details of transfers, contracts, the renewal of contracts and every extramural earning activity from promoting pizzas to finding ghost writers for their autobiographies.

True, all contracts could go through the Professional Footballers' Association but that is as likely as Equity handling everything from Arsenic and Old Lace at the local rep to the next James Bond. Independent agents will always be essential to players' careers provided their activities can be controlled in the sort of manner suggested by Dein and Holmes.

What football cannot afford, however, is the free for all which will follow if, at the EU's behest, players are able to move where they like, when they like, with contracts worth about as much as bus tickets. If this happens the manager's role will become redundant as far as team-building is concerned. As is it the number of clubs still able to maintain continuity in their squads from one season to the next is diminishing fast.

Pinning irregular transfers on rogue agents will not be easy. So much of football's business is conducted on a nod and a wink . . . nudge, nudge . . . know what I mean? . . . say no more! Easy to talk about, difficult to prove.

But rectifying the agent's image would be a start. And Dick Barton would surely be an improvement on Dick Turpin.

fields.headline: Raiding the larder
fields.standfirst: Patricia Fenn finds fine food and frescoes in the Po valley
fields.trailText: Patricia Fenn finds fine food and frescoes in the Po valley.
fields.body:
If truth be told, the mighty Po, Italy's longest river at 675km, is no beauty. The waters are khaki, the banks are high, the wild life scarce; worst of all, the danger of flooding in its immense fertile valley limited the development of local communities along its course. In fact, there are no towns punctuating the 85km stretch covered by the KD Line cruiseship MV Venezia, from Venice to Cremona.

That's the bad news; the good is that the cruise offers a hassle-free opportunity to visit some of Italy's most interesting cities, all rich in history and, not surprisingly for a region referred to as the larder of Italy, good food. The Venezia glides between them in a watery green world far removed from urban pressures, her passengers relaxing on the upper deck, with no more effort involved on their part than remembering what time the coach leaves the next tie-up to transport them to another cultural delight.

Any cruise that begins in Venice is guaranteed to get off to a good start. There can be few more favoured bases from which to explore La Serenissima than from a vessel tied up on the quayside of the Sette Martiri, just a short walk from Piazza San Marco. From the upper deck, the vista down the Grand Canal begs to be photographed. To starboard, there is never a dull marine moment, a steam boat, car ferry, cruise liner, private launch, tug, freighter, taxi or gondola always on hand to liven up the scene. To port there is a steady passeggiata , with more Italians than tourists strolling out to the nearby public gardens.

Two nights are spent here, with the option of staying in the city during the day or taking a mini-cruise to the islands of Burano and Torcello. The former needs no guide - the rainbow paint, cobbled piazzas and photogenic bridges ooze instant charm. In Torcello, we needed enlightenment about the part this ghost island played in the history of the region - why its population, once 20,000, has shrank to 60; why its basilica, founded in 639, is the oldest building in the lagoon. Ship's guides kept us well briefed, in three languages.

Next morning, the ship followed the long thin streak of the barrier islands, Lido and Pellestrina, and crossed to the busy fishing port of Chioggia. This is emphatically no tourist honeypot. Hundreds of blue working boats lined the quays, shops sold food, not souvenirs, and the mood was down to earth, unlike its glamorous neighbour. In other words, a likely choice to eat ashore, with the freshest fish on the menu.

The unpromising exterior of trattoria El Gatto made us wonder if we had chosen wisely, but this proved to be a memorable meal. Here is a renowned restaurant, famous for its seafood. Alessandro, the chef/patronne's son, insisted we try the softshell crab, in season for a few brief weeks in May. Fried in oil and garlic, they justified his enthusiasm. Sea bream cooked en papillote was equally good. We insulted him by refusing the desserts; he brought us ricotta cheesecake anyway.

Monday was May 1. The significance escaped us until our coach arrived in Padua. Not only were the piazzas deserted, the shops shuttered, the famous fruit and vegetable market closed, but Giotto's illustrious 39 frescoes in the Capelli di Scrovegni, one of the high spots of the cruise, were not on view. Only four days in the year are they shut away, and this was one of them. The Orto Botanica, the oldest botanical garden in Europe, was closed, too.

We consoled ourselves with the Mantegna fragments in the 13th-century Chiesa degli Eremitani, the Donatello equestrian statue of Gattamelata, and a cappuccino in the famous Caffé Pedrocchi. Here, students argued and plots were hatched in the rebellion of 1848. Now it is a national monument.

Ferrara, once an important Renaissance centre, is today unusually tranquil, with more bicycles than cars. The city is dominated by the forbidding castle, seat of the powerful Este family, and surrounded by 9km of massive ramparts. From the vantage point of a café in the central piazza, you can admire the glorious triple facade of the Romanesque-Gothic cathedral before plunging into the cool maze of narrow medieval lanes.

In Mantua, Mantegna paid homage to the glory of the Gonzaga family's court with his cycle of frescoes that can be seen in the Palazzo Ducale. Be advised, though, it is necessary to make a reservation in order to see them.

Mantua deserves more than a few hours to explore the town's treasures and the 16th-century Palazzo del Te, an imposing country house on the outskirts. For us, the visit was spoiled by gaggles of school children. Italians are noisy by nature and so are children. Combine the two and bedlam reigns. We shall just have to go back at a quieter time.

Charles Dickens irreverently described Correggio's frescoes in the dome of Parma's 12th-century cathedral as a fricassee of frogs. Whether you share his view or that of Ruskin, who thought there were only two reasons for getting out of bed in the morning - Mozart's music and Correggio's use of light - nobody can deny that there is an even greater visual treat across the piazza, namely, the octagonal baptistry executed in rose-coloured marble, begun in 1196, with a breathtaking frescoed interior.

Parma overflowed with interest. The 1619 all-wooden Farnesi theatre (bombed in 1944 but skilfully restored) is a must-see, along with the entire city centre, neatly divided into half Renaissance, half medieval.

We also found time to drop in at a cheese producer's to sample the two-year-old Parmigiano Reggiano. (Parma and Reggio each claims to be the original home of the cheese, so the honours are divided.) Next to every cheese producer is a pig farm, where the animals consume the surplus whey.

The final stop was Cremona and the chance to see the Romanesque/Gothic cathedral, and 13th-century campanile from whose 112m high summit there is said to be a wonderful view. But when informed there was no lift, we decided that we were packing to many excess pounds from our culinary adventures to attempt an assualt on the stairs.

We returned to the Venezia for the captain's farewell cocktail party, a useful forum for discussing what goodies we missed on short stay in "the larder". One thing was sure: the cruise had served only to whet our appetites, and we shall be back to dawdle over selected second helpings.

The practicals

KD Cruises, Travel Renaissance Holidays, 28 South St, Epsom, Surrey KT18 7PF (tel: 01372 742033, fax 01372 724871, e-mail: info@kd-clipper.co.uk. A seven-day cruise on the MV Venezia costs £1,445, from April to October, including British Airways flights from Heathrow to Venice, and from Milan to Heathrow, and all transfers. It is possible on some dates to travel on the Orient Express from London before joining the ship at Venice. Italian Tourist Board: 020-7355 1557, www.enit.it/uk/

fields.headline: Netjetters
fields.trailText: Sam, one of our trio of netjetters who is keeping in touch with thousands of Guardian Unlimited users at www.guardian.co.uk/netjetters on their trips around the world, has been having a fantastic time in New Zealand. Here is a taste of his description of being in Wanaka:
fields.body:
Sam, one of our trio of netjetters who is keeping in touch with thousands of Guardian Unlimited users at www.theguardian.com/netjetters on their trips around the world, has been having a fantastic time in New Zealand. Here is a taste of his description of being in Wanaka:

"That evening I treated myself to a trip to the pictures. The movie was a laughably bad... but the film didn't really matter because Wanaka cinema was such a delight. About the size of a village hall, the seating was a motley assortment of armchairs and sofas with a convertible Morris Minor thrown in for good measure. Half way through, the film stopped and everyone went outside to the adjoining café and got freshly-baked cookies (still warm), home-made ice cream or a beer and then settled back into their armchairs. This is how all cinemas should be."

Then he went to Queenstown and was persuaded to go for a bunjee jump: "You are supposed to perform an elegant swan dive, but standing there on the edge I lost my nerve and basically fell off. I had a brief sensation of hanging in the air. I felt like I was in one of those cartoons where the animated character has run off the cliff and his legs are whirring over nothing. Then I was plummeting down towards the river. Then I was bouncing back up to the bridge. Then I was falling back down again."

Watch video of Sam's jump

Later, the 28-year-old civil servant, went on a two-day kayaking trip in Doubtful Sound, in Fiordland National Park, at the bottom of New Zealand's west coast, and encountered some dolphins: "As they got closer to us, the pod dived. For a moment everything was still. And the next moment the dolphins were playing all around us. They jumped over each other. They raced us. They dived under the kayaks. They swam alongside us. Two leapt out of the water either side of me. It must have only lasted a few short minutes but what an incredible emotional experience. I will never forget it."

Meanwhile Sue, a 51-year-old divorcee, is in Sarawak, Malaysia:

"Mulu park has the largest limestone cave system in the world. There are four show caves. On Wednesday, I set off for the Deer and Lang caves. With what appears to be becoming my usual timing, I picked the day the generator broke down so the caves were not lit. Deer cave is huge, home to millions of bats. The towering walls and rock formations are all covered with a layer of guano.

"You had to be careful not to gape too much at the magnitude of the cave as the smell of ammonia was very powerful, or to not slip on the fine layer of droppings on the walkway..."

To read their full accounts, and catch up with gap-year student Millie in Australia, visit www.theguardian.com/netjetters.

fields.headline: Somewhere for now
fields.standfirst: UK | France | Italy | Spain | Egypt | Goa | Singapore | Thailand
fields.trailText: UK | France | Italy | Spain | Egypt | Goa | Singapore | Thailand
fields.body:
Europe

UK: Ashdown Park Hotel (01342 824988) near Forest Row in East Sussex has a Valentine's weekend break (any two nights from February 9-11 or 16-18) for £245pp including fruit, flowers, champagne, home-made chocolates, cocktails, five-course gourmet meal, breakfast and table d'hôte dinner on the second night.

France: A Valentine weekend at the Htel de la Chenevière near Port en Bessin, Normandy costs £167pp (two sharing) including return ferry travel from Portsmouth to Caen with a standard car and two nights' accommodation with breakfast or a four-course dinner. Brittany Ferries 0870 5360 360.

France: A two-night family break at Disneyland Paris costs £496 two adults and two children under 12) at www.cheapflights.com. The package includes return flight from Heathrow, family accommodation and two-day Disney passes.

Italy: Two nights at the three-star Hotel Regno, Rome costs £179pp for departures up to March 15 through British Airways Holidays (0870 24 24 243). The price includes return scheduled flights from Gatwick and B&B accommodation.

Spain: Travelscene (0870 777 4445) is offering two-night breaks to Madrid at the three-star Los Condes for £265pp. The price includes B&B accommodation and return scheduled flights from Heathrow with Iberia. Valid for departures until February 15.

Africa

Egypt: Crusader Travel (020-8744 0474 www.crusadertravel.com) is offering seven- and 14-night packages, from £379 and £525pp respectively, to Egypt's Red Sea Riviera resorts of Taba and Taba Heights during February and March. The price includes return flights and half-board accommodation.

Asia

Goa: Stay at the Alor Beach Resort Hotel as part of a two-week Valentine's package departing February 10. The price of £429pp from Gatwick, or £459 from Manchester includes B&B accommodation based on twin share and is available from Jewel in the Crown Holidays 01293 533338.

Singapore: Five-night packages are available through Travelmoods (08700 66 45 55), including return British Airways flights from Heathrow plus four-star hotel accommodation. The price is £529pp based on twin share.

Thailand: Trek around the high north of the country with Explore Worldwide (01252 760 100) for departures throughout February. The itinerary includes the isolated valleys around Mae Hong Song and Pai, transport via elephant and raft. There will also be the opportunity to explore Chiang Mai and Bangkok. The trip costs from £739pp including flights, transfers, transport, accommodation, most meals and tour leader.

fields.headline: Austin rover
fields.standfirst: George Bush has exchanged the Texan capital for the White House. Mary Fitzgerald guides you through what the former governor has left behind
fields.trailText: George Bush has exchanged the Texan capital for the White House. Mary Fitzgerald guides you through what the former governor has left behind.
fields.body:
George Bush may be a typical Texan, but he was never a typical Austinite. In the popular image, Texans wear 10-gallon hats, drive pick-up trucks, and are only too happy to point out the exact location of the Mason-Dixon line. Their women are shoulder-padded, lip-glossed Sue Ellen clones for whom 80s power dressing never really went away. Austin is different, a diverse community of artists, musicians, low-budget guerrilla film makers, writers and twentysomething bohos. The state capital stands out like a vegetarian at a Texan barbecue.

Its attitude towards its old governor was best expressed in the post-election issue of the popular newsweekly, the Austin Chronicle. The front page was just a blank sheet of funereal black, the header picked out in a sombre grey.

Austin is full of people who will tell you they came for a week and decided to stay for good. The city has a young feel, in part due to the colossal University of Texas, the only campus in the world that has its own oil drill, and also because of its reputation as a low-rent slacker's paradise where the many cafés, bars, bookshops and clubs have elevated hanging out to an art form.

Local indie film director, Richard Linklater shot Dazed and Confused here, and committed Austin's own brand of laid-back cool to celluloid in his 1991 film Slacker, a cinema-verité style portrayal of Austin's deadbeat anti-yuppie subculture.

People don't come to here to spend time sightseeing and ticking off a list of must-sees, which are a little thin on the ground anyway. A quick run around the downtown area takes care of the more conventional tourist sights including the rosy granite Texas State Capitol which, in a typically Texan touch, stands 7ft taller than the one in Washington. The nearby Greek-revival governor's mansion is only a must for Dubya fans who hanker after the vicarious thrill of sitting at his old desk. On East 5th Street, the O Henry Museum celebrates the 19th-century short-story writer.

But music is what really matters in Austin. The city claims to be the Live Music Capital of the World, a moniker which is included on every piece of official city letterhead. In a town where local heroes such as Willie Nelson and the late Stevie Ray Vaughan are gods, Austin music never entirely forgets its Texan roots, but the hybrid of country twang, blues licks, folk and the odd psychedelic flourish has spawned unique musical mutations such as cowpunk and an alt-country cowboy style that is more cosmic than rhinestone.

Best venues

Antone's on 5th Street is a cornerstone of Austin's music heritage. Owner Clifford Antone has been hosting blues legends such as Muddy Waters and Fats Domino since 1973. With the Continental Club on South Congress, this is the place to catch homegrown musicians such as Joe Ely, Jimmie Vaughan, Alejandro Escovedo and Toni Price.

At night, the downtown area can seem like one long pub crawl with more than 50 clubs and music venues (more per capita than LA or New York) all clustered around 6th Street.

The 6th Street area is also home to Leslie, a much-loved local transvestite, as much a part of Austin as the Capitol itself. Treated by many as an unofficial city mascot, Leslie sashays down Congress Avenue often dressed in little more than a bra and thong and has even run for mayor. Many think he would make a better president than Dubya.

Cooler Austinites are to be found reclining on threadbare sofas in Lovejoys on Neches Street, sipping dirty martinis at Club Deville or experiencing live aural mayhem at Emo's or Stubbs on Red River Street.

The Warehouse District around 4th Street has witnessed a rash of cigar-and-martini bars to cater largely for out-of-towners who have relocated in droves to work in Austin's burgeoning hi-tech industry. The yuppified velvet-rope cocktail lounges and faux-Irish bars seem out of place in a town where not wearing shorts counts as formal dress.

Ruta Maya on 4th Street is a more typical Austin hangout. Photographs and paintings of the Zapatistas hang on the well-worn walls, and your cup of joe comes with a conscience, the coffee beans bought from cooperative farmers in the Mexican highlands of Chiapas. You can sample some hand-rolled Cuban Cohibas in the adjoining smokeshop or listen to live reggae bands while sipping a Ruta Maya beer imported from El Salvador.

But in case you think that Austin is all about lo-fi boho chic and bands such as local post-punk industrial darlings The Butthole Surfers, a visit to the Broken Spoke on South Lamar Boulevard should remind you that you are still in the state of Texas. While not quite the Grand 'Ole Opry, this is the place to listen to real "howdy partner" Texan country music and queue for ice-cold beer with cowboy-booted, vowel-strangling good ol' boys, known in Austin parlance as "Bubbas".

Where to eat

If LA is the home of the resting actor who waits tables between auditions, and Miami is where wannabe models take food orders with a surly smile, Austin is the city where your plate of artery-clogging Tex Mex will more than likely be served up by a jobbing musicians who may slip you a demo tape with the side order of tortillas. The vast range of restaurants, cafés and mom 'n' pop diners means that Austin's musician/waiter population can always depend on waiting tables to make the rent.

A popular breakfast stop is Las Manitas on Congress Avenue with its renowned migas, a mix of eggs scrambled with tortilla chips, onions, monterey jack, cilantro and the obligatory chillis.

Jovitas and El Mercado, both on South 1st Street, serve up Tex Mex enchiladas, burritos, tacos and guacamole in belt-straining portions best washed down with locally-brewed Celis beer or a glass of chilled horchata, a milky drink made from tiger nuts.

Austinites take their preferences for the local mesquite-smoked barbeque seriously. Everybody has a favourite barbeque joint, with Stubbs, Ruby's and the Saltlick cropping up on most lists.

Stubbs Bar-B-Q on Red River Street is famous for its sauce, which is sold all over the States. If you want to do your constitution serious damage, try an all-American, additive-packed tooth destroying dessert of Twinkies - a really sweet spongecake with an even-sweeter filling. Ruby's on West 29th Street is an after-hours meeting place for musicians, students and clubbers who come for the smoked ribs and hormone-free beef. Die-hard barbecue fans make the 20-mile journey out of town to the Saltlick, which can seat up to 800 hungry carnivores outside.

Threadgills restaurant, a former 1930s gas station, is serves downhome Southern cooking, but its fame rests on the fact that it was here that Janis Joplin started off as just a smalltown Texan girl with a guitar. One of the specials is the ubiquitous Texan chicken-fried steak - ground beef fried in a thick batter coating and served with creamy gravy, biscuits and greens.

Where to stay

The grand old dame of Austin hotels has to be The Driskill on the corner of 6th Street. Built in 1886 by cattle baron Jesse Driskill, the elegant lobby has played host to stars of Hollywood's golden age, stringy-haired musicians, Texan oil barons and politicians - local boy made good Lyndon Johnson had a suite here.

The unintentionally phallic neon sign for the Austin Motel on South Congress is an Austin landmark and one of the longest-running local jokes. No two rooms are alike, with some featuring murals of the Great Wall of China, Mount Fuji and Dutch tulip fields, which some people think are just on the tasteful side of kitsch.

Further along South Congress is the San Jose motel. Blending hacienda-style architecture with zen-like minimalism, it is a haven of calm and tranquility on this busy stretch of vintage clothing stores, cafés, gun shops and boutiques that leads right into the downtown area.

The practicals

British Airways (0845 7733377) flies Heathrow to Dallas with American Airways connection to Austin from £376.69 return inc tax. The Driskill Hotel, 604 Brazos St (tel: 001 512 451 5440) costs $165-$225 per night for a double room. Austin Motel, 1220 South Congress Avenue (tel: 001 512 441 1157, $46-$99 per night). San Jose Motel, 1316 South Congress (tel: 00 1 512 444 7322, $90 per night).

webTitle: A city restored to its former glory

fields.headline: A city restored to its former glory
fields.trailText: Revisiting student haunts in middle age can be a bad idea. Not so with Rome. As an impoverished art history student, I would gravitate from my daily doses of culture, crazy traffic, petrol fumes and an assortment of street dangers to Piazza Navona, to me the city's soul.
fields.body:
Revisiting student haunts in middle age can be a bad idea. Not so with Rome. As an impoverished art history student, I would gravitate from my daily doses of culture, crazy traffic, petrol fumes and an assortment of street dangers to Piazza Navona, to me the city's soul. It was a scruffy square surrounded by peeling palaces and reeking of a history that you could trace back through Papal processions and medieval markets to the Romans themselves. There I would hang out with other travellers beside Bernini's Four Rivers Fountain eyeing the upscale ice-cream cafés where the smallest treat cost more than my daily budget for food.

Thirty years later, I found myself sitting in the shade of Bar Tre Scalini overlooking that same fountain, fulfilling my student dreams as I polished off a large bowl of chocolate and coffee ice-cream. The square was immaculately clean, the air clear, there was no sound of traffic, and the building facades were mostly repainted. Indeed, Rome was not merely as good as I remembered it; it was much better in almost every way. And it was not just because I could now afford a classy gelato.

Rome's liberal and controversial mayor, Francesco Rutelli, was the catalyst behind the city's recent make-over. Despite recalcitrant locals, central Rome has been scrubbed and sorted out. Heavy restrictions on car-parking permits and the pedestrianisation of whole chunks of the city keep the cobbled lanes and elegant piazzas quiet and easy to enjoy. Massive restoration programmes funded by public and private money - lucrative advertising hoardings block some facades while repairs are in hand - have made much of the city's impossibly rich heritage sparkle once more. And a crack-down on crime has made Rome one of Europe's safest cities.

Even on arrival, as I sped into the city past a pristine Colosseum and Caracella's baths, where the traditional opera season is to be revived, I could feel the difference.

Soon, I was standing on the Pincio balcony in the hilltop Borghese Gardens, the city laid out before me. Dedicated shoppers criss-crossed the now pedestrian lanes between the Spanish Steps and Via del Corso. I turned from the balcony and followed the pine-scented paths lined with sculptures of history's great and good - Aristotle to Goethe - from Pope Paul V's collection. They led to Villa Borghese built by the Pope's nephew, Cardinal Scipione Borghese, in 1612-13. I reached the entrance hall to be visually ravished by the ceiling-to-floor opulence before me.

At the other end of the park, I found the exquisite Renaissance Villa Julia, newly reorganised to display archaeological finds in and around Rome. This is the pattern of the city down the centuries: as it is rebuilt, so more bits of earlier Romes are found. Later, in Palazzo Massimo, I saw quantities of near-perfect frescoed Roman walls decorated with birds, fish and flowers, and peaked into whole suites of rooms dug up by Renaissance, Baroque or 20th-century workmen improving their city.

Cultural overdose was as dangerous now as 30 years ago. I broke off to seek out Trastevere, a favourite area locked in my student memory. I made for the church of Santa Maria and its glittering Byzantine mosaics, then sat at Bar Marzio to enjoy the little piazza. How different it was: almost all the Renaissance facades had been restored and painted, not in the familiar burnt-umber tones but in pale salmon pink, ice blue and cream, the gentle colours that would have been used when they were built.

Rome's cultural tentacles engulfed me again. At the packed Vatican, I relished revisiting the Raphael stanze. Beside the Colosseum, I plunged underground to explore the newly-excavated rooms of Nero's immense imperial palace, Domus Aurea, built in 64-64AD. In the reviving industrial area of Testaccio, I found new bars and clubs springing up around the Centrale Montemantini, Rome's answer to the Tate Modern: a grand, disused electrical power station that plays host to several hundred robust Roman sculptures, some still with tantalising fragments of gilt and coloured paint.

Late one afternoon, I met up with my friend Donata, a native of Rome. We wandered through the traffic-free lanes, making our way from Piazza Farnese through Campo dei Fiori, where Rome's weekday fruit and vegetable market is held. Already, people were gathering for their nightly passeggiata through the old city, talking incessantly either to each other or into their mobile phones. We made our own passeggiata, drawn inevitably to the lanes around Piazza Navona to eat, drink and wonder why, if Barcelona, Chicago and Rome can do it, can't London be cleaned up and sorted?

The practicals

Go (0870 6076543, www.go-fly.com) has flights from £80 return.

fields.headline: All you need is...
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor searches out St Valentine's Day specials
fields.body:
Far too many lovers will be making an exhibition of themselves on the Ile de la Cité and lining gondoliers' pockets on the Rialto on Valentine's Day. If you really want to join them, go straight to lastminute.com and revel in the shocking pink heaven that is Britain's best-known travel site. Guardian readers, I know, will have better ideas.

Go clubbing in Brighton
Choose a night of the week and pick a club. Reviews are frank, enthusiastic and intelligible, and This is Brighton covers the other attractions of Britain's newest hot spot fairly well.

Attend a mediaeval tournament in Kaltenberg, Germany
Germany's national website is currently celebrating the joys of Romanesque architecture. For just under £75 you can book three nights' B&B, a guided tour of a basilica and a place at the tournament.

Cycle in Derbyshire for a weekend/
Saddle Skedaddle runs cycling tours all over the world. Their site is informative, although it can be a bit slow to load. Peak District breaks with accommodation, food and bike hire cost £165.

Snowboard in Glencoe
Scottish pistes can't rival the Alps, but the good selection of blue runs and relatively cheap ski and board hire, tuition and lift pass package deals make it a serious alternative, especially if you live a long way away from the cheap Stansted flights to Europe.

Have lunch in Brussels
Click the Euroguide logo for special offers on daytrips to the Belgian capital. They can only be booked by phone, the price starts at £65 and you only get one drink with your two courses, but there is usually some spare time to stock up on chocolate and beer.

Porsche Boxster for a day
I was about to give a mention to Virgin's half-price train travel during this month. But you could probably save some time by renting a Porsche for the day: it costs £283. "Prestige" cars such as this one have to be booked over the phone, so you can't claim the usual £5 discount for online booking.

Porsche Boxster for a day I was about to give a mention to Virgin's half-price train travel during this month. But you could probably save some time by renting a Porsche for the day: it costs £283. "Prestige" cars such as this one have to be booked over the phone, so you can't claim the usual £5 discount for online booking.

fields.headline: RAC Inspected Hotels and B&Bs, BBC Worldwide, £14.99
fields.trailText: For a simple, no-nonsense guide to places to stay this RAC book is as good as it gets. Over 4,000 properties, from old country house hotels to quaint independent guest houses in Britain and Ireland have been looked at - all are inspected on an annual basis
fields.body:
For a simple, no-nonsense guide to places to stay this RAC book is as good as it gets. Over 4,000 properties, from old country house hotels to quaint independent guest houses in Britain and Ireland have been looked at - all are inspected on an annual basis and for hotels an overnight visit is done every other year and for guest accommodation every third year. The visits are unannounced and the inspector pays his or her own bill.

But hotels do pay to be in the RAC scheme. The fee covers the cost of the inspection, including the night's stay and entry in the guide. Once the properties have put themselves forward fro accreditation, they have to live with the assessment.

This guide has a bewildering number of symbols but once you have worked them out it all makes sense.

It is organised by region, with each property's listing broken down into sections. There are also road maps and a list of local attractions. The fact that some of the hotels take ads is a bit disconcerting. Langley Castle in Northumberland describes itself as a genuine 14th-century castle. Is there any other type of 14th-century castle?

Keep this in the glove compartment. It's useful.

fields.headline: Peace in our time
fields.standfirst: Georgina Henry discovers a corner of the famous region that really is off the beaten track
fields.trailText: Georgina Henry discovers a corner of the famous region of Tuscany that really is off the beaten track.
fields.body:
For some, Tuscany, like Islington, is a place that conjures up a particular image. But how perverse it would be to avoid it just because Tony Blair holidays there and certain types of English men and women own grand homes on the gentle slopes of some of the most beautiful countryside in Italy.

And the popular caricature is not, of course, the whole story. Head west from Florence to Lucca, and north up into the mountains and you come to the remotest corner of Tuscany, where the most isolated medieval villages have not been repopulated by rich outsiders and are clinging as perilously to life as they are to the rugged hills.

Any village more than 20km from the main road is probably doomed as the population ages and the young move to homes within easy reach of the Garfagnana valley, which contains some of Europe's largest paper mills and is the main source of local employment.

Our destination was San Romano, about 10km off the main road that snakes through the valley and a two-hour drive from Florence airport. Forewarned that although it passed the accessibility test and is a thriving if sleepy hamlet, it contains only one tiny shop and no bar, we stopped off at the municipal centre of Borgo a Mozzano to buy provisions from the old-fashioned little shop on the main street. The staff speak no English, like most people in the valley, but they are cheerful, patient, very friendly and seem genuinely pleased to see you again. There is a reasonable selection of hams and cheeses and local wines, and the chicken we bought was easily the best poultry I can remember. Only the bread - not a speciality of Tuscany, or of Italy for that matter - was a disappointment; it's baked with very little salt or none at all, and is as hard as rock by next morning.

A short drive from Borgo and we struck off the highway and into the mountain, a steep and narrow road with twists and turns and blind corners that takes you eventually to Casa al Colle, an old stone, irregularly-shaped farmhouse built into the side of the hill around 1760 by the local landlord. It lay semi-derelict for a long time until the present owners, Fiorella and Thomas, refurbished it a couple of years ago.

It's charm is apparent the moment you pull up on the gravel drive. Throw the shutters open in the morning and you will see the sun come up over the mountains, San Romano in the heavily- wooded valley below, and, away on a distant mountaintop, the beautiful but dying medieval village of Motrone.

One of Casa al Colle's main attractions is its remoteness: if it's peace and quiet you're looking for, this is the place to go. However, its isolation, and the terror of the drive up the hairpin bends, can be a major disincentive to going anywhere other than up the stone steps to the pool in the morning. That would be a mistake, however: the region is rich in history and beautiful mountain villages, the magnificent walled town of Lucca is less than an hour away (except if you get stuck behind the endless and very slow paper trucks in the single-lane road through the valley) and Florence, Siena, Pisa and the coast are within easy reach.

Before the coming of the paper mills, the Garfagnana valley was one of the poorest regions of Tuscany - the road to San Romano was not even paved until the 60s. Work was scarce, and so the young people migrated to the cities. There is a missing generation - people in their 40s and 50s, the ones who left before the coming of roads and employment. A few of them have snuck back with their young families to take advantage of the jobs and depressed property prices and to bring up their children in the safety of the countryside.

But with steady depopulation - Motrone is not the only dying village - the demographic profile is essentially old people, old people, more old people and a handful of The Good Lifers with their kids. There are outsiders in the more accessible villages and hamlets along the Garfagnana valley, many of them writers and painters who live there permanently, rather than holiday in the summer months. It says a lot about Italians that there seems to be an almost complete absence of resentment about this, and little hostility directed towards foreigners. Small-scale agri-tourism and bed and breakfasting is an important part of the local economy, but it really only works if it's relatively near the main road. San Romano is borderline in this regard.

If what you've come for is to rest and recharge the batteries you won't be disappointed because Lucca is definitely worth the trip. It's probably best simply to wander at random through the streets. Every time you turn a corner there'll be something to admire. The local people use the walls - "the living room of Lucca" - to socialise and to promenade in the evenings. It's a good way to get a feel for the layout of the town. Take the time to enjoy the local apperitif, Chiodino - white wine or spumanti with a drop of Campari.

As for eating in Lucca, the tourists throng the restaurants around the Piazza Puccini. It's hard to have a bad meal here. Mushrooms are big in the Garfagnana valley, and an awful lot of dishes come with the celebrated porcini. But if you're fed up with funghi, there are plenty of alternatives. Try the faro soup with bacon and beans, the crostini with black butter, or the lardo with honey (forget about the calories - you're on holiday).

And because of the area's historic poverty, the local people have developed interesting ways to cook poor vegetables. Try the zuppa alla frantoiana, made mostly from black cabbage, carrots and celery. Formerly hardy peasant food, it is now served in all the smartest restaurants. Similarly, the flat sweet bread made from farina di castagne (chestnut-flower bread), eaten with cheese, is now considered a delicacy, though during the worst days of the second world war this bread was about all that people had to eat.

The wine of the region is not particularly special. The best white is from Montecarlo, near Lucca, which sells for about L11,000 (half the price of a bottle of run-of-the-mill Australian or French), and the best red is the Colline Lucchesi, which costs a little more. While even the proudest Lucchesi would hesitate to boast about the wine, they will tell you that the local olive oil is not only the best in in Tuscany but outshines anything from the other regions of Italy. It is light and fruity, and you should bring home as many bottles of this wonderful stuff as you can carry.

Another highlight is Barga, a small and pretty cathedral town, its splendour partly explained by the one-time residence of the Borgias.

The walking around Casa al Colle isn't great - too steep and too heavily forested - but the nearby Apuane Alps, much wilder than the Apennines, with gorges, ravines and caves, offer a spectacular alternative. In common with the rest of the province, they offer a relaxing, unpretentious taste of Tuscany.

The practicals

One week's self catering at Casa al Colle in Borgo a Mozzano in Lucca, costs £1,430, sleeping up to ten, between now and April 7 from Cottages to Castles (01622 726 883, www.cottagestocastles.com). The company can also book car hire from £210 per week for a Daewoo Lanos 1.4 and flights from Gatwick to Florence from £146.60 per adult. In July, a week costs £2,080, car hire is £250 and flights are £308.60.

fields.headline: Somewhere in Britain
fields.trailText: Painswick Rococo Garden | The Bloomsbury Group | British Trust for Conservation Volunteers | Nature's World Environmental Centre | Watercolours and Drawings Fair | Secret Hills Discovery Centre | Cadbury World
fields.body:
Spring into action

Convince yourself that spring has sprung with a visit to Painswick Rococo Garden to see the snowdrops. There are plenty of cosy Cotswold pubs in the vicinity with open fires and good food.

 Open daily 11am-5pm. £3.30/£1.75. Painswick, Gloucestershire. (01452 813204). Gloucestershire Tourism: 01452 425673.

Heirs and graces

The literary, intellectual and artistic achievements of The Bloomsbury Group live on in Bloomsbury Heirs, a display of work by students of the original gathering.

 Until February 7. Open Mon-Sat, 10am-5pm. Free. Oxford Gallery, 23 High Street, Oxford (01865 242731).

Workers unite

Join the British Trust for Conservation Volunteers every Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday in February and March to build bridges, paths, fences and steps in the Edinburgh area.

 Tues-Thur, 9.30am-5pm. Free. Various venues. 0131-332 8700.

Back to nature

An apothecary's garden and a scale model of the River Tees are among the attractions at the Nature's World Environmental Centre. Three adventure playgrounds, tea rooms, plant and gift shops, too.

 Open daily 10am-3.30pm. £2.50/ £1.50/family £6. Ladgate Lane, Acklam, Middlesbrough (01642 594895).

Art of the matter

Works from the 18th century to the modern day are on display at the annual Watercolours and Drawings Fair.

 Sat/Sun. Prices from £50. Park Lane Hotel, Piccadilly, London W1. Tickets and information: 07000 785613.

The hills are alive

Through the doors of Shropshire's brand-new Secret Hills Discovery Centre, visitors are led on a trail back through time to discover how the Shropshire Hills were first created and how they have inspired writers, poets and artists ever since. Twenty-five acres of meadowland give further insight.

 Open daily from next Friday,10am-3.30pm. £4.25/£2.75/family £12.20. School Road, Craven Arms, Shropshire (01588 676000).

Eat your heart out

Chocaholics of all ages will find something tasty at Cadbury World. The story of chocolate begins with the Aztecs and Mayans in a mocked-up jungle and leads via Victorian Birmingham and the Quaker Cadbury family to an enormous confectionery shop.

 Open Weds/Thurs/Sat/Sun; daily after February 14. £8.25/£6.25/family discounts. Off Linden Road, Bournville, Birmingham (0121-451 4159, www.cadbury.co.uk.

fields.headline: Ski tips
fields.trailText: Skiing families desperate for a last-minute getaway at half-term could try Leisure Direction Ski (020-824 3030), which has space left in France's highest resort, Val Thorens. The firm is offering a week's self catering in apartments sleeping up to five people, for a total of £841. Customers have to drive the Alps, but the price covers car-ferry crossings. Val Thorens is part of the enormous Trois Vallées ski network which also includes Méribel and Courchevel. Snowcoach (01727 866177) has full-board, one-week holidays in Austria's Mayrhofen costing £399 for adult and £339 for children. The price includes coach travel from London Victoria, Watford, Bexley or Dover or, for a supplement, from 30 other pick-up points. Departure is on February 16.

How do you pick the right resort? Seasoned observers may disagree with some of its judgments but overall, the Consumer Association's Good Skiing and Snowboarding Guide is a sound starting point. The Ski Club of Great Britain (020-8410 2000/ www.skiclub.co.uk) says it is planning to make it accessible to non-members online for an annual fee of £10 - £5.99 less than the book-shop price of the latest annual edition. The guide is already accessible for free on the internet to members. Fees are £45 or £10 for under 24s and £66 for families.

It is three years since First Choice last offered packages to the American west. It pulled out of the Rockies with the demise of charter flights to Denver. Now the firm is considering offering packages to California for next season.

Heavy demand for ski holidays at Easter has prompted Powder Byrne (020-8246 5300) to extend its season in the Swiss resort of Grindelwald from mid-February until early April. It now offers departures from Heathrow until April 8. Accommodation is available in three hotels, the Regina, Belvedere and Fiescherblick with half-board prices, including flights and transfers, from £726.

If you can slip away before the start of school half-term, there are bargains to be had this month. Among the packages from Thomson (0870 606 1470) are a week in the Colorado resort of Breckenridge for £399. The price includes flights to Denver, transfers and room-only accommodation. Half-board packages to resorts on the Milky Way, which links resorts on either side of the French-Italian border, and which has excellent snow conditions this winter, are on offer from £349. Flights are available from a range of airports. The firm also has self catering deals to French resorts, including Les Deux Alpes and Alpe d'Huez, from £299.

fields.headline: Travel tips
fields.trailText: Sound advice from readers in the know
fields.body:
To protect local delicacies on the long drive home from the gîte, chill a coolbag in the freezer compartment, pre-chill the cool-box with some ice cubes and discard, pack the produce in the coolbag and put in the box with the usual two or three frozen blocks on top (or a cheap bag of frozen chips can substitute). Put the box in the boot well away from the line of the exhaust, and cover with a blanket. If you have to break your journey, ask the hotel kitchen for help with overnight storage.
Chris O'Hagan

When travelling light, take a bar of Simple soap. Use it to wash and bathe, and lather to shave. For dirty clothes, rub it wet on the wet soiled patch and manually rub the dirty patch, then rinse.

When travelling to Ladakh, stop off in Dah Hanu near the Pakistan border - delightful people, breathtaking scenery and cheap accommodation.
C Breeze

Sean Mackay writes that while citronella may deter mosquitoes (Travel tips, January 27) the smell is very enticing for elephants and it should not be used in elephant-inhabited areas. "They have been known to rip open tents and even cars to get to the source of the smell," he says.

 If you have a tip you would like to share with your fellow readers please write to: Travel Tip, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER or e-mail us at: travel.tips@theguardian.com. Every reader whose tip we use will receive a Rough Guide of their choice.

fields.trailText: Croatia | Cyprus | Spain | The Med | Madagascar | Australia | Barbados | Oman
fields.body:

fields.headline: New directions
fields.standfirst: Martin Bell tackles the parallel turn manouevre
fields.trailText: Martin Bell tackles the parallel turn manouevre.
fields.body:
After gaining a few weeks of experience, all intermediate skiers aspire to mastering parallel turns. In theory, the first part of a parallel turn should be the easiest, because gravity is already trying to pull your skis down the hill, in the direction you want to go. But as you're traversing, before starting a turn, your skis are tilted on to their uphill edges. While you're "holding an edge" like this, your skis are resisting the pull of gravity down the hill. To go from a traverse to a new parallel turn, you need to release those edges by flattening your skis, and then eventually rolling them on to their opposite edges - the "new" edges that will control the new turn.

There are two ways to learn the initiation of parallel turns: the "drift initiation", and the "hop initiation".

With the former, you need to extend from the traverse position (where the body is angulated into a curved shape), and stand upright, into the "neutral position". Your skis will flatten, allowing them to drift naturally down towards the pull of gravity. Once the turn is underway, you can roll the skis on to the new edges, and drive them around the rest of the turn. With practice, you will learn to speed up the drift initiation, by using a swivelling movement of the feet. This is also described by various ski schools as a "rotary", "pivoting", or "steering" movement.

The hop initiation is a learning method better suited to children and more athletically built adults. It is based on the same movement as the drift initiation, extending from an angulated traverse position into the neutral position, but is done more dynamically. This extension of the body should result in a hop, where the skis leave the ground. As the skis are in the air, the aforementioned swivelling movement of the feet is used to start them turning. As the skis regain contact with the snow, they should already be tilted on to the new edges, so that the remainder of the turn can be completed.

The problem that most novice parallel skiers have is an inability to release both edges simultaneously, and tip both skis together on to their new edges. They generally find it easy enough to do it with the new outside ski (ie the right ski when turning left) because of all their experience with stemming. But the problem is getting the new inside ski to do the same thing at the same time. Therefore, some teachers ask the pupil to concentrate on the new inside foot (ie the left foot when turning left), and focus on tilting it from the "big toe edge" over on to the "little toe edge".

Whichever method you use to get the hang of the parallel turn initiation, that is only half the battle. Also you must get into the habit of making a pole-plant. This should be done at the same time as you extend your body upwards to start the turn. For shorter, rhythmical turns, it provides a vital link to the snow during the almost weightless transi tion phase between turns, and it helps stabilise the upper body - for all turns, but especially for short, quick-rhythm ones, the upper body (above the waist) should remain facing permanently down the hill.

This has two advantages: in short turns, it enables you to turn your skis simply by pivoting your legs beneath you, instead of rotating your whole body each time - this uses less energy and increases your nimbleness - and, in long turns, keeping your upper body facing down the hill has the automatic effect of keeping your hips angulated into the turn, helping to keep your skis on edge.

Next week: angulation of both the knees and the hips in the context of carved parallel turns. Martin Bell is running ski courses for intermediate skiers this season in Vail & Breckenridge, Colorado. For more information, call 0170 8224080 or e-mail: vailresorts@clara.co.uk.

fields.headline: Feelgood factory
fields.standfirst: Tessa Boase finds pampering works wonders for mind and body
fields.trailText: During her visit to the spa town of Abano Terme, Tessa Boase finds pampering works wonders for mind and body.
fields.body:
There was something essentially frivolous about Doctor Buoncuore. He was too tanned, his teeth too square and white, his brows too beetling. He informed me, in a seductive Italian accent, that I would be covered in hot mud every day. And then I would be hosed down and placed in a bubbling tub. Then I would take to my bed for an hour, after which the day would be mine - fashion shows, exfoliations, excursions... I would, he soothed, soon feel the benefit. "Perhaps lose a few kilos, no?" Another flash of the Persil teeth.

I had come to the town of Abano Terme with a back injury, having heard about the magical curative properties of its thermal waters. I imagined sulphurous corridors, spartan regimes and gaunt inmates in dressing gowns. But, I reasoned, with Venice just an hour away, and the gorgeous city of Padua right on its doorstep, I could always escape if it got too depressing.

But I had got it wildly wrong. For as I soon discovered, this elegant little spa town with its clutch of fancy hotels is almost entirely given over to pleasure. Street stalls stock paperbacks on erotic massage and horoscopes for your dog. Full-fat ice cream parlours proliferate, spangly boutiques line the streets.

There are evening concerts, waltzes, elaborate aperitifs and courteous waiters; the leafy boulevards encourage short strolls in pretty frocks. It is an intensely sociable place - as it was in its heyday, when Europe's glitterati took the cure in one of the most fashionable spa resorts of the Belle Epoque.

In such a determinedly hedonistic atmosphere, it is easy to forget the the real business of Abano Terme. And after a fabulous five-course dinner in the five-star Hotel Trieste e Vittoria, I, too, had forgotten what I was doing here. My timetable, however, decreed "fangotherapy" at 9am the next morning. There was no getting out of it.

So I donned my white robe and shuffled along to the mud suite. Men wheeling trollies of what looked like steaming potter's clay - "fango" - trundled up and down the corridors. A whiff of bad eggs hung in the air. Algae-rich and warmed by thermal water, this was no ordinary mud. The Romans swore by it. Madonna swears by it, too. Many of Abano's clients spend a fortnight here twice a year. But to mud virgins like me, the prospect was faintly terrifying.

"Signorina, please, it's good for you." White-coated Bertilla, grandmotherly and reassuring, propelled me into a cubicle and eased me backwards onto the bed of steaming gunge. Naked. Oof! It was hot - 40 degrees, according to the doctor's prescription - and squelched horribly.

Having wrestled my shoulders, one arm, hips, knees and ankles into 45kg of mud, Bertilla wrapped me in grey linen, set a timer and left the cubicle. I felt like an Egyptian mummy in a furnace. The heat fought its way to my core, needling stiff joints, penetrating to my bones. Alarm gave way to exhaustion. Beads of sweat trickled down my chin.

I was woken by Bertilla tenderly wiping my brow and loosening my wrappings. "Piano, piano, signorina." The mud was prised off, I was heaved upright, hosed down and guided into my ozone bath, where I floated groggily for 15 minutes.

For the first two days I fought the system. I felt over-pampered, guilty, lethargic. My mind was vegetating. I had to escape. Padua was a 10-minute bus ride away, and ploughing into the rush-hour traffic of vespas, vegetable vans and Alfa Romeos, I felt myself wake up again. A lively university city, Padua is big enough to be interesting - Giotto's frescoes in the Scrovegni Chapel were worth the trip alone; there was also a Baroque music festival in full swing.

Then it was back to the cossetted world of the spa where, by day four, I was contemplating liposuction for the simple reason that the food was exquisite; Italy's best, served with great speed and silver-domed ceremony by a personal waiter. Sparrow-like ladies, dressed as if for a Cannes film premiere, ate their way through five courses twice a day without batting an eyelid. Their husbands, magnificent paunches straining through jacket and tie, did the same without reproach. Often no word would pass between them, the ladies' eyelids lifting only to flutter, coyly, at passing waiters.

Before dinner, the ritual stroll was a fashion parade without any concession to subtlety - handbags, sunglasses and sandals all flashed with gold. But it was more entertaining than intimidating, and before long I was competing as best as I could despite my pitifully un-spangly wardrobe. Next year, I told myself, I would pack far more outrageously.

Next year? Yes, I admit it. I was utterly seduced. Italy is, incurably, a pleasure-loving country - whether expressed through exuberant architecture, spangly boutiques, or simple physical pampering. It is hard not to give in to it on every level. After one week, I truly felt a new person - but couldn't put my finger on the precise nature of the "cure". Was it the mud, the thermal waters, or the general atmosphere of happy indulgence? Sometimes a little frivolity is just what is needed.

The practicals

Thermalia Travel (020-7483 1898, www.thermalia.co.uk) offers one week at the five-star Grand Hotel Trieste e Vittoria, Abano Terme near Padua, from £1,025pp, including scheduled flights, full board, plus daily fango, ozone bath and massage. Two and three-star hotels in Abano Terme also available from £836pp.

fields.headline: Chow bella
fields.standfirst: Tracey MacLeod sets her heart on the best meal in Rome.
fields.trailText: While in Rome, Tracey MacLeod sets her heart on the best meal in town.
fields.body:
I was about to turn 40 and looking for somewhere to hide out with my partner until it was all over. Rome was the perfect destination: cheap tickets were available online, the city would provide a suitably epic backdrop for a big occasion and surprisingly, neither of us had ever visited it before.

By the time you get to 40, you pride yourself on having acquired a certain degree of competence. You know how to get results. But minutes after arriving in Rome, it feels as though all those painfully-acquired life skills are starting to slip away. First there's the white-knuckle taxi ride from the airport, which has us scrabbling like infants for our rear seat-belts (they prove to be for show purposes only), then helplessly handing over bundles of lire when the requested price proves to be double the sum on the meter.

Walking turns out to be no less of a problem. Emerging from our hotel - the super-chic new Hotel de Russie, just off the Piazza del Popolo (9 Via del Babuino, tel: 39 06 32 88 81, single rooms from L590,000, doubles from L800,000) - we find ourselves among the promenading hordes. Of course, we've heard about la passeggiata; we just didn't know that in Rome it goes on all day. And a warm Sunday afternoon in autumn gives locals an ideal opportunity to show off their world-beating array of shiny leather suits and snakeskin hipsters. Whether the stiffness of the leather restricts movement, or new outfits have to be run in at low speed, like a new car engine, the shopping streets are virtually impassable, and what looks on the map like a short stroll turns into a Versace-clad obstacle course.

Our next challenge arises when we decide to get some lunch. We want our first Italian meal in Rome to be perfect, and having wandered around the area, we're reassured to see a large number of promising-looking trattorias with pavement tables. But at 2pm, it's as though a lunch bell has sounded, and suddenly every restaurant has a queue outside, right down to the humblest pizza chain. We beat a retreat to a cavernous pizzeria. Forty minutes later, we're still waiting to be brought so much as a piece of bread. When our pizzas do eventually arrive, though, they're worth the wait - yeasty and crisp-based in the Roman style.

Happily, this first dining experience turns out not to be typical. Despite their reputation, Romans aren't unfriendly to tourists. We just don't seem to register with them. Which is great, if you hate being hassled by people trying to sell you things. The centurions posing for photos outside the Colosseum are as near as Rome comes to pandering to the tourist trade.

After our lunch experience, we are even more determined to find the perfect, mythical trattoria. Our pre-dinner stroll takes in the huge monument to King Vittorio Emanuele II, inaugurated in 1911 to celebrate the unification of the nation but often dismissively referred to as "the wedding cake". Then on to the Spanish Steps, where the mating call of hundreds of suburban adolescents rises on the evening breeze.

Next, the Trevi fountain, immortalised in La Dolce Vita. We are overwhelmed by the size and swagger of the rococo marble confection, with its underwater carpet of glinting coins. I'm only left standing alone for a moment, gazing into the fountain's depths, when a soulful young man sidles up to me, and asks whether I speak Italian. Had I indeed been able to speak Italian, I could have snapped "What are you playing at? I'm going to be 40 tomorrow!" As it is, I flash him my biggest Anita Ekberg smile while backing away. Oh well, when in Rome...

Around the corner from the Parliament building, we stumble across what looks like our ideal, untouristy little trattoria. At first, it seems perfect. It obviously hasn't been decorated since Mussolini's day, and its handful of tables are filled with laughing groups of students and other bohemian types. There's no written menu - a shy waitress recites the evening's choices - three pastas and two meat dishes. It's only after we've ordered that we notice the state of the kitchen and, even more alarming, the state of its only occupant, a mountainous, be-slippered female straight from the kitchen of Castle Gormenghast.

Perfectly good though our spinach and ricotta ravioli turns out to be, this place falls just on the wrong side of authentic. We resolve to do some research and book somewhere really good for tomorrow night's birthday dinner.

How can we go wrong with Il Convivio (31,Vicolo dei Soldati, tel:06 686 9432)? It's listed in the "splashing out" section of our guidebook as "a temple of foodie excellence". And temple is just about right. From its forbidding wooden door and whispering waiters, to the reverential near-silence of its clientele, this is a place of worship rather than enjoyment. The food is predictably fantastic, in the teased-up, whittled-down style peculiar to Michelin-starred restaurants. But the best dish is the simplest: a heap of fresh, buttery tagliatelle, over which our waiter grates white truffle until I tell him to stop - rather a hair-raising judgment call, as I've been given a menu with no prices on it. In the end, our meal comes to around £100, which is less than we'd feared.

On the last full day of our Roman holiday, we abandon any pretence of sightseeing, and concentrate on finding our dream restaurant. The breakthrough comes with our discovery of the Bar Notegen (159 Via del Babuino tel: 06 320 0855). Seemingly unchanged since the 1950s, it's a snug, wood-panelled room lined with old black-and-white photos of Italian actors and artists. This feels very much like Fellini country - the director lived nearby - and some of the characters who hang around the Notegen still seem to be auditioning for a part in one of his movies.

That evening, just around the corner from the Notegen - and our hotel - we finally find our perfect vision of a Roman trattoria. The Edy (4 Vicolo del Babuino, tel: 06 36 00 17 38) has everything - a glowing, candle-lit interior, warm and welcoming staff, a chef who pops out from the kitchen to see how his dishes are going down, cooed-over infants in high chairs munching on breadsticks. And most importantly, really great cooking. Seafood spaghetti is baked in a foil parcel, which is brought to the table to spill its aromatic contents. Bean and pasta soup is thick enough to stand a spoon in. Grilled lamb cutlets bring out the Ancient Roman in me, and I'm soon attacking them with both hands.

No doubt there are hundreds of restaurants in Rome as unpretentious, friendly and atmospheric as the Edy. But we didn't have the time to find them all.

However, during our brief stay we managed to take in a fair number of Rome's most famous sights. Inevitably, though, things got left off the list. We didn't make it to the Sistine Chapel, or inside Saint Peter's. Instead, we opted to avoid the crowds of pilgrims by walking around the Vatican City late at night. This turned out to be a good move - we found ourselves alone in the square in front of the magnificently-spotlit cathedral as its bells tolled midnight, the only spectators at a spooky son et lumière.

The practicals

British Airways Holidays (0870 24 24 243, www.britishairways.com/ holiday/holiday.shtml), Citalia (020-8686 0677, www.citalia.co.uk), Italian Journeys (020-7373 8058), Thomson Breakaway (0870 606 1476), Travelscene (0870 777 4445, www.travelscene.co.uk), and the Magic of Italy (08700 270 500, www.magictravelgroup.co.uk) are some of the companies that offer packages to Rome. Go (0870 6076543, www.go-fly.com) has flights from £80 return.

Of course, we've heard about la passeggiata; we just didn't know that in Rome it goes on all day. And a warm Sunday afternoon in autumn gives locals an ideal opportunity to show off their world-beating array of shiny leather suits and snakeskin hipsters. Whether the stiffness of the leather restricts movement, or new outfits have to be run in at low speed, like a new car engine, the shopping streets are virtually impassable, and what looks on the map like a short stroll turns into a Versace-clad obstacle course. Our next challenge arises when we decide to get some lunch. We want our first Italian meal in Rome to be perfect, and having wandered around the area, we're reassured to see a large number of promising-looking trattorias with pavement tables. But at 2pm, it's as though a lunch bell has sounded, and suddenly every restaurant has a queue outside, right down to the humblest pizza chain. We beat a retreat to a cavernous pizzeria. Forty minutes later, we're still waiting to be brought so much as a piece of bread. When our pizzas do eventually arrive, though, they're worth the wait - yeasty and crisp-based in the Roman style. Happily, this first dining experience turns out not to be typical. Despite their reputation, Romans aren't unfriendly to tourists. We just don't seem to register with them. Which is great, if you hate being hassled by people trying to sell you things. The centurions posing for photos outside the Colosseum are as near as Rome comes to pandering to the tourist trade. After our lunch experience, we are even more determined to find the perfect, mythical trattoria. Our pre-dinner stroll takes in the huge monument to King Vittorio Emanuele II, inaugurated in 1911 to celebrate the unification of the nation but often dismissively referred to as "the wedding cake". Then on to the Spanish Steps, where the mating call of hundreds of suburban adolescents rises on the evening breeze. Next, the Trevi fountain, immortalised in La Dolce Vita. We are overwhelmed by the size and swagger of the rococo marble confection, with its underwater carpet of glinting coins. I'm only left standing alone for a moment, gazing into the fountain's depths, when a soulful young man sidles up to me, and asks whether I speak Italian. Had I indeed been able to speak Italian, I could have snapped "What are you playing at? I'm going to be 40 tomorrow!" As it is, I flash him my biggest Anita Ekberg smile while backing away. Oh well, when in Rome... Around the corner from the Parliament building, we stumble across what looks like our ideal, untouristy little trattoria. At first, it seems perfect. It obviously hasn't been decorated since Mussolini's day, and its handful of tables are filled with laughing groups of students and other bohemian types. There's no written menu - a shy waitress recites the evening's choices - three pastas and two meat dishes. It's only after we've ordered that we notice the state of the kitchen and, even more alarming, the state of its only occupant, a mountainous, be-slippered female straight from the kitchen of Castle Gormenghast. Perfectly good though our spinach and ricotta ravioli turns out to be, this place falls just on the wrong side of authentic. We resolve to do some research and book somewhere really good for tomorrow night's birthday dinner. How can we go wrong with Il Convivio (31,Vicolo dei Soldati, tel:06 686 9432)? It's listed in the "splashing out" section of our guidebook as "a temple of foodie excellence". And temple is just about right. From its forbidding wooden door and whispering waiters, to the reverential near-silence of its clientele, this is a place of worship rather than enjoyment. The food is predictably fantastic, in the teased-up, whittled-down style peculiar to Michelin-starred restaurants. But the best dish is the simplest: a heap of fresh, buttery tagliatelle, over which our waiter grates white truffle until I tell him to stop - rather a hair-raising judgment call, as I've been given a menu with no prices on it. In the end, our meal comes to around £100, which is less than we'd feared. On the last full day of our Roman holiday, we abandon any pretence of sightseeing, and concentrate on finding our dream restaurant. The breakthrough comes with our discovery of the Bar Notegen (159 Via del Babuino tel: 06 320 0855). Seemingly unchanged since the 1950s, it's a snug, wood-panelled room lined with old black-and-white photos of Italian actors and artists. This feels very much like Fellini country - the director lived nearby - and some of the characters who hang around the Notegen still seem to be auditioning for a part in one of his movies. That evening, just around the corner from the Notegen - and our hotel - we finally find our perfect vision of a Roman trattoria. The Edy (4 Vicolo del Babuino, tel: 06 36 00 17 38) has everything - a glowing, candle-lit interior, warm and welcoming staff, a chef who pops out from the kitchen to see how his dishes are going down, cooed-over infants in high chairs munching on breadsticks. And most importantly, really great cooking. Seafood spaghetti is baked in a foil parcel, which is brought to the table to spill its aromatic contents. Bean and pasta soup is thick enough to stand a spoon in. Grilled lamb cutlets bring out the Ancient Roman in me, and I'm soon attacking them with both hands. No doubt there are hundreds of restaurants in Rome as unpretentious, friendly and atmospheric as the Edy. But we didn't have the time to find them all. However, during our brief stay we managed to take in a fair number of Rome's most famous sights. Inevitably, though, things got left off the list. We didn't make it to the Sistine Chapel, or inside Saint Peter's. Instead, we opted to avoid the crowds of pilgrims by walking around the Vatican City late at night. This turned out to be a good move - we found ourselves alone in the square in front of the magnificently-spotlit cathedral as its bells tolled midnight, the only spectators at a spooky son et lumière. The practicals British Airways Holidays (0870 24 24 243, www.britishairways.com/ holiday/holiday.shtml), Citalia (020-8686 0677, www.citalia.co.uk), Italian Journeys (020-7373 8058), Thomson Breakaway (0870 606 1476), Travelscene (0870 777 4445, www.travelscene.co.uk), and the Magic of Italy (08700 270 500, www.magictravelgroup.co.uk) are some of the companies that offer packages to Rome. Go (0870 6076543, www.go-fly.com) has flights from £80 return.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Clearing the air
fields.body:
Clearing the air

British Airways is to be part of a three-year research project into cabin air quality in planes. The group of 15 organisations from seven European countries, including SAS and KLM, will study ways to improve the health and comfort of passengers. At present, there are only limited standards governing the quality of cabin air, which is blamed by some for air rage and illness. The group will be known as Cabinair.

All the rage

Air rage incidents are on the increase, according to the first-ever survey of the world's airlines carried out by London Guildhall University. Of the 206 commercial airlines polled for the study, staff rated the key triggers in the following order: excessive alcohol, demanding or intolerant personality, timetable delays, smoking bans, and cramped conditions. Over a third of airlines had no formal training to prevent and manage air rage, said the report.

Little beauties

The new edition of the European Connection, a guide to 60 privately-owned small luxury hotels in the UK and Europe was launched this week. Copies can be obtained post free on 020-7434 3223, or from their website at www.europeanconnection.co.uk.

Kenyan visas

The government of Kenya has reinstated visa requirements for UK tourists visiting for less than 30 days. The requirement came into effect this week. The government says that the visa waiver had created administrative problems, and tourists from other countries not affected by it were annoyed. A single-entry visa will cost £35. For more details, contact the visa section at the High Commission of Kenya on 020-7636 2371.

Epic journey

A team of five British climbers will set off in the next few weeks to retrace Sir Ernest Shackleton's epic crossing of South Georgia in the South Atlantic. Shackleton's desperate journey to secure rescue for members of his Imperial Transantarctic Expedition (1914-1917) is one of the great survival stories.

Code of practice

The Association of Independent Tour Operators (AITO) has launched Responsible Tourism Guidelines for its members. The guidelines include: protecting the environment, respecting local cultures, benefiting local communities, conserving natural resources and minimising pollution.

Staying power

Bridge the World has published a guide to the B&Bs of New Zealand. To get a copy, call 0870 444 7474.
