fields.headline: La dolce vita
fields.standfirst: From pick-you-own dinner ingredients to paint-your-own masterpieces,  Sarah Barrell selects the best and most unusual holiday options
fields.trailText: From pick-you-own dinner ingredients to paint-your-own masterpieces, Sarah Barrell selects the best and most unusual holiday options.
fields.body:
Getting there

Book at the right time and flights with the low-cost airlines can leave you paying less than your cab fare to the airport. For the widest variety of destinations (and the most frequent online seat sales) try Ryanair, who now flies to Alghero (Sardinia), Brescia (Milan), Genoa, Pisa, Rimini, Turin and Venice. Go flies to the lively university town of Bologna, along with Naples, Milan, Rome and Venice.

Sovereign and Travelscene have packages to all the main Italian cities, including Rome, Verona, Florence and Venice. Sovereign has some special deals for travel up to the end of March.

 Ryanair (0870 1569569, www.ryanair.com) has returns to Italy from as little as £29 and Go (0845 6054321, www.go-fly.com) has returns to Bologna, Milan and Venice from £78 and Naples and Rome from £88. If you book before March 31, Sovereign (08705 768373, www. sovereign.com) has two-night packages to Verona and Bologna from £200 pp including return flights with British Airways and B&B hotel accommodation, Venice, Florence, Rome and Milan from £219-260pp. Travelscene (020-8427-4445, www.travelscene.co.uk) has a wide selection of weekend city breaks from £225pp.

The three As

Art, architecture and antiquities are combined in Martin Randall's spring programme to Rome. Forget trudging dutifully around the Colosseum and squeezing up the Spanish Steps, this escorted tour takes in many little-known Roman and Etruscan sites around the city and some of Lazio's most exclusive gardens and villas (such as Jardina di Ninfa, built around medieval ruins, admission by appointment only, and Villa d'Este in Tivoli). The tour is based in Viterbo (about an hour and a half from Rome) and Frascati, at a 17th-century villa, complete with original frescos .

Artscape offers painting holidays to Italy's Renaissance heartland. Based in the small town of Pienza, just outside Siena, the trip is open to artists of mixed ability, using a variety of mediums.

Run by archaeologists, Andante Travel has several trips including one visiting the abbeys of central Italy and tracing the rise of Christianity from its earliest days in Rome through to the middle ages.

 The seven-day Campagna Romania: Villas, Gardens and Estruscan Sites tour from Martin Randall Travel (020-874 23355) costs £1,090pp (based on two sharing) all-inclusive. Painting tours to Tuscany from Artscape (01722 743163, www.artscape.uk.com) costs £984pp including tuition, half-board accommodation and return flights. Early Christianity and the Great Abbeys of Central Italy, October 4-12, from Andante Travels (01722 713800, www.andantetravels.co.uk) costs £1,250pp, including full-board accommodation in converted monastery hotels, scheduled flights from Heathrow, transfers, admission fees and guides.

Foodie heaven

Italian Cookery Weeks begins its classes for 2001 on the Amalfi Coast, the heartland of Neapolitan cuisine. The course is based at a rustic inn overlooking the sea. Between morning and evening classes, there are excursions for shopping and sightseeing to Capri, Positano, Ravello and Sorrento.

If you prefer to leave the cooking to others, you can join Arblaster & Clarke's new gourmet tour of southern Italy staying in the Palazzo Belmonte in the heart of the Cilento National Reserve, with a final night in a five-star hotel in Naples. Visits include an organic water buffalo farm to see how mozzarella is made and sample the buffalo-milk ice cream, demonstrations of the Neapolitan art of pizza throwing, and a day out on a local fishing boat before dining on some of the day's catch.

 Italian Cookery Weeks (020-8208 0112, www.italian-cookery-weeks.co.uk begin on May 5, £1,249pp including everything: return flights, transfers, full-board accommodation, all tuition and excursions. Arblaster & Clarke Wine Tours (01730 893344, www.arblasterandclarke.com) Gourmet Southern Italy tour, April 30 - May 5, costs £1,499pp (based on twin-share), including half-board accommodation, transport, guide, transfers and return flights.

Walking

After a little more exercise than the nightly passeggiata around the piazza? Spring and early summer are the perfect time to lace-up walking boots and head into the hills.

How about a seven-day walk through classic Tuscan countryside, from the Etruscan town of Volterra, through the Chianti vineyards to Siena? Inntravel will take your luggage on ahead so you can concentrate, with the maps and notes, on the walk and lunch.

If you want to get away from the classic routes, consider walking the mountainous instep of Italy with Alternative Travel. Its escorted tour of one of Italy's most deserted regions begins at Terranova di Pollino culminating 55 miles of dramatic countryside later in Maratea.

Hotfoot it further south, to Sicily, where walking becomes something of an extreme sport. From May onwards, Explore Worldwide is taking a group tour to explore the steaming craters of Mount Etna, the lava-carved paths of Stromboli and the black-sand beaches of the Aolian island of Lipari.

 Inntravel (01653 629010, www.inntravel.co.uk) has a seven-night trip staying in three- and four-star hotels B&B from £679pp including return scheduled flights Gatwick-Pisa and rail and taxi transfers. The eight-day tour of Italy's instep from Alternative Travel (01865 315678, www.atg-oxford.co.uk) costs from £670pp, including full-board, transfers and guide. Flights are extra but can be arranged. Explore Worldwide (01252 319448) offers volcano hiking from £639pp including B&B hotel and full-board mountain hut accommodation, boat and ground transfers, return flights and guide.

Rural retreats

Long Travel has a wide range of properties in central and southern Italy offering an undiluted flavour of the countryside. Try Villa Magnolie, near Loreto Aprutino, half an hour from the Adriatic coast. Set among 6,000 olive trees, this family-run farm has won a coveted DOP ranking for its olive oil, one of only 28 in the whole country. The farm is a good base for exploring the seldom-visited Abruzzo region which boasts the highest concentration of national parks in the country.

The highlight of the Abruzzo year is the Processione dei Serpari in the town of Cocullo on the first Thursday in May when its patron saint, San Domenico, receives the dubious honour of a live snake-draped effigy processed through the streets.

Further south, Calabria is home to some of the best beaches in Italy, and some truly rural retreats. Italian Breaks offers self-catering accommodation in a converted farmstead outside Lamezia, where guests can pick their own ingredients for southern Italian suppers.

 Long Travel (01694 722193) offers half-board at Magnolie farm, in Abruzzo, for £39pp per night. Flights and car hire can be arranged. Italian Breaks (020-8660 0082, www.italianbreaks.com) has self-catering farmhouse apartments, sleeping two, in Calabria for £240 per week plus car. Flights are not included but can be arranged.

Musical chairs

This is an important year for Italian opera with next month's centenary of Giuseppe Verdi's death and November's bicentenary of Vicenzo Bellini's birth. Travel for the Arts has put together a special three-day tour starting March 16 with a visit to Verdi's birthplace in Parma followed by a performance of Bellini's Norma at the Teatro Regio and La Traviata at La Scala in Milan.

Florence's early-summer festival of concerts, ballets and operas including Handel's Tamerlano and Purcell's Dido and Aeneas, Maggio Musicale Fiorentino, runs from May 6-June 30. Liaisons Abroad can arrange packages and concert tickets .

 Travel for the Arts (020-7483 4466) Verdi and Bellini trip, March 16-18, costs £950pp, based on twin-share and includes flights, B&B hotel accommodation, transfers, guided sightseeing and top-category tickets for both operas. Liaisons Abroad (020-7376 4020, www.liaisonsabroad.com) can arrange a three-night package to Florence for £390pp based on two sharing, including B&B at the Maggio hotel and a premier opera ticket. Flights are not included, but Ryanair (0870 1569569, www.ryanair.com) flies Stansted to Pisa, a short train ride from Florence, from £80 return.

Parlare Italiano

Euro Academy, with bases in Siena, Florence and Rome, combines language tuition with special-interest courses such as cookery, wine, art history, and Italian cinema. The courses are suitable for all levels and age groups, including intensive courses for business travellers. The tuition can be taken one-on-one or in groups, and home-stay accommodation is available.

 Euro Academy (020-8686 2363, www.euroacademy.co.uk) charges £235 for a two-week course in Siena, including 20 hours of language and culture classes, plus £335 for half-board accommodation with an Italian family. Flights are not included.

Festivals

You have to book now for the Venice Carnival (February 16-27) as hotels are filling up fast for the last word in pre-Lenten indulgence. Venetians don bauto (hood and cape) and tabarro (cloak) and take to the waters for a firework-illuminated extravaganza of gondolas, street theatre and costumed bacchanalia, recalling the grand festivals of the 18th century. Citalia still has availability for packages throughout the carnival.

The Festa di San Gennaro in Naples is held three times a year (first Sunday in May, September 19 and December 16) when the faithful gather in the Duomo to see if the blood of San Gennaro will liquefy. If it does, the fortunes of the city are assured, or so the legend goes. Packages are available from Magic of Italy.

 Magic of Italy (020-8939 5453, www.themagictravelgroup.co.uk) has three-night packages to Naples during May from £384pp, including four-star B&B accommodation at the Hotel Mediterranean and return flights, based on twin-share. Citalia (020-8686 5533, www.citalia.co.uk) has three-night packages to the Venice Carnival, including return flights from Stansted with Go and B&B accommodation in the three-star Hotel Hette, two minutes from Piazza San Marco, from £311pp, based on twin-share.

Doing it in luxury

Naomi Campbell, Tom Cruise and Nicole have all been spotted recently strolling through the cobbled streets of Capri or sipping a bellini in the Piazzetta, a miniature town square. A stunningly-beautiful island, but no beaches, it is 40 minutes from Naples by hydrofoil (or luxury yacht) and boasts views over the bay of Naples, chic shopping and great nightlife. Take your credit cards and close your eyes when you get the bill.

 Exclusive Italy (01892 619 650 www.exclusivedestinations.co.uk) offers three nights' B&B at the Quissisana Hotel, Capri, for £590pp or the Capri Palace and Spa from £650, both including return flights from Gatwick to Naples and private transfers.

Beaches

Forget Rimini, Amalfi or the Gargano peninsula; the best beaches are off the mainland in Sardinia. Among several new properties in its 2001 brochure, Voyages Ilena is offering early-season deals on the stylish three-bedroom apartment Casa Stefania on the south coast near Pula and the Roman town of Nora. The terracotta-tiled, natural stone apartment is a short walk from the beach and the lagoon at Nora, a protected habitat for rare birds.

 From 19 May, Voyages Ilena (020-7924 4440, www.voyagesilena.co.uk) is offering seven nights at Casa Stefania for £435pp including direct flights from Heathrow, car rental and travel insurance.

Venetians don bauto (hood and cape) and tabarro (cloak) and take to the waters for a firework-illuminated extravaganza of gondolas, street theatre and costumed bacchanalia, recalling the grand festivals of the 18th century. Citalia still has availability for packages throughout the carnival. The Festa di San Gennaro in Naples is held three times a year (first Sunday in May, September 19 and December 16) when the faithful gather in the Duomo to see if the blood of San Gennaro will liquefy. If it does, the fortunes of the city are assured, or so the legend goes. Packages are available from Magic of Italy.  Magic of Italy (020-8939 5453, www.themagictravelgroup.co.uk) has three-night packages to Naples during May from £384pp, including four-star B&B accommodation at the Hotel Mediterranean and return flights, based on twin-share. Citalia (020-8686 5533, www.citalia.co.uk) has three-night packages to the Venice Carnival, including return flights from Stansted with Go and B&B accommodation in the three-star Hotel Hette, two minutes from Piazza San Marco, from £311pp, based on twin-share. Doing it in luxury Naomi Campbell, Tom Cruise and Nicole have all been spotted recently strolling through the cobbled streets of Capri or sipping a bellini in the Piazzetta, a miniature town square. A stunningly-beautiful island, but no beaches, it is 40 minutes from Naples by hydrofoil (or luxury yacht) and boasts views over the bay of Naples, chic shopping and great nightlife. Take your credit cards and close your eyes when you get the bill.  Exclusive Italy (01892 619 650 www.exclusivedestinations.co.uk) offers three nights' B&B at the Quissisana Hotel, Capri, for £590pp or the Capri Palace and Spa from £650, both including return flights from Gatwick to Naples and private transfers. Among several new properties in its 2001 brochure, Voyages Ilena is offering early-season deals on the stylish three-bedroom apartment Casa Stefania on the south coast near Pula and the Roman town of Nora. fields.headline: Website of the week
fields.standfirst: www.virgintravelstore.com
fields.trailText: www.virgintravelstore.com
fields.body:
Wake up.

I do beg your pardon. I was just clicking round Virgin's new travel site when I was overcome by a wave of ennui.

Oh come on.

If there were an award for Most Tedious Site Launch of the Year, then Virgin Travelstore would have it in the bag already. (Incidentally, it's not to be confused with travelstore.com, by the way, which specialises in the sector of business travel.) The front page of the new Virgin site is bland, uninspiring and - remarkably, I must say - actually manages to undersell what the site can provide.

But apparently it offers a "sunshine guarantee".

This may well be true - but only if daily rainfall is approximately 30 times higher than average for three days, which isn't very likely in a Mediterranean resort. Still, if you visit the site in the next few days you'll find some generous discounts on packages from the likes of First Choice and Airtours. The site's chief selling point is that it rounds up other package operators in one place.

Hence the lack of a identity of its own?

Maybe. It doesn't help that some of the resort photos are still being developed. The flight search is unremarkable and the car rentals rely on the Holiday Autos site. However the Travelstore does come into its own when it comes to choosing a package holiday - it's probably the most helpful and systematic booking process yet created, and there is an impressive choice of beach holidays. You start by choosing a region and then specify which aspects of the holiday are most important to you. However, if it is a city break that you are after, then I'm afraid you will have to look elsewhere.

fields.headline: Alfresco
fields.trailText: Deet-free anti-mosquito spray, made from natural fragrances such as melissa, geranium and lavender.
fields.body:
I'm off for some winter sun but how I can get past the mosquitoes without dousing myself in chemicals?

Get on the web and order Alfresco. It's deet-free, made from natural fragrances such as melissa, geranium and lavender, and said to be an effective repellent and a great moisturiser.

Said by whom?

Robert Redford. He and Kristin Scott Thomas used it on the set of The Horse Whisperer. And Jodie Foster used it while filming Anna and the King in Malaysia.

So it's fashionable, but does it work?

The London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine have given it the thumbs up especially for children.

Why haven't I heard of it?

It's a small family business started by Sarah-Lou Reekie who works at the Chelsea Physic Garden in London and got the idea after a midge-infested sojourn in Scotland.

 Alfresco comes in two sizes, a 50ml bottle for £5 and a 200 ml size £15, p&p from £2.50. Order on the web at www.alfresco.uk.com or by mail order on 020-8348 6704.

fields.headline: Making tracks
fields.standfirst: Simon Birch has time to admire the stunning scenery on a cross-country course in Norway
fields.trailText: Simon Birch has time to admire the stunning scenery on a cross-country course in Norway.
fields.body:
We're 1,300m up, and our small group of skiers has been on the move for three hours, steadily climbing the low rounded hills that surround the southern Norwegian skiing resort of Kvit vatn.

Here, just above the tree-line, we're rewarded with a sweeping panorama: to the north lies the rolling plateau of the Hardangervidda stretching out to the skyline, while to the south rising above the trees is the distinctive hump-back outline of Gausta which at 1,883m is the region's highest mountain.

A few steps from where we've stopped, I noticed a near feather-perfect imprint in the snow made by either a ptarmigan or a black grouse and, judging by its freshness, the bird flew off just as we emerged from the pines.

In many ways, this is a classic cross-country skiing moment: unlike downhill, winter sport's fast-food activity, cross-country gives you the time to experience not only the vastness of the views but also the chance to take in the wildlife.

Despite being one of the leading cross-country skiing centres in Norway, on first impressions Kvit vatn appears to be tiny. This, however, may have something to do with the fact that with no building higher than a pine tree, most of the resort nestles unobtrusively among the trees and series of low hillocks.

What is obvious though is the virtual absence of any traffic or bustle, which results in a silence and calm that remains unbroken for the whole week of my stay.

On my first morning, after a potentially overwhelming smorgasbord breakfast at my temporary residence, Fjellstoge Lodge, there was just time to pick up the equipment before heading to the gentle nursery slopes where my group are to have our first lessons. The band of a dozen beginners was a mixed bunch, in terms of both age and experience.

The first thing we learned was that the key to a cross-country skier's ability lies in the boots. As snug and comfy as your favourite slippers, cross-country boots are attached to the ski only at the front, crucially leaving the heel free at the back.

The first two mornings were then spent being taught by Katherine, our British instructor, who was soon helping us gain the confidence we needed. We began by skiing in tracks, or "tramlines", that are cut by machines into the snow and into which your skis snugly fit. The length of these tracks can vary from a few kilometres in a valley bottom to a vast network, sometimes floodlit, through forests and over hills.

Come lunchtime, we'd nip back to the lodge to eat a packed lunch washed down with mugs of hot chocolate. In the afternoons, our newly acquired skills were put to the test when we were led out by Katherine for a two-hour off-track tour around the frozen Lake Kvit vatn at the back of the lodge.

Each day we'd be out skiing for six hours both on and off track, and by the late afternoon when the sun was starting to send the temperature tumbling, I was always looking forward to getting back to base and being able to dive into the sauna. Come the evening, it took an effort of Olympic proportions just to prise myself from the fireside sofa and stumble into bed where I immediately fell into a deep sleep.

Getting started

If you've never been cross-country skiing before you're probably better off signing up with one of the handful of the UK's specialist operators that organise holidays throughout the Alps and Scandinavia.

All the operators place an emphasis on holidays based in either quiet, Alpine villages or in low-key resorts.

My trip was booked through Waymark Holidays (01753 516477, brochure@waymarkholidays.co.uk). Seven nights in mid-February costs £655 with flights from Heathrow.

This season, Inntravel (01653 629010, www.inntravel.co.uk) is organising special Try It Out Weeks specifically designed for cross-country novices. Included in the price are two-hour lessons for the first three days and the hire of equipment for the week. These introductory weeks are available at nine resorts throughout the Alps and in Norway. A Try It Out Week in Kandersteg in Switzerland costs £599 flying from London City airport and includes seven nights' half board.

If you're not sure cross-country is for you but would like to give it a go, Headwater Holidays (01606 813333, www.headwater-holidays.co.uk) recommends Autrans in the western French Alps. Because of the wide range of winter activities available locally, if you don't take to cross-country there are downhill runs close by, plus you can always get a winter buzz from snow-shoeing, dog-sleigh rides and skating. Seven nights in Autrans in mid-February costs £788 flying from Gatwick.

Another good cross-country centre is S-Chanf in Switzerland, set in the upper Engadine valley. The flat valley floor offers over 150km of tracks with the added benefit that if you flag you can use the narrow-gauge train to get your back to base the easy way. Waymark offers seven nights in S-Chanf in early February for £575 half-board flying from Heathrow.

More information

The English Ski Council operates a dozen local groups across England. To find out where your nearest club is, contact Paddy Field, the Director of Nordic Skiing 01252 626339; paddyfield@ski-nordic.co.uk, or visit www.escnordic.org.uk. In Scotland, contact Snow Sport Scotland (01529 497007 www.snsc.demon.co.uk

webTitle: Who lost their heart in Biarritz?

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... Biarritz
fields.standfirst: Jonathan 'Jono' Coleman
fields.trailText: Jonathan 'Jono' Coleman
fields.body:
Why? We went for a week last summer and stayed in the Plaza, a 1920s hotel. It was a bit of a gamble because it was the first time we'd taken our two children, Emily and Oscar, to stay in a hotel, but it was great. The Plaza is like one of those old English seaside hotels but with a bit more art-deco style, a bit more haw-hi-haw. There's also an old casino in Biarritz, so there's this strange feeling of stepping back in time. The thing we loved about it, though, was the golden, sandy beach, which reminded us of a cross between Cornwall and the Gold Coast of Australia. The tide goes out a long way so the kids can safely wander out, but there's also quite a bit of surf - there are a lot French surfies and Brits who go there. Being a proper Australian, my wife Margot did a bit of body surfing; I need slightly bigger waves to move me.

What's the best thing? The thing I loved about it - and this is probably typical me - was the fact that you had a choice of not just French food but Basque, too, because it's so close to Spain - paellas, platters of mussels and oysters, tapas, that sort of thing. It's also more relaxed because of the Basque influence, it's great for walking around, and you don't really need a car.

My perfect day: Going to the Chocolate Museum of Biarritz. Margot said we were going to walk there after breakfast one day, but we found it was a lot further away than we thought, it took an hour and a half, and we got there just as it was closing for lunch. We bought lots of fantastic Henriet of Biarritz chocolate though and scoffed it as we walked back in the drizzle. Then we had a nice little lunch, the sun came out and we went swimming. It was one of those four seasons in one day.

My advice: After you've spoiled yourself in other parts of France, go to Biarritz and have a very healthy, laid-back beach-side holiday.

 Jonathan 'Jono' Coleman presents the breakfast show on Heart 106.2 FM from 6.30am-9am.

webTitle: Prescott gives way in row over tube

fields.headline: Prescott gives way in row over tube
fields.standfirst: Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText:
John Prescott yesterday signalled an unmistakable
climbdown over plans to part-privatise the London tube
when he announced that he had asked Ken
Livingstone's transport commissioner, Bob Kiley, to
"modify" the government's public-private partnership for
the underground.
fields.body:
John Prescott yesterday signalled an unmistakable climbdown over plans to part-privatise the London tube when he announced that he had asked Ken Livingstone's transport commissioner, Bob Kiley, to "modify" the government's public-private partnership for the underground.

The move, following weeks of negotiations with Mr Kiley and the direct intervention of Tony Blair, represents a notable victory for Mr Livingstone, who made opposition to the partial selloff of the London Underground the central plank of his bid to become the capital's first elected mayor.

Under the terms of a compromise deal finalised between Mr Prescott and Mr Kiley yesterday morning, the transport commissioner will draw up changes to the government scheme, tenders and contracts, with the aim of maintaining unified management control of the tube.

Monday's tube strike over safety by the traindrivers' union Aslef will still go ahead in the absence of management assurances and in an atmosphere which the union said had been poisoned by the outlawing of parallel industrial action by the Rail Maritime and Transport union.

In the wake of the Hatfield rail disaster, widely blamed on the fragmentation of the mainline network under privatisation, the prospect of a similar breakup of control of London Underground has been a key factor in laying the ground for the shift in the government's thinking.

The appointment of the internationally respected Mr Kiley, the breadth of opposition to the partial selloff across the political spectrum, the threat of legal action and industrial disruption in the run-up to a general election also helped to convince the government to change course.

Mr Livingstone hailed the agreement as a "victory for Londoners after months of deadlock" and went out of his way to praise the efforts made by Mr Prescott - as opposed to the Treasury, which has been criticised by Mr Kiley for its role in the negotiations - to shift the government line.

The shadow transport minister, Bernard Jenkin, said the deal between Mr Prescott and Mr Kiley amounted to a "crushing" defeat for the deputy prime minister, who had been forced to admit his plans were "deeply flawed".

Mr Kiley, the man credited with turning round the New York subway, will submit his revised plans for a public-sector controlled modernisation of the tube by the end of the month. If they are accepted by the government, the existing private consortia will be invited to bid for new contracts.

The likelihood is now that those contracts will not involve the breakup of the tube, nor the 30-year handover of stations, track and signalling to private compa nies envisaged under the government's scheme - if so, the "modifications" will be seen as marking a significant retreat in its wider part-privatisation programme for the public services.

Mr Kiley said there were still points of difference between himself and the government, but those differences were "narrowing".

Mr Prescott's department emphasised that there had been compromise on both sides, but the deputy prime minister left open the possibility that Mr Kiley's changes to the part-privatisation scheme might still be rejected, while praising Mr Kiley's "strong management team" and emphasising that they would be "working closely" together to "enhance" the existing plans.

The transport minister, Lord Macdonald, insisted that the government had "ruled nothing out and nothing in", adding that "unified management is a very big issue and that is a question we will be mulling over in the next few weeks".

The agreement was welcomed by business organisations in London. Peter Bishop, acting chief executive of the London chamber of commerce, said that Mr Kiley was "clearly a man the government can do business with".

"He will have to operate the system once the new arrangements are in place and it would have been untenable to proceed if he were not convinced they are workable."

London Underground chairman and managing director, Derek Smith, described the deal as a "platform to move forward" after a funding structure that had been "hit and miss" for most of the last four decades.

The agreement means that Mr Kiley, who has described the government's partial selloff plan as "fatally flawed", will finally have full access to all commercial details of the existing contracts and will take control of negotiations with the private consortia bidding to modernise the tube.

Some of the companies involved in bidding for the existing multi-billion pound contracts yesterday privately expressed anger at the government's last-minute change of heart - the contracts were supposed to have been finalised by the end of last month - but a spokeswoman for Mr Prescott said that the decision would not have "come as the most massive surprise" to them.

The appointment of the internationally respected Mr Kiley, the breadth of opposition to the partial selloff across the political spectrum, the threat of legal action and industrial disruption in the run-up to a general election also helped to convince the government to change course. Mr Livingstone hailed the agreement as a "victory for Londoners after months of deadlock" and went out of his way to praise the efforts made by Mr Prescott - as opposed to the Treasury, which has been criticised by Mr Kiley for its role in the negotiations - to shift the government line. The shadow transport minister, Bernard Jenkin, said the deal between Mr Prescott and Mr Kiley amounted to a "crushing" defeat for the deputy prime minister, who had been forced to admit his plans were "deeply flawed". Mr Kiley, the man credited with turning round the New York subway, will submit his revised plans for a public-sector controlled modernisation of the tube by the end of the month. If they are accepted by the government, the existing private consortia will be invited to bid for new contracts. The likelihood is now that those contracts will not involve the breakup of the tube, nor the 30-year handover of stations, track and signalling to private compa nies envisaged under the government's scheme - if so, the "modifications" will be seen as marking a significant retreat in its wider part-privatisation programme for the public services. Mr Kiley said there were still points of difference between himself and the government, but those differences were "narrowing". Mr Prescott's department emphasised that there had been compromise on both sides, but the deputy prime minister left open the possibility that Mr Kiley's changes to the part-privatisation scheme might still be rejected, while praising Mr Kiley's "strong management team" and emphasising that they would be "working closely" together to "enhance" the existing plans. The transport minister, Lord Macdonald, insisted that the government had "ruled nothing out and nothing in", adding that "unified management is a very big issue and that is a question we will be mulling over in the next few weeks". The agreement was welcomed by business organisations in London. Peter Bishop, acting chief executive of the London chamber of commerce, said that Mr Kiley was "clearly a man the government can do business with". "He will have to operate the system once the new arrangements are in place and it would have been untenable to proceed if he were not convinced they are workable." London Underground chairman and managing director, Derek Smith, described the deal as a "platform to move forward" after a funding structure that had been "hit and miss" for most of the last four decades. The agreement means that Mr Kiley, who has described the government's partial selloff plan as "fatally flawed", will finally have full access to all commercial details of the existing contracts and will take control of negotiations with the private consortia bidding to modernise the tube. Some of the companies involved in bidding for the existing multi-billion pound contracts yesterday privately expressed anger at the government's last-minute change of heart - the contracts were supposed to have been finalised by the end of last month - but a spokeswoman for Mr Prescott said that the decision would not have "come as the most massive surprise" to them.

fields.headline: Church sued over 'undue influence'
fields.trailText:
A controversial charismatic church admitted yesterday that it is being sued by a former
         member over allegations that its leader exercised undue influence over her.
fields.body:
A controversial charismatic church admitted yesterday that it is being sued by a former member over allegations that its leader exercised undue influence over her.

The Peniel Church of Brentwood, Essex, promised to fight allegations that its leader, "Bishop" Michael Reid, a former insurance salesman, had used his personal magnetism to force a member of the congregation to do his bidding financially.

Caroline Green, 33, now divorced and living in Wales, is alleging that Mr Reid overrode her parents' wishes concerning her education and ordered guests at her wedding to tithe a 10th of their gross income to the church.

Ann Brown, a spokeswoman for the church, said: "The claims she is making are bizarre. We are anxious that the matter should be brought before a judge so that we can contest it vigorously."

This is not the first time the church has found itself at the centre of controversy. The local parliamentary constituency of Brentwood and Ongar has been riven by claims that church members have signed up en masse for the local Conservative association.

The independent MP Martin Bell has promised to contest the seat at the general election in response to calls from independent Conservatives that the church's influence should be challenged. It is known that 119 members of the church joined the local Conservative association on the same day.

fields.headline: What it's all about: Amalfi
fields.standfirst: Author David Lodge takes in the sights and smells of Sorrento and Capri before enjoying a spot of southern hospitality in Ravello courtesy of Gore Vidal
fields.trailText: Author David Lodge takes in the sights and smells of Sorrento and Capri before enjoying a spot of southern hospitality in Ravello courtesy of Gore Vidal.
fields.body:
Whoever Mario Lanza was imploring to Come Back to Sorrento, I only hope they made straight for the Hotel Excelsior Vittoria.

Our intention was to try a week's self-catering sandwiched in between two short hotel stays that would allow for some pampering. Certainly the Excelsior Vittoria did not let us down in that department, recapturing as it does some sense of past grandeur when celebrities such as Caruso were regular patrons.

Conveniently situated at the heart of Sorrento, it is insulated from the noise and bustle of the Piazza Tasso (the Renaissance poet of the same name was born here) by extensive grounds that include an elegant swimming pool. The floors and walls of the interior are clad in gleaming marble, and the terrace and open-air restaurant (with excellent cuisine) afford stunning views across the bay of Naples.

My wife and I had chosen the town because it is such a good base for sightseeing. Boats of all kinds ply back and forth to Naples, Capri, and Ischia, while the Circumvesuviana Railway offers cheap and frequent services to Pompeii and Herculaneum.

Sorrento is built along the top of a high cliff, and getting up and down to the seafront can be a tiring and tedious trek. But the Excelsior Vittoria has its own private lift, which transports you straight from the terrace to the harbour. One morning we left our room at 9.10am, took the lift, bought a return ticket to Capri, stepped on to a hydrofoil, and disembarked at the Marina Grande 20 minutes later.

By 10am, after a short trip on the funicular railway, we were each sipping a cappuccino in the sun outside the Gran Café in the Piazzetta of Capri Town. The little square was swarming with people, but its charm survives the daily sea-borne invasion, and it doesn't take long to find peace and quiet on the island. We walked out of the town, up steep narrow alleys, shaded by trees and flowering shrubs, and blessedly free from motorised vehicles, to the ruined Villa Jovis which the Emperor Tiberius built as his retreat on the edge of a precipitous cliff from which those who offended him were hurled to their deaths.

I had recently read Shirley Hazzard's memoir, Graham Greene on Capri, which describes this walk. We didn't have time to look for the novelist's villa in Anacapri, but we did have lunch - a buffet of tasty antipasti - at his favourite restaurant, Gemma, in Capri Town, which is reached by a quaint, crooked alley bored through the rock, and where his photograph is proudly displayed, pasted to the ceiling of the tiny lobby along with those of many other celebrities.

Our other main excursion from Sorrento was Pompeii. I won't attempt to add anything to what so many literary visitors have said about this astonishing place over the centuries, except that the famous moulded corpses of the original inhabitants, preserved forever as they were at the moment when they were overwhelmed by volcanic ash, strongly reminded me of the statues of Anthony Gormley exhibited in the forecourt of the Royal Academy last year, and I wondered whether he was influenced by them.

There seemed to be as many people in the streets of Pompeii as there must have been in AD79 when the wrath of Mount Vesuvius descended upon the inhabitants. Tourists squeezed into the Casa dei Vettii to look at the naughty frescos, like punters in a Soho peepshow. The pretty avenue that leads to the Villa dei Mysteri outside the walls was, however, comparatively empty, and you could easily picture it with togaed citizens and solid-wheeled ox-carts going up and down.

The Amalfi Coast and its environs are spectacularly beautiful and full of historical interest, but also very crowded in the high season, and the topography pushes people even closer together. The corniche from Sorrento to Salerno is described by Michelin as the finest in Europe, but when we drove along it to our next destination I was too busy negotiating the blind hairpin bends, traffic jams and anarchic roadside parking to appreciate the scenery. It was a relief when, south of Salerno, the countryside became flatter, more open, and less densely populated.

The Palazzo Belmonte is wedged into one end of Santa Maria di Castellabate, once a small fishing village and now a thriving seaside resort mainly patronised by Italian families. Fortunately, most of the new development has taken place at the other end. The ancient rooms of the Palazzo have been converted into apartments of various sizes, comfortably furnished and well equipped. It has a delightful flower-fringed swimming pool with bar, and a small private beach on the other side of the boundary wall. The beach is sandy and shelves gently - ideal for children. Lunch and dinner (if you don't want to cook your own or go out) are served under umbrellas on a grass terrace overlooking the sea, an ambience that seems more picnic than restaurant. The dishes on the limited menu range from good to adequate, and the service is enthusiastic rather than professional. The atmosphere of the whole place is pleasantly informal and conducive to rest and relaxation; but there's a busy pedestrianised shopping street just five minutes' walk away, where you can buy excellent local produce very cheaply, and cafés, where you can sit and watch authentic Italian pavement life.

We occupied one of the gallery apartments, converted from the former store rooms of the Palazzo into split-level, open-plan accommodation. It was terrific, apart from one design flaw: hot air and kitchen smells rise into the upper bedroom level. The Palazzo has no air-conditioning, relying on its thick walls and high ceilings, which is fine in the more traditional apartments, into which we enviously peeped, but the gallery apartments must be uncomfortable in really hot weather. We were also disconcerted to find that our "sit-out" balcony faced out on to a public lane, above a row of dustbins, and, as a result, we made little use of it. If you're thinking of booking into the Belmonte, check out the accommodation in detail. With that caveat, it offers an attractive compromise between the convenience of a hotel and the independence of self-catering.

Perched on a conical hill above the palazzo is the old village of Castellabate, a warren of odd little houses, tiny squares, narrow alleys and steep steps, which is interesting to explore and contains several restaurants. We enjoyed an unfussy but good dinner at Il Callice on an open terrace as the sun set over the Gulf of Salerno.

Only 40 minutes away is Paestum, with its three Greek temples, reputed to be the finest surviving specimens on the Continent. Two of them are currently undergoing restoration, but the site is still well worth visiting, if only to see the exquisite Temple of Ceres. The museum nearby contains amazing frescos, including one that looks startlingly modern, taken from the Tomb of the Diver. In essence, it is a kind of Roman David Hockney.

After an excellent lunch at the local Helios Hotel, it was back to the Amalfi coast, and Ravello. Like most first-time visitors, we found it enchanting - and surprisingly peaceful considering its fame. Perhaps the narrow and tortuous road up from the coast deters the really big tourist coaches. We stayed at the Hotel Palumbo, an elegant and comfortable five-star hotel converted from another old palazzo, with astonishing views of both the mountains and sea from its terrace and an atmosphere of civilised calm.

There is not a great deal to see in Ravello, apart from its two villas - the ruined Rufulo, which has open-air concerts in the evenings, and the Cimbrone with its lush gardens overlooking the sea - but it is pleasant just to ramble through the cobbled lanes or linger over a drink in a café on the main square.

Many writers have passed through the town over the years, and plaques record that Gide, Forster and DH Lawrence wrote some of their works here. The current writer in residence, and Ravello's most celebrated inhabitant, is Gore Vidal, who kindly invited us to drinks one evening. His white villa, full of fine old paintings, statues and mosaics, clings to the steep mountainside overlooking the Gulf of Salerno. Pleasure boats look like toys on the sea hundreds of metres below, but the writer claims that he can sometimes faintly hear the amplified voices of the tour guides pointing out "the house of Gore Vidal..." in different languages.

He entertained us with wit and whisky on his balcony, a literary Tiberius metaphorically tossing politicians, critics, and a good deal of contemporary literature over the balustrade and into the abyss. He also recommended a fish restaurant called Zachario down on the shore just outside Amalfi, where we enjoyed a delectable lunch the next day.

Amalfi, itself, was heaving because it was the feast of the patron saint, the apostle Andrew. "Is there a legend connecting him with the town?" I asked innocently at the ticket booth for the cathedral museum. "No, it is true," said the lady, severely. Apparently his body was brought from Constantinople in the 4th century, and is entombed in the cathedral, a fascinating architectural fusion of Moorish and European styles.

I wondered idly why Andrew hadn't generated an international pilgrimage cult, like his fellow apostle St James in Santiago. Perhaps Amalfi was just too small and congested even in the middle ages. We were glad to take the bus back to the tranquil comforts of the Hotel Palumbo. As far as I am concerned, they can re-write that song as Come Back to Ravello.

The practicals

fields.headline: Robert Coleman
fields.standfirst:
A devoted Cambridge scholar, he revelled in the delights of language, ancient and modern

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A devoted Cambridge scholar, he revelled in the delights of language, ancient and modern.
fields.body:
The professor of comparative philology, Bob Coleman, who has died aged 71, once recommended to me Eaden Lilley's department store as the best place for a morning cup of coffee. He was not, however, thinking of the Eaden Lilley in central Cambridge, a few yards away from Emmanuel, his college, but the sister store in Saffron Walden, "a mere", as he put it, "20 minutes' drive". I doubt if any other Cambridge professors regularly made a 40 minute round-trip for their elevenses, but then Bob was not like other Cambridge professors.

This was immediately apparent to students, who would find that a lecture on Virgil's Eclogues would include Sanskrit etymology and a discussion of Shakespeare's sonnets; a lecture on the Latin language would involve a long digression on terms for "urinate" in English slang, with "pump ship" singled out for particular praise.

It was not just his subject matter that was unconventional. Bob actually took an interest in students - he would invite them to tea; he would discuss ideas and personalities with them; he would offer advice and support. Maybe it was because of his continued delight in the company of both undergraduates and graduates that he retained until his retirement his youthful looks, enthusiasm and the iconoclasm of a Young Turk.

Bob always delighted in being radical, and enjoyed shocking (or was it teasing?) with the unorthodoxy of his views, whether it was a proposal for the abolition of college masterships, his claim that Shane Warne could not bowl proper leg-spin, or insisting to his Cambridge colleagues (including John Chadwick) that Mycenaean Greek was much less Greek than they all thought.

Born in New Zealand, and keeping his citizenship and support for the All Blacks throughout his life, Bob liked to play the role of the antipodean outsider. He came to Cambridge as an affiliated student after gaining a degree at Victoria University, Wellington, and immersed himself in the academic, musical and sporting life of the university.

He found his real inspiration in the lectures of Sir Harold Bailey on Vedic Sanskrit, and Ilya Gershevitch on Iranian languages. He planned to do graduate work on the comparative philology of the Indo-European family (of which Greek and Latin are members), in particular on Latin and the closely related pre-Roman languages of Italy.

But he had scarcely time to read through the scanty remains of Oscan, the ancient language of Campania, and Umbrian before he was appointed a lecturer in the department of humanity at Aberdeen University.

He taught there for five years, supplementing his courses on classics with a class on Maori - to the initial surprise, and eventual delight, of his students - before returning to Cambridge. Life as a classics don at Emmanuel College meant that he had to teach across the board, including the whole range of classical literature and philosophy, as well as courses on the history of the Latin language and Indo-European philology.

Indeed, he said recently that he had enough projects in hand to last him until the age of 102.

Bob's sudden death, all the more shocking since he was always so full of life, not only leaves scholars cheated of books not yet written, but also deprives Emmanuel College and the classics faculty of Cambridge of one of the keepers of their oral history.

He was not, however, thinking of the Eaden Lilley in central Cambridge, a few yards away from Emmanuel, his college, but the sister store in Saffron Walden, "a mere", as he put it, "20 minutes' drive". I doubt if any other Cambridge professors regularly made a 40 minute round-trip for their elevenses, but then Bob was not like other Cambridge professors. This was immediately apparent to students, who would find that a lecture on Virgil's Eclogues would include Sanskrit etymology and a discussion of Shakespeare's sonnets; a lecture on the Latin language would involve a long digression on terms for "urinate" in English slang, with "pump ship" singled out for particular praise. It was not just his subject matter that was unconventional. Bob actually took an interest in students - he would invite them to tea; he would discuss ideas and personalities with them; he would offer advice and support. Maybe it was because of his continued delight in the company of both undergraduates and graduates that he retained until his retirement his youthful looks, enthusiasm and the iconoclasm of a Young Turk. Bob always delighted in being radical, and enjoyed shocking (or was it teasing?) with the unorthodoxy of his views, whether it was a proposal for the abolition of college masterships, his claim that Shane Warne could not bowl proper leg-spin, or insisting to his Cambridge colleagues (including John Chadwick) that Mycenaean Greek was much less Greek than they all thought. fields.headline: Teachers label 3.7% pay rise inadequate
fields.standfirst:
Unions attack refusal to match conditions package planned for Scotland
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Teachers' leaders in England and Wales last night dismissed as inadequate a pay rise of 3.7% and lambasted the education secretary, David Blunkett, for refusing to introduce the kind of package planned in Scotland.
fields.body:
Teachers' leaders in England and Wales last night dismissed as inadequate a pay rise of 3.7% and lambasted the education secretary, David Blunkett, for refusing to introduce the kind of package planned in Scotland.

The rise from April is on a par with nurses and well above the headline inflation rate of 2.9%, but below the 4.2% average increase in earnings. However, many teachers will get more from the £564m deal announced yesterday.

New teachers receive a 6% rise, with other rank and file teachers getting increases on a sliding scale down to 3.7%. London allowances also increase by 30% as part of what Mr Blunkett described as a three Rs package - "recruitment, retention and reward".

Schools will also have the option of encouraging teachers with "golden handcuff" bonuses of more than £15,000 if they stay three years.

Officials said the average teacher would earn £27,900, compared with £23,434 in March 1998. Mr Blunkett angered unions by failing to follow the Scottish executive, which is phasing in a contracted 35-hour week and a maximum 25 hours' contact time. This was "difficult and cumbersome to administer", the education secretary said.

He also released figures suggesting that the unions have hyped the recruitment problems faced this winter. On the government's narrow definition of a vacant post, a survey of 1,453 schools showed secondary vacancies up from 0.7% to 0.8% but primary vacancies down from 0.8% to 0.5%. Vacancies in London have apparently fallen, though they have risen elsewhere in the south-east. Unions believe the true level is much higher.

New teachers with second class honours degrees or better start on £17,001 from April, up from £16,050. The London allowance rises from £2,316 to £3,000 in inner London, from £1,524 to £1,974 in outer London, and from £591 to £765 in the fringes around the capital. Starting salaries in inner London will be £20,001, up 9%.

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, said: "The government has missed yet another chance to make teaching attractive and recruit young people into the profession."

Using figures from the Association of Graduate Recruiters, Mr McAvoy said the rises would leave newly qualified teachers still earning £1,600 less than the average they would receive outside teaching. After five years that gap would grow to £11,000.

"The government complacently believes it can pile more and more work onto our teachers. It has done nothing to limit their working hours, nor to ensure they have time outside the classroom during the school day - both of which have been guaranteed in Scotland," Mr McAvoy said.

Scottish teachers have won a 10% rise this year but still lag behind salaries in England and Wales.

The pay deal follows the advice of the school teachers review body report, released yesterday. Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, described it as "the most disappointing review body report for many years".

The pay scale available to heads of department has gone up by 10%, and by 9% for headteachers. A headteacher's maximum goes up to £78,800 - or £81,800 in London.

Schools can encourage staff to stay with bonuses of more than £15,000 if they stay three years; alternatively they could pay up to £5,085 a year for three years.

"Schools have substantial extra resources this year and can choose to use direct grants to attract and retain good teachers. This will help schools and areas facing the greatest recruitment challenges to offer significantly better pay for specialist teachers," Mr Blunkett said. He also promised £5m extra to support those returning to teaching from refresher courses.

Theresa May, shadow education secretary, welcomed the deal but said: "The government's failure to properly fund this settlement will mean a large proportion of this rise will be funded by local taxpayers."

The Local Government Association predicted council taxes might have to rise by 10% to cover the award, a claim dismissed by education department officials.

The Liberal Democrat spokesman Phil Willis said: "Teachers in England and Wales need the same guarantees as their Scottish colleagues of shorter working hours, less bureaucracy and smaller class sizes."

webTitle: Leader: a fair deal for teachers

fields.headline: A fair deal for teachers - as long as it starts a five-year catch up
fields.trailText: No trend which has lasted for a generation is going to be corrected in a year.
fields.body:
No trend which has lasted for a generation is going to be corrected in a year. The government's R and R problem, the recruitment and retention of teachers, is going to take at least five years to resolve. That is the extent to which teachers' pay has fallen from its last high point, in 1974, when the Houghton award restored their position on the white collar ladder. At that time teachers were being paid 137% above the white collar average. By now, it is only a few percentage points above 100%.

Yesterday's pay deal from the school teachers review body is not nearly as bad as the teaching unions are making out. Unlike many years in the last decade, it is not being staged and is above inflation. There are all manner of generous bribes for both new and experienced teachers, pushing the total cost to 4.2%, (in line with the rise in average earnings). But what is missing is a clear vision of the future. If this was the first year of a five-year catch-up operation, which is what the schools need, there would be loud cheers in the staff room. But because it is a one-off, disgruntlement has filled the air waves.

It is difficult to gauge the current level of teacher shortage. The pictures painted by unions and ministers could not be more different. A union survey in October found an 11% vacancy rate in primary schools and 9% in secondary posts. Union leaders have talked of schools being forced to introduce four-day working weeks. Ministers suggest that there are only 2,670 vacancies, which in a teaching force of 400,000, represents a vacancy rate of 0.5% in primary schools and 0.8% in secondary. Reality is somewhere in the middle. There have been some four-day schools, but not many. But the respected academic, Prof Alan Smithers of Liverpool University, who produced a report on teacher shortage in December, is in no doubt that there is a serious underlying problem. He believes government figures underplay the seriousness by not counting vacancies which have temporary cover.

Ministers have been taking the issue seriously. Even before yesterday's package, they had introduced £6,000 training salaries, plus £4,000 golden hellos for teachers in specialist subjects with serious shortages (maths, science and modern languages), and even £13,000 salaries for 1,600 graduates following classroom-based training programmes. In the new package, fresh recruits, who are crucial in a profession in which over half are over 45, will get a 6% rise, boosting their salaries to £17,000 (or £20,000 in inner London with its special weighting). Experienced teachers who pass the performance threshold - an expected 150,000 out of the 200,000 who have applied - will see their pay rise from £24,000 to £26,900 (or £30,000 in London). On top of this, schools will be able to pay recruitment or retention bonuses of up to £5,000. And in tough schools, these can be rolled into three-year "golden handcuffs" worth £15,000.

The corner has been turned. An extra 7,000 teachers have been recruited and there are 2,250 more people in training programmes than last year - although there are also an extra 164,000 pupils in the system since 1997. What ministers need to do now is to commit themselves to an independent review of teachers' pay. They can give it to the review board, but free it from the spending restraints which are currently imposed. Teaching is much too important to be left in its present semi-professional state. Full professional status must be restored. This will only be achieved when, in the new and more competitive graduate market, schools can offer more attractive deals.

webTitle: Princess Pauline de Metternich, Hilaire Germain Edgar Degas (c. 1865)

fields.headline: Princess Pauline de Metternich, Hilaire Germain Edgar Degas (c. 1865)
fields.trailText: · View the work online
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: Hilaire Germain Edgar Degas (1834-1917), who studied under Ingres at the Ecole des Beaux Arts and experimented with history painting before becoming fascinated by the contemporary world. He exhibited with the impressionists, yet his art was always less spontaneous and more analytical than that of any other painters in the movement.

Subject: Princess Pauline de Metternich, wife of the Austro-Hungarian ambassador in Paris. The image was copied from a photograph taken by Eugène Disderi (1819-89), which was used by the diplomatic couple as a visiting card.

Distinguishing features: It is the strange quality of her face that pulls you up. Her left profile is painted clearly, but her nose and right cheek, while given a neat, crisp precision, are oddly incomplete, even blurred. To anyone who has ever looked at an old photograph, this painting is spine-tingling, because you recognise almost straight away that Degas has painted one of the first portraits ever to be based on a photographic image. The blurring of the Princess's features is what happens in a slow- exposure camera trying to capture motion; Degas makes the photographic origin of the image unmistakable.

Unlike the black-and-white original, his painting is in colour; but the colours are unhealthy, a little mad, with Pauline de Metternich posed against floral-patterned yellow wallpaper that overlaps strangely with her body. This is not from the photograph but Degas's invention; he has also cropped out her husband, who was in Disderi's picture. Degas has isolated Princess Pauline de Metternich in a yellow-painted garden, with dry, sparse branches. Her straw-coloured top jars uncomfortably with the background. The colours of her skirt - a flat, dark grey - and her high-contrast face and black hair have the monochrome harshness of a photograph. Degas makes it clear that he has not painted Princess Pauline; he has painted a photograph of her.

Visiting cards were a popular use for photography in the 19th century. Degas has exposed the way the photograph creates a new kind of public face, reproduced and widely circulated, no longer a unique exchange between portrait painter and model. Degas's painting is a study of the modern way of life. Degas was an intellectual sensualist, and his desire to break up and take apart the act of looking, to freeze and hold the moment of visual pleasure, made him turn repeatedly to photography.

This is a very early example. Later, in the 1880s, he compared Eadweard Muybridge's series of photographs of a horse in motion to his own paintings at the racetrack. Then, in the 1890s, after a lifelong fascination with the camera, he took up photography seriously, taking grand portraits of his friends and erotic pictures of nudes. A late painting such as After the Bath, Woman Drying Herself (c1894-96) has a direct photographic equivalent taken by the artist, a stunning photograph in its sharp, sexual examination of a woman's thighs, buttocks and back. Degas used photography in his late art as part of his attempt to hold and possess what gave him visual delight.

Inspirations and influences: Degas's portrait anticipates by a century the photo-based silkscreen paintings of Andy Warhol and especially the work of the German artist Gerhard Richter. Like this work, Richter's paintings deliberately imitate the blurring effects of photography to stress our inability to completely understand something, for example in his haunting painting of his daughter, Betty (1988).

Where is it? The National Gallery, London WC2 (020-7747 2885).

webTitle: Blow to government's private-public schools venture

fields.headline: Blow to private-public schools venture
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government's flagship for a new type of local education authority outside London has been substantially changed in the face of a mutiny by the local Labour party and school staff.
fields.body:
The government's flagship for a new type of local education authority outside London has been substantially changed in the face of a mutiny by the local Labour party and school staff.

The schools minister, Estelle Morris, agreed yesterday to give Leeds city council full legal ownership of a joint venture company that is taking over the education authority after a highly critical Ofsted report a year ago.

The switch abandons a plan to bolster the independence of the firm, EducationLeeds, by dividing ownership 50-50 between the council and the private sector. EducationLeeds' first chairman, Peter Ridsdale, chairman of Leeds United football club, said opposition to the plan had been made plain to him.

"I have spent a lot of time in the last four months visiting and listening to schools. I have heard what they say," he said.

"I have also been conscious that those staff who are providing support to schools have been very concerned."

Protests at the takeover, which have included a march and moves towards a legal challenge, are likely to continue. Dave Roberts of Leeds' Campaign for State Education said the switch was a concession, but "essentially a cosmetic change".

Leeds lost control of its £300m school education service after Ofsted highlighted political meddling in a report last February, which also described some support services as being in "a parlous state".

fields.headline: Holidaying in Cuba
fields.standfirst: Richard Davies wants to take his family on holiday to Cuba but is concerned that his passport will be stamped making later visits to the US difficult or impossible.
fields.trailText: Richard Davies wants to take his family on holiday to Cuba but is concerned that his passport will be stamped making later visits to the US difficult or impossible.
fields.body:
To enter Cuba, all travellers need either a visa or a tourist card. If travelling on business or if you want to stay more than a month, you will need a visa obtainable from the Cuban consulate at 167 High Holborn, London WC1V 6PA (tel: 020-7240 2488).

For a short holiday, a tourist card is sufficient, and this can be obtained from the consulate, your tour operator or from the Cuban national airline, Cubana de Aviacion, 49 Conduit Street, London W1R 9FB (020-7734 1165).

The tourist card is in two parts and has to be filled in before travel. The first part is stamped and retained on entry by the immigration authorities. The second part is stamped and kept by the authorities on departure. Your passport is not stamped, though if you ask nicely the immigration officer will gladly do so.

Probably the only people not allowed to visit Cuba as tourists are US citizens, unless they have prior permission from their government. However, they can travel via a Caribbean island, Mexico or Canada and, not having their passports stamped, return to the US without their government being any the wiser. Guilherme Eduardo Tully

fields.bodyText: To enter Cuba, all travellers need either a visa or a tourist card. If travelling on business or if you want to stay more than a month, you will need a visa obtainable from the Cuban consulate at 167 High Holborn, London WC1V 6PA (tel: 020-7240 2488). For a short holiday, a tourist card is sufficient, and this can be obtained from the consulate, your tour operator or from the Cuban national airline, Cubana de Aviacion, 49 Conduit Street, London W1R 9FB (020-7734 1165). The tourist card is in two parts and has to be filled in before travel. The first part is stamped and retained on entry by the immigration authorities. The second part is stamped and kept by the authorities on departure. Your passport is not stamped, though if you ask nicely the immigration officer will gladly do so. Probably the only people not allowed to visit Cuba as tourists are US citizens, unless they have prior permission from their government. However, they can travel via a Caribbean island, Mexico or Canada and, not having their passports stamped, return to the US without their government being any the wiser. webTitle: More adventurous ways to spend Valentine's day

fields.headline: Put your heart into it
fields.standfirst: Traditionalists may still want chocolates and champagne but Juliet Shedden suggests some more adventurous ways to celebrate St Valentine's day
fields.trailText: Traditionalists may still want chocolates and champagne but Juliet Shedden suggests some more adventurous ways to celebrate St Valentine's day.
fields.body:
Go off the rails: enjoy an intimate dinner on the Orient Express or soar above London in your own Eye capsule

To all singletons out there beware; St Valentine's day approaches. Yes, it's that dreaded time of year when women and men can either hold their heads high asking everyone: "How many did you get?" or shamefacedly mumble: "None". What they are referring to, of course, are St Valentine's day cards.

This is a rather strange tradition. It dates back to 270AD when a bold young Roman called Valentinus sent his girlfriend a note just before he was executed saying "from your Valentine". The gesture touched the hearts of many; his martyrdom took place on February 14. This coincided with another Roman festival, Lupercalia, held on February 15 to honour the gods Pan and Juno. The festival was celebrated by the pairing of young girls and boys and a tradition was born.

However, these days men and women are no longer satisfied with receiving a card with the simple words "from your Valentine". Many want flowers (must be 12 red roses), chocolates (must be Belgian) and an engagement ring (must be platinum and diamond). And don't forget the candlelit dinner.

But this year we thought we'd give you some alternative ideas for St Valentine's day. As it falls on a Wednesday, why not postpone your romantic gestures until the weekend, when you'll really be able to let your hair down?

Activity Superstore has a range of romantic things for couples to do. For the wild at heart wanting to get to know each other just a little more, what about a tantric sex weekend in Brighton at £199 for two?

The weekend, at the Brighton School of Tantra, aims to teach couples the philosophy and techniques of sexual tantra: physical exercises to heighten the senses, meditations and visualisations to develop awareness of subtle sexual energy. There is no explicit sexual activity and the package does not include accommodation.

For couples preferring a more romantic day, why not treat your partner to lunch or supper on the Orient Express (£350 for two). You can experience magical and elegant surroundings while enjoying fine cuisine and wines. On arrival guests are welcomed with a glass of champagne. The train winds its way through the countryside for four hours while you and your partner enjoy the scenery and a five-course meal. Trains leave from Bristol, Cardiff, Edinburgh, Birmingham and London.

More adventurous couples, with heads for heights, might enjoy a champagne balloon flight (£299 for two). Gliding over the countryside as dusk is falling - what could be more romantic and adventurous? The three-hour flight ends with a glass of champagne and locations are nationwide.

British Airways' London Eye is offering what promises to be an unforgettable experience for lovers. During St Valentine's week (Feb 10-16) you can reserve a Cupid's Capsule for two with a waiter to serve you champagne, strawberries and chocolate 450 feet above London. (£250 plus VAT, book 48 hours in advance: 0207 654 0813). Your 35-minute flight will be captured by a London Eye fun camera so memories can last forever.

Those with a spirit of fun can book a llama trekking trip in Bridgewater, Somerset (£69 for two). You are given a local map, a picnic and a llama and are then free to wander at will, enjoying the countryside with no one to spoil your romantic day.

Traditionalists may prefer a 24-hour chocoholic experience set in the idyllic Cotswolds in a three-star hotel (£199 for two). The dish of the day, of course, is chocolate, which is on every menu. The weekend ends with a treasure hunt: no prizes for guessing where you eventually end up.

St Valentine's day is not just for couples. Singletons can also enjoy the pleasures of romance. Why not try to impress the someone you fancy by taking them on an unusual date? Get physical with a salsa dancing lesson (£19 for two hours). This most sensual of dances originated in Latin America. A warm-up lesson will show you how it's done and you then have a free rein to impress your date with those sexy hip movements.

Or perhaps take your date on a world wine tasting tour at Vinopolis in London (£11.50 p/p, 0870 444 4777). Sample more than 120 wines from 14 regions, finishing up in Wine Wharf over a glass of your new-found wine and some tapas.

If these ideas are a little too intimate, a day's rapid running for two (£75, Nottingham) may blow your inhibitions away. Adrenalin levels will be at a high as the two of you make your way on an inflatable raft down a man-made slalom course. And the best thing is, it isn't dependent on the weather.

 For more details contact Activity Superstore , 01799 526526; London Eye, 0207 654 0813; Vinopolis, 0870 444 4777.

webTitle: Prescott gives way in row over tube

fields.headline: Prescott gives way in row over tube
fields.trailText: John Prescott yesterday signalled an unmistakable climbdown over plans to part-privatise the London tube when he announced that he had asked Ken Livingstone's transport commissioner, Bob Kiley, to "modify" the government's public-private partnership for the underground.
fields.body:
John Prescott yesterday signalled an unmistakable climbdown over plans to part-privatise the London tube when he announced that he had asked Ken Livingstone's transport commissioner, Bob Kiley, to "modify" the government's public-private partnership for the underground.

The move, following weeks of negotiations with Mr Kiley and the direct intervention of Tony Blair, represents a notable victory for Mr Livingstone, who made opposition to the partial selloff of the London Underground the central plank of his bid to become the capital's first elected mayor.

Under the terms of a compromise deal finalised between Mr Prescott and Mr Kiley yesterday morning, the transport commissioner will draw up changes to the government scheme, tenders and contracts, with the aim of maintaining unified management control of the tube.

Monday's tube strike over safety by the traindrivers' union Aslef will still go ahead in the absence of management assurances and in an atmosphere which the union said had been poisoned by the outlawing of parallel industrial action by the Rail Maritime and Transport union.

In the wake of the Hatfield rail disaster, widely blamed on the fragmentation of the mainline network under privatisation, the prospect of a similar breakup of control of London Underground has been a key factor in laying the ground for the shift in the government's thinking.

The appointment of the internationally respected Mr Kiley, the breadth of opposition to the partial selloff across the political spectrum, the threat of legal action and industrial disruption in the run-up to a general election also helped to convince the government to change course.

Mr Livingstone hailed the agreement as a "victory for Londoners after months of deadlock" and went out of his way to praise the efforts made by Mr Prescott - as opposed to the Treasury, which has been criticised by Mr Kiley for its role in the negotiations - to shift the government line.

The shadow transport minister, Bernard Jenkin, said the deal between Mr Prescott and Mr Kiley amounted to a "crushing" defeat for the deputy prime minister, who had been forced to admit his plans were "deeply flawed".

Mr Kiley, the man credited with turning round the New York subway, will submit his revised plans for a public-sector controlled modernisation of the tube by the end of the month. If they are accepted by the government, the existing private consortia will be invited to bid for new contracts.

The likelihood is now that those contracts will not involve the breakup of the tube, nor the 30-year handover of stations, track and signalling to private compa nies envisaged under the government's scheme - if so, the "modifications" will be seen as marking a significant retreat in its wider part-privatisation programme for the public services.

Mr Kiley said there were still points of difference between himself and the government, but those differences were "narrowing".

Mr Prescott's department emphasised that there had been compromise on both sides, but the deputy prime minister left open the possibility that Mr Kiley's changes to the part-privatisation scheme might still be rejected, while praising Mr Kiley's "strong management team" and emphasising that they would be "working closely" together to "enhance" the existing plans.

The transport minister, Lord Macdonald, insisted that the government had "ruled nothing out and nothing in", adding that "unified management is a very big issue and that is a question we will be mulling over in the next few weeks".

The agreement was welcomed by business organisations in London. Peter Bishop, acting chief executive of the London chamber of commerce, said that Mr Kiley was "clearly a man the government can do business with".

"He will have to operate the system once the new arrangements are in place and it would have been untenable to proceed if he were not convinced they are workable."

London Underground chairman and managing director, Derek Smith, described the deal as a "platform to move forward" after a funding structure that had been "hit and miss" for most of the last four decades.

The agreement means that Mr Kiley, who has described the government's partial selloff plan as "fatally flawed", will finally have full access to all commercial details of the existing contracts and will take control of negotiations with the private consortia bidding to modernise the tube.

Some of the companies involved in bidding for the existing multi-billion pound contracts yesterday privately expressed anger at the government's last-minute change of heart - the contracts were supposed to have been finalised by the end of last month - but a spokeswoman for Mr Prescott said that the decision would not have "come as the most massive surprise" to them.
