webTitle: Review: Take Me to the River, by Al Green with Davin Seay

fields.headline: You can call me Al
fields.standfirst: Soul man, preacher man -  Ian Sansom explores the many sides of Al Green in Take Me to the River, by Al Green with Davin Seay
fields.trailText: Soul man, preacher man - Ian Sansom explores the many sides of Al Green in Take Me to the River, by Al Green with Davin Seay
fields.body:
Take Me to the River
Al Green, with Davin Seay
Payback, £14.99, 343pp
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Reading the rock biography, one might argue, is probably the closest most of us come these days to reading the Greek myths. Indeed, in her recent, brilliant and completely bonkers book I'm a Man , the poet Ruth Padel makes that very claim, in mind-blown prose: "It was ultimately Greek mythic ideals of relationship, quest, triumph and danger, of exploring self through impersonating other people, which powered this sci-fi mix of ancient and primitive, male and female, ultra-sophisticated electronics and crazed rawness, violence and darkness, all this theatrical dream of being male, in our time."

Padel has a lot of interesting things to say about rock and gods, but almost nothing to say about rock and the good old-fashioned monotheistic God to whom many of the great rock and pop musicians of the 20th century paid lip-service. Al Green's extraordinary testimonial, Take Me to the River , puts God the Father back at centre stage: "God has prepared Al Green for such a day as this, when I will lift my voice like the prophets of old to reveal His glory."

The Reverend Al Green can be found serving God's glory these days at his church in Memphis, Tennessee, and also in his appearances in Ally McBeal , which he graces white-suited and with full gospel choir to serenade the eponymous heroine in her gradual descent into lip-syncing madness. But there was a period in the early 1970s, with "Tired of Being Alone", "Let's Stay Together", "I'm Still in Love With You", "Call Me (Come Back Home)" and "Here I Am (Come and Take Me)", when Green was serving the Lord with some of the sweetest soul music ever to come out of the American south.

Born into a sharecropping family in Arkansas in 1946, one of 10 children, Green started his singing career in church with his father and brothers as the Greene (sic) Brothers. After the family made the move north to Michigan and his father had thrown him out for playing Jackie Wilson's "A Woman, A Lover, A Friend" too often and too loudly, Green formed the Creations with Curtis Rogers and Palmer Jones, and they had their first and only hit as Al Greene and the Soul Mates in 1967 with "Back Up Train".

It wasn't until Green went solo and teamed up with the legendary Willie Mitchell - band leader, producer and impresario - that he discovered his own unique style. Mitchell recognised what Green calls a "surrendering feeling" in his voice, and encouraged him to write his own material. What distinguishes both Green's delivery and his lyric writing to this day is its beguiling lack of force: there's no shouting, nor any of that horrible soothing that you get in a lot of soul and R&B. It's not sentimental; it's genuinely sad. Of all the great soul voices, Green's perhaps expresses the greatest vulnerability. It's a voice seeking recognition.

At first, there came no response. Green Is Blues , Green's first solo album, was released in the summer of 1969, but the first three singles from the album were a flop. Singles from the next album, Al Green Gets Next to You , didn't fare much better. The breakthrough came with the solid, chugging "Can't Get Next to You", and then, with increasing degrees of subtlety, "Tired of Being Alone", "Let's Stay Together" and "Love and Happiness". This early Hi Records sound isn't Stax, Motown or Atlantic - it's much smoother, with the drums high in the mix and the famous brothers Hodges creating the perfect rich complement to Green's apparent soft-spoken simplicity. You never get the feeling that he's having to fight the band. It's all obbligato .

And also a winning of formula rather than just a winning formula: where Percy Sledge had gone before, trailblazing in 1966 with "When a Man Loves a Woman", the first big R&B/pop crossover, Green followed, but in his own way and with a sound that appealed to black and white alike. With the release in 1974 of his seventh album, Al Green Explores Your Mind , Green looked set to consolidate his success. He was, as he says, "in the groove". He was also enjoying the considerable privileges - of every kind - to which a man of his celebrity feels entitled. "Did I sin and then sin again," Green asks, "with no thought to the consequences or the great and sure judgment I was bringing down upon myself?" You bet he did.

Then in October 1974 everything changed. As legend and The Virgin Encyclopedia of R&B and Soul has it, "Following an argument, his girlfriend, Mary Woodson, burst in while the singer was taking a bath and poured boiling grits over his back . . . a scarred and shaken Green vowed to devote more time to God." Green's version in Take Me to the River runs rather differently. Mary Woodson wasn't his girlfriend: she was one of several. And he wasn't in the bath: he was brushing his teeth. And he'd already been devoting more time to God since being born again and starting to speak in tongues in a hotel room in Anaheim, California, back in 1973. Whatever the details, the consequences are pretty much the same. Green sustained third- degree burns, and Woodson shot herself. If anything, Green now achieved an even greater, diabolical fame. The hits kept coming - "L-O-V-E (Love)" and "Full of Fire", both in 1975 - but something had come apart.

In Take Me to the River Green attempts to pick up the pieces. "Introducing the real Al Green," he says, "is like introducing three different people, each one with his own point of view and each one with his own side of the story. And more often than not, they're all fighting with each other." These three Al Greens are, for reference, "Al Green, the Last Great Soul Man; Al Green, the Country Preacher with the common touch; and Al Green, the family man". The book is remarkable not for its candour or clarity, but because of these deep confusions, because it depicts a divided mind and tells the story of Green's seeking a wholeness that is not there to be had. This is also, one suspects, why people still listen to his songs. And incidentally, in case you were worrying, it's probably why you watch Ally McBeal .

Buy it at a discount at BOL

John Wilmot, Second Earl of Rochester (1647-1680), was a leading figure in the gang of wasters who fed off the degenerate Restoration court of Charles II. Among his roles were those of poet, satirical wit, drinker, naval hero, duellist, kidnapper, philanderer, brothel-haunter, patron of the theatre, pornographer and public nuisance. Adored, banished, recalled, reviled, he died at home in bed, blind and in torment, of syphilis, aged 33. A deathbed convert to the Christianity he had formerly despised, he lived too soon to benefit from Pangloss's reflection that without syphilis we should never have had chocolate, though he might have seen the joke.

Rochester was not a prolific or consistent poet. He could be fierce in defending the amateur's gift: "Five Hundred Verses, every Morning writ,/ Proves you noe more a Poet, than a Wit". His own poems show a fragmentary brilliance, and his fame has as much to do with his conduct as with his work, but even in a period whose major poetic figures include his friend the metaphysical poet, Andrew Marvell, and the ultimate literary professional, Dryden (with whom he quarrelled), Rochester's poems and letters stake a continuing claim to our attention. This is partly a matter of his complete disregard for decorum: his satire is based at least as much in personal loathing as in moral vision.

"A Ramble in St James's Park" opens: "Much wine had passed with grave discourse/ Of who fucks who and who does worse", and describes a pleasure zone whose surplus of fallen semen meant that "Rowes of Mandrakes tall did rise/ Whose lewd Topps Fuckt the very Skies". If this were Rochester's only note, he wouldn't detain us. But his fleshy polymorphous relish, his sense that everyone's at it like knives with"Signior Dildo" and anything or anyone else they can get hold of, is combined with anger and hatred, often of women, and underlain by terror. "Lampoone" identifies the society names who carry "A Fate, which no man can oppose,/ The losse of his heart and the fall of his Nose". Nonetheless, he declared, in a translation from Ovid, "Such sweet, dear, tempting Devills, Women are".

So it was all their fault, as usual, for making him do it. Rochester's attitudes are hard to take but he tells it as he sees it, and gives access to a world becoming incoherent. As in Jacobean tragedy, sexual licence and cruelty are symptoms of a wider disorder, which he construes philosophically (via Hobbes) as well as sexually, and with an undecorated power which owes more to the verse of Ben Jonson than to his immediate contemporaries.

In his most famous poem, "A Satire on Mankind", inspired by Juvenal, Rochester attempts to think himself clear of the cast of mind that sought teleological explanations of human conduct and purpose through the application of reason to the alleged mysteries of the cosmos. Man, "Stumbling from thought to thought, falls headlong down,/ Into doubts boundless Sea, where like to drown/ Books bear him up awhile, and make him try,/ To swim with bladders of philosophy". There is nothing to discover, he contends, merely the senses to satisfy.

Rochester anticipates Augustan balance and epigram here, but the rhetoric serves a rage that - necessarily - lacks an anchor of value and belief. He has nothing to speak on behalf of except himself. His loyalties were to the charming and improvident King, "who never said a foolish thing/ Nor ever did a wise one", and his own political interventions in the House of Lords were intermittent at best. He was more inclined to write to his wife than to visit her, leaving her in the clutches of his grimly puritan mother while he got on with drinking, whoring and dying. Although his love for his children was genuine, it too was distant.

The poems are correspondingly claustrophobic, their vaunting aristo "realism" confined to a world whose possibilities are so shrunken as to make oblivion preferable. The wonderful translation from Seneca's Troas actually seems to draw sustenance from the prospect of nothingness: "Dead, we become the Lumber of the World/ And to that mass of matter shall be swept,/ Where things destroy'd, with things unborn, are kept". His abrasive energy is at times reminiscent of Donne, as in the great exercise in paradox, "Upon Nothing". In moments such as this we see the poet Rochester might have been: "Nothing thou elder brother ev'n to Shade/ Thou hadst a being ere the world was made/ And (well fixt) art alone of ending unafraid".

It is unfair to speak ill of the dead, though such considerations would not have stopped Rochester. The late Cephas Goldsworthy QC, who died with this book in the press, has not been well served by his publishers. The Satyr scarcely seems to have been read, never mind edited. It is clearly a labour of love, but it is diffuse and repetitive. It sheds little light on the poems, and with neither index nor illustrations is clearly overpriced. The most interesting passages, guaranteed instructively to darken anybody's day, provide an account of syphilis and of its treatment with hot tubs and mercury in specially adapted whorehouses. The horror of the once-implacable disease is easily matched by the futile pains undergone by sufferers in pursuit of relief, which goes some way to account for Rochester's ire.

Rochester provides a hectic portrait of a world whose futile indulgence has much in common with today's celebrity circuit, but the primary force of the poetry is felt at the intersection of talent, fury and the frenzied attempt to make something out of seeming nothingness. And he should appeal to a nation of boozers such as Britain. "On drinking a Bowl" might have been written for a falling rock star: "Cupid and Bacchus, my Saints are,/ May drink, and Love, still reign,/ With Wine, I wash away my cares,/ And then to Cunt again."

The Deregulated Muse , Sean O'Brien's collection of essays on contemporary poetry, is published by Bloodaxe Books.

fields.headline: GMC bans Alder Hey pathologist
fields.standfirst: Special report: Alder Hey hospital
fields.trailText: Dick van Velzen, the pathologist at the centre of the Alder Hey organs scandal, was yesterday banned from practising in Britain as the general medical council suspended him from the medical register.
fields.body:
Dick van Velzen, the pathologist at the centre of the Alder Hey organs scandal, was yesterday banned from practising in Britain as the general medical council suspended him from the medical register.

New disciplinary powers to impose interim suspension pending further investigations were invoked during a three-hour emergency meeting in London, which was closed to the public.

Professor van Velzen, 52, who is to be dismissed by the Dutch hospital that now employs him, did not appear at the hearing, despite being invited to attend, nor was he represented by a solicitor.

The council's five-member interim order committee said the suspension would continue until final decisions were made on charges against Prof van Velzen, although the decision would be reviewed in six months. The GMC's professional conduct committee is expected to consider whether to strike him off as quickly as possible .

Ed Bradley, acting chairman of the Alder Hey families' support group Pity II, said he would have preferred yesterday's decision to have been more final. "I expected him to be struck off and I am surprised he has only been suspended. This gives him a chance to appeal and even if he is struck off, he can apply in future to be reinstated."

Mr Bradley said other people named in the inquiry report this week ought to face disciplinary action. "We still maintain that van Velzen was made something of a scapegoat."

Prof van Velzen, in charge of pathology at Alder Hey between 1988 and 1995 before taking a job in Nova Scotia, Canada, has not been seen since Monday night when he went into hiding the night before a damning report accused him of "systematically, illegally and unethically" stripping organs from the bodies of thousands of children.

Michael Redfern QC, who headed the independent inquiry behind the report, had concluded Prof van Velzen "must never be allowed to practise again" after finding he lied when applying for the job of senior pathologist at Alder Hey children's hospital in Liverpool and falsified records and postmortem reports.

Prof van Velzen, who may face criminal charges for the way he built up a collection of organs, is facing a trial in Canada over charges of illegally possessing children's and animals' organs.

The Medisch Centruuk Haaglanden hospital in the Hague, where Prof van Velzen is now working, has said his contract will be terminated.

fields.headline: Teenager given wrong drug dies
fields.trailText: Two doctors could face manslaughter charges after the death yesterday of a teenager from a powerful anti-cancer drug that was wrongly injected into his spine.
fields.body:
Two doctors could face manslaughter charges after the death yesterday of a teenager from a powerful anti-cancer drug that was wrongly injected into his spine.

The parents of Wayne Jowett, 18, announced his death in a statement released through their lawyers. His father, also called Wayne, and his mother Stella said: "Our son Wayne Matthew Jowett died today at the University hospital in Nottingham where he had been seriously ill after doctors mistakenly injected an anti-cancer drug into his spine instead of into a vein. We now wish to be left to grieve in peace."

Wayne, an apprentice heavy goods vehicle mechanic, had been receiving treatment for leukaemia at the Queen's medical centre in Nottingham. On January 4 doctors injected vincristine into his spine.

An attempt to "wash out" the drug failed and until yesterday Wayne, who was in a coma, was being kept alive on a life support machine.

The mistake happens because another drug, methotrexate, which is used at the same time, is meant to be injected into the spine. Doctors mix up the two although the packaging and data sheet for vincristine warn that it is fatal if injected into the spine.

The case is the 14th in which the blunder has been made in Britain since 1985. Ten of the previous 13 cases were fatal, and the other victims were paralysed. Paul Balen, the family's solicitor, said: "My clients have been appalled to learn that so many other families have suffered as a result of similar mistakes."

The medical centre suspended two junior doctors after the incident and an investigation was launched. A police investigation is continuing.

John MacDonald, chief executive of the Queen's medical centre, said: "We have failed Wayne and his family and for that we are deeply sorry."

Four doctors have previously been prosecuted for manslaughter for the same mistake. Two were convicted but their convictions quashed on appeal. In 1999 two doctors at Great Ormond Street hospital in London were due to stand trial at the Old Bailey but the prosecution offered no evidence after concluding that the real cause was a catalogue of "chance events and failings" at the hospital.

Wayne Jowett's death comes the day after an inquest into the death of a 23-year-old Northamptonshire woman who died after a doctor in Leicester made a similar mistake. Donna Horn, who had also been receiving treatment for leukaemia, was injected in the spine with vincristine by Peter Greally. She had been paralysed from the neck down since the blunder in 1990 and died after developing a chest infection aggravated by her paralysis.

Dr Greally apologised at the inquest on Wednesday for "a genuine mistake from a lapse in concentration". Recording a verdict of accidental death, the coroner, Anne Pember, said: "It seems the only ay to avoid human error is to make it impossible to attach these syringes to a lumbar puncture needle [a needle used for spinal injections]. I implore the medical profession to pursue as a matter of urgency the obtaining of an alternative syringe to avoid such a repetition."

webTitle: The unusual suspects: Dumas; Floch-Prigent; Deviers-Joncour

fields.headline: The unusual suspects: Minister, mistress and oil chief
fields.trailText:
Roland Dumas
Loik le Floch-Prigent
Christine Deviers-Joncour
fields.body:
Roland Dumas

Was one of Mitterrand's closest and oldest friends, a brilliant and charming barrister. Twice foreign minister and recently president of the constitutional council, France's highest legal body.

Accused in court of benefiting from Elf's largesse, Dumas, 78, raged: 'One day I'll take care of certain judges in this country. Then you'll see what happens.'

Loik le Floch-Prigent

President of Elf Aquitaine from 1989 to 1993. Once one of France's best-known civil-service high-flyers, he claims he is a scapegoat for the French state's 'subtle game', and that all he did was in accordance with a deal worked out with Mitterrand. He did, however, manage to charge his company credit card for £6,800-worth of CDs in an afternoon.

Christine Deviers-Joncour

Was employed by Sirven in a largely non-existent job at Elf, allegedly on the recommendation of Dumas, her lover.

A twice-married 53-year-old former lingerie model, she is the author of a book that tells her side of the story. It is called The Whore of the Republic.

She long ago turned on Dumas, and said in court this week that she had been given so much cash by Elf to court the then foreign minister that "I believe I had no idea of the value of money".

fields.headline: The White Swan, Pickering
fields.trailText: Voted Hotel of the Year 2000 by the Yorkshire Tourist Board, it has only 12 bedrooms, so the atmosphere is intimate and relaxed.
fields.body:
Address: Market Place, Pickering, Ryedale, North Yorkshire Y018 7AA.

Tel: 01751 472288.

Web address: www.white-swan.co.uk

First impressions: A 16th-century former cottage and coaching inn that was once used by smugglers moving salt from Whitby via Saltersgate to York. Voted Hotel of the Year 2000 by the Yorkshire Tourist Board, it has only 12 bedrooms, so the atmosphere is intimate and relaxed.

What are the rooms like? They are all individually designed, some are more spacious than others, and most offer stunning views of Pickering and the surrounding countryside. Our room was huge with plenty of space for a lively 18-month-old toddler to play in. Surprisingly quiet, despite being in the centre of Pickering. The television was cleverly concealed in a little cupboard.

The bed test: An antique bed that was just right - not too hard or soft - for a good night's sleep. The travel cot was comfortable, too.

The bathroom test: Compact but with shower and large bath. A champagne bucket doubles as a waste bin.

The restaurant: Gourmet menu served in comfortable surroundings, and with a vast selection of wines. The chocolate cake was the most delicious I have ever tasted.

The lounge: Comfortable sofas and an open fire. Plenty of reading material.

What is there to see within walking distance? Pickering Castle is just around the corner. As is the North Yorks Moors railway.

What is there to see within a 20-minute drive? The North Yorkshire Moors; Goathland, where the TV series Heartbeat is filmed; and Whitby, with its Gothic ruined abbey and plethora of fish and chip shops, is only 19 miles away.

How much a night? £100 per room per night,with full English breakfast and newspaper.

fields.headline: Tuscan Steak, London
fields.standfirst: Rarely has Matthew Fort so suffered for his art than at Tuscan Steak. And they still had the cheek to charge an arm and a leg, too
fields.trailText: Rarely has Matthew Fort so suffered for his art than at Tuscan Steak. And they still had the cheek to charge an arm and a leg, too.
fields.body:
If only some restaurant conceptualists gave the same amount of thought to their restaurants as they do to their lavatories, eating out would be a vastly more entertaining and enjoyable experience.

Tuscan Steak is the second dining experience to be had at American wunder hotel showman Ian Schrager's newish gaff, St Martin's Lane. I reviewed the other, Asia di Cuba, some months back with a mixture of wonderment (at the prices) and pleasure (at the Philippe Starck froufrou folie de thétre design and the fact that the food wasn't as bad as I had expected). You might think that I was tempting fate to come back for a second bite at the St Martin's cherry, as it were. Indeed, it was tempting fate. And, do you know, fate just couldn't resist.

Back to the lavvies for a moment. I'm not sure about the ladies, but the gents was a pleasure to visit - suave, smooth, soothing to the eye, and seductively utilitarian, a wonderful example of the unity of form and function. The dining room, meanwhile, certainly had the function part sorted, but is sadly lacking in the suave, smooth, soothing and pleasing to the eye business. It had more of the stripped-down sternness of the canteen of one of our more successful architectural practices about it - which, I suppose, makes a kind of sense by way of contrast with the camp froth of Asia di Cuba.

The thing about canteens, however, as I understand them, is that the food is subsidised for the benefit of the consumers. Tuscan Steak seems to operate on the opposite principle. This may be because the workers lunching there that day seemed to have been taken exclusively from the stripped-down, modish Stakhavonites of advertising and associated meejah. Whatever the reason, it was the first time that I, or indeed Porthos, Aramis or Athos - all of whom have degrees with honours in eating - had ever seen steak on the menu at £65 a helping. As Athos said, "You can buy a cow for that in Wales." Come to that, it's also a long time since I came across a wine list with no wines for less than £20, aside from those in the wine-by-the-glass section.

As we were digesting the financial implications of the £65 steak, our charming waiter - who bore an uncanny and disturbing resemblance to the young AA Gill, a man of Dorian Gray-like youthfulness himself and the restaurant and TV critic of the Sunday Times - explained that the servings were intended for one and a half people, were served in the order that the kitchen thought that they were ready and that we shouldn't order too much.

As Porthos is the size of one and half men, this instruction caused a raised eyebrow. It raised rather more than that as we struggled to order. Did you ever have to do those questions in maths exams that went along the lines of: "If eight men can dig a trench five metres long by three metres wide by two metres deep in two hours, how long will it take six and a half men to dig one eight metres long by two metres wide by four deep?" Well, that's child's play compared to working out how to divide one and a half among four - or four and a half, to count Porthos properly. Or should it be two? Or how about one? That is assuming, of course, that one and a half people want to eat the same dish. Which we didn't. Have you ever heard of anything so richly, ripely, transparently bonkers? It will lead to broken friendships and blood on the carpet, mark my words.

Rather than fall out over anything so silly, we did what every right-thinking person would do under the circumstances, and ordered for ourselves. So we ended up with, to start, the "Tuscan Steak antipasto plate", Friuli basil soup, Parma ham with figs and marinated silver anchovies, linguini with white clam sauce, and then the cheaper of the two T-bones on offer (sadly, the £65 blockbuster - "American USDA Prime" - was not available because they hadn't yet been licensed to import it, or so the AA Gill doppelgänger told us), a veal chop with porcini and Marsala sauce, grilled fillet steak with a Gorgonzola topping and "Tuscan house salad".

This sequence comprises a restaurant reviewer's dream. To list the inadequacies of each dish would take up all of this week's space, and next week's as well. The antipasti were Arctic from the chiller cabinet and reminded me irresistibly of the buffet section during Italian Week at the Grand Hotel, Leeds, circa 1970. It included salami of that iridescent pink favoured by the Germans, rather than the more natural, darker burgundy of, say, Milanese salami. The soup appeared to have been made with industrial stock. The linguini had that dry, dense, rubbery quality that comes from reheating. The inclusion of anchovies with the prosciutto produced one of the most memorably mismatched combinations that I have ever encountered. The fillet steak was tough, which is something of an achievement, and came capped with a thatch the same colour, consistency and flavour as Astroturf. The house salad featured many of the ingredients in the antipasto plate, but with the addition of limp green bits.

The two marginally acceptable dishes in terms of edibility were the steak (Aberdeen Angus, hung for 28 days, said the menu) and the veal chop. Neither exactly lit up the universe, and what little charm they did possess was rather dished by the extravagance of their pricing - £40 in the case of the steak, £22.50 for the veal - and by the fact that the steak was almost gelid in its lack of heat. We had a rocket salad and a helping of spinach, too.

The injunction not to over-order proved absolutely correct - but not on the grounds originally suggested. We simply couldn't face finishing most of the dishes in the interests of sanity. We drank two bottles of red wine, which came to a total of £60, some water and a coffee apiece. The bill was £253, including service. I'll leave you to guess what I thought of that.

The portion control is cock-eyed, condescending and appears to have been devised to cause maximum confusion to would-be diners. The food is a kind of dumb show version of Italian food, with the emphasis on the dumb. The quality of the food preparation was desultory to the point of constituting dereliction of duty. The pricing is so predatory as to amount to brigandage. It's difficult to know what the point of Tuscan Steak actually is, except to part people from their money as expeditiously as possible.

fields.headline: Spring awakening
fields.standfirst: Life is stirring outdoors and it's the perfect time to switch on to bulbs, says Christopher Lloyd
fields.trailText: Life is stirring outdoors and it's the perfect time to switch on to bulbs, says Christopher Lloyd
fields.body:
February is a most encouraging month. The days are lengthening by leaps and bounds and the garden is visibly coming to life. Small bulbs are a major theme. Have we enough of them? If you visit the Royal Horticultural Society (RHS) show in Westminster on Tuesday, February 13, you'll be bowled over by the assortment and choice on offer. Shouldn't your garden be joining in the bonanza?

It is doubtless full of bare spaces, but they need assessing. First big question: what happens in those spaces during the summer? Shall I be wanting to dig in them, thereby disturbing my bulbs, when they should be allowed tranquillity and the chance to colonise where they are? Are they going to be visually in the way? Daffodils with large leaves become a menace once they have flowered, and will remain an eyesore until June. But the little ones, close to a species such as Narcissus cyclamineus or N. bulbocodium or even our own native Lent lily, N. pseudonarcissus , are no problem. Their leaves are small and narrow enough to be quickly absorbed.

But what about those perennials I do not want to disturb for many years at a stretch - eryngiums, for instance, and Japanese anemones? They cry out for inter- or over-planting. I like lightweight narcissi - those that are classified as triandrus hybrids, for example - among my clumps of day lilies (hemerocallis). As the perennials grow up, their own strap leaves totally mask the bulbs.

Deciduous shrubs have bare ground around them that is full of light, until their own foliage unfolds. To give the bulbs a little headroom, I may cut some of the lowest branches of Weigela florida 'Florida Variegata', for instance, away. That leaves room for sweet-scented violets, Viola odorata , for the hardy Cyclamen neapolitanum , whose marbled foliage makes such fine patterns from autumn to spring, and for primroses. I especially enjoy pale yellow primroses with the dwarf yellow trumpet daffodil, 'T te-à-T te'. This is a chunky little number with no pedigree to flaunt, but so cheerful and willing and a great multiplier. It is early, too; the first blooms should be out by now.

Beneath rooty trees is a difficult place to colonise. Plants that will tolerate all that dry shade in the summer tend not to be really worth growing, anyway. And they would be a lot happier in the open. But early bulbs, out and growing while there is still moisture and light about, are ideal, especially if you spread an organic mulch over the surface in the autumn - leaf mould, well-rotted bark or mushroom compost (if its alkaline reaction won't upset anything).

Crocus tommasinianus , slender and mauve, opening to the sun all this month, is an ideal coloniser as it is such a good self-sower. I consistently fail with winter aconites, Eranthis hyemalis , but many gardeners find them as easy as falling off a log and they make ideal partners under a tree (a beech tree, even) for the crocus. They are also good among hostas. These self- sowers are especially rewarding, as they'll put themselves where you could never plant - right into the crown of a late-developing hosta, such as H. sieboldiana var. elegans , for example.

I am grateful to the many cranesbills, the hardy geraniums, that have a rambling habit but die back to a central crown in the autumn, leaving a lot of vacant space around them. In one of these I have a prosperous colony of the February-flowering Iris reticulata . The flowers of that are deep purple, and I thought they'd benefit from being enlivened with a paler, simultaneously flowering bulb, mixed in. So with them I have planted the little snowdrop 'Tiny'. It is a miniature form of the common Galanthus nivalis . I didn't want anything as muscular or competitive as 'Atkinsii' (of which I have a great deal). That would, anyway, have been flowering too early; it is one of the earliest. I have a great drift of it in a damp border that in summer is devoted to rodgersias, Euphorbia palustris and the herbaceous Aralia cachemirica .

I am thinking of places for snowdrops all the time. Among the crowns of deciduous ferns is one of the best spots. Any of the male ferns, dryopteris, are good, and even the evergreen shield ferns, polystichum. They do not greatly object to having their fronds cut away in the new year, just as the snowdrops are pushing through. We also plant snowdrops among hydrangeas and among the stems of the suckering shrub, Clerodendrum bungei , which flowers in late summer and autumn but is utterly stark in winter and spring. Another suckering shrub that is a good host for early bulbs is the tree poppy, Romneya coulteri , if you can grow it. I don't know why I am having so much difficulty. When it takes off, it can become quite aggressive, but you can treat it like a herbaceous perennial and cut it right to the ground in winter, leaving the field clear for all sorts of bulbs.

Early bulbs with small leaves are great among roses, if you are not neurotic about treating these as a monoculture. The scilla-like, blueand-white Chionodoxa luciliae , a self-sower, entirely filled a bed of HT roses in the garden of friends. They rated it a weed, but it kept coming back; personally, I don't mind that sort of weed at all. Dutch crocuses, at their best next month, love it under and among roses. True, their foliage is a bit of a mess later on, but then the roses are not yet worth looking at themselves. By the time they are, the crocuses will have gone

fields.headline: Snow conditions
fields.trailText: Some fresh snow for Austria and France over the past few days has improved conditions although most of the Alpine region will enjoy some sun ...
fields.byline: Liz Russel, The Ski Club of Great Britain
fields.body:
Some fresh snow for Austria and France over the past few days has improved conditions although most of the Alpine region will enjoy some sun and clear skies over the next few days. Up to 30cm of new snow fell across Utah and Colorado.

Austria
After several weeks of little fresh snow, Kitzbuhel (**), St Anton (***) and Obergurgl (****) have had up to 15cm.

France
Light snowfall mid week at high altitude has refreshed the pistes, particularly in Val Thorens (****), Val d'Isère (****) and Argentière (****).

Switzerland
Excellent ski and board conditions exist in St Moritz (****), Zermatt (****) and Saas Fee (****). Grindelwald (***) and Murren (***) have both had a dusting of fresh snow.

Italy
Cortina (***) has great conditions although the lower slopes are a little hard packed in places. Livigno (****) has some excellent conditions. All lifts are open.

Andorra
There has been a large amount of new snow across Andorra, and more is forecast. But the bad weather has led to the closure of many of the lifts above the mid station in Soldeu (****).

North America
Utah and Colorado have finally had a huge dump of new snow which should give powder conditions for the next couple of days. Aspen (****) has had up to 30cm of new snow and Snowbird (****) in Utah has had up to 25cm. In Canada, the Banff Ski Area (***) is still waiting for new snow. Fernie (***) has received a light dusting of new snow recently, but it has been very windy and therefore much of the snow has drifted.

Key to conditions: No asterisks = a serious lack of snow - no lifts open.
* = poor snow conditions, very few lifts open.
** = conditions reasonable, some slopes in poor condition.
*** = plenty of good skiing.
**** = good conditions.
***** = fantastic on and off piste.

For the latest snow conditions in more than 250 resorts, check out www.skiclub.co.uk

webTitle: Writ says Kilshaws abducted net twins

fields.headline: Writ says Kilshaws abducted net twins
fields.trailText: The couple in the internet adoption row has been ordered to appear before a United States court to answer a claim they abducted the children.
fields.body:
The couple in the internet adoption row has been ordered to appear before a United States court to answer a claim they abducted the children.

Judith and Alan Kilshaw were served with a writ by lawyers for Richard and Vickie Allen, the Californians who had the twin baby girls for two months before the Kilshaws paid £8,200 for them.

The two couples came face to face on the Oprah Winfrey show in Chicago earlier this week - Mrs Kilshaw being as outspoken as ever. Afterward the Kilshaws were served with a writ, saying they had abducted the twins and deceived British and American officials to take them to north Wales, and ordering the Kilshaws to appear in a court in Arkansas. They had planned to stay in the US for more television appearances. Apparently horrified, they indicated they would contest the writ.

The affair began when the Allens handed the twins, obtained through an adoption broker, Tina Johnson, to their mother, Tranda Wecker, for a visit. The mother gave them to the broker, who handed them to the Kilshaws. The Allens' lawyer said he was confident the Kilshaws' adoption was void, due to them not being resident in Arkansas.

Yesterday at a private hearing at Birmingham high court, a judge ruled the twins stay in care of Flintshire county council for the present.

fields.headline: 1m Britons own second homes
fields.standfirst: Better mortgage deals fuel rise in demand for an extra property
fields.trailText: Better mortgage deals fuel rise in demand for an extra property.
fields.body:
Britain is becoming a nation of second home owners, with more than a million people owning another property for holidays or as an investment.

Better mortgage deals and a healthy economy have brought what was once a luxury purchase for the rich within reach of more households, according to the Council for Mortgage Lenders, the trade body representing banks and building societies.

Two thirds of buyers rent out their second home, while the rest use it as a holiday house or a long-term investment.

"Flats and terraced houses in highly desirable city and town centres, such as London, Edinburgh and Bristol, are being bought up effectively as a long-term pension fund," the CML said.

Second home ownership has risen from 250,000 10 years ago to 1.139m today - representing 5.6% of the population.

"Buying a second home usually requires a higher than average income, but it is no longer the preserve of the rich," said the CML's deputy director general, Peter Williams.

The increase is due partly to looser borrowing requirements. Mortgage lenders used to require hefty deposits for second homes but are now encouraging those with spare cash to consider property as an investment.

Competition in the mortgage market had forced lenders to relax their rules, said Peter Mounty, head of communications at Cheltenham and Gloucester.

They were "taking a more liberal approach to how people choose to spend their own money", he said. "The relaxation in the way industry views second homes has fuelled the rise in demand."

But the trend is pushing up prices in popular locations. Well-established holiday destinations such as Cornwall and Devon have already seen prices soar, so buyers are searching for cheaper seaside towns.

In Weymouth the estate agent Tony Gregson has seen an explosion in interest by second home buyers in the past 18 months. The new marina in the centre of town is the lure for many. "We have buyers who have a £500,000 boat in the harbour and are looking for a flat close by," he said.

A two-bedroom flat in a converted warehouse by the harbour fetches £200,000 - expensive by local standards but a snip for buyers used to stratospheric London prices.

Poor summer weather has attracted British buyers to warm spots throughout southern Europe, while the strong pound and cut-price air fares have made foreign property more affordable.

"The time to buy in Europe has probably never been better, with estate agents reporting large numbers of Britons seeking to buy cut-price second homes," the CML said.

"Wealthy Britons wanting to retire to the sun are heading to the Costa del Sol, rather than to Tuscany, Malta or the Algarve."

France, Italy, Spain and Portugal are the most popular locations for second homes abroad. Advertisements for houses for sale often refer to their proximity to Buzz, Go and EasyJet destinations.

Property in Europe is on average cheaper than in Britain. In France, the choice of most second home buyers, a rundown property in the north-east can go for as little as £25,000, according to the CML.

Mortgage lenders used to require hefty deposits for second homes but are now encouraging those with spare cash to consider property as an investment. Competition in the mortgage market had forced lenders to relax their rules, said Peter Mounty, head of communications at Cheltenham and Gloucester. They were "taking a more liberal approach to how people choose to spend their own money", he said. "The relaxation in the way industry views second homes has fuelled the rise in demand." But the trend is pushing up prices in popular locations. Well-established holiday destinations such as Cornwall and Devon have already seen prices soar, so buyers are searching for cheaper seaside towns. In Weymouth the estate agent Tony Gregson has seen an explosion in interest by second home buyers in the past 18 months. The new marina in the centre of town is the lure for many. "We have buyers who have a £500,000 boat in the harbour and are looking for a flat close by," he said. A two-bedroom flat in a converted warehouse by the harbour fetches £200,000 - expensive by local standards but a snip for buyers used to stratospheric London prices. Poor summer weather has attracted British buyers to warm spots throughout southern Europe, while the strong pound and cut-price air fares have made foreign property more affordable. "The time to buy in Europe has probably never been better, with estate agents reporting large numbers of Britons seeking to buy cut-price second homes," the CML said. "Wealthy Britons wanting to retire to the sun are heading to the Costa del Sol, rather than to Tuscany, Malta or the Algarve." France, Italy, Spain and Portugal are the most popular locations for second homes abroad. Advertisements for houses for sale often refer to their proximity to Buzz, Go and EasyJet destinations. Property in Europe is on average cheaper than in Britain. In France, the choice of most second home buyers, a rundown property in the north-east can go for as little as £25,000, according to the CML.

webTitle: Papers set the pace in euro debate

fields.headline: Papers set the pace in euro debate
fields.standfirst: Europe and the media
fields.trailText: There cannot, of course, be any linkage, but the departure for the wilderness and the lawyers of the cabinet's most pro pro-European, Peter Mandelson, was followed by a collapse in the popularity of the single currency.
fields.body:
There cannot, of course, be any linkage, but the departure for the wilderness and the lawyers of the cabinet's most pro pro-European, Peter Mandelson, was followed by a collapse in the popularity of the single currency.

Radio 4's Today programme carried a poll showing, as the Daily Mail cheerily reported, "that only a bare majority of Britons want to stay in the EU, while nearly a third want to pull out". And 71% of voters are opposed to the euro, with only 19% believing that Britain should "give up the pound".

The government has a lot of work to do before the referendum. But it remains quiet on the subject, while many commentators - and, it seems, fellow members of the government - detect the increasing influence of Gordon Brown, and find it irritating.

Rachel Sylvester, in her Daily Telegraph column, challenged the received wisdom by suggesting that the departure of Mr Mandelson actually strengthened the hand of the pro-euros.

The combination of his unpopularity and his enthusiasm for all things European was counterproductive to the euro case, she said. "He seemed determined to tweak the tail of the chancellor at every opportunity, creating an impression of cabinet splits at a time when the government was trying to promote membership of the EU."

Leave aside that there is precious little sign of such "promotion", particularly from the chancellor. Sylvester sees it differently. She quoted one "senior pro-European" as saying: "In the old days, whenever you mentioned the euro there might have been an understandable suspicion at the Treasury that this was all a great plot to get at Gordon. That's no longer true. We can now discuss the issue on its merits."

We shall see. It would certainly make a change and create a worthwhile debate. The signs this week were that at last some serious discussion is starting to take place, although it is newspapers rather than senior members of the government who are leading it. David Aaronovitch, in the Independent, considered the huge redundancies caused by Corus's announcement of plant closures and argued that being outside the eurozone was a key reason.

The outcry against Corus, led by Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary, failed to focus on this real problem. Aaronovitch recognised, as has this column repeatedly, that the anti-euros are the ones making the loudest and most confident noise.

"This is our fault," he said. "We Eurorealists cannot match the phobes' monomania. We are a bit namby-pamby. So let me make amends by talking with the same aggression that might be shown by a Bill Cash or Bill Hague. The main reason why we are losing thousands of steel jobs this year is because we are not in the euro. And every year that we are not in the euro we stand to lose thousands more."

The Mirror took the same line. Its leader was headlined, "Only euro will save our jobs". It went on: "The politicians and newspapers who have led the campaign against the euro are guilty of a cruel deception on the British people."

Elsewhere it was dinner. Dinner for Tony Blair in Berlin with Gerhard Schröder, the German chancellor. Dinner in Strasbourg for the French president, Jacques Chirac, and Mr Schröder. With relations between Paris and Berlin as poor as they have been in a long time, the Independent was proposing that Britain and Germany should "forge a new alliance to mould Europe's future".

Sadly the Berlin dinner backfired when it was reported that Mr Blair had told Mr Schröder Britain would eventually accept a common European tax policy. It was denied that this unlikely statement had been made. But it is likely to be exploited by the Eurosceptics.

The Strasbourg dinner went little better, reports said. According to the Telegraph, "neither President Chirac nor Chancellor Schröder could conceal the fact that they remained at loggerheads over how far and how fast to push European integration".

Peter Cole is professor of journalism at Sheffield University

fields.headline: Murdoch-backed e-tailer is sold off
fields.standfirst:
More net news
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The UK offshoot of e-tailer buy.com, part-owned by Rupert Murdoch, is to be sold to an unnamed buyer after failing to generate the sales investors had hoped for.
fields.body:
The UK offshoot of e-tailer buy.com, part-owned by Rupert Murdoch, is to be sold to an unnamed buyer after failing to generate the sales investors had hoped for.

The move, which is likely to cost many of its 90 British staff their jobs, is a further blow to the internet ambitions of News Corporation.

Mr Murdoch is one of the key investors in the UK arm of buy.com through eVentures, an investment unit he set up in partnership with Japanese dot.com investment specialist Softbank.

A spokesman for the British operation said a "letter of intent had been signed with a European entity".

Buy.com in the UK has been sacrificed as part of the parent company's accelerated drive to profitability.

"We are focusing on just one thing - getting to a positive cash position, and we're going to do it very aggressively," said chief executive Greg Hawkins.

Buy.com sells books, CDs and computer equipment at discounted prices but has found profits difficult to come by, reporting a loss of $27.4m in the last quarter.

It is to concentrate on its core business of selling computer hardware, software and consumer electronics in the US.

Buy.com is the latest internet retailer in the UK to suffer from declining sales after the collapse of letsbuyit.com, boo.com and boxman.com.

A year ago e-tailers were one of the hot investments, but they have seen their valuations slump dramatically after failing to generate the sales that their founders had forecast.

Softbank ventures has said that it remains fully committed to its two other UK investments - Riot-E, the wireless entertainment provider, and Ripcord Systems, the wireless enterprise solutions company.

fields.headline: Rank outsider
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: There is not much left of the once mighty conglomerate Rank.
fields.body:
There is not much left of the once mighty conglomerate Rank.

Under the guidance of chief executive Mike Smith, the company has embarked on a radical disposal programme selling its Odeon cinema chain, and its Butlins, Haven, Oasis and Warner holiday camps.

Rank would be even slimmer if Mr Smith had found a buyer willing to match the £473m valuation he put on the video and film processing operation, Deluxe. But in recent days traders have been hearing rumours that Mr Smith is plotting to take the company, which is centred on Mecca bingo and Grosvenor casinos, private.

Thanks to his disposal programme, group debt stands at £300m and the decision to keep Deluxe - the second largest contributor to profits - means Mr Smith has access to predictable cashflows that could be used to support a buyout.

webTitle: TV group surrenders share of Popstars loot

fields.headline: TV group surrenders share of Popstars loot
fields.standfirst:
Granada pulls out of deal over manufactured band's debut recording in fear of contravening strict programme code

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: TV producers have been forced to pull out of a lucrative deal that gave them a stake in the first-single success of the manufactured band featured in the hit show Popstars.
fields.body:
TV producers have been forced to pull out of a lucrative deal that gave them a stake in the first-single success of the manufactured band featured in the hit show Popstars.

The Granada media group, which is behind the ITV show, had hoped to pocket a share of the profits from the debut single, but there were fears that the deal would contravene the strict programme code laid down by the independent television commission.

The commission said yesterday that it was monitoring the series, which reaches a peak tonight, and said the programme-makers must not give "undue prominence" to the single.

But Granada will not lose out; a deal with the record company Polydor means that it will still benefit from a share of the profit from future single releases and the band's planned album, which would come after the end of the show's run.

Associated merchandising, such as dolls and books, will also prove lucrative for the television company.

LWT, the Granada Media subsidiary that is making Popstars, insisted it was taking great care not to break the rules. A spokesman said a single and merchandise were an "authentic part of the story", but said rules would be followed to the letter.

"Nothing will be given undue prominence. Nothing will be promoted or hyped. Honouring the code provision, we will ensure that any reference to a product is limited to what can clearly be justified by the editorial requirements of the programme."

Such is the success of the programme, which has documented the selection of a pop band from 3,000 largely tuneless hopefuls, that the band's first single is almost certain to be a No 1 hit. As well as gaining higher ratings than the last TV sensation, Big Brother, the show has received blanket press attention. The tabloids have carried daily stories about the participants, while serious-minded sections of the media have analysed the success of the format.

Viewers have become hooked on the cruel jibes of "nasty" Nigel Lythgoe, the LWT entertainment chief who has helped pick the final band.

ITV has met viewer demand by scheduling extra episodes of the show. Wednesday's edition drew more than 10m. Tonight the band line-up will be revealed over two episodes, at 6.45pm and 9.15pm, when viewers will see whether the sensitive Welshman Noel Sullivan, the extrovert northerner Kym Marsh and the ever-smiling Londoner Danny Foster make it to the final five.

In an unusual move, the press has not been tempted to name the final line-up, even though their identities have been known in media circles for some time. When the Sunday People broke ranks and pictured the line-up shortly after the show began, other newspapers apparently decided not to risk the wrath of readers.

The band, which according to internet gossip is called Inner Spin, flies back from a recording studio in Norway on Monday to face reporters at a Heathrow press conference.

fields.headline: At this price?  Pearson
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: A week ago, Marjorie Scardino and management developing Pearson's presence in the online education market took three hours out to demonstrate their business to the City's massed media community.
fields.body:
A week ago, Marjorie Scardino and management developing Pearson's presence in the online education market took three hours out to demonstrate their business to the City's massed media community.

The idea was to give some substance to what otherwise can seem to be an intangible subject. For a day it worked, breathing a little life into the company's shares which climbed 41p to £16.88. But then the gradual fall the share price has suffered since the peaks in the sector last March was back in place.

Given its exposure to the internet, Pearson, which also owns the Financial Times and Penguin Books, has performed relatively well. At peak its shares were worth just over £23.

That is in part explained by the high regard the management of the company is held in. Ms Scardino, in particular, is well thought of because of the large-scale restructuring she has wrought on the business.

The two areas where Pearson is heavily involved online, financial information and education, are also two key areas where the the internet is making an inexorable impact. Most investment banks rank the shares a hold.

The latest this week was UBS Warburg which has a 12-month target of £16.50 a share, suggesting little movement in the price over the coming year.

The City presentation may have convinced investors of the growth opportunity for online education - some of the applications are compelling. Where Pearson is unique is in its attempt to integrate content, data, testing and connectivity through its acquisition of NCS, the software and schools testing group last year.

UBS at least seems unconvinced that it will have the market to itself. Neither is it certain that the people on the front line, the teachers and the parents will, adopt the technology as quickly as might be hoped. Difficult to disagree with the experts. Hold.

fields.headline: London's glory: see it while you can
fields.trailText: Whether a gift or a curse, never has the art of English compromise been expressed more boldly than in the glorious mongrel design of St Paul's Cathedral.
fields.body:
Whether a gift or a curse, never has the art of English compromise been expressed more boldly than in the glorious mongrel design of St Paul's Cathedral.

Wren's peerless dome rides serenely above high Baroque walls concealing the plan of a medieval Gothic cathedral.

Architect and client wrestled to produce London's greatest building. And it remains the pivot around which the City, the apotheosis of mongrel design, turns.

Now with the demolition of the dreary offices that have hemmed it in, the cathedral is suddenly on naked display, more eye-popping than a Wonderbra ad, more sensational than any aesthetic outrage by a Britpop artist.

Stripped of is post-war appendages St Paul's appears afresh, like some titanic architectural ocean liner come to berth among the computerised counting houses of the Square Mile. It dominates its surroundings as readily as it has done at any time in its 300-year life.

If you can, go to look at the extraordinary site soon - St Paul's will be hemmed in again, this time by new office blocks of a polite and deeply compromised banality; no better and no worse than the glum piles they replaced.

These new buildings have been designed by people among the supposed cream of contemporary British architects. Sir Michael Hopkins, designer of the new Portcullis House at Westminster, is among them. They should hang their heads in collective shame.

Come here in a few years time when the redevelopment of what is known as Paternoster Square is complete and Wren's masterpiece will be the lesser for this new intervention.

Yet it has been St Paul's destiny to ride majestically above tides of architectural mediocrity. After the Great Fire of 1666 Wren had hoped to rebuild the City of London along grand Renaissance lines. It would be a city of dramatic vistas, imposing piazzas and heroic boulevards. But London got back to business as usual and had little time for the finer points of urban planning.

And St Paul's rose above a rags and patches cityscape destroyed during the Blitz. A symbol of London's wartime defiance, the cathedral reaped the reward of London commerce when the war was over: it was girdled round with dismal new buildings. The office boom of the 1980s encouraged the redevelopment scheme that so enraptured Prince Charles and which led to a proposal to demolish these offices and replace them with cod-classical temples of City trading floors and shopping arcades.

Famous architects were called, some from the US, and set about the potential ruination of St Paul's. The developer, Mitsubishi, was embarrassed by the ensuing row: the scheme for massive classical buildings, tripped up mainly by mid-Atlantic architectural fancy dress, was finally rejected. Mitsubishi absorbed a heavy loss which continues to this day.

A compromise scheme steered by the veteran architect Sir William Whitfield was announced in the late 1990s. Bit by bit buildings of unbridled compromise are beginning to rise in the shadow of St Paul's. They promise to be at best politely boring, at worst flatulent.

But St Paul's will take the new development in its magisterial stride. Once again its great dome will sail above a sea of mediocrity.

· Jonathan Glancey is the Guardian's architecture critic.

webTitle: Writ says Kilshaws abducted net twins

fields.headline: Writ says Kilshaws abducted net twins
fields.standfirst: Special report: babies for sale
fields.trailText: The couple in the internet adoption row has been ordered to appear before a United States court to answer a claim they abducted the children.
fields.body:
The couple in the internet adoption row has been ordered to appear before a United States court to answer a claim they abducted the children.

Judith and Alan Kilshaw were served with a writ by lawyers for Richard and Vickie Allen, the Californians who had the twin baby girls for two months before the Kilshaws paid £8,200 for them.

The two couples came face to face on the Oprah Winfrey show in Chicago earlier this week - Mrs Kilshaw being as outspoken as ever. Afterward the Kilshaws were served with a writ, saying they had abducted the twins and deceived British and American officials to take them to north Wales, and ordering the Kilshaws to appear in a court in Arkansas. They had planned to stay in the US for more television appearances. Apparently horrified, they indicated they would contest the writ.

The affair began when the Allens handed the twins, obtained through an adoption broker, Tina Johnson, to their mother, Tranda Wecker, for a visit. The mother gave them to the broker, who handed them to the Kilshaws. The Allens' lawyer said he was confident the Kilshaws' adoption was void, due to them not being resident in Arkansas.

Yesterday at a private hearing at Birmingham high court, a judge ruled the twins stay in care of Flintshire county council for the present.

webTitle: Campbell told to tone down political attacks

fields.headline: Campbell told to tone down political attacks
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's press spokesman, has been warned by the head of the home civil service, Sir Richard Wilson, to tone down his party political attacks on the Conservative party.
fields.body:
Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's press spokesman, has been warned by the head of the home civil service, Sir Richard Wilson, to tone down his party political attacks on the Conservative party.

The reminder followed claims by Mr Campbell that Tory economic policy was an insult to Mickey Mouse, remarks he made at a briefing for political journalists this week. Sir Richard has told Mr Campbell to be especially careful in the run-up to a general election.

He was responding to a formal complaint about the remarks from the Tory MP Andrew Tyrie, who claimed Mr Campbell had breached the rules on civil service impartiality. Mr Tyrie, a member of the Commons public administration select committee, said last night that Sir Richard's admonishment of the press spokesman did not go far enough and effectively left him free to breach the rules again.

Conservative frontbenchers including the shadow Cabinet Office minister, Andrew Lansley, have called for Mr Campbell's dismissal.

Sir Richard said in his letter: "I attach a lot of importance to ensuring that the resources of the government are not used for party political purposes. What is, and is not, acceptable is sometimes a grey area where difficult distinctions have to be made, but rules still have to be observed."

Two years ago he told a select committee that Mr Campbell's contract allowed him to criticise other parties so long as he did not "attack them with bricks and bottles".

Sir Richard reminded Mr Tyrie that Mr Campbell would stand down from his job when a general election was called.

webTitle: FO seeks block on MI6 author's profits

fields.headline: FO seeks block on MI6 author's profits
fields.trailText: The government ratcheted up the pressure on MI6 renegade Richard Tomlinson last night when Treasury solicitors issued an injunction freezing profits from his memoirs.
fields.body:
The government ratcheted up the pressure on MI6 renegade Richard Tomlinson last night when Treasury solicitors issued an injunction freezing profits from his memoirs.

The royalties ban was secured three days after the first copies of The Big Breach arrived in Britain from Russia after attempts to ban them by the British authorities failed.

An FO briefing document said action was being taken against the former spy because he had breached government copyright and should not profit from his unauthorised disclosures.

"Tomlinson assigned copyright over 'any work written by me and relating to my employment by the crown in SIS (the secret intelligence service)' in a formal written agreement on February 18, 1997," the FO document said.

It dismissed Mr Tomlinson's claim that he had been made to sign the 1997 agreement under duress.

The FO document added: "We are not proposing to seek an injunction restraining publication of Tomlinson's book but the government is firmly of the view, however, that Tomlinson should not profit from his unauthorised disclosures. We are therefore seeking to deprive him of the proceeds of his breach of confidence. Copyright is copyright: the principle is the same. There is no difference between the crown's case in asserting its ownership in this case and any other non-intelligence related instance."

Attempts were made by the British authorities to stop publication of Mr Tomlinson's disclosures in a series of extracts in the Sunday Times. But last week the court of appeal ruled that once the book was in the public domain, it could be made available in the UK.

The internet firm 192.com imported more than 1,000 copies of the memoirs, printed by an unknown Russian publishing house, and offered them for sale in Britain this week claiming to be "defenders of the right to freedom of information".

Mr Tomlinson, who worked for MI6 between 1991 to 1995, was jailed in 1997 for breaching the Official Secrets Act and now lives in Italy. It is believed he has received a £28,000 advance for his memoirs.

fields.headline: Saying no to good advice
fields.standfirst: If you can't smoke, take drugs, drink and fornicate when you're young, when can you? Things will never slide off you so easily again
fields.trailText: If you can't smoke, take drugs, drink and fornicate when you're young, when can you? Things will never slide off you so easily again
fields.body:
Oops! Teenage smoking is up again. Ditto teenage drug-taking, teenage drinking, teenage obesity, teenage abortions and teenage motherhood. Once again, we come top of the European pops in all these things. But we've got our downside, too. As I'm not a killjoy, or someone who had a boring teenage and, therefore, envies kids today all these things, I am obviously not complaining about this state of affairs. If you can't smoke, take drugs, drink, eat tasty, fattening food and fornicate when you're young, when can you do it? Things will never slide off you so easily again, like scribbles off a child's Magic Slate; far better a juvenile delinquent than a senile swinger.

But I do believe that these statistics are interesting in that they demonstrate the absolutely shameful waste of resources that is government propaganda, which is, of course, funded by the taxpayer. Perhaps some people respond to being bossed around - I was going to say that our German cousins, sadly, spring to mind, but their rate of teenage Aids and heroin addiction is far higher than ours, so there you go. Nobody likes it - but obviously the British aren't one of them.

How much has been spent on stating the bleeding obvious by various health departments over the past 30 years? Billions? Trillions? It's obviously not working. Is it ever going to stop? Funny, we're always told that "throwing money at a problem is never the answer", but how do successive governments deal with the fact that their ingrate populations seem to be intent on living fast, dying young and having extremely fat corpses? Why, by spending yet another £5m of our money on hiring a bunch of advertising airheads to think up ways to tell us not to drink, smoke or take drugs.

Might this government therefore consider a brief moratorium on public health education, as it so obviously isn't working? And might they also consider throwing just a fraction of the money they throw at Touche, Snort & Grabbit Partners at real alternatives to smoking, drinking and hanging around McDonald's? For instance, I know for a fact that teenagers love hanging around swimming pools, both indoor and outdoor. Swimming is a lovely way to keep fit, and you can't smoke, drink or eat while you're doing it. Yet local councils all around the country have, for the past 30 years, been closing down swimming pools and - especially - lidos with a zeal that borders on the obsessive. Brighton & Hove council seems particularly bent on abolishing any rogue patch of water whatsoever, and after years of lidocide have even closed down the huge, glorious paddling pool by the West Pier, where generations of harassed women have kept the kiddies occupied for a blessed hour. This followed close on the heels of the crushing of the artisans' market just the other side of the pier.

You can't help thinking that they're part and parcel of the same unholy crusade: to split up the entire Brighton seafront between the three big leisure corporations currently eating the town alive. Anything that doesn't turn a profit for these monsters - be it an artisans' market or a paddling pool - is now closed down as a point of principle. And all the pools, skating rinks and bingo halls - places where people have gone for decades to have good, cheap, healthy fun - end up as bars, restaurants and cinemas, where the good people of these islands can then proceed to eat, drink and goggle themselves into an early grave.

In short, just a fraction of the billions that have been spent telling people not to do things could have been better spent providing distractions from eating, drinking, drugging and couch-potatoing. But no - that wouldn't create the right kind of jobs. It would only create jobs for working-class people, providing real, life-enhancing services to other working-class people - rather than jobs in public-health departments and advertising agencies for the thousands of useless graduates who swarm out of the universities every year having been told by the government that any education is good education.

It's a long way from healthy eating to concentration camps, but I can't help feeling that Blair's Holocaust Day is a similarly misguided bit of bossiness. I remember finding out about What Happened In Germany when I was 10, through reading about it almost accidentally one summer afternoon in my dad's World At War magazines, and it still remains the most vivid and indelible memory of my whole life. The Holocaust is such a huge, ongoing trauma for the human race, so hard for any of us to understand and live with, that to have just one special day for it, as though it was National Prune Day or Take Your Child To Work Day, seems wildly inappropriate and gimmicky. Some things are best remembered in private.

And while we're on the subject, let's remember that Hitler's Germans were an extremely sporty people, who did follow government guidelines on health and efficiency to the letter - proving once and for all what junk that "a healthy mind in a healthy body" stuff is. Paradoxically (or do I mean ironically?), it is that very strand of human perversity that says, "DON'T TELL ME WHAT TO DO, POLITICIAN" - be that about eating cheeseburgers or remembering the Shoah - which remains the best guarantee of all that stuff never happening again. Just say no to good advice. You know it makes sense.

Just as the Telegraph letters page will invariably soon feature some sweet old buffer who has seen the first crocus of the year, so the Guardian letters page on Tuesday featured the first well-meaning MEP of the year who had just seen his first legalised European brothel and had to share it with the rest of us. Unreconstructed feminist I may be, but whenever I hear any man suggest that prostitution can be anything other than a degrading, soul-destroying blight and should be made more socially acceptable, I have to smile nicely and say, "And would you like your wife to work as a paid whore, sir? Or your daughter?" Somehow, they don't see it quite the same way then. Other jobs may be unpleasant, but none of us would really be ashamed to say that one of our loved ones was a drains inspector, undertaker or toilet attendant. I venture that most of us would, however, shrink from revealing at parties that our children or relatives were prostitutes, no matter how clean and legal their brothel. This is because we instinctively realise that prostitution is vile and exploitative.

The Swedes, who tend to know a bit about sex, have the right idea; it is a crime to pay for sex anywhere, from anyone - but NOT to sell it. Let's try that instead, shall we? Oh, no - men wouldn't like it.

fields.headline: La belle France
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: Saturday, January 27, Ashby-de-la-Zouch
fields.body:
Saturday, January 27, Ashby-de-la-Zouch

It is Glenn's birthday on Friday. Yes, the lad will be 14. Mohammed, whose brother works for Midland Main-line, gave me two Eurostar vouchers to Paris last week saying, "You use 'em, Aidy. I daren't leave the country. I'm frit that immigration won't let me back in."

I said, "Mohammed, you were born in the Leicester Royal Infirmary maternity unit, you have a strong Leicester accent, you cried when Martin O'Neill left Leicester City Football Club. Nobody could possibly question your English nationality."

"Oh, yeh," said Mohammed cynically. "And who was the only kid to be stopped at Dover when we come back from that school trip to France?"

I cast my mind back to that heady day when I became a European. I will never forget my first sight of la belle France. As the ferry prepared to dock, Miss Elf gathered her class of 30 around her on the vomit-stained deck and said, "Mes petits enfants, regardez vous la belle France, la crème de la crème, de la Continent". (Or words to that effect, diary. My French is a little rusty, as I rarely have occasion to use it.)

We lost precious time in France because Barry Kent tried to leap from the ferry on to the harbour wall before the docking procedure was quite finished. He wasn't in the water long, but by the time the gendarmes had finished their paperwork, a couple of hours had been lost.

On the coach, Miss Elf announced that, due to Barry Kent's foolhardy leap, there would now be no time for the planned visit to the war graves cemetery (we were doing a class project on first world war poetry). A few of the more sentimental girls wept, I recall, though Pandora was not among them. "Instead," she said, "we will sample French bread and French coffee, and we will visit a market and observe the care with which the French choose their fruit and vegetables."

When I returned home late that night, my mother was waiting for me in the car park of Neil Armstrong comprehensive. As I stepped off the coach, I said to her, "Maman, I have seen and tasted paradise. You must throw away your Maxwell House and your Mothers Pride thin-sliced and embrace the baguette and café au lait." I can't recall her exact words of reply, but they were said with a snarl.

Anyway, diary, what I said to Mohammed was, "It was your own fault you got stopped by immigration at Dover - you were openly smoking a Disque Bleu fag and you were only 12 years old."

Sunday, January 28

My plan is to take Glenn to Paris for his birthday. It is to be a surprise, so my preparations must be made behind his back. Tonight, I washed and ironed his least gangsterish-looking clothes and hid them in my wardrobe. There is nothing I can do about his hair or the Buffy The Vampire tattoo he's now got on his wrist, but with luck it will be cold and he'll have to roll down his sleeves. I'm looking forward to showing him the Louvre - he's a very lucky boy; I was 26 before I saw that the Mona Lisa wasn't worth the wait in the queue.

Tuesday, January 30

I was checking and re-checking my travel necessities list tonight. Two Eurostar tickets, travellers' cheques, Nurofen, map of Paris, French/English dictionary, passports, umbrella. There was something missing. Then the realisation hit me like an orange thrown by a toddler in a supermarket trolley: GLENN DOES NOT HAVE A PASSPORT!

Wednesday, January 31

Pandora has refused to help fast-track a passport for Glenn. I phoned Keith Vaz MP, but there was nobody available to take my call.

Adrian Mole: The Cappuccino Years is on BBC1 (not Scotland) on Fridays at 9.30pm.

fields.headline: Do Jury service
fields.trailText: How to...
fields.body:
Jury service is a government-sponsored project for people without access to television to experience the excitement and interest of courtroom dramas. When you are called up for jury service, you have to go unless you can prove you are doing vital work. Amazingly, few people find their work so vital that they can't take a couple of weeks' paid holiday.

The most important part of jury service is the claim for expenses. This is enshrined in the Magna Carta and is the inalienable right of every freeborn Briton. The experience of being off work and actually claiming 'loss of earnings' is possibly the most satisfying part of the whole criminal justice system.

Once you arrive at the court, there's a wait before you can start sweeping the criminal filth off our streets. First of all, you have to be picked for a case from the pool of available jurors, many of whom appear to be exactly the sort of criminal filth of which the streets need cleaning.

Eventually, you get picked for a case and you file into the courtroom. Try not to whoop with excitement, as this is not the desired tone. The first person you'll notice is a shifty, feckless, degenerate. This is the judge. It's the smart-looking person in the suit and tie who's the criminal. (Barristers often call witnesses, who also wear suits and ties, but you are not allowed to find these people guilty, even though some of them are crying out for it.)

At this stage, you may feel the urge to find the criminal guilty, but you should wait to hear what he's done before you bang him up for 15 big ones. Sadly, you're unlikely to find out, because you'll have two of the finest minds in the country telling outrageous porkies. These are the barristers. Their job is to confuse everyone and everything but in a very impressive way.

The good thing about the jury 'retiring' is that there are no barristers in the jury room. Juries spend so long deliberating because they have to try and salvage the truth from all the barristers' whoppers.

Once you get into the jury room, everyone argues for 10 hours about whether they can smoke. Then they divide into the reasonable-doubters (he could have had that assault knife for whittling) and the no-smoke-without-firers (what was he doing there in the first place). Eventually, when the pressure for a cigarette is too intense, you reach a verdict.

On your way home, you wonder about two things: whether he really was guilty, and why you're being followed by a mob of angry relatives.

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Les Dennis
fields.trailText: Les Dennis, 46, was born in Liverpool. After school, he made a living by doing impressions in working men's clubs, before winning TV's New Faces and going on to appear on Russ Abbott's Madhouse, his own series, The Les Dennis Laughter Show, and hosting Family Fortunes since 1987. He has also acted in theatre, film and television. He is married to the actress Amanda Holden.

Growing too old to do things for myself.

John Lennon, only because I went to the same school. I loved his attitude to life.

Which living person do you most admire?

I don't have heroes: they let you down.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?

I worry unnecessarily.

Ruthlessness.

I vary my fantasies so I don't get bored.

I bite my fingernails, and then use them as toothpicks.

Labour.

Labour.
