webTitle: To rule, or not to rule

fields.headline: To rule, or not to rule
fields.standfirst: I often fantasise about being a constitutional monarch, thinking what great fun it would be. They get lovely houses and long holidays
fields.trailText: I often fantasise about being a constitutional monarch, thinking what great fun it would be. They get lovely houses and long holidays
fields.body:
I'm just back from a few days in Rome, where it was raining all the time. But the city was nevertheless resplendent, having spent what Britain spent on the Millennium Dome on cleaning its churches, monuments and public buildings to spectacular effect. If only we had had the sense and modesty to do the same.

Two news stories dominated the press during my stay. The first was mad-cow disease and an imminent EU ban on beef on the bone, which threatens one of Italy's most sacred culinary institutions - the T-bone Florentine steak. The ban has yet to come into effect, but the nation is already in mourning and feeling very sorry for itself. The other story was the death, at the age of 94, of Italy's last queen, Maria José, which has reopened a long-standing dispute about the future of the House of Savoy. The nation, if less so, is in mourning for her, too.

I have often fantasised about being a constitutional monarch, thinking what fun it would be. Monarchs get lovely houses, long holidays, and easy access to anybody or anything that interests them. They have to cut ribbons and pay state visits to other countries, which must sometimes be rather boring. But, provided they emulate the example of our own dear Queen and never express an opinion or say anything interesting, they are permitted to lead very pleasant, comfortable and protected lives, while earning popular admiration for their "sense of duty". However, there is nothing worse than being an ex-monarch, and especially than being an exiled monarch, as the pretenders to the Italian throne have been since the referendum of 1946, in which the people narrowly decided to replace their monarchy with a republic.

Maria José, a daughter of King Albert I of Belgium, reigned for only 27 days as the wife of King Umberto II following the abdication of his father, Victor Emmanuel III, who was widely held in contempt for having acted as a willing tool of Benito Mussolini. But there are even many anti-monarchists who believe that the republic went too far when, in its new constitution, it banned in perpetuity all male members of the royal house and their consorts from setting foot in their native land. As a lover of Italy, I agree with those members of the European Parliament who tried, unsuccessfully, a year or two ago to have them allowed back home on the grounds that keeping them out was a cruel and unusual punishment.

The ban was lifted on Maria José in the 80s after her husband died and she was therefore no longer a consort of anybody, but she paid only token visits to Italy because she preferred to stay in Switzerland with her children. It was there that, last Monday, her eldest son - another Victor Emmanuel, who thinks he should be king - held a press conference in the Savoy family villa in Geneva. His aim was to capitalise on national sadness at the death of his mother to press his family's case for being allowed home.

It was an opportune moment for this. In the first message ever sent by an Italian president to any member of the former royal house, President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi had sent a condolence telegram praising the late queen's dignity and reserve and "her sincere liberal inclinations". The prime minister, Giuliano Amato, said it was time for the ban to be lifted, provided Victor Emmanuel swore loyalty to the Italian Republic.

Unlike the family she married into, Maria José was reputed to be anti-fascist, and even sympathetic towards the communists. There are rumours that she actually voted against the monarchy in the referendum. This is highly improbable, especially as one of her daughters said this week that her greatest regret in life was that she had not been able to carry on reigning, which she liked. Still, the republic has decided, rightly or wrongly, that here was one royal person whose heart was in the right place, and she was certainly a gifted and independent-minded woman who played the piano very well.

But her son presented a pitiful spectacle at the press conference. He tried to be friendly, but became angry and depressed as the journalists poured salt into old wounds. Why had he not disowned Mussolini's racist laws? Why would he not swear loyalty to the republic? To the first he gave no answer; to the second he replied that, since he was a mere private citizen and not a public servant, there was no reason for him to swear loyalty to the state. It was 10.30 in the morning, and he polished off three glasses of white wine to calm his nerves. His mobile phone rang to the tune of the Italian national anthem, and he responded testily to the general surprise by saying that he had "more right than anybody to have it in my telephone". The problem is that being a king is such an agreeable position that even the remotest prospect of becoming one is well nigh impossible to give up.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: This is an organic column. Could you not tell just by looking? It's the same with wine - a non-organic specimen often looks no different from its organic relative, and can also taste much the same. Vintage Roots, the Berkshire-based organic merchant, claims one difference is that organic wine can give you a hangover-free existence. This is what they trumpeted before Christmas, and I must chide them for it (even though this week features their wines exclusively). It is alcohol that causes hangovers, and though organic wine must be made from grapes that are certified free of artificial fertilisers, herbicides, pesticides and fungicides, any infinitesimal residues of these - which, in my opinion, should be declared on every non-organic wine's label - are unlikely to give any normal brain a bad time unless taken in such horrendous quantities that the amount of alcohol ingested will see you in hell, anyway. Sulphur, which can cause an allergic reaction in asthmatics, is used by winemakers of all persuasions.
fields.body:
This is an organic column. Could you not tell just by looking? It's the same with wine - a non-organic specimen often looks no different from its organic relative, and can also taste much the same. Vintage Roots, the Berkshire-based organic merchant, claims one difference is that organic wine can give you a hangover-free existence. This is what they trumpeted before Christmas, and I must chide them for it (even though this week features their wines exclusively). It is alcohol that causes hangovers, and though organic wine must be made from grapes that are certified free of artificial fertilisers, herbicides, pesticides and fungicides, any infinitesimal residues of these - which, in my opinion, should be declared on every non-organic wine's label - are unlikely to give any normal brain a bad time unless taken in such horrendous quantities that the amount of alcohol ingested will see you in hell, anyway. Sulphur, which can cause an allergic reaction in asthmatics, is used by winemakers of all persuasions.

Overindulgence in La Folie Domaine de Soulie Vin de Pays Monts de la Grage 1997, say, will induce a headache in anyone, for it is a massive 16% of alcohol (reached naturally, of course; there is none of the Bordeaux sugar additions here via the so-called chaptalisation). This is a wine to approach judiciously, then, but not so the food required to rebuff its hearty rusticity. With a savoury vegetable stew, La Folie is a triumph. Carnivores will find all manner of offal dishes appropriate: kidneys, pig's trotters, andouillettes. This huge, aromatic raisiny/liquoricey/herby wine parades figs, cherries, blackcurrants and tannins. It costs £11.99 and rates 16 points out of 20.

Soulie des Joncs Domaine de Soulie St Chinian 1998 (£9.50, 17 points) has a touch more, for a touch less. It offers magnificent liveliness of herbs, figs and hedgerows, and they leap from the glass without needing to be searched for.

With Chateauneuf du Pape Pierre André 1995 (£15.99, 16.5 points), there is no need to search hard, either. It has sweetness but dryness, liquorice richness and subtle, finely evolved tannins. This is a very interesting C-d-P, and one that would repay cellaring for a few more years to get even classier.

Four terrific reds from Catalonia next. Penedes Syrah Col.leccio 1998 (£11.50, 16.5 points) has gorgeous, chewy fruit, stunning texture, great tannins. Penedes Tempranillo Col.leccio 1998 (£10.99, 17 points) is in a similar but richer vein, offering perfect ripeness of fruit and brilliance of tannins. Penedes Cabernet Sauvignon Col.leccio 1998 (£11.25, 17 points) is a wine to make any claret producer gag with delicious disbelief. First, there is tremendous natural alcohol, 14.6%. Second, there are marvellous tannins. Third, which is the sum of these two things, the wine is mouthwateringly balanced and challenging to the mind - all manner of nuances are to be unearthed in this bottle. Reserva Marti 1996 (£15.95, 17 points) is also a wine to set riddles that the enquiring palate will delight in solving. It is an astonishing blend of merlot, tempranillo, cabernet sauvignon, syrah and petite syrah.

White-wise, Vintage Roots has several interesting bottles. Sauvignon Blanc Domaine Bassac Vin de Pays des Cotes de Thongue 1999 (£5.15, 16.5 points) has lovely mineral vivacity and tanginess. Pinot Blanc André Stentz 1998 (£6.99, 16.5 points) has superb, musky richness and subtle melon/peach/ pear/lemon fruit. Penedes Chardonnay Col.leccio 1998 (16.5 points, £10.50 ) is an elegant statement of delicacy and poise.

Finally, two non-vintage cavas. Cava Brut 21 (£10.99, 16.5 points) has a degree of fruit, yet still finishes with delicacy. Can Vendrell Cava (£7.25, 17 points) is even tastier. Indeed, with its classic dry richness and hint of almonds, it is one of the world's greatest bubblies. It makes Krug appear like the overwrought artefact for rich imbeciles that it is.

You can acquire Vintage Roots' catalogue and place an order on 0800 980 4992 (www.vintageroots.co.uk). Minimum order is six bottles, delivery £4.95 (plus VAT). Five or more cases delivered free.

For the latest wine news, or to email Malcolm Gluck, visit www.superplonk.com.

fields.headline: Luvvie Cottage
fields.standfirst: We amuse ourselves by casting cabinet members in a Jane Austen panto
fields.trailText: Dulcie Domum: We amuse ourselves by casting cabinet members in a Jane Austen panto
fields.body:
Invited to supper by Jonathan, Roy and Fred at my old abode, formerly known as Vile but now (unofficially) Luvvie Cottage. Officially, it was always Chervil, but I notice the gate now bears a sign saying "Dog's Mercury". Wonder if this is some kind of tribute to the late Freddie. Am greeted with air-kisses by Jonathan and Roy, and a slightly more enthusiastic squeeze by Fred. Wonder if he still fancies me - if that's what it was.

"Why Dog's Mercury?" I enquire.

"Oh, that was Roy's idea," says Jonathan, with a bitchy glare. "He said Chervil Cottage was too twee. Herbs are so last season, apparently." Roy, muscular and glowering, pokes the fire. Fred catches my eye. There is an atmosphere.

"So how are things in town?" beams Fred. Assure him things are fine, and that the spectacle of my ex being hounded and hunted by his subsequent wife and child is v acceptable bloodsport. "You have such a postmodern family, Dulcie!" cries Jonathan. "Roy and I are so boring: just a devoted little old Darby and Joe."

Roy strokes his moustache and pouts. Supper is served - a divine feast, as usual. We amuse ourselves by casting past and present members of the cabinet in panto versions of Jane Austen. Tony Blair stars as Fanny Price in Mansfield Park with Peter Mandelson lazing in silk on the sofa as Lady Bertram and John Prescott as her devoted pug.

"And how do you like being back in your old cottage?" asks Fred. Assure him it's not mine any more - what with the atrium, the parterre, the deck, etc. It's sublime, a cut above my leaky old shed.

"I do adore it!" explodes Jonathan. An uneasy pause. "Strange, after all our hard work and now we've got it perfect, Roy decides he wants to up sticks and move."

Roy writhes. "I can't help it," he growls. "I'm a mutable sign. I must have change. You knew my Mercury was Square Uranus when you met me."

"We met in Earl's Court," recalls Jonathan. "And first it was, Oh God, I must have the sea, so he dragged me off to Brighton, and then it was, Oh God, we must have the Cotswolds, and now - now he's become obsessed with Clun - he wants to become his granny and go off and put a whacking great taproot down in Clun. Well, I've told him, I can't - I just can't face living in a four-letter word."

"My granny had a little black-and-white cottage by a stream," murmurs Roy. "We went there last weekend and it was for sale!"

"Totally derelict!" Jonathan rolls his eyes. "And three acres of rocks and brambles. I'm too old to start again. I'm going through the male menopause. It's murder. Now he wants to drag me off to a ruin in a wilderness!"

"What's the cottage called?" I enquire.

"Cwmffrwd," replies Roy tenderly.

"Well, that's certainly not twee," observes Fred.

"Not twee!" screams Jonathan. "It hasn't even got any vowels! You can't escape back into the past, Roy!"

"It wouldn't be the past," persists Roy. "You could open a restaurant like that one in Ludlow."

"Such a divine place!" admits Jonathan in a cadenza of enthusiasm. "One minute you're surrounded by wattle and daub, you step over the threshold, and instantly it's San Francisco! Chrome, sculptures, and they were so clever with their plaice and bananas!"

"You see?" begs Roy. "You could really get into it."

"No, no!" insists Jonathan. "I'll go, of course, because I have to. It'll break my heart to leave this place - but what do you care?"

"Excuse me, Dulcie," says Roy, and gets up and stalks off upstairs.

"He's gone off to read A Shropshire Lad again," whispers Jonathan. "And the irony is, he grew up in Surbiton. If AE Housman was alive today, they'd have pumped him full of Prozac and done us all a favour. Still, the die is cast. We're off. So the question is, Dulcie, would you like to buy your cottage back? Oh, do say yes! It's the one thing that would make me feel better - handing it back to you. It's going on the market for £250,000, but to you - £230,000. So what do you say? Fred'll go halves with you, if you like."

Fred raises an eyebrow quizzically. "A timeshare?" he murmurs. "No strings?"

Fred'll go halves with you, if you like." Fred raises an eyebrow quizzically. "A timeshare?" he murmurs. "No strings?"

fields.headline: Super natural
fields.standfirst: For Strenesse designer Gabriele Strehle, simplicity is the essence of style. And off the catwalk? As in fashion, so in life, finds Suzie Mackenzie
fields.trailText: For Strenesse designer Gabriele Strehle, simplicity is the essence of style. And off the catwalk? As in fashion, so in life, finds Suzie Mackenzie
fields.body:
Style, Jean Cocteau said, is a simple way of saying something complex. Like art, its essence is effortlessness, no matter how great the effort that goes into its making. There is a modesty at its core that does not seek attention for attention's sake. Maybe this is why so many people who search for style miss it. As if to want it is somehow not to get the point.

For 15 years, the German fashion designer Gabriele Strehle has been practising, modestly, quietly, the art of simple style - in her life and in her work. The pretty home that she shares with husband Gerd and daughter Clara is the perfect representation of this aesthetic. It is long, low and unpretentious, decorated with window boxes in spring - indistinguishable from the outside to the other artisanal houses that line Nördlingen's canal. Nothing betrays the effort that went into converting the house from essentially a 14th-century medieval cottage into a contemporary home. Inside, the feel is warm, homely, the antithesis of formal. As is Strehle herself, who will greet you in black leggings, big pullover and barefoot. Quiet-spoken yet outspoken. Though shy. "I have never been good at going out into the world."

For the first 10 years, her name was not attached to the label she designs, Strenesse. "No one knew it was me." But as she began to become more successful, people would increasingly ask, "Who is Strenesse?" And one day, at an international fashion show in Milan, she overheard someone say, Strenesse is a person who stays all the time behind. "And for me this was the biggest compliment. That I am an identity - consistent, whole, recognisable - but not pushing myself or my name." It is this reticence that characterises her clothes. Classic, pure lines, but with a modern informed style that appeals to women such as herself. Women of confidence and authority, who have reached a certain level of sophistication and who have nothing to prove. Fashion has nothing to do with mimicry, Strehle says. It is not a style created by a designer and copied and commercialised. "It is an expression of what we want to say about ourselves. 'I am at ease.' That is very hard to get right, and why I work so hard at making it perfect. Because if I can do it then women will come back."

She went into the business straight out of college, having studied not fashion but tailoring - a craft. Always a perfectionist. "I don't believe you can do anything without first learning how it is done."

In 1973, she was hired as one of a number of designers by a middle-range utility clothing company in Nördlingen, a small, robustly medieval town about an hour's drive north of Munich. The company was selling mainly raincoats to high-street outlets, but Gerd Strehle, who had inherited the factory from his father, wanted to develop something different. "Something modern, of our time. My father's business had been created after the war, when there was no money, no certainty." Within two years, he had given Gabriele her own line. "I was looking for somebody who could give the company an identity. A particular sort of sensibility that could find a balance between the modern and the classic. And that is Gabriele."

As the company grew, the Strehles took the decision not to move their headquarters out of the town to, say, Munich, or even Milan, but to stay close to their roots, and to Gerd's family. Though much of the manufacturing has to be done elsewhere, for reasons of production and distribution, all prototypes are produced in the Nördlingen factory. They like to think of it, too, as "family", which sounds corny until you realise that the only other major industry in Nördlingen is tourism, and that Strenesse is the town's biggest employer by far.

They also liked the connection with the town's history. In the middle ages, Nördlingen was a thriving trade centre, a crossroads at the heart of Europe. Many crafts flourished here. A tanning industry, metal work. There was also a massive brewery. Through its affluence, great burgher houses were built in its centre alongside smaller master craftsman houses - pretty half- timbered buildings. When choosing their own home in 1977, it was one of these that they bought. "You see that it is not a very rich person's house," Gerd says. "We were poor then." But of course everything had to be done perfectly. Walls were stripped out, or pushed back - part of the house abuts the old city wall. Light was let in, but the spaces created were true to the architectural character of the building. Where possible, they kept to original materials: terracotta tiles, wide planed-wood floors. "If you are false to what you start with then you lose all identity."

"The house feels intact," Gabriele says, "like a home." Their sort of home. No clutter, not much furniture. A few carefully chosen craft objects. The doors of each room are beautifully carved and painted, medieval doors with ornate iron hinges - a gift from the town in recognition of the employment they have created here. Upstairs, in the gable of the house, is their white sitting room - the carpet pure as freshly fallen snow, on which stands Gerd's ebony-black grand piano. It is only in their young daughter's room that you find any colour. "I am a person who is very black and white," Gabriele says. "Children have a need to be more eloquent."

It was having a child, quite late in life - she was 40 when Clara was born - that helped her to develop her philosophy. "I think both Gerd and I had been, up to that point, totally perfectionist, quite rigid, inflexible at home and at work." As their daughter grew up - she is now 10 - they recognised that things had to change. Clara needed her own space. "It's interesting with children. You see they need structure, but they also need freedom. Not complete freedom, but they have to have the two. But how to get this balance right is very difficult."

So Clara changed their personal life, but in many ways their working life also. "I remembered how my mother had brought us up: with clear lines to follow but in a very open way. We were expected to be correct with people, straight. Ego was discouraged. But our opinions were always our own. She educated us by bringing out our character."

You can adapt this philosophy to anything, she says - home, life, clothes. "Again you see it with children. How they dress is an expression of themselves as individuals and as part of a group. They are following in one way and they are separate in another. Their security comes with the expression of both. Now I take this as the basis of everything I do."

Security is a word she uses often. Clothes, she says, should give a sense of "personal security", not in the sense of being something you conceal yourself beneath. "Some labels do this, I know. They give identification, not identity, But this is not my sensibility." In the same way, home is security - somewhere you retreat to to be yourself. "Where whatever you do, you do it with feeling. When you cook, you cook with passion. Otherwise there is no pleasure."

She feels that time has caught up with her ideas. "This is a good time for me." The 80s were a strange period. Superficial, flamboyant. "But that cool, gourmet style - all presentation - gave way to something more natural." The influence of the Japanese aesthetic was important here. In Japan, as she says, everything is aestheticised. There is distance, discretion, a certain sparseness combined with a delicacy. "It is via Asia that we found our way back to something more natural, traditional." That is their art of living. Perfection. Whereas hers, as she says, has moved on. "Has become imperfectly perfect."

 Gabriele Strehle's clothes are available at Harrods and Selfridges.

fields.headline: The Knowledge
fields.standfirst: The honey trap
fields.trailText:
The subject
What bears like. What anything sweet is compared to. 'A supersaturated sugar solution out of which the glucose tends to crystallise' (technical brochure from www.nhb.org). And the focus of National Honey Week (www.honeyassociation.com) starting on Monday.
fields.body:
The subject
What bears like. What anything sweet is compared to. 'A supersaturated sugar solution out of which the glucose tends to crystallise' (technical brochure from www.nhb.org). And the focus of National Honey Week (www.honeyassociation.com) starting on Monday.

The basics
The Knowledge could bore you senseless with interesting facts about honey production, but will make do with just one: it would take a single bee three trips around the world to make 450g of honey. Finished marvelling? Let's wax prosaic. Honey table of contents: around 80% sugars, 18% water, 2% miscellaneous pollens, proteins, vitamins and minerals. Pollen: the reason honey tastes of more than sugar. Water: the reason honey is soft, whether a clear, free-flowing syrup (higher proportion of fructose) or a set, opaque block (glucose busily crystallising). Vitties etc: make some people think honey is 'good for you'.

The details
Don't talk about 'honey-coloured' or 'tasting like honey': there's more variety in both departments than Pooh ever imagined. Colour: off-white through dark amber. Flavour: light, sweet and flowery to astringent, sharp and bitter. Ready reckoner: darker colour correlates with stronger flavour. Buzzword in connoisseurship: monofloral honey, principally from a single type of flower. Monofloral marvel: honeys that taste distinctively of the source. Monofloral misery: honeys, some wickedly expensive, that are duller than a Jeffrey Archer novel. Artisanal production doth not necessarily make heavenly honey. When the Knowledge tasted honeys with Stephen Beaty of the Honey Association, he preferred the full, rounded flavour of a cheaper blended honey (China, Argentina, Mexico, etc) over some pricey monoflorals. Mr B[ee] commented, 'Expensive honey may not be better, but it may be what you want.'

The easy way out
Bzzzzzzz.

Where to buy
For busy bees: Beekeeping For Beginners, Penelope Hands, Kitchen Garden Press (01328 838468). For consumers: Tropical Forest Products (01970 832511), Heritage Honey (01842 878673), Garvin Honey Company (01993 775423).

fields.headline: Eyes Wide Open
fields.standfirst: Stanley Kubrick is remembered for some of the most remarkable films of the past 50 years - Lolita, 2001. Few realise that, even as a schoolboy, he was making his mark - moonlighting as a photo-journalist for Look magazine. Tom Dewe Matthews looks for signs of the grandeur that was to come in the early pictures, now on show in a rare exhibition in Edinburgh
fields.trailText: Stanley Kubrick is remembered for some of the most remarkable films of the past 50 years - Lolita, 2001. Few realise that, even as a schoolboy, he was making his mark - moonlighting as a photo-journalist for Look magazine. Tom Dewe Matthews looks for signs of the grandeur that was to come in the early pictures, now on show in a rare exhibition in Edinburgh
fields.body:
In the spring of 1945, a skinny, dark-haired 16-year-old boy is walking along 172nd Street in The Bronx. He's carrying an unwieldy Graflex camera given to him by his father as a birthday present two years before. So as not to alert potential subjects, this self- possessed teenager has taken the precaution of concealing the camera in a paper shopping bag, with the top open and a hole for the lens; this way he can shoot incognito. On the corner of Grand Concourse and 172nd, he spots an unfolding drama. A news vendor bends over a banner headline announcing the death of President Roosevelt. Quickly the boy raises his bag, frames the shot, focuses, and presses the shutter. For the first time, Stanley Kubrick has sensed a collective feeling and captured it in a single image. What's more, the next day he sells that image to a leading US magazine, Look.

Kubrick had visited the Look offices previously, but had been turned away because the editor's assistant thought he was a messenger. But that spring day in 1945, the Look editor, Lucy O'Brian, bought not only the Roosevelt picture, but all the other ones he brought with him. From then on, at an age when other boys were still at school - when he was still at school - the young Stanley covered more than 100 photo-stories for Look, the photo-monthly based in New York. He was allowed a remarkable degree of independence: often, he wasn't allotted a subject but chose his own stories. He travelled from one end of the country to the other on a huge range of assignments: light-hearted candid camerawork on juvenile dating habits, pseudo science projects such as How We Look To Monkeys, photo-reportage on an orphanage outside Chicago or a circus during a winter layoff in Sarasota, Florida, and an intimate photo-journal of the young Montgomery Clift living in Manhattan. Twenty years later, Kubrick said, "It was an invaluable experience. It taught me how things work in the real world."

It was also a way of operating that never left him. "Just as a cop always carries a gun, Stanley always made sure he had a camera on set," says Kubrick's first producer, James B Harris. Which gives an insight into how some of the most effective images of 20th-century cinema were created. Whether or not we've seen the movies, Kubrick has etched into our collective psyche the nymphet Lolita in her heart-shaped sunglasses, 2001's light-suffused spaceman, and Alex, the Clockwork Orange droog, with his jaunty bowler and single mascara'd eye. What makes these images indelible is that, although they all come from motion pictures, they are also emphatically static, frozen in time - for before Stanley Kubrick became a master of movies, he was first one of America's leading photographers.

Garrett Brown, best known as the inventor of the Steadicam camera that is now an indispensable part of any film shoot, worked with Kubrick on The Shining in 1978. It was, according to Kubrick's biographer Michael Herr, "a technological marriage made in heaven". Throughout the shoot, while Jack Nicholson hacked his way through doors and Shelley Duvall took repeated re-takes, Brown and Kubrick had endless conversations about the pursuit of what they called "the elusiveness of perfection". "What is important about Stanley is that his images were all his alone," recalls Brown, who now lives in Philadelphia. "All of us cameramen learn the rules of composition: the golden mean, the rule of thirds, and so on. Stanley had no time for that. That wasn't even in his universe. He made frames that were centred, but they were his own and, because they weren't orthodox compositions, that is one of the reasons why they are so powerful."

Unsurprisingly, since they were one-off shots produced for a magazine, Kubrick's early photo-journalism has, until now, very rarely been seen. But a German professor and Kubrick enthusiast, Rainer Crone, has curated an exhibition of the Look pictures which is currently on show in Edinburgh. He sees a direct link between Stanley's teenage work and his later career. "What Kubrick tried to do in his own unconventional way was to create a moving picture through his stills camera," says Crone. "Although he was very young, he did something entirely new in photography. He wasn't a social photographer like Walker Evans and he didn't try to catch the right moment like Cartier-Bresson. He told a story, but then he stopped it, he suspended it with his camera, and that's why I have called the show Still Moving Pictures."

Kubrick's own story began in The Bronx. His father was a doctor and hoped his son would follow in his footsteps. By Bronx standards, the family was prosperous. "They lived in a house," exclaims Kubrick's oldest living friend, Alexander Singer. "I didn't know anybody who lived in a house. We all lived in apartments."

Singer, now a robust 74-year-old, who has been living in California for more than 40 years, went to William Howard Taft High School with Kubrick. There, they both joined the photographic club. Stanley had been taught about photography from an early age by his father, and had another advantage over his friend: "It was almost unimaginable for kids like me," says Singer, "but Stanley had a darkroom at home. It took me a while to figure out how important this experience would be for him later on, when he became a master of light on a film set."

Kubrick also very soon became adept at pushing film to high speeds to exploit natural available light. He needed that edge because at the age of 17 he was competing with New York veterans. "The combination of his youth, technical skill and storytelling ability so early on was unbearable for photographers up to four times his age," says Singer. "Stanley had an omnivorous appetite for every form of learning, but neither of us had much appetite for the rigidity and narrowness of the learning at Taft."

Instead, both boys paid regular visits to the cinema at the Museum of Modern Art, where Kubrick watched the entire collection - twice. His favourite film was Eisenstein's rousing hymn to Russian statehood, Alexander Nevsky. Aside from closely studying Eisenstein's imagery and use of montage, Singer says, "Stanley never got over the Prokofiev score for the battle on the ice in that movie. He bought a record of it and played it over and over until his kid sister couldn't stand it and broke it over his head."

Contrasting his obsession with film and his truancy from school, Kubrick admitted in later years that his schooldays were dominated by fear - "fear of failing grades, fear of not staying with your class" - but he added, "Interest can produce learning on a scale compared to fear as a nuclear explosion to a firecracker." Working for Look was at the very least a training. What such news-photo magazines wanted during the late 40s and 50s was not so much portraits or single shots, but photo essays; and, as Crone points out, "Even then, there was a sense of unfolding drama in his pictures. In effect, he was learning how to direct his camera rather than merely taking a snapshot." Garrett Brown recalls: "What interested Stanley was the moment of freezing motion... In one sense a still photograph is a motion that has stopped. You freeze nature for that moment."

Kubrick's pictures began to look more and more like movie stills. In between his assignments, he composed his own stories, which looked as though they were real, had just happened to take place at that moment. In A Short Movie In A Movie Balcony, for example, a young couple appear to have just met in a cinema - but, Singer reveals, "That was set up. The boy was a friend of Stanley's from school and he cast the girl from another class."

And it wasn't just casting - which Kubrick would later say was "75% of a movie" - he also showed his determination to get the best possible performances out of his subjects by first telling the boy, "to make a move on the girl", then, without letting on, telling the girl, "When he goes too far, let him have it."

"He caught the slap low down with an infra-red flash," says Singer. "That kind of on-the-nose, direct, simple storytelling really paid off for Stanley, because those pictures had a structure. You wanted to know, 'What's going to happen next?'"

Singer, who would go with Kubrick to Hollywood in 1956 and later become a movie director himself, believes, "That little story has the essential quality of his films: the appearance of honesty, which is carefully arranged, the framing of the picture so that it has the authenticity of photo-journalism, and the lighting, which looks as though it comes from natural, available sources but which actually came from a flash. All of those techniques fell naturally to his hand. For all practical purposes, Stanley was fully formed at 17. The changes were a matter of degree."

With his continued absence from school, Kubrick gave up any chance of going to college. Not that he cared. He already had a career. He already knew what a mass audience wanted, and he had the means of giving it to them. By 1949, his pal Singer was working as an office boy for the March Of Time documentary news series - which was put out before the main feature in movie theatres. Why didn't Stanley contribute a little film to that, Singer suggested. After all, the money was good. But what to film?

Kubrick turned to his most ambitious piece of photo-journalism, Prizefighter, a seven-page spread - a sequence of 19 shots - he had done for Look about a day in the life of middleweight boxer Walter Cartier. For his eight-minute film, Kubrick cut almost immediately to the end of that day, to the fight. Even so, the film is still a joined-up version of the photo-story. Both share stark overhead neon lighting, which concentrates on the combatants, leaving everything outside the ring in semi-darkness. Both the still and moving versions have figures in the foreground to pull you into the picture. And both feature the low-angle shot that would become a Kubrick signature - although, in fact, the angle was forced on Kubrick by the weight of his Graflex (nearly 4kg), which dictated a shooting position seldom higher than the waist and more often almost on the floor.

Kubrick was later to boast that he did everything on this little film, including cleaning up afterwards, but he was actually helped by his old buddy, Singer, who worked as a general assistant. "It took eight weeks," says Singer. "We re-did and re-did everything. He took as much care with that movie as he did with 2001. He pulled out all the stops, and was learning very rapidly and applying everything that he had learned from his Look days - lighting, staging, positioning the camera. There was a visual acuity, a mind-eye connection that was already first-rate. I was looking over his shoulder, which, even then, I felt was a privileged position."

Kubrick sold Day Of The Fight for a mere $100 profit. He went on to make five short movies, including two fiction films, over the next three years. But it wasn't until 1954 when he met James B Harris - through Singer - and secured more solid financing for his films that his directorial career began to take off. Singer had himself been tempted to "buffalo" Harris into one of his own "idiot projects", but he gracefully stood aside for his lifelong friend. Returning the favour, Kubrick gave Singer an entrée into Hollywood the next year as associate producer on his first truly successful movie, The Killing. Singer, however, believes that any debt had actually been paid off by Kubrick five years earlier, "when he took my wedding photographs".

The introduction was the start of a promising partnership. Beginning with The Killing, through Paths Of Glory, Spartacus and Lolita, and ending with Dr Strangelove in 1964,Jimmy Harris would produce some of Kubrick's greatest movies. Nowadays, likeSinger, Harris lives in Los Angeles and is also a director. Indeed, back in 1965, it was Kubrick who helped Harris in his move away from production into direction.

By then a veteran director, Kubrick offered all sorts of suggestions to his erstwhile producer but, nearly four decades later, Harris remembers only one particular piece of advice: "It was a war film," he says. "I needed to do some research, and I didn't know what sort of camera would be best for taking black-and-white pictures on board an American destroyer. 'A 10 D,' Stanley fired back. 'It shoots half frames. It's made by Olympus.'"

 Stanley Kubrick: Still Moving Pictures, Photographs 1945-1950, is at Inverleith House, Royal Botanic Garden, Edinburgh, until April 1.
fields.bodyText: In the spring of 1945, a skinny, dark-haired 16-year-old boy is walking along 172nd Street in The Bronx. He's carrying an unwieldy Graflex camera given to him by his father as a birthday present two years before. So as not to alert potential subjects, this self- possessed teenager has taken the precaution of concealing the camera in a paper shopping bag, with the top open and a hole for the lens; this way he can shoot incognito. On the corner of Grand Concourse and 172nd, he spots an unfolding drama. A news vendor bends over a banner headline announcing the death of President Roosevelt. Quickly the boy raises his bag, frames the shot, focuses, and presses the shutter. For the first time, Stanley Kubrick has sensed a collective feeling and captured it in a single image. What's more, the next day he sells that image to a leading US magazine, Look. Kubrick had visited the Look offices previously, but had been turned away because the editor's assistant thought he was a messenger. But that spring day in 1945, the Look editor, Lucy O'Brian, bought not only the Roosevelt picture, but all the other ones he brought with him. From then on, at an age when other boys were still at school - when he was still at school - the young Stanley covered more than 100 photo-stories for Look, the photo-monthly based in New York. He was allowed a remarkable degree of independence: often, he wasn't allotted a subject but chose his own stories. He travelled from one end of the country to the other on a huge range of assignments: light-hearted candid camerawork on juvenile dating habits, pseudo science projects such as How We Look To Monkeys, photo-reportage on an orphanage outside Chicago or a circus during a winter layoff in Sarasota, Florida, and an intimate photo-journal of the young Montgomery Clift living in Manhattan. Twenty years later, Kubrick said, "It was an invaluable experience. It taught me how things work in the real world." It was also a way of operating that never left him. "Just as a cop always carries a gun, Stanley always made sure he had a camera on set," says Kubrick's first producer, James B Harris. Which gives an insight into how some of the most effective images of 20th-century cinema were created. Whether or not we've seen the movies, Kubrick has etched into our collective psyche the nymphet Lolita in her heart-shaped sunglasses, 2001's light-suffused spaceman, and Alex, the Clockwork Orange droog, with his jaunty bowler and single mascara'd eye. What makes these images indelible is that, although they all come from motion pictures, they are also emphatically static, frozen in time - for before Stanley Kubrick became a master of movies, he was first one of America's leading photographers. Garrett Brown, best known as the inventor of the Steadicam camera that is now an indispensable part of any film shoot, worked with Kubrick on The Shining in 1978. It was, according to Kubrick's biographer Michael Herr, "a technological marriage made in heaven". Throughout the shoot, while Jack Nicholson hacked his way through doors and Shelley Duvall took repeated re-takes, Brown and Kubrick had endless conversations about the pursuit of what they called "the elusiveness of perfection". "What is important about Stanley is that his images were all his alone," recalls Brown, who now lives in Philadelphia. "All of us cameramen learn the rules of composition: the golden mean, the rule of thirds, and so on. Stanley had no time for that. That wasn't even in his universe. He made frames that were centred, but they were his own and, because they weren't orthodox compositions, that is one of the reasons why they are so powerful." Unsurprisingly, since they were one-off shots produced for a magazine, Kubrick's early photo-journalism has, until now, very rarely been seen. But a German professor and Kubrick enthusiast, Rainer Crone, has curated an exhibition of the Look pictures which is currently on show in Edinburgh. He sees a direct link between Stanley's teenage work and his later career. "What Kubrick tried to do in his own unconventional way was to create a moving picture through his stills camera," says Crone. "Although he was very young, he did something entirely new in photography. He wasn't a social photographer like Walker Evans and he didn't try to catch the right moment like Cartier-Bresson. He told a story, but then he stopped it, he suspended it with his camera, and that's why I have called the show Still Moving Pictures." Kubrick's own story began in The Bronx. His father was a doctor and hoped his son would follow in his footsteps. By Bronx standards, the family was prosperous. "They lived in a house," exclaims Kubrick's oldest living friend, Alexander Singer. "I didn't know anybody who lived in a house. We all lived in apartments." Singer, now a robust 74-year-old, who has been living in California for more than 40 years, went to William Howard Taft High School with Kubrick. There, they both joined the photographic club. Stanley had been taught about photography from an early age by his father, and had another advantage over his friend: "It was almost unimaginable for kids like me," says Singer, "but Stanley had a darkroom at home. It took me a while to figure out how important this experience would be for him later on, when he became a master of light on a film set." Kubrick also very soon became adept at pushing film to high speeds to exploit natural available light. He needed that edge because at the age of 17 he was competing with New York veterans. "The combination of his youth, technical skill and storytelling ability so early on was unbearable for photographers up to four times his age," says Singer. "Stanley had an omnivorous appetite for every form of learning, but neither of us had much appetite for the rigidity and narrowness of the learning at Taft." Instead, both boys paid regular visits to the cinema at the Museum of Modern Art, where Kubrick watched the entire collection - twice. His favourite film was Eisenstein's rousing hymn to Russian statehood, Alexander Nevsky. Aside from closely studying Eisenstein's imagery and use of montage, Singer says, "Stanley never got over the Prokofiev score for the battle on the ice in that movie. He bought a record of it and played it over and over until his kid sister couldn't stand it and broke it over his head." Contrasting his obsession with film and his truancy from school, Kubrick admitted in later years that his schooldays were dominated by fear - "fear of failing grades, fear of not staying with your class" - but he added, "Interest can produce learning on a scale compared to fear as a nuclear explosion to a firecracker." Working for Look was at the very least a training. What such news-photo magazines wanted during the late 40s and 50s was not so much portraits or single shots, but photo essays; and, as Crone points out, "Even then, there was a sense of unfolding drama in his pictures. In effect, he was learning how to direct his camera rather than merely taking a snapshot." Garrett Brown recalls: "What interested Stanley was the moment of freezing motion... In one sense a still photograph is a motion that has stopped. You freeze nature for that moment." Kubrick's pictures began to look more and more like movie stills. In between his assignments, he composed his own stories, which looked as though they were real, had just happened to take place at that moment. In A Short Movie In A Movie Balcony, for example, a young couple appear to have just met in a cinema - but, Singer reveals, "That was set up. The boy was a friend of Stanley's from school and he cast the girl from another class." And it wasn't just casting - which Kubrick would later say was "75% of a movie" - he also showed his determination to get the best possible performances out of his subjects by first telling the boy, "to make a move on the girl", then, without letting on, telling the girl, "When he goes too far, let him have it." "He caught the slap low down with an infra-red flash," says Singer. "That kind of on-the-nose, direct, simple storytelling really paid off for Stanley, because those pictures had a structure. You wanted to know, 'What's going to happen next?'" Singer, who would go with Kubrick to Hollywood in 1956 and later become a movie director himself, believes, "That little story has the essential quality of his films: the appearance of honesty, which is carefully arranged, the framing of the picture so that it has the authenticity of photo-journalism, and the lighting, which looks as though it comes from natural, available sources but which actually came from a flash. All of those techniques fell naturally to his hand. For all practical purposes, Stanley was fully formed at 17. The changes were a matter of degree." With his continued absence from school, Kubrick gave up any chance of going to college. Not that he cared. He already had a career. He already knew what a mass audience wanted, and he had the means of giving it to them. By 1949, his pal Singer was working as an office boy for the March Of Time documentary news series - which was put out before the main feature in movie theatres. Why didn't Stanley contribute a little film to that, Singer suggested. After all, the money was good. But what to film? Kubrick turned to his most ambitious piece of photo-journalism, Prizefighter, a seven-page spread - a sequence of 19 shots - he had done for Look about a day in the life of middleweight boxer Walter Cartier. For his eight-minute film, Kubrick cut almost immediately to the end of that day, to the fight. Even so, the film is still a joined-up version of the photo-story. Both share stark overhead neon lighting, which concentrates on the combatants, leaving everything outside the ring in semi-darkness. Both the still and moving versions have figures in the foreground to pull you into the picture. And both feature the low-angle shot that would become a Kubrick signature - although, in fact, the angle was forced on Kubrick by the weight of his Graflex (nearly 4kg), which dictated a shooting position seldom higher than the waist and more often almost on the floor. Kubrick was later to boast that he did everything on this little film, including cleaning up afterwards, but he was actually helped by his old buddy, Singer, who worked as a general assistant. "It took eight weeks," says Singer. "We re-did and re-did everything. He took as much care with that movie as he did with 2001. He pulled out all the stops, and was learning very rapidly and applying everything that he had learned from his Look days - lighting, staging, positioning the camera. There was a visual acuity, a mind-eye connection that was already first-rate. I was looking over his shoulder, which, even then, I felt was a privileged position." Kubrick sold Day Of The Fight for a mere $100 profit. He went on to make five short movies, including two fiction films, over the next three years. But it wasn't until 1954 when he met James B Harris - through Singer - and secured more solid financing for his films that his directorial career began to take off. Singer had himself been tempted to "buffalo" Harris into one of his own "idiot projects", but he gracefully stood aside for his lifelong friend. Returning the favour, Kubrick gave Singer an entrée into Hollywood the next year as associate producer on his first truly successful movie, The Killing. Singer, however, believes that any debt had actually been paid off by Kubrick five years earlier, "when he took my wedding photographs". The introduction was the start of a promising partnership. Beginning with The Killing, through Paths Of Glory, Spartacus and Lolita, and ending with Dr Strangelove in 1964,Jimmy Harris would produce some of Kubrick's greatest movies. Nowadays, likeSinger, Harris lives in Los Angeles and is also a director. Indeed, back in 1965, it was Kubrick who helped Harris in his move away from production into direction. By then a veteran director, Kubrick offered all sorts of suggestions to his erstwhile producer but, nearly four decades later, Harris remembers only one particular piece of advice: "It was a war film," he says. "I needed to do some research, and I didn't know what sort of camera would be best for taking black-and-white pictures on board an American destroyer. 'A 10 D,' Stanley fired back. 'It shoots half frames. It's made by Olympus.'"  Stanley Kubrick: Still Moving Pictures, Photographs 1945-1950, is at Inverleith House, Royal Botanic Garden, Edinburgh, until April 1.

fields.headline: A Lifelong Liaison
fields.standfirst: In the golden era of European cinema, the names Ingmar Bergman and Liv Ullmann went hand in hand. He was the most revered film-maker of his generation. She was his muse, his star, his love. But though they separated, they would, she tells Simon Hattenstone, never be really apart. And now their roles are reversed. She is the feted director, and he is the subject of her latest film.
fields.trailText: In the golden era of European cinema, Ingmar Bergman was the most revered film-maker of his generation and Liv Ullmann was his muse, his star, his love. But though they separated, they would, she tells Simon Hattenstone, never be really apart. And now their roles are reversed.
fields.body:
A quarter of a century ago, Liv Ullmann wrote a haunting autobiography called Changing. The great Norwegian actress had recently parted from the great Swedish film-maker Ingmar Bergman, and she could feel middle age encroaching. She wanted to embrace it, but was drowning in her fears - was she a bad mother, had she sacrificed her daughter's well-being to her own ambition, what would happen when her breasts started to sag, when she was no longer a desirable commodity? The only constant she could see in the future was Bergman. Although they had separated, although there was no prospect of reconciliation, in one way or another she knew that she and Bergman would never be apart. "I was right - we never did leave each other," she says today. "You know, soon after we met, Ingmar told me he had a dream that we would be painfully connected."

We are sitting in a suite in a swanky Los Angeles hotel. It's such a strange place to meet her. Ullmann, the dour, heartbreaking actress who peeled off layer after layer until she revealed her raw, bleeding soul. If Bergman was the master of human misery, she was the canvas on which he painted. And here we are in LA, the home of have-a-nice-day fatuity, where the object of ageing is to remain unchanged, and the object of talking is not to communicate. If Bergman and Ullmann had a motto, it would probably be "Have a bad day".

Ullmann is now 62, Bergman 82. Both have continued to evolve in the 25 years since she wrote Changing. Ullmann no longer acts and is now an established director in her own right. Bergman no longer directs (his last film, Fanny & Alexander, won four Oscars in 1982) and is more reclusive than ever. Perhaps the relationship has been turned on its head. Ullmann has just directed Bergman's autobiographical screenplay, Faithless. But she has not just dutifully realised his vision. Instead, she has taken it, shaken it, rewritten it and created a film that might well turn out to be their greatest collaboration.

Most of today's fans of Hollywood blockbusters will not have heard of either of them. Indeed, many of Bergman's fans presume that he is dead. But in the 60s and early 70s, they were one of the world's most celebrated couples. She was his muse, his star, his love. He was her inspiration, her director, her love. This was the golden age of European cinema. Godard and Truffaut in France, Buñuel in Spain, Fassbinder in Germany, Antonioni in Italy, Tarkovsky in the Soviet Union and, of course, Bergman in Sweden. The golden age of cinema full stop. And Bergman was at the peak of his powers with a string of angst-soaked classics to his name - Wild Strawberries, The Virgin Spring, The Seventh Seal.

Those were the days when films were taken seriously. And no one's films were more serious than Bergman's. It was cinema as psychoanalysis. His movies didn't have plots, as such, let alone special effects. Yet they were gripping. They were stripped to the essence - long, brutally cropped close-ups of characters talking and talking about love and hate, guilt and God, hope and despair. Bergman showed, more powerfully than any film-maker, how people tear each other apart in the name of love. Somehow, he showed cinema at both its most humane and at its cruellest. And Ullmann, with her complex, ever-changing face, was his ideal actress - chaste, frigid, hungry, sensual, lumpen, elegant, tormented, beatific Ullmann. She had an extraordinary knack of showing contrary emotions at any one time. In Cries And Whispers, she orgasms through tears of anguish after her husband announces that he is leaving her; in Autumn Sonata, she plays a quiet, kindly daughter whose bitterness rages behind her selfless love.

Within seconds of meeting Ullmann, you realise why she was so pivotal to Bergman. She can't do small talk. She says that her head is so full of stuff these days that she is selective with her memories, and suddenly she's talking about how images define memory, and how smell is one of the strongest images, and how she's spent a lifetime trying to recapture the smell of childhood security. "My grandmother's neck smelled of safety. She was my best friend, and I used to sit on her lap when I was a little girl, and she'd tell me all these wonderful stories, and she always said the stones and the trees talked to us. If I fell asleep I would have this wonderful smell in her neck, and I would always search for this smell."

What was the smell? "Maybe just being old, but in a good way. Being old in a safe way. Being human, being understandable." For a while, she thought Bergman smelled of her grandmother, but... "he took the safety out of the smell, so it didn't smell like her any more." Years later, she discovered the smell again - on an old woman dying of leprosy whom she met while visiting refugees in Macau.

Ullmann was born in Tokyo to Norwegian parents. Childhood was blessed with securities, but ruptured by loss and fear. By the close of the second world war, both her father and grandfather had been killed. "My grandfather died in Dachau, but we are not Jewish. He was sent there because he had helped Jewish people escape from the town where he lived in Norway. Then they took 10 hostages instead, and he died there... the same time as his son, more or less."

How did her father die? "I was six, and we had been in Japan, then we went to Toronto, where there were many British and Norwegian pilots, and my father was a civil engineer. According to my mother, my father walked into the propeller of a plane. I didn't think you could survive that, but apparently he did for a year and then he died."

She tells her war stories dispassionately, as if she's talking about people she doesn't know. You sense she doesn't want to exploit a false emotion. Does she remember her father? "I only remember that he held my hand."

Ullmann grew up in a house of women - mother, grandmother, older sister. She was always an unwieldy mix: strong and fearful, oppressed and free-spirit. As a young girl, she deliberately scalded her foot so she could miss her hated cookery lesson at school. Between 11 and 15, when she was left alone at home in the evening, she would sleep in the bath with the door locked until her mother or sister returned. She says that she still longs for the bathroom and then corrects herself: "Not the bathroom, but for that tiny little space that is mine." Childhood was also the time of her greatest happiness. She talks about the times she would lift herself on to the handlebars and do a handstand on her bicycle, and says that she has never felt so liberated.

Ullmann is tired. She's just flown into LA, and she massages her head, irons out the creases. As she talks about how her Lutheran faith has strengthened over the years, a shadow passes behind me. "The man behind you, oh I think he's left again, he's Jewish." Who is he? "He's my husband. We divorced, but we are living together." She says it so matter of factly that I laugh. They got back together as soon as they divorced? "Yeah. I always seem to keep friends with the people after." Donald is from Boston, in his mid-60s and is big in property.

She says the split with Donald was initially acrimonious. "He divorced me, and I hoped I'd never see him again. But then I went on my plane back to Norway and he came on the plane and he said that no one else shall sit at your side. He came all the way to Norway and then took the plane back. I thought that was really romantic - I fall for those things very easily." So they got back together. They married in 1985 and divorced four years ago. "It was when I did Private Confessions." Private Confessions was the first Bergman script she directed.

When she first met Bergman, she was married to a psychiatrist and already an established actress in her 20s. Bergman cast her in Persona (1966), opposite Bibi Andersson, as an actress having a breakdown, tormented into silence. Andersson, who had had an affair with Bergman, warned her against the film-maker. Bergman was a serial star-fucker, who seemed to sleep with his actresses as a matter of course. He was nearing 50, had been married four times and had seven children. Ullmann and Bergman duly fell in love. She left her husband, moved in with him and they had a daughter, Linn.

The most revealing film Ullmann starred in is Scenes From A Marriage, made in 1973, a few years after they split up. Both of them denied that this devastating account of a break-up was autobiographical, but it's hard to believe. Ullmann is Marianne, the repressed, diffident wife of a scientist, played by Bergman regular Erland Josephson, who leaves her for another woman. At the beginning of the film, the couple, being interviewed, are asked to describe themselves. The husband says that he is successful, clever, quite brilliant actually, moral, decent, popular, responsible, considerate and an absolute wow in bed. Marianne struggles to think of anything to say. Eventually, she manages, "I am a mother." As so often with Bergman, it is an unsparing study of the neurotic loneliness of women and the savage egotism of men.

Faithless could easily be called Scenes From A Marriage 2. Again, it's about the collapse of a relationship. Again, the leading woman, brilliantly played by Lena Endre, is called Marianne. But the wheel has turned. While Ullmann directs, Bergman is now the barely fictionalised character, David Bergman (played by Josephson), looking back on his life as a film-maker, lover and home-wrecker. Like much of Bergman's work, it is also about the nature of art. Faithless tells the story of a film-maker trying to recapture the pain of his old love so that he can exploit it; so he can turn it into the movie we are watching. Ullmann has a lighter touch than Bergman - somehow, there's more humour to the tears - but she directs with all his spartan vigour. It's an astonishing achievement to make such relentless misery so compelling.

Do people expect her to be a misery-guts when they meet her? "Yes, always. But I am not miserable. At times, I can be sad, but I love to play, I love to laugh." She pauses, mulling something over. "I think I make people nervous at times." She tells me how the photographer Annie Leibovitz recently came to her Miami home and was unnerved by the way Ullmann looked her in the eye and listened to her so attentively. She left without a picture.

Perhaps her strength has been a weakness? She nods enthusiastically. "Oh, it is. All women know that we have to underplay strength at times, because men don't always like it." She says that she grew up at the same time as women's liberation, and her generation had two choices: "To be the way our mothers brought us up to be - you know, pleasant, nice - or to be who we wanted to be. My choice was to be pleasant and nice."

Did she downplay her success with Bergman? "No. Yes . A little. I would say to him, 'With other directors, I think of what you would have said to me', and sometimes I'd say that and it wasn't true, because I like working with a lot of directors."

It must have been tricky, when his success was so dependent on hers. "No, it wasn't... well, it was intertwined. Maybe he could have found somebody, maybe they wouldn't have been as gifted as I was then as an actress, but the chances are not so big. I know I couldn't have found a better director. But now I'm already into that Ingmar thing, that [deferring to] man thing, saying, 'I could not have been what I am without him'. If you've done that all your life, it's very difficult to get away from it."

Actually, she says, it's only with Faithless that she has overcome all that. "I managed to say, for the first time in my life, that I'm very proud of this film, I think I know how to do this, I think I'm professional. I've never said these things, and now I'm saying it a lot. Now, it's almost natural." And it feels good? "Oh, it feels fantastic."

Next day, we meet up in Palm Springs, where Ullmann is receiving the International Film-Makers Award. Palm Springs is 100 or so miles from Los Angeles. Hollywood stars retire here to play golf. Plastic surgery is compulsory. Ullmann is interviewed on stage before Faithless is screened. She is wearing a little black dress, a fabulous, multicoloured coat and looks beautiful; huge, blue eyes; soft, heavy lips; a smile both seductive and maternal. She makes no attempt to disguise her lined skin.

She appears so confident as she reveals how Bergman wrote the story of Faithless as a monologue and how she had to sculpt the characters out of that. "Ingmar didn't want anything to do with it. He didn't see it for two years until it was finished. He expected to see a rough cut, but I know he's very controlling, so when he did see it, I said, 'Sorry, this is the movie.' " One of her most important additions is the daughter, who becomes the emotional fulcrum of the movie. "That was not in Ingmar's script, and he really liked it - he said, 'Oh, why didn't I think of that?' But now he's forgotten that, because now he feels he thought of it."

In Scenes From A Marriage, we never saw Marianne's children. It was as if they didn't exist. And, for much of Bergman's life, his children haven't. He used to say, almost boast, that he didn't know the ages of his children, that he measured the years by his movies, not by his offspring.

The on-stage interviewer tells the audience that Faithless is "best described as 'not a date movie'". Ullmann is unhappy with that. "I disagree. It is a date movie - it teaches you about relationships." She says that, nowadays, in our godless world, few people believe in the sanctity of relationships because the core values aren't there."

She talks about why she became a director: "I was tired of working for bad directors. And, the older you get, the more bad directors you work for." Someone asks how big an influence Bergman is on her directing style. "I'm not so conscious of him, but everyone else is," she says. "If I have a man and a woman, they'll say it is inspired by Bergman and forget that everyone has a man and a woman." Directing is so much more fulfilling than acting, she says, because you get to be yourself and talk about what's important for you. And what is important for her is to make films about real people, unremarkable people, older people. "I'm 62, and I started when I was 18. There's so much shame about age these days, and I don't know why." The applauserises in a crescendo.

Ullmann tells the storyline of a short film she made a few years ago. "An old man is lying in a big double bed by himself. He wakes up all alone, has a bath, goes into the kitchen, makes a picnic basket, puts his hat on, looks in the mirror and leaves. He walks through the streets and he's old and little and nobody notices him because he's just... old. He goes to the hospital, walks through the corridor, and no one notices. He enters the room, and then finally he smiles because she's there. His wife has lost her mind. He gives her the soup he has made for her, waters the flowers, kisses her, and leaves. No one sees him leave. He walks back down the corridor and through the streets unnoticed. But we know he is the carrier of love. That is the kind of film I want to make."

Later, I suggest to her that the story about the old man seems to illustrate a crucial difference between her and Bergman. If Bergman had made the movie, the old man would have visited his senile wife and they would have torn each other apart. She laughs, and says he would find it sentimental.

Did she never want to give Bergman a good slap and tell him to cheer up? "No, I've never hit anyone. Not my child, not a man. I banged on somebody's chest, that's the closest. I have been hit, but I've never hit. I can get very angry, but I can't stay with anger. There is no one I can hate for ever. Ingmar is good at that."

There must have been times when she was dragged down by his bleakness? "I thought so at the time - five years on that miserable dark island, I thought I was dragged down, but I wasn't in a prison. I could have left, and I didn't. But we did quarrel a lot." What about? "Everything. When we lived together, later when we made movies, and we have our disagreements now. Yes, I get very angry at him." She has always said that what makes it worse is that she sees so many of her own traits in him. "I get angry when he tries to control me. He's very controlling. I'm probably controlling myself, but I don't recognise it so well in me."

How could it not be a controlling relationship when for so much of their life together he doubled as her director? "When he controls, he says this is how it is and there is no discussion." She says that she is more democratic. I smile as she talks, and suddenly she changes tack. "He's a good listener, too. Things don't avoid him. Then he gets one of those little smiles that you have now, and you'd know the danger was coming. You'd see that smile and think, 'Oh my God, I should have never said that.'" I tell her that Bergman sounds like an abuser. "He uses strong language, but he's not abusive. He makes the law and he lives by it."

Ullmann and Bergman lived together for five short and long years on Faro, his remote Baltic island . They never married, and when they separated in the early 70s, Bergman kept Ullmann's dog, Pett, and Ullmann kept their daughter, Linn. It was while making Cries And Whispers with Ullmann that Bergman began an affair with Ingrid von Rosen, who later became his wife and remained so until she died in 1995.

Ullmann decided to escape the frozen darkness of the Scandinavian climate and Bergman's vision. She went to Hollywood, where she was sold as the new Ingrid Bergman. And she certainly gave it a go, most notably in 40 Carats, a romantic comedy somewhere between Shirley Valentine and The Graduate. But Hollywood never really took to her - Scandinavian melancholy was no longer considered exotic in Tinseltown, just morose. For a short time, she was entranced by the sun, the heated pools and Henry Kissinger. But she also worried. She was shy, she was made to feel stupid by Kissinger, she wondered whether she should be out on the town when she had a young daughter. She says that she only saw Kissinger socially because he did all the talking and made her feel less self-conscious. "I absolutely disapprove of what he did politically, and I told him so, but he tells good stories. He just thought it was fun to be with me because I don't understand anything, because I'm stupid in politics and I'm on the wrong side."

Does she consider herself political? "Yes, living is political. The choices you make, the people you condone or do not condone. What you want to do with your life, how you want to connect with other people, how you want to use the time you're living here." What makes her most angry today, she says, is the way wealthy countries abuse asylum seekers. For many years she has been a Unicef ambassador. She tells me about a boy she fostered who had lost his parents in the bloodshed of Sierra Leone's civil war. "He hated everybody when he came, especially me, because he had never had anybody. Now he is the most wonderful generous person - he calls me Mummy."

Ullmann says people were so generous to her that it was only when she got home that she realised what a fiasco Hollywood had been. She achieved great success on Broadway, as Nora in Ibsen's A Doll's House, but even then the roots lay in Norway. Over the years, she has made Nora, that trapped butterfly of a housewife who finally breaks free, her own. She still feels Norway in her bones. "We are surrounded by mountains, we want to come out of it, we want to explore, we are not sophisticated, but we are more natural. We celebrate the light summers and shudder in the cold, dark winters." Where does she live now? "I don't know." She has a home in Norway, lives in America with Donald, and spent two and a half years making Faithless in Sweden.

I suggest that now Bergman no longer directs, he has entrusted his eyes to Ullmann. She looks sceptical. " Well, in that case he has changed his tune. He's just come out in an interview and said film-making is whorish work and film-makers are whores. To say that because it's something he no longer wants to do or can do is shit ."

Have the men in her life been jealous of Bergman? "Maybe, but none of them has said so. They may have been..."

I ask Donald why he got on the plane after divorcing her. "Because I love her. I was never going to leave her, I was just changing the balance of the relationship. I don't think most marriages that continue are as honest and as clear as they pretend to be."

"That's his word, you know," Ullmann says. "I think if you marry once, and you keep it, to stand in front of God and be together in sickdom and health, I think that is wonderful. I wish I had experienced it."

Next day, Ullmann is smiling and chatty. The waiter comes over. She orders coffee and he her asks for her number. "My phone number?" She giggles flirtatiously. He giggles ecstatically: "You're trying to make me a happy man, aren't you?"

She talks about Linn, who is now 35, and her 10-year-old boy, Ullmann's grandson, with such tender pride. In Changing, she wrote that when Linn grew up she wanted to be a trapeze artist. Did she succeed? "No, she didn't. Well, she did in a way. She's a writer, she's a trapeze artist. Her writing is full of fantasy and images. Incredible."

For so many years Ullmann considered herself a bad mother. "Yes, I felt very guilty. When I look back now, I'm not guilty any more. I gave as much as I had in me, and could do. I failed, but who doesn't fail? And I didn't hit and I didn't deceive." She says she has grown up, that even Bergman has grown up into a better parent. Nowadays, most of his children visit him in summer on Faro. "They live in different houses and they see him when he shows movies and he comes and has coffee with them. Now I think they are a wonderful source of life for him."

She's been thinking about Changing, and changing, and the importance of optimism. "Optimism wins out in the end. If you don't seek happiness, it is going to be a really sad life and it doesn't mean you have to be Polyanna. You know Polyanna? It doesn't mean you should smile at everything."

Is that the main difference between her and Bergman? She says it's not so simple: "I think he is, to a certain degree, optimistic in life, but he doesn't put it into his movies. And of course that has really helped him, because, in spite of them being pessimistic, looking very cold and unforgiving, he has also touched people. And he has won. He is looked upon as one of the best cinema people in the world. Probably if it had been more life-affirming, it wouldn't have been so complimented." She says it's a pity that he's not made more comedies, that even now no one makes her laugh like Bergman.

It turned out that she had not attended the festival gala dinner the evening before, where she could have done her own bit of basking in glory. "I don't know what to say to the people, I don't know this kind of conversation, I get panicked, I really get so panicked, dancing or anything." Maybe that is one of the great changes in Ullmann's life. It's not that she has overcome her fears, it's that she does everything she can to manage them. Ten years ago, she stopped drinking because she was worried that she drank to overcome social fears. The better solution was simply not to go to the events she didn't want to.

She says that there have been so many uncomfortable silent nights in her life. Recently, she and Donald were invited to Clinton's farewell dinner. She put her fear to one side because she really wanted to meet him. "Suddenly, I was placed beside Clinton and I couldn't say a word. I was 18 and I was terrified, and there were so many things I wanted to say to him."

Then there was the night with Woody Allen and Bergman."I was doing A Doll's House a long time ago on Broadway and Woody Allen was kind of courting me, probably to get to know Ingmar . Then Ingmar came to New York to see me in A Doll's House. He stayed in a hotel with Ingrid, whom he had just married. I told him Woody Allen wanted to meet him. Ingmar wanted to meet him, and he said come to my suite and we will have dinner. Then Woody Allen came to get me and he was so excited, he was shivering and talking, talking. Anyway, Ingmar opened the door and said welcome. That's all he said. And the two of them looked at each other. Two geniuses met. We sat down at the table - and this is the honest to God truth, Ingrid was sitting there, I was sitting there, Ingmar there, and Woody Allen there - and they did not talk. They just looked at each other, almost lovingly.

Ingrid, for once, was allowed to talk at the table, so she talked to me about meatballs. We talked about meatballs because I didn't know what to talk about. And in the middle of the thing she gave me my child support in an envelope and said this is for Linn next year. It was a little embarrassing in front of Woody Allen. So she did that and I hated her a little more. And the two of them would look at each other and smile, look at these two sweet women. I hated that - that I was only a meatball person - and probably she hated that, too. They never talked. They never talked. They laughed to each other but never said a word. Then it was over and they said goodbye . On the way home Woody Allen said, 'Thank you. He is an incredible man.' I couldn't believe it. Then, when I came home, Ingmar called, 'Thank you, Liv, what an incredible meeting.'"

These days, she would not so easily be patronised as a daffy little woman. When she was a young success, more militant feminists attacked her as a conservative. "It was because I was pleasing. They were maybe right, but they are more pleasing now than I am." She is less pleasing than she used to be? "Yes, I strive to be. I used to say, poor little me, I'm not strong. But I am strong." She laughs at the idea that she thought she'd reached her sell-by date in her mid-30s. Now, there's so much to look forward to. "I want to be available... maybe for my grandson, for living, for whatever..." Would she ever have plastic surgery? "Never. Never did. Never will." Why not? "Because I want to see what I was meant to be, what my face is meant to be."

Donald joins us. They look happy together. Did she think things would work out okay when she started out? "Yes, but in a different way. I thought my mother would praise me and my men would praise me, and my daughter would praise me, and they don't necessarily praise me. But I praise myself. I'm not big in my head, and I don't feel terrible about myself, and I'm not a drunk, and I've not burnt out, and I have feelings, and I feel very young inside. I think I'm a very okay person, and that's the best thing I've done in life."

Ullmann tells me of the last time she saw Bergman. Yes, of course, they fought and disagreed, but they also realised that they had reached an understanding. "We have found what real love is. It's respect, trust, admiration. It's everything except sex. But, you know, even that is there, the fondness, wanting to hug, wanting to hold hands. The last time I saw him he followed me down to my hotel in Stockholm. It was very late and I really wanted to go because I'd been sitting in his flat for a long time. And he said I'll follow you home and I said no, you don't have to. Then suddenly it was a wonderful, wonderful walk. We didn't say much. We went by a church where his father had been a preacher and it wasn't so much what he said, and it wasn't sex at all, but it was the same intimacy as sex, the way we were walking that night.
