And he was moved and I was moved because we hadn't been walking in the street in the dark alone for 30 years since we'd been lovers."

Liv, Ingmar and Donald: it could be one of Bergman's films but, of course, in the movies things never turn out as well as in real life

 Faithless is released on February 9.
fields.bodyText: A quarter of a century ago, Liv Ullmann wrote a haunting autobiography called Changing. The great Norwegian actress had recently parted from the great Swedish film-maker Ingmar Bergman, and she could feel middle age encroaching. She wanted to embrace it, but was drowning in her fears - was she a bad mother, had she sacrificed her daughter's well-being to her own ambition, what would happen when her breasts started to sag, when she was no longer a desirable commodity? The only constant she could see in the future was Bergman. Although they had separated, although there was no prospect of reconciliation, in one way or another she knew that she and Bergman would never be apart. "I was right - we never did leave each other," she says today. "You know, soon after we met, Ingmar told me he had a dream that we would be painfully connected." We are sitting in a suite in a swanky Los Angeles hotel. It's such a strange place to meet her. Ullmann, the dour, heartbreaking actress who peeled off layer after layer until she revealed her raw, bleeding soul. If Bergman was the master of human misery, she was the canvas on which he painted. And here we are in LA, the home of have-a-nice-day fatuity, where the object of ageing is to remain unchanged, and the object of talking is not to communicate. If Bergman and Ullmann had a motto, it would probably be "Have a bad day". Ullmann is now 62, Bergman 82. Both have continued to evolve in the 25 years since she wrote Changing. Ullmann no longer acts and is now an established director in her own right. Bergman no longer directs (his last film, Fanny & Alexander, won four Oscars in 1982) and is more reclusive than ever. Perhaps the relationship has been turned on its head. Ullmann has just directed Bergman's autobiographical screenplay, Faithless. But she has not just dutifully realised his vision. Instead, she has taken it, shaken it, rewritten it and created a film that might well turn out to be their greatest collaboration. Most of today's fans of Hollywood blockbusters will not have heard of either of them. Indeed, many of Bergman's fans presume that he is dead. But in the 60s and early 70s, they were one of the world's most celebrated couples. She was his muse, his star, his love. He was her inspiration, her director, her love. This was the golden age of European cinema. Godard and Truffaut in France, Buñuel in Spain, Fassbinder in Germany, Antonioni in Italy, Tarkovsky in the Soviet Union and, of course, Bergman in Sweden. The golden age of cinema full stop. And Bergman was at the peak of his powers with a string of angst-soaked classics to his name - Wild Strawberries, The Virgin Spring, The Seventh Seal. Those were the days when films were taken seriously. And no one's films were more serious than Bergman's. It was cinema as psychoanalysis. His movies didn't have plots, as such, let alone special effects. Yet they were gripping. They were stripped to the essence - long, brutally cropped close-ups of characters talking and talking about love and hate, guilt and God, hope and despair. Bergman showed, more powerfully than any film-maker, how people tear each other apart in the name of love. Somehow, he showed cinema at both its most humane and at its cruellest. And Ullmann, with her complex, ever-changing face, was his ideal actress - chaste, frigid, hungry, sensual, lumpen, elegant, tormented, beatific Ullmann. She had an extraordinary knack of showing contrary emotions at any one time. In Cries And Whispers, she orgasms through tears of anguish after her husband announces that he is leaving her; in Autumn Sonata, she plays a quiet, kindly daughter whose bitterness rages behind her selfless love. Within seconds of meeting Ullmann, you realise why she was so pivotal to Bergman. She can't do small talk. She says that her head is so full of stuff these days that she is selective with her memories, and suddenly she's talking about how images define memory, and how smell is one of the strongest images, and how she's spent a lifetime trying to recapture the smell of childhood security. "My grandmother's neck smelled of safety. She was my best friend, and I used to sit on her lap when I was a little girl, and she'd tell me all these wonderful stories, and she always said the stones and the trees talked to us. If I fell asleep I would have this wonderful smell in her neck, and I would always search for this smell." What was the smell? "Maybe just being old, but in a good way. Being old in a safe way. Being human, being understandable." For a while, she thought Bergman smelled of her grandmother, but... "he took the safety out of the smell, so it didn't smell like her any more." Years later, she discovered the smell again - on an old woman dying of leprosy whom she met while visiting refugees in Macau. Ullmann was born in Tokyo to Norwegian parents. Childhood was blessed with securities, but ruptured by loss and fear. By the close of the second world war, both her father and grandfather had been killed. "My grandfather died in Dachau, but we are not Jewish. He was sent there because he had helped Jewish people escape from the town where he lived in Norway. Then they took 10 hostages instead, and he died there... the same time as his son, more or less." How did her father die? "I was six, and we had been in Japan, then we went to Toronto, where there were many British and Norwegian pilots, and my father was a civil engineer. According to my mother, my father walked into the propeller of a plane. I didn't think you could survive that, but apparently he did for a year and then he died." She tells her war stories dispassionately, as if she's talking about people she doesn't know. You sense she doesn't want to exploit a false emotion. Does she remember her father? "I only remember that he held my hand." Ullmann grew up in a house of women - mother, grandmother, older sister. She was always an unwieldy mix: strong and fearful, oppressed and free-spirit. As a young girl, she deliberately scalded her foot so she could miss her hated cookery lesson at school. Between 11 and 15, when she was left alone at home in the evening, she would sleep in the bath with the door locked until her mother or sister returned. She says that she still longs for the bathroom and then corrects herself: "Not the bathroom, but for that tiny little space that is mine." Childhood was also the time of her greatest happiness. She talks about the times she would lift herself on to the handlebars and do a handstand on her bicycle, and says that she has never felt so liberated. Ullmann is tired. She's just flown into LA, and she massages her head, irons out the creases. As she talks about how her Lutheran faith has strengthened over the years, a shadow passes behind me. "The man behind you, oh I think he's left again, he's Jewish." Who is he? "He's my husband. We divorced, but we are living together." She says it so matter of factly that I laugh. They got back together as soon as they divorced? "Yeah. I always seem to keep friends with the people after." Donald is from Boston, in his mid-60s and is big in property. She says the split with Donald was initially acrimonious. "He divorced me, and I hoped I'd never see him again. But then I went on my plane back to Norway and he came on the plane and he said that no one else shall sit at your side. He came all the way to Norway and then took the plane back. I thought that was really romantic - I fall for those things very easily." So they got back together. They married in 1985 and divorced four years ago. "It was when I did Private Confessions." Private Confessions was the first Bergman script she directed. When she first met Bergman, she was married to a psychiatrist and already an established actress in her 20s. Bergman cast her in Persona (1966), opposite Bibi Andersson, as an actress having a breakdown, tormented into silence. Andersson, who had had an affair with Bergman, warned her against the film-maker. Bergman was a serial star-fucker, who seemed to sleep with his actresses as a matter of course. He was nearing 50, had been married four times and had seven children. Ullmann and Bergman duly fell in love. She left her husband, moved in with him and they had a daughter, Linn. The most revealing film Ullmann starred in is Scenes From A Marriage, made in 1973, a few years after they split up. Both of them denied that this devastating account of a break-up was autobiographical, but it's hard to believe. Ullmann is Marianne, the repressed, diffident wife of a scientist, played by Bergman regular Erland Josephson, who leaves her for another woman. At the beginning of the film, the couple, being interviewed, are asked to describe themselves. The husband says that he is successful, clever, quite brilliant actually, moral, decent, popular, responsible, considerate and an absolute wow in bed. Marianne struggles to think of anything to say. Eventually, she manages, "I am a mother." As so often with Bergman, it is an unsparing study of the neurotic loneliness of women and the savage egotism of men. Faithless could easily be called Scenes From A Marriage 2. Again, it's about the collapse of a relationship. Again, the leading woman, brilliantly played by Lena Endre, is called Marianne. But the wheel has turned. While Ullmann directs, Bergman is now the barely fictionalised character, David Bergman (played by Josephson), looking back on his life as a film-maker, lover and home-wrecker. Like much of Bergman's work, it is also about the nature of art. Faithless tells the story of a film-maker trying to recapture the pain of his old love so that he can exploit it; so he can turn it into the movie we are watching. Ullmann has a lighter touch than Bergman - somehow, there's more humour to the tears - but she directs with all his spartan vigour. It's an astonishing achievement to make such relentless misery so compelling. Do people expect her to be a misery-guts when they meet her? "Yes, always. But I am not miserable. At times, I can be sad, but I love to play, I love to laugh." She pauses, mulling something over. "I think I make people nervous at times." She tells me how the photographer Annie Leibovitz recently came to her Miami home and was unnerved by the way Ullmann looked her in the eye and listened to her so attentively. She left without a picture. Perhaps her strength has been a weakness? She nods enthusiastically. "Oh, it is. All women know that we have to underplay strength at times, because men don't always like it." She says that she grew up at the same time as women's liberation, and her generation had two choices: "To be the way our mothers brought us up to be - you know, pleasant, nice - or to be who we wanted to be. My choice was to be pleasant and nice." Did she downplay her success with Bergman? "No. Yes . A little. I would say to him, 'With other directors, I think of what you would have said to me', and sometimes I'd say that and it wasn't true, because I like working with a lot of directors." It must have been tricky, when his success was so dependent on hers. "No, it wasn't... well, it was intertwined. Maybe he could have found somebody, maybe they wouldn't have been as gifted as I was then as an actress, but the chances are not so big. I know I couldn't have found a better director. But now I'm already into that Ingmar thing, that [deferring to] man thing, saying, 'I could not have been what I am without him'. If you've done that all your life, it's very difficult to get away from it." Actually, she says, it's only with Faithless that she has overcome all that. "I managed to say, for the first time in my life, that I'm very proud of this film, I think I know how to do this, I think I'm professional. I've never said these things, and now I'm saying it a lot. Now, it's almost natural." And it feels good? "Oh, it feels fantastic." Next day, we meet up in Palm Springs, where Ullmann is receiving the International Film-Makers Award. Palm Springs is 100 or so miles from Los Angeles. Hollywood stars retire here to play golf. Plastic surgery is compulsory. Ullmann is interviewed on stage before Faithless is screened. She is wearing a little black dress, a fabulous, multicoloured coat and looks beautiful; huge, blue eyes; soft, heavy lips; a smile both seductive and maternal. She makes no attempt to disguise her lined skin. She appears so confident as she reveals how Bergman wrote the story of Faithless as a monologue and how she had to sculpt the characters out of that. "Ingmar didn't want anything to do with it. He didn't see it for two years until it was finished. He expected to see a rough cut, but I know he's very controlling, so when he did see it, I said, 'Sorry, this is the movie.' " One of her most important additions is the daughter, who becomes the emotional fulcrum of the movie. "That was not in Ingmar's script, and he really liked it - he said, 'Oh, why didn't I think of that?' But now he's forgotten that, because now he feels he thought of it." In Scenes From A Marriage, we never saw Marianne's children. It was as if they didn't exist. And, for much of Bergman's life, his children haven't. He used to say, almost boast, that he didn't know the ages of his children, that he measured the years by his movies, not by his offspring. The on-stage interviewer tells the audience that Faithless is "best described as 'not a date movie'". Ullmann is unhappy with that. "I disagree. It is a date movie - it teaches you about relationships." She says that, nowadays, in our godless world, few people believe in the sanctity of relationships because the core values aren't there." She talks about why she became a director: "I was tired of working for bad directors. And, the older you get, the more bad directors you work for." Someone asks how big an influence Bergman is on her directing style. "I'm not so conscious of him, but everyone else is," she says. "If I have a man and a woman, they'll say it is inspired by Bergman and forget that everyone has a man and a woman." Directing is so much more fulfilling than acting, she says, because you get to be yourself and talk about what's important for you. And what is important for her is to make films about real people, unremarkable people, older people. "I'm 62, and I started when I was 18. There's so much shame about age these days, and I don't know why." The applauserises in a crescendo. Ullmann tells the storyline of a short film she made a few years ago. "An old man is lying in a big double bed by himself. He wakes up all alone, has a bath, goes into the kitchen, makes a picnic basket, puts his hat on, looks in the mirror and leaves. He walks through the streets and he's old and little and nobody notices him because he's just... old. He goes to the hospital, walks through the corridor, and no one notices. He enters the room, and then finally he smiles because she's there. His wife has lost her mind. He gives her the soup he has made for her, waters the flowers, kisses her, and leaves. No one sees him leave. He walks back down the corridor and through the streets unnoticed. But we know he is the carrier of love. That is the kind of film I want to make." Later, I suggest to her that the story about the old man seems to illustrate a crucial difference between her and Bergman. If Bergman had made the movie, the old man would have visited his senile wife and they would have torn each other apart. She laughs, and says he would find it sentimental. Did she never want to give Bergman a good slap and tell him to cheer up? "No, I've never hit anyone. Not my child, not a man. I banged on somebody's chest, that's the closest. I have been hit, but I've never hit. I can get very angry, but I can't stay with anger. There is no one I can hate for ever. Ingmar is good at that." There must have been times when she was dragged down by his bleakness? "I thought so at the time - five years on that miserable dark island, I thought I was dragged down, but I wasn't in a prison. I could have left, and I didn't. But we did quarrel a lot." What about? "Everything. When we lived together, later when we made movies, and we have our disagreements now. Yes, I get very angry at him." She has always said that what makes it worse is that she sees so many of her own traits in him. "I get angry when he tries to control me. He's very controlling. I'm probably controlling myself, but I don't recognise it so well in me." How could it not be a controlling relationship when for so much of their life together he doubled as her director? "When he controls, he says this is how it is and there is no discussion." She says that she is more democratic. I smile as she talks, and suddenly she changes tack. "He's a good listener, too. Things don't avoid him. Then he gets one of those little smiles that you have now, and you'd know the danger was coming. You'd see that smile and think, 'Oh my God, I should have never said that.'" I tell her that Bergman sounds like an abuser. "He uses strong language, but he's not abusive. He makes the law and he lives by it." Ullmann and Bergman lived together for five short and long years on Faro, his remote Baltic island . They never married, and when they separated in the early 70s, Bergman kept Ullmann's dog, Pett, and Ullmann kept their daughter, Linn. It was while making Cries And Whispers with Ullmann that Bergman began an affair with Ingrid von Rosen, who later became his wife and remained so until she died in 1995. Ullmann decided to escape the frozen darkness of the Scandinavian climate and Bergman's vision. She went to Hollywood, where she was sold as the new Ingrid Bergman. And she certainly gave it a go, most notably in 40 Carats, a romantic comedy somewhere between Shirley Valentine and The Graduate. But Hollywood never really took to her - Scandinavian melancholy was no longer considered exotic in Tinseltown, just morose. For a short time, she was entranced by the sun, the heated pools and Henry Kissinger. But she also worried. She was shy, she was made to feel stupid by Kissinger, she wondered whether she should be out on the town when she had a young daughter. She says that she only saw Kissinger socially because he did all the talking and made her feel less self-conscious. "I absolutely disapprove of what he did politically, and I told him so, but he tells good stories. He just thought it was fun to be with me because I don't understand anything, because I'm stupid in politics and I'm on the wrong side." Does she consider herself political? "Yes, living is political. The choices you make, the people you condone or do not condone. What you want to do with your life, how you want to connect with other people, how you want to use the time you're living here." What makes her most angry today, she says, is the way wealthy countries abuse asylum seekers. For many years she has been a Unicef ambassador. She tells me about a boy she fostered who had lost his parents in the bloodshed of Sierra Leone's civil war. "He hated everybody when he came, especially me, because he had never had anybody. Now he is the most wonderful generous person - he calls me Mummy." Ullmann says people were so generous to her that it was only when she got home that she realised what a fiasco Hollywood had been. She achieved great success on Broadway, as Nora in Ibsen's A Doll's House, but even then the roots lay in Norway. Over the years, she has made Nora, that trapped butterfly of a housewife who finally breaks free, her own. She still feels Norway in her bones. "We are surrounded by mountains, we want to come out of it, we want to explore, we are not sophisticated, but we are more natural. We celebrate the light summers and shudder in the cold, dark winters." Where does she live now? "I don't know." She has a home in Norway, lives in America with Donald, and spent two and a half years making Faithless in Sweden. I suggest that now Bergman no longer directs, he has entrusted his eyes to Ullmann. She looks sceptical. " Well, in that case he has changed his tune. He's just come out in an interview and said film-making is whorish work and film-makers are whores. To say that because it's something he no longer wants to do or can do is shit ." Have the men in her life been jealous of Bergman? "Maybe, but none of them has said so. They may have been..." I ask Donald why he got on the plane after divorcing her. "Because I love her. I was never going to leave her, I was just changing the balance of the relationship. I don't think most marriages that continue are as honest and as clear as they pretend to be." "That's his word, you know," Ullmann says. "I think if you marry once, and you keep it, to stand in front of God and be together in sickdom and health, I think that is wonderful. I wish I had experienced it." Next day, Ullmann is smiling and chatty. The waiter comes over. She orders coffee and he her asks for her number. "My phone number?" She giggles flirtatiously. He giggles ecstatically: "You're trying to make me a happy man, aren't you?" She talks about Linn, who is now 35, and her 10-year-old boy, Ullmann's grandson, with such tender pride. In Changing, she wrote that when Linn grew up she wanted to be a trapeze artist. Did she succeed? "No, she didn't. Well, she did in a way. She's a writer, she's a trapeze artist. Her writing is full of fantasy and images. Incredible." For so many years Ullmann considered herself a bad mother. "Yes, I felt very guilty. When I look back now, I'm not guilty any more. I gave as much as I had in me, and could do. I failed, but who doesn't fail? And I didn't hit and I didn't deceive." She says she has grown up, that even Bergman has grown up into a better parent. Nowadays, most of his children visit him in summer on Faro. "They live in different houses and they see him when he shows movies and he comes and has coffee with them. Now I think they are a wonderful source of life for him." She's been thinking about Changing, and changing, and the importance of optimism. "Optimism wins out in the end. If you don't seek happiness, it is going to be a really sad life and it doesn't mean you have to be Polyanna. You know Polyanna? It doesn't mean you should smile at everything." Is that the main difference between her and Bergman? She says it's not so simple: "I think he is, to a certain degree, optimistic in life, but he doesn't put it into his movies. And of course that has really helped him, because, in spite of them being pessimistic, looking very cold and unforgiving, he has also touched people. And he has won. He is looked upon as one of the best cinema people in the world. Probably if it had been more life-affirming, it wouldn't have been so complimented." She says it's a pity that he's not made more comedies, that even now no one makes her laugh like Bergman. It turned out that she had not attended the festival gala dinner the evening before, where she could have done her own bit of basking in glory. "I don't know what to say to the people, I don't know this kind of conversation, I get panicked, I really get so panicked, dancing or anything." Maybe that is one of the great changes in Ullmann's life. It's not that she has overcome her fears, it's that she does everything she can to manage them. Ten years ago, she stopped drinking because she was worried that she drank to overcome social fears. The better solution was simply not to go to the events she didn't want to. She says that there have been so many uncomfortable silent nights in her life. Recently, she and Donald were invited to Clinton's farewell dinner. She put her fear to one side because she really wanted to meet him. "Suddenly, I was placed beside Clinton and I couldn't say a word. I was 18 and I was terrified, and there were so many things I wanted to say to him." Then there was the night with Woody Allen and Bergman."I was doing A Doll's House a long time ago on Broadway and Woody Allen was kind of courting me, probably to get to know Ingmar . Then Ingmar came to New York to see me in A Doll's House. He stayed in a hotel with Ingrid, whom he had just married. I told him Woody Allen wanted to meet him. Ingmar wanted to meet him, and he said come to my suite and we will have dinner. Then Woody Allen came to get me and he was so excited, he was shivering and talking, talking. Anyway, Ingmar opened the door and said welcome. That's all he said. And the two of them looked at each other. Two geniuses met. We sat down at the table - and this is the honest to God truth, Ingrid was sitting there, I was sitting there, Ingmar there, and Woody Allen there - and they did not talk. They just looked at each other, almost lovingly. Ingrid, for once, was allowed to talk at the table, so she talked to me about meatballs. We talked about meatballs because I didn't know what to talk about. And in the middle of the thing she gave me my child support in an envelope and said this is for Linn next year. It was a little embarrassing in front of Woody Allen. So she did that and I hated her a little more. And the two of them would look at each other and smile, look at these two sweet women. I hated that - that I was only a meatball person - and probably she hated that, too. They never talked. They never talked. They laughed to each other but never said a word. Then it was over and they said goodbye . On the way home Woody Allen said, 'Thank you. He is an incredible man.' I couldn't believe it. Then, when I came home, Ingmar called, 'Thank you, Liv, what an incredible meeting.'" These days, she would not so easily be patronised as a daffy little woman. When she was a young success, more militant feminists attacked her as a conservative. "It was because I was pleasing. They were maybe right, but they are more pleasing now than I am." She is less pleasing than she used to be? "Yes, I strive to be. I used to say, poor little me, I'm not strong. But I am strong." She laughs at the idea that she thought she'd reached her sell-by date in her mid-30s. Now, there's so much to look forward to. "I want to be available... maybe for my grandson, for living, for whatever..." Would she ever have plastic surgery? "Never. Never did. Never will." Why not? "Because I want to see what I was meant to be, what my face is meant to be." Donald joins us. They look happy together. Did she think things would work out okay when she started out? "Yes, but in a different way. I thought my mother would praise me and my men would praise me, and my daughter would praise me, and they don't necessarily praise me. But I praise myself. I'm not big in my head, and I don't feel terrible about myself, and I'm not a drunk, and I've not burnt out, and I have feelings, and I feel very young inside. I think I'm a very okay person, and that's the best thing I've done in life." Ullmann tells me of the last time she saw Bergman. Yes, of course, they fought and disagreed, but they also realised that they had reached an understanding. "We have found what real love is. It's respect, trust, admiration. It's everything except sex. But, you know, even that is there, the fondness, wanting to hug, wanting to hold hands. The last time I saw him he followed me down to my hotel in Stockholm. It was very late and I really wanted to go because I'd been sitting in his flat for a long time. And he said I'll follow you home and I said no, you don't have to. Then suddenly it was a wonderful, wonderful walk. We didn't say much. We went by a church where his father had been a preacher and it wasn't so much what he said, and it wasn't sex at all, but it was the same intimacy as sex, the way we were walking that night. And he was moved and I was moved because we hadn't been walking in the street in the dark alone for 30 years since we'd been lovers." Liv, Ingmar and Donald: it could be one of Bergman's films but, of course, in the movies things never turn out as well as in real life  Faithless is released on February 9.

fields.headline: Dear weekend
fields.standfirst: Email: weekend@guardian.co.ukA postal address must be supplied. Letters should reach us by Tuesday afternoon for inclusion on Saturday, and may be edited.
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
There are many reasons why the Holocaust Day should refer to the Armenians, for their treatment is intimately linked with Nazi action during the second world war. Hitler used it as part of his justification: 'I have sent my Death's Head units to the East with the order to kill without mercy men women and children of the Polish race or language. Only in such a way will we win the lebensraum that we need. Who, after all, speaks today of the annihilation of the Armenians?' (As quoted in Europe, by Norman Davies).
Rev David Bronnert
Southall, Middlesex david.bronnert@talk21.com

Julia Pascal is wrong to refer to a 'genocide' in Bosnia (A People Killed Twice, January 27). What occurred in the former Yugoslavia was a series of vicious civil wars in which between 50,000 and 200,000 people were killed mainly on the grounds of their nationality. This is typical of most wars throughout history, including many which resulted in far greater numbers of deaths than in Yugoslavia. To talk of genocide in relation to the war in Bosnia, and to equate what happened there with the slaughter of the Armenians in 1915 and of the Jews during the second world war, serves to help empty the term genocide of its very real meaning.
Paul Flewers
London WC1 hatchet.job@virgin.net

In Adrian Mole on January 27, he told his postman that, now the Post Office has changed its name to Consignia, he is 'a consignée'. Was the postman a female-to-male transsexual? If so, wasn't Adrian being politically incorrect in referring to him using a female form of the noun?
Julian Dunn
Great Haseley
Oxon

'It is true... that he did not generally want "to improve anything at all" and opposed most forms of progress.' And this is Alexander Chancellor's defence of his friend, Auberon Waugh (January 27)? I can't see how one of Waugh's enemies could have damned him more thoroughly.
Sophie Wiggins
Birmingham
sophie_w@blueyonder.co.uk

The use of American accents in song when singers are not American is something a lot of us folk musicians have been fretting about for some decades (Julie Burchill, January 27). It is, in fact, part of a wider phenomenon, which, as Julie Burchill ought to know, has a name: cultural hegemony.
Ruth Grimsley
Sheffield

Julie Burchill derides All Saints for using the American slang word 'ass', when they are English. The Appleton sisters, Natalie and Nicole, (50% of the group) are, in fact, Canadian, so their use of the word 'ass' is not so unusual, and neither is the fact that they 'sing with American accents'.
Paul Mann
Glasgow

I must admit to being in a state of confusion following Julie Burchill's claim that Natalie Appleton is 'literally the most beautiful woman in the world today'. I thought I lived with the most beautiful woman in the world. Her name is Melanie and she comes from Harrogate.
Phil Rumney
Sheffield
PRumney@shu.ac.uk

fields.headline: Scambuster!
fields.standfirst: In France, where there's corruption in high places, Madame Eva Joly will sniff it out. Her assault on the sleaze in an establishment that considers itself above the law is sending shockwaves through the nation. Right now, she has a former foreign minister in the dock. He isn't the first to feel the weight of Joly's steely justice - and he won't be the last.
fields.trailText: In France, where there's corruption in high places, Madame Eva Joly will sniff it out. Her assault on the sleaze in an establishment that considers itself above the law is sending shockwaves through the nation. Right now, she has a former foreign minister in the dock. He isn't the first to feel the weight of Joly's steely justice - and he won't be the last. Interview by Peter Lennon
fields.body:
For the past two weeks, Paris has been witnessing the spectacle of a former foreign minister, Roland Dumas,appearing in the dock to answer charges of corruption. There is some £6m in kickbacks and a mistress at the heart of these charges, but what has devastated the French establishment is that Dumas was, at the time of the original accusation in 1997, France's highest legal authority, the president of the Constitutional Council. He finally resigned last year.

What law officer could have dared to initiate and obstinately bring to its awful conclusion an investigation targeting the highest legal authority in the land? Well, it wasn't a Frenchman. It was, in fact, a former Norwegian au pair, Gro Eva Farseth, who married into a distinguished French family and then appalled them by transforming herself into the all-powerful Investigating Magistrate, Madame Eva Joly. As such, she has become the scourge of France's untouchables - the business moguls and political leaders. A co-defendant in the Dumas affair is the former president of the oil giant Elf-Aquitaine, one-time head of the state-owned railway network, SNCF. But this case forms only a small part of Eva Joly's spectacular reach. She was also instrumental in uncovering the Crédit Lyonnais banking scandal, described in 1997 as the world's biggest financial disaster. Her investigations into the Elf affair uncovered a political slush fund that went beyond the borders of France to touch Germany's former chancellor, Helmut Kohl. And then there was the affair of the frigates sold to Taiwan... All this was achieved in a post that Eva Joly has held for only seven years.

It all started more than 30 years ago, when the 20-year-old Gro Eva Farseth travelled to Paris from her home in Oslo to study French. Already on the train down, there was a hint of the determination and steadiness of purpose to come: instead of preparing herself for Parisian life with Elle magazine or Paris Match, she passed the journey studying French verbs. She very soon found a position as au pair in an urban palace by the Luxembourg gardens, home of the Joly family. This was a family that had for generations contributed soldiers, scientists and academics to the glory of their country.

When Gro was courteously permitted by her employers to dine with them, she became privy to the etiquette that distinguishes such a family of true taste from that of - well, plebeian is too base a concept - let's say the nouveau riche. As you stir your coffee, for instance, the ear must not be offended by the sound of the spoon touching the bottom. Nor must you ever cut your lettuce; it must be folded.

Mlle Farseth caught on quickly that observance of a dozen or so rules would see you comfortably through the best drawing rooms. But what this condescending family of distinguished lineage did not realise about Growas that, while she might be what they would call brute de coffrage (unpolished), she had powerful values of her own. The most deadly proved to be an inherent lack of respect for hierarchy. There is no aristocracy in Norway. Gro is the daughter of a carpenter, and her family lived at one point in the same apartment block in Oslo as their prime minister.

There is one photograph of Madame Eva Joly that delights egalitarians. It is January 23, 1998, and we see a reserved lady escorting a distinguished, grey-haired man into his residence in the 5th arrondissement. It is Joly arriving to conduct personally a search of the home of the president of the Constitutional Council, Roland Dumas.

To give the full measure to the difficulties faced by Joly: before her appointment as Investigating Magistrate in 1994, no corporate financial prosecution of any real weight had ever been brought before a French tribunal. There was neither resource nor inclination for such an enterprise.

To bring to justice some of the country's most powerful men and corporations, certain conditions must prevail: the perpetrators must be already vulnerable (usually when a belief in immunity makes them careless); tradition must be a shield for the magistrate, rather than a block; luck must provide opportunity; and, above all, you must have the character to want to act. Over many years, all these fell into place for Mme Joly.

Seven years ago, Eva Joly (you couldn't go around France calling yourself "Gro") finally made it as a Juge d'Instruction (Investigating Magistrate). Many of the world's legal systems harbour a subversive corner, protected by tradition, that caters for society's need to guarantee a last-ditch stand against tyranny. Such a system operated successfully in Spain against Pinochet; and we saw similar independent legal powers abused in the Lewinsky/Clinton affair. A Juge d'Instruction is one of them: a legal officer with unlimited powers of investigation and rigorously protected independence. Not even the president of the republic can fire a Juge d'Instruction. The establishment's one recourse, when investigations become too embarrassing, is to promote him, or her, out of office, normally a very successful ploy creating only minimal criticism. Mme Joly has refused that kind of promotion.

When Roland Dumas, who denies the allegations, was preparing to face the court, I met Eva Joly in Paris. She received me in the new headquarters of the Investigating Magistrates close to metro L'Opéra. There is a certain symbolism in the recent removal of this department from the Palais de Justice, where it formerly occupied a few cubbyholes. For all its intimidating exterior, the Palais de Justice is not secure. Joly's office in the Palais was burgled more than once.

The new spacious offices are protected by surveillance cameras, metal detectors and an armed policeman with his copy of Joly's book, Notre Affaire à Tous (Everybody's Business - a reference to the degree fiscal fraud affects us all). "I haven't had the chance to ask her to autograph it yet," the policeman told me. Joly currently enjoys that rarest of honours in France: the hero worship of cops... well, some of them, at any rate.

Inherently democratic (and still short of staff), Joly herself came down to the lobby to escort me back to her office. She wore a bright, sky-blue suit, very unmagisterial. You would have guessed an executive of a fashionable corporation. She is 57. It is only recently, she confided, that she has had the confidence to discard the traditional authoritarian black garb of the lawyer. She speaks with careful precision, but without the theatrical gravity one expects from lawyers, nor do you get any sense of a lawyer's perpetual calculation. The character that comes through is almost neighbourly - a confident, candid person, but not lacking in prudence.

It's hard to know what the Joly family was thinking of, taking a 20-year-old Scandinavian into a family where there was a 21-year-old son. Aristocratic inattention might explain it. "In opening their doors to me," she agrees, "the Joly family were perhaps playing with fire." Very soon, the scion declared he would marry Gro Farseth. They disinherited him. Values must be maintained.

Initially, the young couple went through the usual impecunious struggle with first one child and then another coming in close succession. He studied to be a doctor; she worked as a secretary in a factory.

There was an early manifestation of Eva's determination to see justice done. To the astonishment of her employer, the young foreigner decided that the working conditions in the factory were "not worthy". She formed a branch of the CFDT (Christian trade union). "We have nourished a viper in our bosom," wailed her boss, rather elegantly.

But the successful crusader never allows a passion for justice to carry her to self-destructive extremes. "I found," she says, "that trades union organisation was too much for me while at the same time having to hold down a job and take care of children in a sixth-storey walk-up". The time for action was not yet ripe.

In 1973, her husband moved to a new practice in Essonne, to the south of Paris. By then, Eva had a law degree and quickly found work in a psychiatric hospital in the region. Her role was to deal with the legal problems of the mentally disturbed - for instance, a patient who (against Eva's advice) made a generous gift of all his money to his family and then found himself abandoned as his relatives grabbed the money and emigrated to Canada. The hospital had, she says, a congenial atmosphere of dedicated public service. "I received my political education there." She dealt compassionately with socially dysfunctional creatures, recognised as such and treated accordingly - unlike the socially dysfunctional high-level thieves she was to deal with later, whom tradition protected from either treatment or restraint.

But she was still a long way from the Palais de Justice. Being a foreigner, there was little possibility of making her way up the judicial ladder. She would be considered by the establishment as having "an insufficiency of general French culture". To break through that barrier would require a small miracle. Joly does not believe in miracles. But when I put to her the Shakespearean proposition that "There is a tide in the affairs of men which, taken at the flood", she admitted this much: "When you work hard, at one point a kind of resonance, a harmony, is created and there comes the moment when 'the mayonnaise takes'."

In 1981, the French government decided to hold a one-off open competition for entry to the magistrature. French culture would not be crucial. Not only was it an opening to the magistrature, it was an accelerated one for those with 10 years' legal experience, which Joly now had. After a couple of months at magistrates' school, the successful applicant would go to work in the courts immediately. Suddenly, Eva Joly found herself assistant to the public prosecutor of Orléans.

The first day was not propitious. When she greeted her new boss with a civil "Bonjour, Monsieur", he snapped: "Please, Madame, in the time, which I hope will be short, that we will spend together, I ask you to address me as Monsieur le Procureur. We have not spent time together taking care of pigs." She left, disenchanted, after two years, convinced that the main preoccupations of her superior "were problems of parking his car".

She gave up the magistrature and got a position with the CIRI, in the ministry of finance, in Paris. She was already 46, with apparently nothing but a routine future in store. But she entered the ministry at a time when the government was focusing on the industrial reconstruction of France, a noble national enterprise within which many a maggot was to find nourishment. Her job concerned "businesses in difficulties" - ie, bankruptcies - which were then reaching dizzying proportions in France. "I was given genuine responsibility and this gave me wings," she says.

After three years of desk duty, she was back in the magistrature. Appointed a Juge d'Instruction concerned with financial crimes, she moved to the Palais de Justice. "It was only seven years ago," she said, "and I was a million miles from imagining what I would discover. I still had confidence in the institutions." She assumed that her resources at the Palais would be as grandiose as that intimidating building. "What I found was a poky little office," she said, "with an old Olivetti typewriter. There was no fax and no Minitel [the French computer linked to the telephone system]. I had one clerk.

"No one said that you cannot deal with an affair involving great international banks, concerning tens of billions of francs, with one judge in a chambre de bonne, a ballpoint pen and a copy of the Penal Code. The contrast with the ministry of finance was shocking. I discovered that one of the most serious cases had been on the books for five years. At the CIRI, I had worked with people who could have cleared it up in 10 days." During the course of her investigation into the Elf case, she had to deal with more than 60 lawyers, studying 50 volumes of evidence.

"I dumped the typewriter in a cupboard. My daughter [now a doctor] had a basic computer bought from the supermarket; I borrowed it. I installed the Minitel from my own home. I bought a fax with my own money, not for comfort but efficiency - the Penal Code permits the use of fax in place of expensive registered letter," she says. "I sold my old car to an architect and then persuaded him to redesign my office. The other magistrates were conquered, amused."

Joly soon discovered the dubious worth of amused admiration: it vanished when she showed her combative side. The only hope for obtaining any real improvement in her working conditions was to go public. She took part in a short TV documentary exposing the farcical lack of resources granted to fiscal investigators. It created a sensation. Then she gave a long interview to an economic journal, La Tribune, which appeared the very day she descended on Crédit Lyonnais with a search warrant. Horror at the Palais! But there was serious panic when the Garde des Sceaux (minister for justice), Elisabeth Guigou, made her displeasure at such publicity tactics known in an unsisterly interview in the newspaper Le Figaro. Joly was summoned before the vice-president of the courts and warned that she was overstepping the line (actually, he said she was walking outside the pedestrian crossing).

Jacques Chirac's government learned of the serious problems at the state-owned Crédit Lyonnais in October 1995. Although the losses, attributed to bad management, were estimated at a staggering £12.8bn, no one believed there would be a criminal prosecution. Financial mismanagement was not thought to be a criminal offence. But this was not a belief shared by Mme Joly. The taxpayer had to meet these losses. The bank was headed by Jean-Yves Haberer, a high-flyer in the financial world and at one time fellow student of President Chirac at the elite Ecole National d'Administration (ENA). Haberer's most bizarre and ultimately fatal decision was, in 1991, to lend a dodgy Italian financier, Giancarlo Parretti, money to buy the Hollywood studio, MGM. After a number of farcical manoeuvres, which included giving Dustin Hoffman a six-figure rubber cheque, Crédit Lyonnais had to move in and become a working partner of MGM. It soon had to sell the studio at a huge loss. The bank became known as Débit Lyonnais.

Eva Joly will not, on principle, discuss any of her cases, past or current, but it is known that after a year of investigations at Crédit Lyonnais, when her team was getting uncomfortably close to essentials, there was a mysterious fire at the bank. More than 2,500 files relating to the case were destroyed. This is the kind of setback Mme Joly and her colleagues take in their stride. The Crédit Lyonnais case still lumbers on, spawning other investigations that now suggest a presidential cover-up.

She continued with her campaign for better facilities and suddenly one evening the president of the courts paid a visit to her chambre de bonne. "He had probably never been in that part of the building," she says. Fellow magistrates had expressed approval for her stand, but none of them turned up for the confrontation with the president. "Magistrates prefer more velvety tête-à-têtes." By this time, Joly had a valuable new colleague, another Juge d'Instruction, Laurence Vichnievsky. If the men chose diplomatic absence, the two women were not intimidated in their confrontation with the president.

From that day everything changed. "Suddenly, there was nothing more urgent than to create a financial centre." That was only three years ago. Joly and Vichnievsky found themselves with a new HQ. They also established contact with a like-minded magistrate in a crucial financial area - Switzerland.

Changes were already taking place in France that help explain Eva Joly's success. Following the economic crisis of the 80s and the increase in bankruptcy frauds, a new law on bankruptcy was passed. The role of the courts was reinforced. There was a new breed of lawyers and there was also a new generation of better-informed police; the economic crisis had attracted police with more diplomas than the earlier ones. The commissaire who handled the Elf case was a product of St Cyr (an elite academy for the military and gendarmerie), and only 29 years old. But one vital factor was for her to have, at a crucial moment, a colleague of similar resolution and courage in Laurence Vichnievsky.

The main facts of the Elf case are now in the open. There are many strands. The former French foreign minister is not only accused of accepting kickbacks indirectly from the bagman of the affair, a former director of Elf-Aquitaine now said to be in hiding in the Philippines, but is also accused of having inexplicably (at the time) reversed a government embargo on arms sales to Taiwan and encouraged the sale of frigates to go through (which involved generous comissions for some). Elf was also involved in this affair. And so was Christine Deviers-Joncour, Dumas's mistress and Elf's favourite lobbyist. Elf allegedly gave her a company credit line of £20,000 a month and a £1.7m apartment on the Left Bank for entertainment. Joly and Vichnievsky allege that she passed on expensive "gifts" to Dumas. The 53-year-old Mme Deviers-Joncour has now become a notorious performer on French TV, following the publication of her memoirs called, The Whore Of The Republic.

"To deal with an affair such as Elf," Joly says, "common sense suggests the mobilisation of dozens of policemen, the collaboration of public services such as the secret service, of tax officials, and that all the weight of the republic be brought to bear on foreign countries who refuse to aid us. But the state, that is you and I, and all taxpayers, allow ourselves to be robbed without reacting."

What is behind this curious laxity? Joly says that the intrinsic problem is that high-class financial crimes "were not really considered a crime". There was also the undermining tradition that those at a certain level of power and influence were above the law. "The great fiscal frauds involved very powerful and respectable people who were convinced - and still are - that they are entitled to be above the law. There is a culture of passe droit. That the law is not equal for everybody. Because you are a minister or a high-ranking personage, you could have immunity. In Norway, there is not this submission to power, to the establishment. Here, there is a notion that this kind of thing does not concern Justice [the courts]. There is also a tradition of 'proximity' regarding government and the law. Some of the attorney generals in France were collaborators of ministers and the president.

"But I realised I would have to treat financial scandals like any other crime. Someone robs a petrol station. He is pursued methodically; the culprit is caught, his home searched and he is sentenced to 10 years. But when the head of an organisation steals a hundred million, Justice surrounds itself with precautionary luxuries. There are prolonged preliminary enquiries, interviews, interminable strings of 'experts'."

Joly was determined, so far as possible, to speed up the process. "We investigated," she said, "put a tail on people and searched premises, no matter whose." In the past year alone, Joly took part in 40 searches. In five years, she has dealt with 200 cases.

What was the initial reaction when she started to put a tail on distinguished citizens as if they were common thieves, and went rummaging through their private property? At first, they blamed it on her "Protestantism" and her nationality.

"People tried to get the public to believe that, because I was a Norwegian and a Protestant, I did not understand anything of what was going on in France," she says. "Actually, I have little contact with religion. This line worked for a while because most people did not want to believe that you can't always have confidence in elected chiefs."

There were also indignant articles in the press, of a kind familiar to us in Britain, about the cruel treatment of wealthy offenders whose "poor health" becomes a major issue. Dumas succeeded in putting off his court appearance for months on these grounds. Then the attacks took a more sophisticated and deadly turn. "They began to say that the independent powers of the Juge d'Instruction were an attack on liberty, that the judges were dangerous. There was a public debate, which totally falsified the issues. It nearly succeeded."

To begin with, public opinion was not always 100% behind her. The public and the media can be indulgent towards popular figures. One example is Bernard Tapie. A rather reckless businessman and one-time minister for urban affairs, he was briefly revered as the owner of European Cup winners, Olympique Marseille. He became bankrupt (he owed Crédit Lyonnais more than £100m) and went to prison for corruption. How supportive was the media in these affairs, I asked.

For the first time, Joly becomes extremely guarded. She is only too well aware that taking on the press can be a losing game. She hints at disappointment, not just with the popular press (although in France they are nothing like as muckily "popular" as our crowd), but also with the more responsible papers. She rarely responds to such attacks, but when one newspaper, alluding to prosecutor Kenneth Starr's investigations into the Clinton/Lewinsky affair in the US, carried the headline, "EVA - OUR STARR IN STILETTOS", and Joly felt it implied that she had suspects beaten up, she fought back. The story was based on a mythical remark, supposedly made to a police escort: "Why did you bring him to me so fresh?" Joly invoked her right of reply. Sternly quoting the legal reference - article 13 of the law of July 29, 1881 - she took apart these fictions about "this blonde capable of humiliating [people] and making them tremble". "I felt I must answer. It was the messenger they wanted killed."

So, are the media more supportive now? All she would say to this is: "The newspapers still don't adequately cover this issue."

The next day, Saturday, I waited for her in a cafe across from the Palais de Justice. When on weekend duty, she is obliged to work again from the Palais. Any crime of a serious nature taking place that weekend in Paris, she and her clerk had to deal with. As she crossed the road, I noted she had reverted to black. With her was a tall, athletic man in running shoes. He was attentive, but with the air of a discreet servant rather than a friend. He showed no sign of wanting to take part in our conversation, but every now and then he spoke into his coat collar.

Fifty yards away, another man was putting on one of those performances of taking no interest in us, but he also nosed his collar at intervals. At one point, she made a puzzling remark: "I got my first new car in 1996, but I still have not driven it." I realised then why she never managed to drive her new car. She has permanent, around-the-clock driver-bodyguards. At crucial moments in her investigations, her office in the Palais was burgled, drawers ransacked or locks tampered with. There was clear intimidation in the absence of any attempt to conceal traces of forced entry. There have also been death threats.

When she went jogging the next morning at 8am, the tall discreet man jogged alongside, a weapon somehow concealed in his jogging gear. The other drove the car. She trotted around the grounds, bereft of any vanity aids. So I was surprised when she agreed to be photographed panting around in sweaty gear. She admitted later that it was a deliberate decision. This magistrate has another mission - to demonstrate to other women that life is by no means over at 57. This is one of the reasons she dares nowadays to dress colourfully, to declare her femininity even on duty. "I lost a lot of time to get to this point," she admitted.

Gradually, there was a transformation in her manner, a definite shift from jurisprudential objectivity to bubbling, subterranean exuberance, hinting at satisfaction with the joys of life. Now that she is - at least for the moment - master of her trade, such satisfaction would be understandable. But a recent long holiday in the heartstopping beauty and purity of the fjords of her native Norway might have contributed to her joie de vivre.

What does her family-in-law now think of little Gro Farseth? There appears to have been something of a reconciliation. "They think it is funny that I am a judge, but some of the family still think it is not right that a Norwegian-born person should be judging French people."

"The one achievement is that it is now more difficult to suppress cases... But we are still like sheriffs in those westerns, where you chase the bad men to the Rio Grande and they just ride across the river and we can't follow." Global crime, she believes, requires a global force. To create one will be her next crusade
