fields.bodyText: For the past two weeks, Paris has been witnessing the spectacle of a former foreign minister, Roland Dumas,appearing in the dock to answer charges of corruption. There is some £6m in kickbacks and a mistress at the heart of these charges, but what has devastated the French establishment is that Dumas was, at the time of the original accusation in 1997, France's highest legal authority, the president of the Constitutional Council. He finally resigned last year. What law officer could have dared to initiate and obstinately bring to its awful conclusion an investigation targeting the highest legal authority in the land? Well, it wasn't a Frenchman. It was, in fact, a former Norwegian au pair, Gro Eva Farseth, who married into a distinguished French family and then appalled them by transforming herself into the all-powerful Investigating Magistrate, Madame Eva Joly. As such, she has become the scourge of France's untouchables - the business moguls and political leaders. A co-defendant in the Dumas affair is the former president of the oil giant Elf-Aquitaine, one-time head of the state-owned railway network, SNCF. But this case forms only a small part of Eva Joly's spectacular reach. She was also instrumental in uncovering the Crédit Lyonnais banking scandal, described in 1997 as the world's biggest financial disaster. Her investigations into the Elf affair uncovered a political slush fund that went beyond the borders of France to touch Germany's former chancellor, Helmut Kohl. And then there was the affair of the frigates sold to Taiwan... All this was achieved in a post that Eva Joly has held for only seven years. It all started more than 30 years ago, when the 20-year-old Gro Eva Farseth travelled to Paris from her home in Oslo to study French. Already on the train down, there was a hint of the determination and steadiness of purpose to come: instead of preparing herself for Parisian life with Elle magazine or Paris Match, she passed the journey studying French verbs. She very soon found a position as au pair in an urban palace by the Luxembourg gardens, home of the Joly family. This was a family that had for generations contributed soldiers, scientists and academics to the glory of their country. When Gro was courteously permitted by her employers to dine with them, she became privy to the etiquette that distinguishes such a family of true taste from that of - well, plebeian is too base a concept - let's say the nouveau riche. As you stir your coffee, for instance, the ear must not be offended by the sound of the spoon touching the bottom. Nor must you ever cut your lettuce; it must be folded. Mlle Farseth caught on quickly that observance of a dozen or so rules would see you comfortably through the best drawing rooms. But what this condescending family of distinguished lineage did not realise about Growas that, while she might be what they would call brute de coffrage (unpolished), she had powerful values of her own. The most deadly proved to be an inherent lack of respect for hierarchy. There is no aristocracy in Norway. Gro is the daughter of a carpenter, and her family lived at one point in the same apartment block in Oslo as their prime minister. There is one photograph of Madame Eva Joly that delights egalitarians. It is January 23, 1998, and we see a reserved lady escorting a distinguished, grey-haired man into his residence in the 5th arrondissement. It is Joly arriving to conduct personally a search of the home of the president of the Constitutional Council, Roland Dumas. To give the full measure to the difficulties faced by Joly: before her appointment as Investigating Magistrate in 1994, no corporate financial prosecution of any real weight had ever been brought before a French tribunal. There was neither resource nor inclination for such an enterprise. To bring to justice some of the country's most powerful men and corporations, certain conditions must prevail: the perpetrators must be already vulnerable (usually when a belief in immunity makes them careless); tradition must be a shield for the magistrate, rather than a block; luck must provide opportunity; and, above all, you must have the character to want to act. Over many years, all these fell into place for Mme Joly. Seven years ago, Eva Joly (you couldn't go around France calling yourself "Gro") finally made it as a Juge d'Instruction (Investigating Magistrate). Many of the world's legal systems harbour a subversive corner, protected by tradition, that caters for society's need to guarantee a last-ditch stand against tyranny. Such a system operated successfully in Spain against Pinochet; and we saw similar independent legal powers abused in the Lewinsky/Clinton affair. A Juge d'Instruction is one of them: a legal officer with unlimited powers of investigation and rigorously protected independence. Not even the president of the republic can fire a Juge d'Instruction. The establishment's one recourse, when investigations become too embarrassing, is to promote him, or her, out of office, normally a very successful ploy creating only minimal criticism. Mme Joly has refused that kind of promotion. When Roland Dumas, who denies the allegations, was preparing to face the court, I met Eva Joly in Paris. She received me in the new headquarters of the Investigating Magistrates close to metro L'Opéra. There is a certain symbolism in the recent removal of this department from the Palais de Justice, where it formerly occupied a few cubbyholes. For all its intimidating exterior, the Palais de Justice is not secure. Joly's office in the Palais was burgled more than once. The new spacious offices are protected by surveillance cameras, metal detectors and an armed policeman with his copy of Joly's book, Notre Affaire à Tous (Everybody's Business - a reference to the degree fiscal fraud affects us all). "I haven't had the chance to ask her to autograph it yet," the policeman told me. Joly currently enjoys that rarest of honours in France: the hero worship of cops... well, some of them, at any rate. Inherently democratic (and still short of staff), Joly herself came down to the lobby to escort me back to her office. She wore a bright, sky-blue suit, very unmagisterial. You would have guessed an executive of a fashionable corporation. She is 57. It is only recently, she confided, that she has had the confidence to discard the traditional authoritarian black garb of the lawyer. She speaks with careful precision, but without the theatrical gravity one expects from lawyers, nor do you get any sense of a lawyer's perpetual calculation. The character that comes through is almost neighbourly - a confident, candid person, but not lacking in prudence. It's hard to know what the Joly family was thinking of, taking a 20-year-old Scandinavian into a family where there was a 21-year-old son. Aristocratic inattention might explain it. "In opening their doors to me," she agrees, "the Joly family were perhaps playing with fire." Very soon, the scion declared he would marry Gro Farseth. They disinherited him. Values must be maintained. Initially, the young couple went through the usual impecunious struggle with first one child and then another coming in close succession. He studied to be a doctor; she worked as a secretary in a factory. There was an early manifestation of Eva's determination to see justice done. To the astonishment of her employer, the young foreigner decided that the working conditions in the factory were "not worthy". She formed a branch of the CFDT (Christian trade union). "We have nourished a viper in our bosom," wailed her boss, rather elegantly. But the successful crusader never allows a passion for justice to carry her to self-destructive extremes. "I found," she says, "that trades union organisation was too much for me while at the same time having to hold down a job and take care of children in a sixth-storey walk-up". The time for action was not yet ripe. In 1973, her husband moved to a new practice in Essonne, to the south of Paris. By then, Eva had a law degree and quickly found work in a psychiatric hospital in the region. Her role was to deal with the legal problems of the mentally disturbed - for instance, a patient who (against Eva's advice) made a generous gift of all his money to his family and then found himself abandoned as his relatives grabbed the money and emigrated to Canada. The hospital had, she says, a congenial atmosphere of dedicated public service. "I received my political education there." She dealt compassionately with socially dysfunctional creatures, recognised as such and treated accordingly - unlike the socially dysfunctional high-level thieves she was to deal with later, whom tradition protected from either treatment or restraint. But she was still a long way from the Palais de Justice. Being a foreigner, there was little possibility of making her way up the judicial ladder. She would be considered by the establishment as having "an insufficiency of general French culture". To break through that barrier would require a small miracle. Joly does not believe in miracles. But when I put to her the Shakespearean proposition that "There is a tide in the affairs of men which, taken at the flood", she admitted this much: "When you work hard, at one point a kind of resonance, a harmony, is created and there comes the moment when 'the mayonnaise takes'." In 1981, the French government decided to hold a one-off open competition for entry to the magistrature. French culture would not be crucial. Not only was it an opening to the magistrature, it was an accelerated one for those with 10 years' legal experience, which Joly now had. After a couple of months at magistrates' school, the successful applicant would go to work in the courts immediately. Suddenly, Eva Joly found herself assistant to the public prosecutor of Orléans. The first day was not propitious. When she greeted her new boss with a civil "Bonjour, Monsieur", he snapped: "Please, Madame, in the time, which I hope will be short, that we will spend together, I ask you to address me as Monsieur le Procureur. We have not spent time together taking care of pigs." She left, disenchanted, after two years, convinced that the main preoccupations of her superior "were problems of parking his car". She gave up the magistrature and got a position with the CIRI, in the ministry of finance, in Paris. She was already 46, with apparently nothing but a routine future in store. But she entered the ministry at a time when the government was focusing on the industrial reconstruction of France, a noble national enterprise within which many a maggot was to find nourishment. Her job concerned "businesses in difficulties" - ie, bankruptcies - which were then reaching dizzying proportions in France. "I was given genuine responsibility and this gave me wings," she says. After three years of desk duty, she was back in the magistrature. Appointed a Juge d'Instruction concerned with financial crimes, she moved to the Palais de Justice. "It was only seven years ago," she said, "and I was a million miles from imagining what I would discover. I still had confidence in the institutions." She assumed that her resources at the Palais would be as grandiose as that intimidating building. "What I found was a poky little office," she said, "with an old Olivetti typewriter. There was no fax and no Minitel [the French computer linked to the telephone system]. I had one clerk. "No one said that you cannot deal with an affair involving great international banks, concerning tens of billions of francs, with one judge in a chambre de bonne, a ballpoint pen and a copy of the Penal Code. The contrast with the ministry of finance was shocking. I discovered that one of the most serious cases had been on the books for five years. At the CIRI, I had worked with people who could have cleared it up in 10 days." During the course of her investigation into the Elf case, she had to deal with more than 60 lawyers, studying 50 volumes of evidence. "I dumped the typewriter in a cupboard. My daughter [now a doctor] had a basic computer bought from the supermarket; I borrowed it. I installed the Minitel from my own home. I bought a fax with my own money, not for comfort but efficiency - the Penal Code permits the use of fax in place of expensive registered letter," she says. "I sold my old car to an architect and then persuaded him to redesign my office. The other magistrates were conquered, amused." Joly soon discovered the dubious worth of amused admiration: it vanished when she showed her combative side. The only hope for obtaining any real improvement in her working conditions was to go public. She took part in a short TV documentary exposing the farcical lack of resources granted to fiscal investigators. It created a sensation. Then she gave a long interview to an economic journal, La Tribune, which appeared the very day she descended on Crédit Lyonnais with a search warrant. Horror at the Palais! But there was serious panic when the Garde des Sceaux (minister for justice), Elisabeth Guigou, made her displeasure at such publicity tactics known in an unsisterly interview in the newspaper Le Figaro. Joly was summoned before the vice-president of the courts and warned that she was overstepping the line (actually, he said she was walking outside the pedestrian crossing). Jacques Chirac's government learned of the serious problems at the state-owned Crédit Lyonnais in October 1995. Although the losses, attributed to bad management, were estimated at a staggering £12.8bn, no one believed there would be a criminal prosecution. Financial mismanagement was not thought to be a criminal offence. But this was not a belief shared by Mme Joly. The taxpayer had to meet these losses. The bank was headed by Jean-Yves Haberer, a high-flyer in the financial world and at one time fellow student of President Chirac at the elite Ecole National d'Administration (ENA). Haberer's most bizarre and ultimately fatal decision was, in 1991, to lend a dodgy Italian financier, Giancarlo Parretti, money to buy the Hollywood studio, MGM. After a number of farcical manoeuvres, which included giving Dustin Hoffman a six-figure rubber cheque, Crédit Lyonnais had to move in and become a working partner of MGM. It soon had to sell the studio at a huge loss. The bank became known as Débit Lyonnais. Eva Joly will not, on principle, discuss any of her cases, past or current, but it is known that after a year of investigations at Crédit Lyonnais, when her team was getting uncomfortably close to essentials, there was a mysterious fire at the bank. More than 2,500 files relating to the case were destroyed. This is the kind of setback Mme Joly and her colleagues take in their stride. The Crédit Lyonnais case still lumbers on, spawning other investigations that now suggest a presidential cover-up. She continued with her campaign for better facilities and suddenly one evening the president of the courts paid a visit to her chambre de bonne. "He had probably never been in that part of the building," she says. Fellow magistrates had expressed approval for her stand, but none of them turned up for the confrontation with the president. "Magistrates prefer more velvety tête-à-têtes." By this time, Joly had a valuable new colleague, another Juge d'Instruction, Laurence Vichnievsky. If the men chose diplomatic absence, the two women were not intimidated in their confrontation with the president. From that day everything changed. "Suddenly, there was nothing more urgent than to create a financial centre." That was only three years ago. Joly and Vichnievsky found themselves with a new HQ. They also established contact with a like-minded magistrate in a crucial financial area - Switzerland. Changes were already taking place in France that help explain Eva Joly's success. Following the economic crisis of the 80s and the increase in bankruptcy frauds, a new law on bankruptcy was passed. The role of the courts was reinforced. There was a new breed of lawyers and there was also a new generation of better-informed police; the economic crisis had attracted police with more diplomas than the earlier ones. The commissaire who handled the Elf case was a product of St Cyr (an elite academy for the military and gendarmerie), and only 29 years old. But one vital factor was for her to have, at a crucial moment, a colleague of similar resolution and courage in Laurence Vichnievsky. The main facts of the Elf case are now in the open. There are many strands. The former French foreign minister is not only accused of accepting kickbacks indirectly from the bagman of the affair, a former director of Elf-Aquitaine now said to be in hiding in the Philippines, but is also accused of having inexplicably (at the time) reversed a government embargo on arms sales to Taiwan and encouraged the sale of frigates to go through (which involved generous comissions for some). Elf was also involved in this affair. And so was Christine Deviers-Joncour, Dumas's mistress and Elf's favourite lobbyist. Elf allegedly gave her a company credit line of £20,000 a month and a £1.7m apartment on the Left Bank for entertainment. Joly and Vichnievsky allege that she passed on expensive "gifts" to Dumas. The 53-year-old Mme Deviers-Joncour has now become a notorious performer on French TV, following the publication of her memoirs called, The Whore Of The Republic. "To deal with an affair such as Elf," Joly says, "common sense suggests the mobilisation of dozens of policemen, the collaboration of public services such as the secret service, of tax officials, and that all the weight of the republic be brought to bear on foreign countries who refuse to aid us. But the state, that is you and I, and all taxpayers, allow ourselves to be robbed without reacting." What is behind this curious laxity? Joly says that the intrinsic problem is that high-class financial crimes "were not really considered a crime". There was also the undermining tradition that those at a certain level of power and influence were above the law. "The great fiscal frauds involved very powerful and respectable people who were convinced - and still are - that they are entitled to be above the law. There is a culture of passe droit. That the law is not equal for everybody. Because you are a minister or a high-ranking personage, you could have immunity. In Norway, there is not this submission to power, to the establishment. Here, there is a notion that this kind of thing does not concern Justice [the courts]. There is also a tradition of 'proximity' regarding government and the law. Some of the attorney generals in France were collaborators of ministers and the president. "But I realised I would have to treat financial scandals like any other crime. Someone robs a petrol station. He is pursued methodically; the culprit is caught, his home searched and he is sentenced to 10 years. But when the head of an organisation steals a hundred million, Justice surrounds itself with precautionary luxuries. There are prolonged preliminary enquiries, interviews, interminable strings of 'experts'." Joly was determined, so far as possible, to speed up the process. "We investigated," she said, "put a tail on people and searched premises, no matter whose." In the past year alone, Joly took part in 40 searches. In five years, she has dealt with 200 cases. What was the initial reaction when she started to put a tail on distinguished citizens as if they were common thieves, and went rummaging through their private property? At first, they blamed it on her "Protestantism" and her nationality. "People tried to get the public to believe that, because I was a Norwegian and a Protestant, I did not understand anything of what was going on in France," she says. "Actually, I have little contact with religion. This line worked for a while because most people did not want to believe that you can't always have confidence in elected chiefs." There were also indignant articles in the press, of a kind familiar to us in Britain, about the cruel treatment of wealthy offenders whose "poor health" becomes a major issue. Dumas succeeded in putting off his court appearance for months on these grounds. Then the attacks took a more sophisticated and deadly turn. "They began to say that the independent powers of the Juge d'Instruction were an attack on liberty, that the judges were dangerous. There was a public debate, which totally falsified the issues. It nearly succeeded." To begin with, public opinion was not always 100% behind her. The public and the media can be indulgent towards popular figures. One example is Bernard Tapie. A rather reckless businessman and one-time minister for urban affairs, he was briefly revered as the owner of European Cup winners, Olympique Marseille. He became bankrupt (he owed Crédit Lyonnais more than £100m) and went to prison for corruption. How supportive was the media in these affairs, I asked. For the first time, Joly becomes extremely guarded. She is only too well aware that taking on the press can be a losing game. She hints at disappointment, not just with the popular press (although in France they are nothing like as muckily "popular" as our crowd), but also with the more responsible papers. She rarely responds to such attacks, but when one newspaper, alluding to prosecutor Kenneth Starr's investigations into the Clinton/Lewinsky affair in the US, carried the headline, "EVA - OUR STARR IN STILETTOS", and Joly felt it implied that she had suspects beaten up, she fought back. The story was based on a mythical remark, supposedly made to a police escort: "Why did you bring him to me so fresh?" Joly invoked her right of reply. Sternly quoting the legal reference - article 13 of the law of July 29, 1881 - she took apart these fictions about "this blonde capable of humiliating [people] and making them tremble". "I felt I must answer. It was the messenger they wanted killed." So, are the media more supportive now? All she would say to this is: "The newspapers still don't adequately cover this issue." The next day, Saturday, I waited for her in a cafe across from the Palais de Justice. When on weekend duty, she is obliged to work again from the Palais. Any crime of a serious nature taking place that weekend in Paris, she and her clerk had to deal with. As she crossed the road, I noted she had reverted to black. With her was a tall, athletic man in running shoes. He was attentive, but with the air of a discreet servant rather than a friend. He showed no sign of wanting to take part in our conversation, but every now and then he spoke into his coat collar. Fifty yards away, another man was putting on one of those performances of taking no interest in us, but he also nosed his collar at intervals. At one point, she made a puzzling remark: "I got my first new car in 1996, but I still have not driven it." I realised then why she never managed to drive her new car. She has permanent, around-the-clock driver-bodyguards. At crucial moments in her investigations, her office in the Palais was burgled, drawers ransacked or locks tampered with. There was clear intimidation in the absence of any attempt to conceal traces of forced entry. There have also been death threats. When she went jogging the next morning at 8am, the tall discreet man jogged alongside, a weapon somehow concealed in his jogging gear. The other drove the car. She trotted around the grounds, bereft of any vanity aids. So I was surprised when she agreed to be photographed panting around in sweaty gear. She admitted later that it was a deliberate decision. This magistrate has another mission - to demonstrate to other women that life is by no means over at 57. This is one of the reasons she dares nowadays to dress colourfully, to declare her femininity even on duty. "I lost a lot of time to get to this point," she admitted. Gradually, there was a transformation in her manner, a definite shift from jurisprudential objectivity to bubbling, subterranean exuberance, hinting at satisfaction with the joys of life. Now that she is - at least for the moment - master of her trade, such satisfaction would be understandable. But a recent long holiday in the heartstopping beauty and purity of the fjords of her native Norway might have contributed to her joie de vivre. What does her family-in-law now think of little Gro Farseth? There appears to have been something of a reconciliation. "They think it is funny that I am a judge, but some of the family still think it is not right that a Norwegian-born person should be judging French people." Eva Joly is under no illusion as to how successful this fight against global financial crime can be. She says only a tiny fraction of the crimes are being dealt with. "The one achievement is that it is now more difficult to suppress cases... But we are still like sheriffs in those westerns, where you chase the bad men to the Rio Grande and they just ride across the river and we can't follow." Global crime, she believes, requires a global force. To create one will be her next crusade  Notre Affaire à Tous, by Eva Joly, is published by Les Arenes, 33 rue Linné, Paris 5005, priced Fr99.

fields.headline: Getting the care targets right
fields.trailText: The Childcare Commission's recommendations include:
fields.body:
The Childcare Commission's recommendations include:

A children's centre in every area;

"Generous financial support" for family care by parents or other relatives for the first three years of a child's life, giving parents who cannot afford not to work the choice of caring for their own children in the early years;

Tax relief at the basic rate on up to £2,000 per year of childcare expenses per year;

Tax incentives to encourage employers to help their employees with childcare;

A new government department of work and family services with responsibility for all the work and family policies currently scattered across seven departments and driven through the Integrated Childcare System;

The right to return to work after the birth of a child extended from six to 12 months;

The right for parents to return to work on a part-time or flexible basis after the birth of their child;

A new "parent-time allowance", paid out of public funds, to enable parents to take their parental leave and fathers to take paternity leave;

Parent-time vouchers issued to new parents ensuring they know about and can take advantage of their right to three months parental leave;

A further education tax credit to help student parents with childcare costs;

More research on the childcare and family support needs of black and ethnic families and families with a disabled child leading to improved provision;

Funding and fast-track training programmes to develop a childcare workforce;

Regulation for nannies.

fields.headline: Unpaid taxes
fields.standfirst: The IR must do some self-assessing itself
fields.trailText: The IR must do some self-assessing itself
fields.body:
Enoch Powell used to look forward to the day each year when, as a citizen, he was required to pay his taxes. Not many people are as public-spirited as that. But they would accept that, if they have to pay tax, the process should be as simple and as painless as possible. That clearly hasn't been happening. Over one million people (out of 9.5m eligible taxpayers) had failed to meet Wednesday's deadline for filling in their self-assessment forms. They should have faced an automatic fine of £100 but there were so many of them that the Inland Revenue decided to extend the deadline.

It should do more than that. The IR clearly needs to simplify the forms to make it easier for taxpayers to fill them in. Ernst & Young, the accountants, reckon it would take a minimum of five hours for someone with the simplest of financial affairs to fill in the forms and up to 12 hours for the self-employed who have had more than one employer during the year. Peter Willey, of Ernst & Young observed: "It is just a nightmare. Self-assessment has been written for tax collectors, not taxpayers". But not, it seems, by collectors wanting to get money quickly.

To be fair, the tax forms have improved in recent years and part of the problem isn't the fault of the IR: it arises from the ludicrous complexity of Britain's tax system. Filling in the forms is more difficult for those who failed to do it by the end of September (until this date the revenue do the calculations for you). Some have found it easier to fill them in after talking over the phone to one of the surprisingly easily available IR advisers - though if the million people who haven't finished their forms all phone in at once it won't solve the problem.

What might solve it would be a much bigger effort to involve consumers. Perhaps a national competition should be held to find ways of simplifying the forms. Even better would be a serious attempt by the Treasury to simplify the tax system itself. This seems to be getting more complicated each year as the chancellor adds more incentives and offsets to a system that is so labyrinthine that hundreds of thousands of people don't even know that they are eligible for grants or reliefs. It may be a sign that the penny is beginning to drop that the revenue extended the deadline, thereby depriving itself of an extra £100m in late penalties. When the revenue starts to forgo money it is entitled to, it is a sure sign that something is wrong.

Some have found it easier to fill them in after talking over the phone to one of the surprisingly easily available IR advisers - though if the million people who haven't finished their forms all phone in at once it won't solve the problem. What might solve it would be a much bigger effort to involve consumers. Perhaps a national competition should be held to find ways of simplifying the forms. Even better would be a serious attempt by the Treasury to simplify the tax system itself. This seems to be getting more complicated each year as the chancellor adds more incentives and offsets to a system that is so labyrinthine that hundreds of thousands of people don't even know that they are eligible for grants or reliefs. It may be a sign that the penny is beginning to drop that the revenue extended the deadline, thereby depriving itself of an extra £100m in late penalties. When the revenue starts to forgo money it is entitled to, it is a sure sign that something is wrong.

fields.headline: The verdict on prisons
fields.trailText: I work at Feltham young offenders' institution and commend the Guardian on the series it has run on prisons during the past week (Behind bars, January 29 - February 2).
fields.body:
I work at Feltham young offenders' institution and commend the Guardian on the series it has run on prisons during the past week (Behind bars, January 29 - February 2). Prisoners and staff are a forgotten part of society, seemingly only newsworthy when something goes wrong. The south-east is facing a staffing crisis, as ministers and senior managers refuse to pay overtime or provide adequate pay awards. In 10 years we have not changed very much, except we have more prisoners and fewer operational staff. Well done to the Guardian, an excellent week's work.
Nigel Herring
Feltham

As a former governor of Grendon therapeutic prison, it is good to read that it prospers (Softly does it, February 2) but it does so without ministerial interest or encouragement. Grendon celebrated its 40th birthday last year with a conference. There was no ministerial presence, nor even a message of support from the home secretary.

When a second therapeutic prison was put out to tender, the prison department was not invited to tender. The accumulated knowledge and skills of the prison department's only sustained successful method of treatment were ignored and the venture handed to an American firm.
Michael Selby
Bristol

The series of articles on prisons made compelling reading. I congratulate your correspondents for the various stories that they so succinctly told.

The picture in Scotland is very different. Over the past six years I have noted a steady improvement in conditions for prisoners. In particular, prisoners on remand are beginning to enjoy the status they deserve, namely that they should have the best accommodation available, not the worst. Prison numbers have been steadying. Overcrowding is no longer the overwhelming problem it is for the prison service in England and Wales.

More still needs to be done for our young offenders, but there are clear signs that the Scottish prison service is beginning to get a much stronger handle on this problem, as it is with drug abuse and has done with its revised suicide strategy.
CB Fairweather
Chief inspector of prisons for Scotland

Jack Straw's proposals to "make the sentence fit the offender rather than the offence" are a deliberate attempt to mislead the public about the effectiveness of prison (Chief justice clashes with Straw on jail policy, February 1). As your powerful series has shown, prisoners lose not only their liberty, but their self-respect, jobs, housing and relationships. It is hardly surprising that 75% of the young people we lock up are reconvicted within two years.

Public confidence depends on effective and proportionate sentencing. To send someone to prison for petty theft, no matter how many times they have done it before, is a waste of taxpayers' money when there are so many constructive alternatives.
Tim Colbourne
London

Jack Straw is right to advocate the greater use of custodial sentences for persistent offenders. The evidence that "prison works" is overwhelming. From 1993 to 1998 the prison population rose by 51%, resulting in a fall in the crime rate of 21%, or about a million fewer crimes.

The lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, said in a radio interview that many things could be done without sending offenders to prison which provide better safeguards for the public. When challenged he could not identify one community-based programme proven to be more effective at protecting the public than a custodial sentence. His anti-prison ideology is dangerously ill-informed.
Peter Coad
Criminal Justice Association

fields.headline: Euro stir
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: My plan is to take Glenn to Paris for his birthday. I'm looking forward to showing him the Louvre - he's a very lucky boy; I was 26 before I saw that the Mona Lisa wasn't worth the wait in the queue.
fields.body:
Saturday, January 27, Ashby-de-la-Zouch

It is Glenn's birthday on Friday. Yes, the lad will be 14. Mohammed, whose brother works for Midland Main-line, gave me two Eurostar vouchers to Paris last week saying, "You use 'em, Aidy. I daren't leave the country. I'm frit that immigration won't let me back in."

I said, "Mohammed, you were born in the Leicester Royal Infirmary maternity unit, you have a strong Leicester accent, you cried when Martin O'Neill left Leicester City Football Club. Nobody could possibly question your English nationality."

"Oh, yeh," said Mohammed cynically. "And who was the only kid to be stopped at Dover when we come back from that school trip to France?"

I cast my mind back to that heady day when I became a European. I will never forget my first sight of la belle France. As the ferry prepared to dock, Miss Elf gathered her class of 30 around her on the vomit-stained deck and said, "Mes petits enfants, regardez vous la belle France, la crème de la crème, de la Continent". (Or words to that effect, diary. My French is a little rusty, as I rarely have occasion to use it.)

We lost precious time in France because Barry Kent tried to leap from the ferry on to the harbour wall before the docking procedure was quite finished. He wasn't in the water long, but by the time the gendarmes had finished their paperwork, a couple of hours had been lost.

On the coach, Miss Elf announced that, due to Barry Kent's foolhardy leap, there would now be no time for the planned visit to the war graves cemetery (we were doing a class project on first world war poetry). A few of the more sentimental girls wept, I recall, though Pandora was not among them. "Instead," she said, "we will sample French bread and French coffee, and we will visit a market and observe the care with which the French choose their fruit and vegetables."

When I returned home late that night, my mother was waiting for me in the car park of Neil Armstrong comprehensive. As I stepped off the coach, I said to her, "Maman, I have seen and tasted paradise. You must throw away your Maxwell House and your Mothers Pride thin-sliced and embrace the baguette and café au lait." I can't recall her exact words of reply, but they were said with a snarl.

Anyway, diary, what I said to Mohammed was, "It was your own fault you got stopped by immigration at Dover - you were openly smoking a Disque Bleu fag and you were only 12 years old."

Sunday, January 28

My plan is to take Glenn to Paris for his birthday. It is to be a surprise, so my preparations must be made behind his back. Tonight, I washed and ironed his least gangsterish-looking clothes and hid them in my wardrobe. There is nothing I can do about his hair or the Buffy The Vampire tattoo he's now got on his wrist, but with luck it will be cold and he'll have to roll down his sleeves. I'm looking forward to showing him the Louvre - he's a very lucky boy; I was 26 before I saw that the Mona Lisa wasn't worth the wait in the queue.

Tuesday, January 30

I was checking and re-checking my travel necessities list tonight. Two Eurostar tickets, travellers' cheques, Nurofen, map of Paris, French/English dictionary, passports, umbrella. There was something missing. Then the realisation hitme like an orange thrown by a toddler in a supermarket trolley: GLENN DOES NOT HAVE A PASSPORT!

Wednesday, January 31

Pandora has refused to help fast-track a passport for Glenn. I phoned Keith Vaz MP, but there was nobody available to take my call.

Adrian Mole: The Cappuccino Years is on BBC1 (not Scotland) on Fridays at 9.30pm.

webTitle: Obituary: Queen Marie José of Italy

fields.headline: Queen Marie José of Italy
fields.standfirst: The unlikely royal consort who plotted against Mussolini and wanted to shoot Hitler
fields.trailText: The unlikely royal consort who plotted against Mussolini and wanted to shoot Hitler.
fields.body:
Marie José, the last Queen of Italy, who has died in Geneva at the age of 94, was an independent-minded royal whose opposition to fascism might have offered a last chance to save the discredited House of Savoy and therefore the Italian monarchy. She was known as "the May Queen" because she and her husband, King Umberto II, reigned for just 27 days, from May 9 1946.

On June 2 that year, Italians voted in a referendum to abolish the monarchy, mindful of King Victor Emmanuel III's close association with fascism and the disasters it had brought on their country. Republicans won the vote by only a narrow margin and a plan, proposed by the philosopher Benedetto Croce, to replace Umberto with his infant son Victor Emmanuel, and have the beautiful and unconventional queen act as regent, might possibly have tipped the balance in favour of the monarchy.

The daughter of Albert I, King of the Belgians, Marie José was related through her Wittelsbach mother, Elizabeth, to Mad King Ludwig of Bavaria and to Empress Sissi of Austria. Herself of a free-thinking and artistic disposition, she found life in the rigidly regimented court of Savoy stiflingly dull.

A fairy-tale wedding at the Quirinale Palace in 1930 was arranged, more for the benefit of the fascist regime than for that of the monarchy. Though it produced four children, the union between the luminously beautiful young woman and the handsome Prince Umberto was only apparently happy. And Marie José's friendship with anti-fascist intellectuals poisoned relations with her difficult father-in-law. "You know, I don't have much to do with the House of Savoy," she confided to the journalist Indro Montanelli in 1940. "It's not a family, it's a Frigidaire."

Marie José took her royal duties seriously, serving for a while with the Red Cross in Libya. With the arrival of the second world war, she was the first - and only - member of the Savoys to appreciate that Mussolini was leading the country to ruin.

She made contact with opponents of the regime, holding a secret meeting with Croce under the guise of an archaeological visit to Pompeii, and with the allies via Monsignor Giovanni Battista Montini, the future Pope Paul VI. She was even in contact with the Italian resistance, whom she reportedly supplied with arms and money.

She appears to have been simultaneously attracted and repelled by Mussolini, who tolerated her political plotting as he judged it to be of no practical consequence. In a 1993 interview, she spoke of his magnetic physical presence and fierce temper. "He was a lion. I, too, am a lion. And we both feared one another."

There was no such sympathy for Hitler, who was struck by her beauty and complimented her on her eyes, "the colour of the German sky". She met him on a visit to Berchtesgaden in 1940 to plead for the release of food to the starving Belgians, and for a more humane treatment for her brother Leopold, who was confined to one of his castles. The answer, on all counts, was "Nein."

Having read Mein Kampf, Marie José appreciated what Hitler represented, and said she might have killed him if she had had a pistol. "I think I would have had the strength to do it," she said.

Following the abolition of the monarchy, she sailed to Portugal to await her husband. But in exile, the couple drifted apart, the ex-king remaining in Portugal, his consort living in Switzerland, ostensibly for health reasons.

A keen painter, competent pianist and chain-smoker, Marie José devoted her maturity to travel, and to writing books about the early Savoys. Like her father, who died in a climbing accident, she loved skiing and walking in the mountains. She was a refreshingly rebellious royal, who prized her own liberty and despised her husband's deference towards his father. "It seemed as though we were in China, with all that bowing," she remarked.

She did actually visit China, her reception by Mao earning her the epithet of the "communist queen." Her political views were not quite that radical, but she claimed to have learned socialism from her father, and they were sufficiently progressive to be out of tune with those of the rest of the Savoys.

The outpouring of sympathy prompted by the death of this maverick queen may hasten the end of the constitutional ban that prevents the male heirs of the Savoy family and their consorts from returning to Italy. There is, today, no reason to fear a monarchist challenge to the republican constitution and, therefore, no reason for the prohibition. Marie José herself returned for a visit in 1988, after the government ruled that a widow could not be considered a consort and lifted the ban.

Most of her Savoy relatives have done little to add lustre to the family reputation, and her son, Prince Victor Emmanuel, has often been his own worst enemy when it came to pleading his case with Italian public opinion.

Marie José was an eccentric acquisition to the Savoys, and gave Italians a glimpse of an alternative monarchy with a human face. For all her commitment to public service, however, she was almost certainly better off ruling only for a month. Being queen, she once remarked, is so boring.

She leaves four children, Maria Pia, Victor Emmanuel, Maria Gabriella and Maria Beatrice, and eight grandchildren.

Princess Marie José Charlotte Henrietta Gabriella of Saxe-Coburg, former Queen of Italy, born August 4 1906; died January 27 2001

fields.trailText: In a column headlined, To live and buy in LA, page 5, G2, January 15, we described English estate agents as "incorrigibly lazy" and said that they "do not work for their 2.5% cut". The accompanying photograph showed a "for sale" board advertising James Tyreman Estate Agents of Harrogate. We wish to make it clear that the above comments did not relate to the professional services provided by James Tyreman. We have no reason to believe that this firm of estate agents is anything less than professional in its conduct and we understand that the charges are certainly not a "2.5% cut". We wish to apologise for any distress that may have been caused.

In a column headlined, To live and buy in LA, page 5, G2, January 15, we described English estate agents as "incorrigibly lazy" and said that they "do not work for their 2.5% cut". The accompanying photograph showed a "for sale" board advertising James Tyreman Estate Agents of Harrogate. We wish to make it clear that the above comments did not relate to the professional services provided by James Tyreman. We have no reason to believe that this firm of estate agents is anything less than professional in its conduct and we understand that the charges are certainly not a "2.5% cut". We wish to apologise for any distress that may have been caused.

In one of the articles in our prisons series, page 16, G2, February 1 (Within these walls), we described Michael Howard as home secretary in Margaret Thatcher's government. In fact, he was home secretary under John Major.

The flower displayed on page 14 of last week's Saturday Review was not the Safflower, Carthamus tinctorius, as the caption said. Nor was it Pheasant's Eye, Adonis aestivalis, as the text said. It was, in fact, the Yellow Pheasant's Eye, Adonis vengalis.

Our graphic showing how a toilet flushes, page 52 Education, January 30, was simplified in an attempt to make it comprehensible to the five-year-old audience for whom it was intended. However, in simplifying it we ended up with a toilet which, if real, would probably leak perpetually - or worse. The system it was attempting to demonstrate is not, in any case, the one generally used in Britain.

The film still of Mel Gibson exercising, across pages 12 and 13, Friday Review, yesterday, was flipped contrary to the Guardian's policy. His Nike swoosh gave the game away.

fields.headline: Word association
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... the need to avoid racial stereotypes
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... the need to avoid racial stereotypes
fields.body:
Just over two weeks ago one of the Guardian's regular columnists used part of her page in G2, the tabloid second section of the Guardian, to express her views about the Ang Lee film Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, a film which she disliked so intensely, she told her readers, that she walked out before the end.

Her opinion of the film was totally at odds with that of the Guardian's film critic, who could hardly have been more enthusiastic, giving it five stars and starting his review with the words, "The year 2001 has got off to the best start possible with this fantastic film."

The columnist told me that what she intended to argue was that the film was no more than "a B-list blockbuster" which, had it been in English, without the screen of a foreign language and the "art-house veneer", would have been seen as such. She was attacking, or thought she was attacking, the racism implicit in the prevailing liberal view of it which suspended proper judgment and sought to raise it to the status of a masterpiece, a view which she felt to be deeply patronising.

However, the way in which she attempted to express these views in the column brought accusations of racism, or at least of gross insensitivity, directed at her. Speaking of the performances, she had said, "Because they were oriental, everyone presumed this was understatement, rather than woodenness." The script, in Chinese, was "delivered inscrutably".

These and other points were picked up in a letter published three days later in the Guardian under the heading Crouching Tiger, not very well-hidden prejudices. "Only in Britain are pundits commenting on oriental 'inscrutability'," said the writer (a couple of letter writers agreed with the columnist's view that the film was greatly overrated).

Several complaints about the piece were made to me. Rather more were made directly to the editor of G2 responsible for publishing the column. My own view is that it was not absolutely clear because it was partially obscured by the phrases complained of, which did cause real offence.

I am not suggesting that this word only triggered the complaints about the column in the Guardian - clearly it did not - but it is taken by those it offends as symptomatic of an attitude that is lacking in respect.

webTitle: Face to Faith: Forgiveness of crimes past

fields.headline: Forgiveness of crimes past
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: How is it that forgiveness seems so easy for some and so hard for others?
fields.body:
How is it that forgiveness seems so easy for some and so hard for others? References to the subject in common parlance and biblical allusion - "Forgive and forget", "Forgive us our trespasses as we forgive them that trespass against us", "Forgive them, for they know not what they do" - might imply that the process is relatively straightforward, demanding not much more than a modicum of goodwill. What is less frequently recognised is that forgiveness is predicated on struggle and sacrifice.

Differing perceptions have led in recent decades to disputes between Christians and Jews about the nature of forgiveness, with particular regard to the Holocaust. Reactions from Jewish communities to former President Reagan's 1985 visit to the military cemetery at Bitburg, where SS members and Wehrmacht officers were buried, provoked some Christian theologians to question why Jews remained so unforgiving. One pronounced that "failure to forgive dehumanises the victims in a way that oppressors could never on their own achieve".

How do Jews respond? An eminently reasonable rabbi explained that if asked by a perpetuator to forgive him for his crime, a rabbi is not empowered to give absolution or to be a pardoner. I have heard the same argument from others; only God, or the dead victims, have the right to forgive.

A possible explanation for these differences lies in the Christian understanding of the life and death of Jesus as the ultimate expiatory sacrifice, unlike the "guilt offerings" or "sin offerings" that were part of ritual worship in ancient Judaism. Re-enacted in the Eucharist, Jesus' death and resurrection represented for all Christian denominations the source of eternal salvation.

No such guarantee exists in Judaism, which prescribes a process of repentance culminating on the Day of Atonement. The acknowledgement of wrongdoing is a crucial first step towards gaining divine forgiveness. In this context, a sinner who "turns from his evil ways", to quote the prophet Ezekiel, acquires the chance to be touched by what rabbis have referred to as "God's forgiving grace", even if he is in no position to make amends towards those he has wronged.

The process also involves human effort. Seeking pardon and making amends are an integral part of what is, in effect, a two-way process. The capacity of the person wronged to grant pardon and let go of resentment is essential. Each side of the process will usually involve internal struggle, as recognised in self-help or self-development groups.

One essential message is that letting go of resentment through acceptance - of oneself, of others who may have wronged us and of life itself, however unjust it may seem - is the only way to live.

This more humanistic perspective has a place, too, in contemporary Christian thinking. The recently published Oxford Companion To Christian Thought speaks of a tension between those who regard the process of repentance as central, and those who rely on the treasury of merit or grace earned through the sacrifice of Jesus.

Some relatives of murder victims do, indeed, express the desire to forgive. What struggle, one wonders, have they gone through? Or may their words of forgiveness be based on the assumption that the sin of the murderers has already been absolved? In contrast, the mother of James Bulger cannot forgive his murderers despite their show of remorse. A majority who find it difficult to accept Lord Woolf's recent ruling is likely to share her attitude. Nevertheless, it compounds her tragedy.

The relevance of repentance and reconciliation is significant, too, in the wider sphere. The sincere efforts of many Germans, on both a national and individual level, to make amends for the sins of their forbears has been one of the more heartening features of the post-second world war years. The visit of Pope John Paul II to Israel last year, and his impressive acknowledgement of centuries of church-fuelled anti-semitism, has also helped to mitigate long-held resentments and barriers to understanding.

Last week, the hope that working for reconciliation might bring forgiveness and heal the burden of survivors' memories was expressed on the eve of Holocaust Memorial Day. The speaker was the Archbishop of Westminster, Cormac Murphy-0'Connor; the occasion, the visit by the presidents of the Council of Christians and Jews to the Holocaust exhibit at the Imperial War Museum with sixth formers and survivors of the Shoah and other genocides.

Emma Klein is Jewish affairs correspondent of the Tablet

webTitle: Goodbye le cost cutter; hello job saver

fields.headline: Goodbye le cost cutter; hello job saver
fields.trailText: The two most striking features of Carlos Ghosn's 15th floor office in Nissan's headquarters in Ginza are distinctly Japanese: An angry red Mount Fuji glowers from a picture hung on the north wall, where it is supposed to bring luck.
fields.body:
The two most striking features of Carlos Ghosn's 15th floor office in Nissan's headquarters in Ginza are distinctly Japanese: An angry red Mount Fuji glowers from a picture hung on the north wall, where it is supposed to bring luck.

Facing it, high on a stack of shelves on the other side of the room, is a dharma doll winking with only one eye painted in - a reminder of unfinished business, work in progress, dreams not yet fulfilled.

Nissan's president seems quite at home among these symbols, which is hardly surprising: his upbringing and career have made him a consummate cultural chameleon. Of Lebanese heritage, he was born in Brazil and educated in France. Three of his four children were born in the United States.

"Home is not one particular place or country, but a collection of places in several countries," he says. "For me, the greatest sin is to consider cultural difference as a problem. I see it as an opportunity."

The boy from Brazil has a CV that reads like that of a Red Adair of the business world. For the past 10 years he has flown around the globe putting out increasingly large fires at multinational corporations: first at Michelin, where he rebuilt the firm's struggling North American operations, and then in Europe at Renault, where he revitalised another company that had been virtually written off.

But Nissan has been his greatest triumph. When he took the wheel of the troubled car maker in June 1999, the company was skidding towards the scrapyard. The product line was stodgy, the management notoriously conservative, the weight of $22bn (£15bn) debt was stifling growth and numerous attempts to jump-start the firm had merely flooded it with red ink.

Enter Ghosn, who was dispatched from Renault after the French firm paid £3.25bn for a 36.8% stake in the troubled Japanese company. He drove through the Nissan revival plan, a new corporate road map that was thrashed out in the whirlwind first three months of his tenure. The plan to close five factories and trim 21,000 jobs was attacked at first for its "un-Japanese" ruthlessness.

Ghosn (pronounced "gone") admits that he had his doubts when he took up the post of chief operating officer after just one week to practice Japanese. "I was in a country I didn't know and I had to turn this firm around," he recalls. "I knew I had to give my best and maybe even that was not enough."

Today, however, such uncertainties have largely been dispelled and not just in Ghosn's mind. In May, the executive expects to announce annual results that will show the company has returned to the black for the first time in seven years with growth of at least the 4.5% level targeted in the revival plan. This follows October's stunning half-year performance, when Nissan quadrupled its net profit forecast. "At first we relied upon motivation, but now we are able to talk about precise quantitative performance. This is very important to give the plan credibility," says Ghosn.

As well as impressive business figures, analysts are also starting to talk once again about Nissan style - a word that has not been associated with the company for some time. French flair was apparent on Tuesday, when Ghosn launched the sleekly redesigned Primera at the Tokyo Metropolitan Museum of Modern Art.

"We are starting to deliver, the wheels are now rolling in the opposite direction," says Ghosn. "This is by the far the largest, fastest, most intense and most stretching operation of my professional life."

As he has got used to Japan, Japan has begun to get used to him and his tough "foreign" methods. In Japan, he is an icon of change. The initial scepticism about his methods is being replaced by adulation.

Trendsetter

Young go-getting executives have even begun to emulate his style of dress and presentation. The changes of perception are apparent in the nicknames he has inspired. When he arrived with promises to slash factories and jobs, he was reviled as "le cost cutter". He says: "I never liked the nickname - cutting costs is only part of what I am trying to do at Nissan."

His ability to plough through Japan's Inc's crusty corporate culture earned him the monicker of "the ice breaker". Now, his admirers are more likely to call him "7-Eleven" for the long hours he works, which have impressed even the most workaholic Japanese.

It is Europe where Ghosn had his foot hard on the accelerator until the announcement that Sunderland - and not a French plant - would build the Micra. Last October, the Nissan boss singled out the region as the biggest drag on the company after European operations posted a loss of £155m. The problem was that the strong pound had turned Sunderland, Europe's most productive car plant, into one of the company's biggest loss makers.

Something would have to be done, Mr Ghosn announced darkly at the time, raising fears that he favoured building the new Micra inside the eurozone at Renault's factory in Flins, near Paris. Mr Ghosn, a dab hand at bridge, then played his trump card - the threat of 1,300 job losses near Tony Blair's Sedgefield constituency - for all it was worth.

By the time, he publicly made up his mind last Thursday, the British government and the plant's management had given him everything he wanted: a regional selective assistance grant of £40m, a pledge to cut costs by 30% and a government promise to pursue a "stable and competitive currency environment".

Despite forcing suppliers to bear 65% of the forex risks, Mr Ghosn came away from Britain not as le cost cutter, but as "le job saver". In France, nobody batted an eyelid that the Flins plant had lost out on the Micra business, prompting cynics to ask whether the factory had ever been in the running in the first place.

Ghosn angrily denies that he finessed the British government. "There are a lot of rumours about how much effort we made to prepare Flins, but these are based on speculation rather than fact." So what tipped the balance towards Sunderland? "A convergence of factors," he insists, though he puts Tony Blair's consistent stance on the issue of foreign exchange rates at the top of his list.

The decision-making process also suggests that a £230m investment was clinched by Downing Street. At a Nissan board meeting one week before the decision Ghosn said it was clear that momentum was moving Sunderland's way.

The Nissan executives, however, did not give the plant the nod. Instead they mandated Ghosn to make a final decision after meeting the prime minister. Exactly what reassurances were given by Blair remain the subject of intense speculation, but the Nissan boss rejects claims that a promise was made by the prime minister or trade secretary Stephen Byers on when Britain would enter the single currency. "The prime minister has said it, Mr Byers has said it and now I want to say it: There was no secret deal between Nissan and the UK," says Ghosn.

The road ahead

An agreement on the single currency may not have been necessary. By the time the decision was made, the weakening of the pound and a decision to use euro for 65% of its supply purchases has already lessened the foreign exchange pain to the point where Ghosn says Nissan can start to make money again in Europe this year.

As to the future, he predicts that there will be "some kind of stability between the pound and the euro" in 2002, though he evaded questions on the single currency saying that it is a "political matter". The prospect of a pick-up in Europe, where Ghosn hopes Nissan can expand on its "unacceptable" 3% market share, is timely given the slowdown in the US, where Nissan notched up its strongest growth rate of 14% last year.

For Ghosn a world view is essential. He argues that his is a blend of management styles - not just a western-style restructuring. None of the 21,000 job cuts are being made by forced lay-offs, and employees at factories due to close are given generous grants to relocate.

As Japan has learned, so has Ghosn. Fluent in seven languages, Nissan's president has just finished his weekly one-hour lesson in Japanese, where he says progress is slow. "I cannot impose my childish Japanese in business discussions and this is frustrating. The president of a company must be able to communicate and that is difficult with an interpreter."

But this drawback is more than offset, he says, by the fresh ideas and energy that he brought to the company as an outsider (he is careful to make the distinction with "foreigner"). "This is not specific to Japanese corporate culture. When you are questioning your business system, outside help is very important." And not just in business either, it seems: Ghosn said he was curious to see how England's football team would fare under its first "outside" manager: Swede, Sven-Goran Eriksson.

How does he choose which country's football team to follow? His answer is not only a model of global political correctness, but an indication, perhaps, of the criteria used to decide where to build the Micra.

"Nationalism plays a part of course, but if the team is lazy then I don't want to support them. For me, it depends on the quality of the players."


The CV

Born Brazil, 1954, to a Brazilian father and a French mother

Education Graduated in engineering from Ecole Polytechnique in 1974 and Ecole des Mines de Paris in 1978

Career Joined Michelin in 1978. In 1990, he presided over restructuring of company's North American operations. Switched to Renault in 1996, where he played a leading role in bringing the company back from the brink as second in command. Chosen by Renault to spearhead revival of Nissan in June 1999. Appointed president in June 2000

Family Married to Rita. Four children aged between six and 14, Caroline, Nadine, Maya and Anthony

Interests Family first, then bridge, reading and football. He is chairman of Yokohama F Marinos, a junior league football team sponsored by Nissan. Spends weekends with children or trying out competitors' cars

None of the 21,000 job cuts are being made by forced lay-offs, and employees at factories due to close are given generous grants to relocate. As Japan has learned, so has Ghosn. Fluent in seven languages, Nissan's president has just finished his weekly one-hour lesson in Japanese, where he says progress is slow. "I cannot impose my childish Japanese in business discussions and this is frustrating. The president of a company must be able to communicate and that is difficult with an interpreter." But this drawback is more than offset, he says, by the fresh ideas and energy that he brought to the company as an outsider (he is careful to make the distinction with "foreigner"). "This is not specific to Japanese corporate culture. When you are questioning your business system, outside help is very important." And not just in business either, it seems: Ghosn said he was curious to see how England's football team would fare under its first "outside" manager: Swede, Sven-Goran Eriksson. How does he choose which country's football team to follow? His answer is not only a model of global political correctness, but an indication, perhaps, of the criteria used to decide where to build the Micra. "Nationalism plays a part of course, but if the team is lazy then I don't want to support them. For me, it depends on the quality of the players." The CV Born Brazil, 1954, to a Brazilian father and a French mother Education Graduated in engineering from Ecole Polytechnique in 1974 and Ecole des Mines de Paris in 1978 Career Joined Michelin in 1978. In 1990, he presided over restructuring of company's North American operations. Switched to Renault in 1996, where he played a leading role in bringing the company back from the brink as second in command. Chosen by Renault to spearhead revival of Nissan in June 1999. Appointed president in June 2000 Family Married to Rita. Four children aged between six and 14, Caroline, Nadine, Maya and Anthony Interests Family first, then bridge, reading and football. He is chairman of Yokohama F Marinos, a junior league football team sponsored by Nissan. Spends weekends with children or trying out competitors' cars

fields.headline: J'accuse!
fields.standfirst: The parallels between Dreyfus and Mandleson are irresistible argues Smallweed
fields.trailText: The parallels between Dreyfus and Mandleson are irresistible argues Smallweed
fields.body:
There seemed at first to be a bit of a proportionality failure when the best- selling author Robert Harris compared the plight of his friend Peter Mandelson to that of Alfred Dreyfus, the French officer wrongly accused of treason and imprisoned on Devil's Island until the writings of Emile Zola rescued him. But as one looks through Dreyfus's own account of his sufferings (Five Years of My Life, published in 1901), the parallels become irresistible.

Both men were high-fliers, suddenly hauled before what they saw as kangaroo courts. Both found hard and unremitting opponents lying in wait: in the case of Dreyfus, a band of bullying and unscrupulous commandants, backed up by the secret police; in Mandelson's, Tony Blair and Alastair Campbell. Both passionately asserted their innocence - Dreyfus throughout his interrogation and subsequent trial, Mandelson once it was over. Both were then banished to grim, inaccessible spots on a distant coast: Dreyfus to Devil's Island in French Guinea, on the north east coast of South America; Mandelson to the no less forbidding Hartlepool on the north-east coast of England.

Admittedly, the privations that Dreyfus went through on the Ile du Diable may exceed anything Hartlepool has to offer. This soi-disant island was simply a barren rock which had formerly been a leper colony. Now it was cleared, except for him and his guards. They berthed him in a stone hut about 13ft square. At first he was given a space of some 200 yards for exercise, though in time that too was taken away from him.

As I say, the efforts of Zola (a part played in this present case by Harris) finally righted this wretched injustice. Dreyfus was restored to the rank of staff officer 12 years after his conviction and in time for the first world war; on which basis Mandelson ought to be back in Stormont some time in 2013. The man chiefly responsible for cooking up the case against Dreyfus killed himself out of remorse.

Next week in Smallweed: Is Peter the new Count of Monte Cristo? by Jeffrey Archer.

So what exactly is a kangaroo court? You may choose one of two answers. 1) A court composed of kangaroos sitting in judgment on fellow marsupials. (I'd go for that if I were you: it's much the simpler). 2) A late-19th-century US term, meaning a court constituted without legal standing, for instance by strikers, prisoners or mutineers. How kangaroos got into this concept seems to me far from clear, but you know how agile they are. Some books say the connection occurred because of the way that kangaroos jump - in a headstrong and arbitrary way, I suppose they mean. Others aver that the expression arose because kangaroos are such cruel beasts. I find this surprising: I always thought of them as cuddly creatures with pouches, more likely to let you off with a caution than impose some ferocious arbitrary sentence. But then one should never judge by appearances.

There was heartening news this week for admirers of the composer Gustav Holst. Apparently the planet Pluto is thought by some good judges not to be a real planet at all. It ought to be degraded, they say, to the rank of comet. If so, this would vindicate the judgment of Holst in keeping his suite, The Planets, to the number he started out with. People offered Holst the chance to expand the work after Pluto swam into the general consciousness round about 1930, four years before he died. "Look here, Holst, old chap," they told him, "we seem to have found this new planet. Wouldn't you like to tag it on to your suite?" "Thanks very much," Holst replied, "but I think I'll stick to the suite as it stands, if you don't mind." (I paraphrase, but not much.)

And thus things continued till the final days of the 20th century, when the composer Colin Matthews, at the invitation of Kent Nagano and the Hallé, added a Pluto, which was first performed in Manchester last May. To much acclaim, it has to be said, though Smallweed continued to think that Matthews was taking a liberty. This was not, after all, like Mahler's 10th or Bartok's third piano concerto, a work which had to be completed by others because the composer died. Holst was still around and said no, and that should have been the end of the matter. Thank goodness for science, which now seems likely to relegate Pluto to some brand new suite called The Comets.

There's one source on which the steelworkers about to be sacked by Corus can surely depend for a sympathetic hearing. The Daily Telegraph, not always over the years a source of compassion for people in dying industries, has lately developed a pretty compassion for those who fall victim to modernisation. Its pages over the past year or so have regularly been full of understanding accounts of such people's predicaments, especially where their skills are irrelevant to other forms of employment, or where job cuts occur in places where no other work is available. True, virtually all of this coverage has been concerned with those who would suffer if blood sports were banned. But surely the Telegraph will be no less generous now to the apprehensions and fears of communities such as Llanwern? Just because its editor is a fanatical huntsman, rather than a fanatical steelworker (there are not so many of those in my trade nowadays), he wouldn't want to condone double standards, would he? Of course not.

Moved perhaps by the example of John Adams's celebrated orchestral piece, The Chairman Dances, BBC television the other night invented a sequel which might have been called The Ombudsman Prances. The parliamentary ombudsman, Elizabeth Filkin, who is involved in investigations featuring Keith Vaz, was pictured advancing past parliament in a kangaroid fashion, as if bouncing from step to step. Maybe this was simply the product of slow-motion filming, though it looked to Smallweed as if technicians lying in wait for her had adroitly carpeted Parliament Square with miniature trampolines. It made her, I have to say, look a trifle ridiculous. But it made the BBC look very silly indeed.

Smallweed@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Kidnapped girl freed in Philippines
fields.trailText: The six-year-old stepdaughter of a British man has been rescued from kidnappers in the Philippines.
fields.body:
The six-year-old stepdaughter of a British man has been rescued from kidnappers in the Philippines.

Eiman Grant was snatched three weeks ago from her home on the island of Basilan by four men, believed to belong to an Islamic group led by Abu Sayyaf, after her mother was said to be unable to meet an extortion demand.

Last night, Philippine military sources were quoted as saying Eiman was rescued on Friday and had been taken to Zamboanga city for a medical check-up.

Her stepfather, Douglas Grant, from Inverness, told BBC Scotland that he had spoken to her on the phone and she sounded withdrawn after her ordeal. Mr Grant said he was "over the moon" that she had been released.

Mr Grant, 50, a hospitality manager, said he had spoken to his wife, Mina, who had given him more details about the girl's condition.

Basilan, 550 miles south of the capital Manila, is a hotbed of Islamic secessionist groups. Last month, officials on the island said Eiman was abducted after four men, armed with M-16 assault rifles burst into the family home. They demanded 100,000 pesos (£1,300). When Mrs Grant said she only had 1,000 pesos, the men grabbed Eiman and fled to two speedboats waiting on the nearby river.

The Grants had settled in the Philippines after moving from Kuwait. The couple have a 22-month-old daughter, Khadija, and Eiman, Mrs Grant's daughter from a previous marriage. Mr Grant, a former soldier in the catering corps ran a taxi business on the island. He returned to the UK last August to care for his elderly parents. He was making preparations for his family to join him when Eiman was taken.

Basilan, an impoverished island, is known as an Abu Sayyaf stronghold. The group achieved notoriety last year when it seized 21 hostages from a Malaysian diving resort and took them to their hideout on the island of Jolo. In the ensuing crisis a further 19 people were seized, including several journalists.

All but two of the hostages were released, some only after the military launched a huge assault on the hideout in September, after five months of negotiations and millions of pounds in ransom money achieved only partial success.

Following Eiman's abduction, it was alleged that Mrs Grant may have been involved, a claim dismissed by Mr Grant. It was also claimed that relatives or neighbours of Mrs Grant may have played a role in the kidnap.

fields.headline: Scargill to take on Mandelson
fields.standfirst: Special report: Peter Mandelson
fields.trailText: The miners' leader Arthur Scargill, scourge of New Labour, is to stand against Peter Mandelson in Hartlepool at the general election.
fields.body:
The miners' leader Arthur Scargill, scourge of New Labour, is to stand against Peter Mandelson in Hartlepool at the general election.

The announcement came as Tony Blair told a private meeting of senior backbench MPs that "Peter's crime was not a heinous one", and that he had not seen all the documents on Mr Mandelson's involvement with the passport application of the billionaire businessman SP Hinduja when he met Lord Irvine, the Lord Chancellor and Alastair Campbell, his press secretary, to discuss whether the Northern Ireland secretary should quit.

Mr Mandelson, who resigned 10 days ago over his role in the affair, was re-elected to Hartlepool in 1997 with a majority of 17,508. The Hartlepool Mail predicts that he will have to fight to retain his seat. The local council has already fallen from Labour control.

From America last night, Mr Mandelson said: "This is the first good news I have had for some time. Arthur Scargill is the man who destroyed the coal industry and betrayed every man and woman in Britain in the process. I am happy to debate the future of the left with him and to champion the achievements of the most successful Labour government in history."

There had been speculation that the sleaze-busting MP Martin Bell might try his hand in Hartlepool, but Mr Scargill's decision probably precludes this.

Mr Scargill, general secretary of the Socialist Labour party, said yesterday the government's policies had been disastrous for the NHS, education and housing. He is still president of the National Union of Mineworkers, now based in Barnsley and seriously depleted in numbers.

He still has strong support among former miners in Co Durham, but his fundamentalist socialist politics may keep many mainstream Labour supporters on side with Mr Mandelson.

Mr Blair's comments to MPs in private that he had not seen all the papers on the passport application at the time he talked to Lord Irvine and Mr Campbell seemed to confirm that papers from the Cabinet Office and Northern Ireland Office had not been examined before the decision to ask for Mr Mandelson's resignation.

His comments have ruffled Labour backbenchers, who thought the matter of Mr Mandelson's future in the government had been settled. One MP told the Guardian that Mr Blair "appeared to be a grieving man".

Sir Anthony Hammond has started his inquiry into the affair. Mr Mandelson has announced that he is bringing in lawyers to help his defence when he is questioned this month. They will seek to get hold of all the papers - depending on precedent.

Sir Anthony is becoming increasingly angry at ministers' comments on the case. He has warned them in a letter circulating in Whitehall to stop speaking about it. He regards it as sub judice.
