webTitle: Blair backs Vaz over latest sleaze allegation

fields.headline: Blair backs Vaz over latest sleaze allegation
fields.standfirst: Special report: Peter Mandelson
fields.trailText: The prime minister's judgment was called into question yesterday as he continued to back his beleaguered minister Keith Vaz amid fresh allegations of sleaze.
fields.body:
The prime minister's judgment was called into question yesterday as he continued to back his beleaguered minister Keith Vaz amid fresh allegations of sleaze.

Downing Street insisted Mr Vaz had not breached the ministerial code of conduct by using a Foreign Office room to host a meeting about an Asian restaurateur's contested insurance claim.

But Liberal Democrat and Tory MPs suggested Tony Blair was flawed in backing a minister being investigated by Sir Anthony Hammond as part of his inquiry into the billionaire Hinduja brothers passport application affair.

Even among his own party, where ministers are braced for further revelations in the Sunday papers, there is disquiet, with one senior government source admitting: "He's just sailing too close to the wind."

The latest controversy to surround the minister for Europe arose after the Daily Mail revealed that Mr Vaz had used Foreign Office premises last September to hold a meeting with representatives of Norwich Union over a disputed £175,000 insurance claim.

Mr Vaz, the MP for Leicester East, had arranged the meeting on behalf of Amin Ali, the owner of the Red Fort restaurant in central London and a Labour supporter who had given £5,000 to Frank Dobson's mayoral campaign. By the end of the meeting, Norwich Union had settled the claim.

A Foreign Office spokesman acknowledged the use of Whitehall offices for such a purpose was "exceptional", but added that the ministerial code did not preclude it, but rather stated government property should not "generally be used for constituency or party matters".

A spokesman for Mr Vaz added: "There's an acceptance this is very unusual, and the emphasis is on 'generally'. As ever with the ministerial code, it's not as clear as it might be."

He said the meeting had occurred in the Foreign Office because of scheduling problems, and suggested Mr Vaz had distanced himself from his ministerial post by not using Foreign Office notepaper.

Mr Vaz had viewed the matter as constituency business even though Mr Ali does not live in Mr Vaz's Leicester East constituency. "Mr Vaz sees himself as having a broader constituency representing the Asian community," one Foreign Office source said.

Downing Street also at tempted to play down the affair by repeating its strategy of insisting the government was "moving on" following the Hinduja brothers controversy, which sparked the resignation of the Northern Ireland minister Peter Mandelson last week.

But Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, said: "By opting to back Keith Vaz, the prime minister appears to show the same lack of judgment that caused him to reappoint Peter Mandelson to the cabinet."

Norman Baker, the Liberal Democrat MP whose questions about the Hinduja brothers set in train Mr Mandelson's downfall, described Mr Vaz's behaviour as "pretty extraordinary".

"Foreign Office rooms are for conducting affairs of state, not sorting out the finances of a Soho restaurant," he said.

He added: "Keith Vaz has a role in life. He should be dealing with Foreign Office affairs or his constituents and this was an inappropriate pressure from a minister from an inappropriate location."

In a statement Amin Ali, who is worth an estimated £7m, called Mr Vaz "an honest broker" who had helped resolve a difficult problem.

A spokeswoman for Norwich Union rejected the insinuation in the Daily Mail that they agreed to settle Mr Ali's claim after Mr Vaz's involvement because they were "anxious to avoid antagonising the government".

webTitle: Merseyside off limits for Bulger two

fields.headline: Merseyside off limits for Bulger two
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: James Bulger's killers are expected to be banned by the parole board from ever returning to Merseyside as a condition of their release later this year.
fields.body:
James Bulger's killers are expected to be banned by the parole board from ever returning to Merseyside as a condition of their release later this year.

Robert Thompson and Jon Venables are also certain to be barred from approaching any members of the Bulger family, including Denise Fergus and Ralph Bulger, the parents of the two-year-old they abducted and murdered in February 1993 when they were 10. The pair will probably have to agree never to contact each other again.

The likely conditions emerged yesterday as the parole board held a preliminary hearing to fix details of the separate hearings in a few months that will decide whether the two killers, now 18, will win their freedom this summer.

They are expected to be released on licence, taking up new identities fashioned for them by the Home Office, and resettled somewhere in England away from their former Merseyside homes.

The hearing yesterday at a secret location, thought to be somewhere in London, is the first step towards their release. The process was set in train after the lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, decided last October that their tariff - the minimum term they should serve for retribution and deterrence - should expire immediately.

The two were represented by lawyers at yesterday's hearing but were not present themselves. They will give evidence along with other witnesses at their full hearings .

The preliminary hearing was held to decide on such details as who should give evidence and what reports need to be prepared. One item on the agenda is the outcome of a Home Office inquiry into claims in a Sunday newspaper that Thompson tried to strangle a fellow inmate with a flex.

Robin Makin, solicitor for James Bulger's father Ralph, last night criticised the decision to go ahead with the preliminary hearing before theoutcome of his high court challenge to Lord Woolf's recommendation of a tariff of less than eight years and its acceptance by the home secretary, Jack Straw. A three-judge court, headed by Lord Justice Rose, vice-president of the court of appeal criminal division, is scheduled to hear the case on February 15 and 16.

Mr Bulger's lawyers will argue that Lord Woolf gave disproportionate weight to the teenagers' rehabilitation in the local authority secure units where they are serving their sentences, and that Mr Straw acted unlawfully in announcing in advance that he was "bound to accept" whatever the lord chief justice recommended. Mr Makin said it was ironic that Mr Straw would have to defend Lord Woolf at the hearing, "when they are at loggerheads over penal policy".

Lawyers for the Home Office and Lord Woolf are expected to argue that he took his decision in his capacity as a judge and is therefore not subject to judicial review.

Mr Makin said he had been contacted by the probation service, which wanted to see Mr Bulger "in a few weeks" to hear his views on parole for his son's killers. Comments from the family will be part of the evidence presented to the parole board before its decision.

James's mother, Denise Fergus, who lives in Kirkby, Merseyside, is to lead a protest march that will end with a memorial service in Kirkby on February 10, two days before the eighth anniversary of his death. Marchers are expected to carry banners calling for Thompson and Venables to be denied parole.

On their release they will be protected by a unique lifetime blanket ban on media stories about their new identities. Newspapers that opposed the ban, imposed last month by Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, president of the high court's family division, have decided not to appeal against it.

fields.headline: Rapist gets life for killing
fields.standfirst: Police fear more victims possible as murderer of three women is jailed
fields.trailText: One of the most evil partnerships in British criminal history was brought to justice yesterday when the serial killer and rapist David Mulcahy was jailed for life after his former accomplice finally testified against him.
fields.body:
One of the most evil partnerships in British criminal history was brought to justice yesterday when the serial killer and rapist David Mulcahy was jailed for life after his former accomplice finally testified against him.

Married father-of-four Mulcahy and his friend, John Duffy, murdered three women - the youngest only 15 - and raped another seven during a "reign of terror".

Duffy was jailed for his part in the attacks in 1988, but though police were convinced that Mulcahy was his partner, he remained free. Duffy finally admitted to a prison psychologist that his schoolboy friend was his accomplice.

Detectives last night said there could be more victims of the pair who had yet to come forward. And they were not ruling out the possibility that Mulcahy may have continued to attack women after Duffy was jailed. Detective Superintendent Andy Murphy said: "There may be victims of Mulcahy in relation to single attacks." At least one woman has come forward to say she was raped by Mulcahy alone.

Mulcahy, 41, was given three life sentences for the murders. He received 24-year jail terms on each of seven rapes he committed with Duffy, and 18 years each for five conspiracies to rape.

He was convicted after Duffy, who has been told he will die in prison, spent 14 days in the witness box describing their crimes to an Old Bailey jury. It was the first time a Category A inmate had testified against a co-defendant.

During the five-month trial the court heard that the pair, whose relationship was described as "unique but wicked", played the Michael Jackson track Thriller on the car stereo as they went on "hunting" expeditions for lone women to rape in the 1980s.

They terrorised their victims with threats and became ever more violent until eventually they killed. Mulcahy was said to have enjoyed "playing God" with their victims.

Duffy, 41, who was dubbed the "railway rapist" because so many of the crimes were committed near stations, was convicted of two murders and five rapes. He said he could not remember his crimes, and police did not have enough evidence to charge his accomplice.

For 18 years after his first offence, Mulcahy continued to live an apparently normal life with his wife and children in north London. Then recent advances in scientific techniques, coupled with Duffy's decision to name his partner, allowed him to be put on trial.

There were gasps from the public gallery when the jury returned its unanimous verdicts after deliberating for five days. Three of the victims hugged each other. Others were too upset to attend.

Judge Michael Hyam, the recorder of London, said the murders had been "sadistic killings." He told Mulcahy: "Of the two of you, I have no doubt it was you who derived gratification from the act of killing. These were acts of desolating wickedness. You descended to the depths of depravity in carrying them out."

Detectives said afterwards that the science which had allowed them to match Mulcahy's DNA profile to material found after one of the attacks, and to discover a fingerprint linking him to another crime scene, had not been available at the time of Duffy's trial.

However, there was strong criticism from one rape victim, who said she had to approach the police four times before they even took a statement from her.

Detectives said there could be more victims who had been too frightened to come forward. One of the pair's tactics had been to obtain personal information from their victims to dissuade them from going to the police.

The police will now work with the national crime faculty to re-examine any unsolved murders or rapes which the pair may have been responsible for. The original inquiry looked at 68 sex attacks suspected of being linked. The detectives will also speak to officers working on Operation Enigma, a review of around 100 unsolved violent crimes.

After the verdicts, Mulcahy's wife Sandra insisted: "David is innocent. I will fight on to prove him innocent."

Mulcahy, a builder, of Chalk Farm, north London, had denied raping and murdering three women during 1985 and 1986. Alison Day, 19, was strangled at Hackney Wick, east London, on December 29 1985. Schoolgirl Maartje Tamboezer, 15, was strangled near her home in Horsley, Surrey, on April 17 1986. Newly married Anne Lock, 29, was killed - probably suffocated - as she returned home to Brookmans Park, Hertfordshire.

Mulcahy also denied seven other rapes and five charges of conspiracy to rape between 1982 and 1985.

webTitle: Arrest of £250m sleaze bagman shakes French state

fields.headline: Arrest of £250m sleaze bagman shakes French state
fields.standfirst: For years he controlled a state-sponsored slush fund. Will he now name names?
fields.trailText: A fugitive French businessman who boasted that he knew enough "to blow up the Republic 20 times over", was arrested in the Philippines yesterday, prompting speculation that France's biggest postwar sleaze trial would be suspended when the hearings resume on Monday.
fields.body:
A fugitive French businessman who boasted that he knew enough "to blow up the Republic 20 times over", was arrested in the Philippines yesterday, prompting speculation that France's biggest postwar sleaze trial would be suspended when the hearings resume on Monday.

Alfred Sirven, 74, was being tried in absentia in Paris in a vast and many-tentacled corruption case that had also put a suave but ageing former French foreign minister, Roland Dumas, his mistress, Christine Deviers-Joncour, and the ex-boss of the formerly state-owned oil giant Elf Aquitaine in the dock.

In the two weeks since the trial started the accused have repeatedly pointed the finger at Mr Sirven, who as number two at the oil company was allegedly the chief fixer and bagman for its then president, Loik le Floch-Prigent, controlling a slush fund allegedly worth more than £250m.

The case, which threatens to reveal explosive details about the state-sponsored sleaze of the late François Mitterrand's 1981-95 Socialist presidency, has captivated France with its tales of multimillion-pound kickbacks, dodgy international arms sales, extravagant illegal gifts and sex in high places.

Mr Sirven's arrest will give it a new and more ominous twist. In a recent book, two French journalists, Gilles Gaetner and Jean-Marie Pontaut, described him as as "a sort of modern-day Mephistopheles".

Pointing out that for four years he was in charge of a slush fund, they added: "It is easy to understand the anxiety of any number of people at the idea of his appearance in a courtroom."

Mr Sirven, whose deportation order was signed yesterday, was put on a flight for Paris last night. The target of three international arrest warrants, he had been on the run for nearly four years, mostly in the Philippines, where - with the help of an alleged £20m of Elf's cash - he lived in ever-changing hideaways with his common-law Filipina wife, Vilma Medina.

Judicial experts said the Paris public prosecutor who has brought charges of fraud, embezzlement and abuse of corporate and public funds against all the accused would almost certainly follow lawyers acting for Mr Dumas and Ms Deviers-Joncour in demanding that the case be suspended.

"It is impossible to imagine that it could continue, as if Sirven had not been arrested," said Ms Deviers-Joncour's lawyer, Sophie Battai. "This will inevitably change the course of the trial. I cannot see the court carrying on when the majority of the accused have blamed Sirven for all the evils of Elf Aquitaine."

Mr Sirven was arrested in a suburb of Tagaytay, south of Manila, after an 11-month hunt by Filipino investigators, aided by four French police officers, whose chase led them to more than 20 different towns, coconut groves, cattle ranches and even prawn farms around the 7,000-island archipelago.

After several near misses when Mr Sirven managed to slip the noose with only hours to spare, a squad of 10 agents from the national bureau of investigation, armed with assault rifles, shotguns and pistols, eventually found him sitting in shorts and sipping wine alone in his living room.

"We were expecting armed security and were prepared for the worst," said James Tosoc, one of the arresting agents. "When we saw him like that we put the guns back in the car." Mr Tosoc said Mr Sirven remarked calmly that it was all over, then asked if he could change his clothes.

Investigators said they had focused their search on Ms Medina, the mother of a maid who had worked for Mr Sirven in France, and her extended family.

"We started following her relatives," said the chief investigator, Ric Diaz, explaining that Mr Sirven was clearly spending money and making investments through Ms Medina's family. "She was a maid, but her family was buying trucks, BMW cars, a coconut plantation, prawn farms and all sorts of things. We knew they shouldn't have that kind of money."

The breakthrough came when Mr Sirven's Filipino chauffeur, Roberto Araza, flew into Manila early yesterday morning after a trip to Hong Kong. Mr Diaz said his agents met him at the airport and convinced him to lead them to his employer. Mr Sirven had been using a fake passport in the name of Robert Lapierre, a Parisian who died in September 1997.

Paraded later at a Manila press conference, Mr Sirven denied any wrongdoing. "I have no money in the Philippines. All the stories about me are rubbish, just a fabrication," he said. "I have never committed an offence. I spent three years in this country .. and I'll leave with much regret."

But he is alleged to have been at the heart of the sprawling Elf scandal. The company's slush fund is the focus of six separate judicial investigations in France which have seen more than 20 people placed under formal investigation.

The principal inquiry involves the £1.6bn sale by the French arms maker Thomson-CSF of six frigates to Taiwan. Mr Dumas was last year forced to resign as head of the constitutional council, France's highest legal authority, over claims that Elf paid his former mistress £6.5m to lobby the then foreign minister to approve the sale. The oil company was often regarded as an unofficial arm of the French government.

Mr Dumas finally agreed to the deal in 1991, after long opposing it as an unnecessary provocation of China. But he denies that he did so under his lover's influence, or because of any financial favours. Ms Deviers-Joncour was employed by Mr Sirven at the time, and the gifts bought with Elf's money and showered on Mr Dumas by her included a pair of £1,000 Italian shoes, six antique statuettes and the use of a £1.7m Paris flat for their trysts.

Mr Sirven's name has also featured prominently in the mysterious case of the £25m that Elf allegedly paid in commissions when it bought the Leuna oil refinery in eastern Germany in 1992. Allegations that the Christian Democratic party of the former German chancellor Helmut Kohl profited from the deal - which he and Mitterrand championed as a sign of French-German cooperation - have never been proven.

fields.headline: Steel boycott by Dutch unions
fields.standfirst: Counterparts of threatened British workers refuse to accept transfer of work to Corus plant in Holland
fields.trailText: Counterparts of threatened British workers refuse to accept transfer of work to Corus plant in Holland.
fields.byline: David Gow, Nicholas Bannister, Patrick Wintour and Ian Black
fields.body:
Dutch steel unions yesterday pledged to boycott any transfer of Corus UK's production to the Netherlands as their British counterparts began drawing up alternative plans to keep threatened plants open and prevent many of the 6,000 redundancies taking place.

Leaders of the FNV union yesterday told Corus's Dutch management in Amsterdam that workers at the group's Ijmuiden plant on the North Sea coast would not undertake work previously done in Wales and other parts of the UK.

Corus insisted it did not intend switching production to Ijmuiden, but admitted that it intended to replace loss-making UK exports to continental customers with "profitable" output from the Dutch plant.

Ijmuiden's output of such products, used in the car and domestic appliance industries, is due to rise by 1.3m tonnes a year while its overall production of steel should go up from 6.3m tonnes to nearer 7m tonnes.

The move came as the European commissioner for re gional aid, Michael Barnier, offered to refocus EU aid to help create jobs in Wales, which is bearing the brunt of Corus's cuts.

But Tony Blair, in a speech setting out the limits of the state's role in fostering British manufacturing, ruled out large-scale intervention to save steel jobs. He said businesses must succeed or fail on their own strengths.

He said jobs were lost as well as created in dynamic economies, but pointed out that overall employment in the UK continued to rise.

The executive of the main UK steel union, the ISTC, said it was working with the government and other unions on a package that could save most of the jobs under threat. It refused to give details but insiders said it was "solid".

Meanwhile, the AEEU union has drawn up a plan which envisages Corus agreeing to mothball plants such as Llanwern, Ebbw Vale and parts of Shotton and Redcar until better trading prospects, helped by a weaker pound, enable it to revive them.

Corus has agreed to listen to union counter-proposals during the two-week moratorium before redundancies and closures are set in train, but has indicated that it is unlikely to change its mind.

Neil Kinnock, vice-president of the European commission, said: "There's a moral to be drawn when we've got the pound 25% overvalued. That doesn't exactly help sell steel."

Mr Kinnock's father worked for 27 years at the Ebbw Vale tin plate plant which is to close with the loss of 780 jobs. His wife Glenys, an MEP, said the impact on Ebbw Vale would terrible. "It is one of the poorest and most disadvantaged areas in Britain," she said.

She said Mr Barnier was ready to discuss proposals from the Welsh assembly and other regional organisations for refocusing existing EU aid programmes on the stricken areas.

Corus's Ebbw Vale and Llanwern plants are within areas targeted by the EU for aid under the structural funds - currently totalling £1.23bn over a seven-year period that began last year.

Wales also benefits from European social fund money, which could be used to help retrain the redundant workforce from the Shotton plant.

Leaders of the FNV union yesterday told Corus's Dutch management in Amsterdam that workers at the group's Ijmuiden plant on the North Sea coast would not undertake work previously done in Wales and other parts of the UK. Corus insisted it did not intend switching production to Ijmuiden, but admitted that it intended to replace loss-making UK exports to continental customers with "profitable" output from the Dutch plant. Ijmuiden's output of such products, used in the car and domestic appliance industries, is due to rise by 1.3m tonnes a year while its overall production of steel should go up from 6.3m tonnes to nearer 7m tonnes. The move came as the European commissioner for re gional aid, Michael Barnier, offered to refocus EU aid to help create jobs in Wales, which is bearing the brunt of Corus's cuts. But Tony Blair, in a speech setting out the limits of the state's role in fostering British manufacturing, ruled out large-scale intervention to save steel jobs. He said businesses must succeed or fail on their own strengths. He said jobs were lost as well as created in dynamic economies, but pointed out that overall employment in the UK continued to rise. The executive of the main UK steel union, the ISTC, said it was working with the government and other unions on a package that could save most of the jobs under threat. It refused to give details but insiders said it was "solid". Meanwhile, the AEEU union has drawn up a plan which envisages Corus agreeing to mothball plants such as Llanwern, Ebbw Vale and parts of Shotton and Redcar until better trading prospects, helped by a weaker pound, enable it to revive them. Corus has agreed to listen to union counter-proposals during the two-week moratorium before redundancies and closures are set in train, but has indicated that it is unlikely to change its mind. Neil Kinnock, vice-president of the European commission, said: "There's a moral to be drawn when we've got the pound 25% overvalued. That doesn't exactly help sell steel." Mr Kinnock's father worked for 27 years at the Ebbw Vale tin plate plant which is to close with the loss of 780 jobs. His wife Glenys, an MEP, said the impact on Ebbw Vale would terrible. "It is one of the poorest and most disadvantaged areas in Britain," she said. She said Mr Barnier was ready to discuss proposals from the Welsh assembly and other regional organisations for refocusing existing EU aid programmes on the stricken areas. Corus's Ebbw Vale and Llanwern plants are within areas targeted by the EU for aid under the structural funds - currently totalling £1.23bn over a seven-year period that began last year. Wales also benefits from European social fund money, which could be used to help retrain the redundant workforce from the Shotton plant. fields.headline: Inner-city scholar
fields.standfirst:
Born in Chicago to radical parents, he reacted against the 'self-indulgence' of 60s alternative culture. When his promising musical career was cut short by illness he changed direction and became an authority on class and urban society.  Melissa Benn on the LSE professor 
who returned to his socialist roots

fields.body:
Richard Sennett enjoys the nearest to loft-style living that central London offers. His spacious, almost surreally well-ordered flat tops a maze of Farringdon offices. His roof terrace offers a dazzling view of an apparent jumble of warehousing and wasteground, a scene of brutal slate-grey beauty. It is the perfect view for one of the great urban enthusiasts of our age.

Chicagoan by birth, New Yorker by temperament, Sennett has settled in London only recently. Now 58, he took up the post of school professor of social and cultural theory at the London School of Economics in 1999. But he is a great deal more than a senior working, writing, administering sociologist. He is also a successful public intellectual, one of that special breed of writers and thinkers who cover a range of so-called specialisms but are called upon to tell us as a society who we are and how we got here.

Chiefly known for his elegant and scholarly writing, Sennett has produced a dozen books, including three novels, since the late 60s, mostly on aspects of the urban experience and the interconnection between authority, modernism and public life. His knowledge spans the disciplines of architecture, design, music, art, literature, history, and political and economic theory, but he adds to all that a rare anthropological hunger for the details of human experience. One of his apparent paradoxes is that while he so fiercely argues for a more disciplined form of public life over any therapeutic-style navel-gazing, he possesses a rare genius for getting into other people's heads and hearts.

He is also a socialist, who has returned to radical politics in late middle age. Ruth Levitas, reader in sociology at the University of Bristol, says he thinks class is important and fundamental, "which lots of people don't, but he also talks about what class means for real lives without drifting off into stuff about identity. He also writes beautifully".

It may be his politics or it may be the complex and wide-ranging nature of his enthusiasms which bring him just short of celebrity intellectual status. The author Victoria Glendinning, a friend for more than 25 years, says of his work, "It really ought to be better known. I will sometimes read some work of social theory and want to say, 'Oh, well, Richard said that'. His work isn't always as acknowledged as it should be because he's not just a sociologist but also a novelist, so his work doesn't fit into any easy slot. It is kind of uncategorisable and all the better for it."

But Sennett's work can also be understood as a life-long attempt to come to terms with his radical heritage, to both honour the idealism of an old left and re-mould it in the light of contemporary realities. Born in Chicago in 1943, he was a classic child of the left. His father and all his uncles were in the Communist party and his mother "was always involved in the labour movement", he says. His father and uncle fought in the Spanish Civil War, first against the fascists, and then against the communists. Proudly he shows me a portrait on his study wall of the Lincoln section of the International brigade. It includes his father and uncle, upright men in caps prepared to die to defend someone else's freedom.

His parents were together for only a few months after his birth. His father returned to Spain, to be with a fellow freedom fighter with whom he had fallen in love. He later became a translator of Spanish and popular Catalan poetry, which Sennett describes as "his one great love". Sennett never met him, although as child of a volunteer in the civil war, he was offered Spanish citizenship in 1988. But he did keep in touch with his uncle, William Sennett, who left the Communist party in 1958 and became boss of a transportation company while never losing his radical politics. Sennett was raised alone by his mother, Dorothy, whom he describes as a "remarkable woman and a fantastic writer. She had wanted to be a writer in the 30s but after my father left she was down on her luck and her dream was shattered."

She later became a distinguished social worker, an occupation she took up, says Sennett, "to arm her against pity". Now 91, and still living in the States, she continued to write until a few years ago. From the mid to late 40s mother and son lived on the Cabrini Green public housing project in Chicago, notorious for its poverty and violence. In book to be published by Penguin, provisionally entitled Socialism: An Essay On Honour And Dishonour, Sennett describes Cabrini Green, which was built during the second world war, as a "mixed community of blacks, the wounded, and the deranged (which) defined all-too tangibly what it meant to be left behind during the post-war boom".

A certain number of places were reserved for the white poor. In the so called "glass wars" black and white youths would sling sheets of broken glass across the street at each other. A young black girl nearly died of cuts to her neck. Yet, as Sennett has since written, this dangerous pursuit was more about the dubious satisfactions of gang warfare than racial revenge. The poor whites saw paternalistic social workers as part of the same threatening "them" as their black neighbours.

The Sennetts lived in two rooms with a bath, but were to some extent isolated from the wider "screaming, laughing, wailing, shouting life" of the housing projects. Playing the cello at six and composing at eight, living in a flat filled with books, the serious young boy could see a way out. "We had a tough time financially, but in the bohemian, radical milieu in which we lived, we were just another family," he says. "It had a curious class composition, this world. Most were Jewish, but it was a cultural milieu, not an ethnic one."

Sennett still remembers at school, "seeing a couple of men in a car watching me play. They wanted to find out who my playmates were. I think they assumed they could get into a network of activities through me. McCarthyism produced a horrible period in American history." By 13 Sennett was already performing in public. He was driven in a little VW bus to play Bach cantatas to exhausted miners in a small town in Minnesota, "people who had never heard classical music before. It was wonderful." It was also on a visit to France to perform that he learned to speak the language fluently and began to make contacts with influential artistic and intellectual figures such as Pierre Boulez and Michel Foucault.

Sennett's hopes of becoming a professional cellist were dashed in 1962, when he developed a form of carpal tunnel syndrome. A disastrous hand operation made his condition worse. His performing career was over. But then the Harvard sociologist David Riesman invited him to Harvard to "figure out what you want to do". It was, Sennett says, a lot easier to get into Harvard in those days. He was then caught up "in all this political stuff, in the 60s". He also discovered that with the help of an electric typewriter he could write painlessly. "I can still recall the joy of being able to do something expressive that wasn't physically painful."

Sennett began teaching at Yale in the late 60s. In the early 70s he went to New York University, where he later set up the influential New York Institute of the Humanities. The young sociologist made his name with his first two books, The Uses Of Disorder, a study of the effect of city life on personal identity, and The Hidden Injuries Of Class, written with Jonathan Cobb, a study of working-class confusion about self and status in a more affluent world.

Sennett and Cobb had set out to understand why an "increase in material power and freedom of choice should be accompanied by a crisis in self respect". Sennett says now that they were innocents. "Sociologists traditionally tended towards opinion surveys. We conducted the work rather as an anthropologist might have done. And we began with completely the wrong intuition, as I so often do in my work. I think it's going to be about politics and outer-world stuff, about economics. But it is often people talking out their subjectivity. In The Hidden Injuries Of Class, people are ashamed that they're not middle class, even though they have contempt for that class.

"In The Corrosion Of Character, published in 1998, the class issue is somewhat effaced and it is more about the long term organisation of one's activity, the narrative of one's own life, rather than one's relation to others. In both cases, though, the issue is lack of mastery over one's life."

The Hidden Injuries Of Class still makes fascinating reading, largely because of its sensitive and subtle exploration of working-class lives. It dissects the ways in which doctrines of equality may work against most people in the modern world; with inherited social distinctions now apparently erased, "social difference can now appear as a question of character, of moral resolve, will and competence". It is an argument which has as much resonance in the age of so-called depressed affluence as it had 30 years ago.

It was clear from these early books that Sennett was a skillful writer. At its best, his sociology reads like a subtle, psychological novel, an absorbing biography or a piece of really good journalism. It amply fulfils his claim to be "a report on the act of thinking". His aim, he says, is to make sociology a form of literature, "as it was in the 19th century. This question of style is a huge issue in sociology," he says. "There's a great gap between politics and expression. So many academics are closed, anxious about performance and status. Foucault wrote in clear evocative French, but his followers have a possessive obscurity. Roland Barthes was a wonderful writer but there is a paralysis about his acolytes."

In 1974 Sennett published what was to become probably his best known book, The Fall Of Public Man, a study of changing forms of public and city life which was also a powerful argument for a more formal public culture and a swipe against the rise of a self-indulgent counter-culture. "Masses of people are concerned with their single life histories and particular emotion as never before; this concern has proved to be a trap rather than a liberation," he wrote. Given that each self is "in some measure a cabinet of horrors, civilised relations between selves can only proceed to the extent that nasty little secrets of desire, greed or envy are kept locked up".

Homi Bhabha, professor of sociology at the University of Chicago, first met Sennett only a few years ago, but as early as 1980 or 1981, he says, "a colleague had urged me to read The Fall Of Public Man. It was a book I'd flirted with but never really read. I realised that it brought in a whole range of social and intellectual interests and experience.

It was completely different from the evaluative, numerical view of experience of his number-crunching contemporaries. If I had to sum up Richard's work, I would say he is always interested in the relation between authority and experience." But the book was not without its critics. The radical commentator Russell Jacoby described it as "diffuse, vague, uncritical. Few pages attain clarity; few seem crafted." In Sennett's intellectual world, says Jacoby, "everyone adds a little piece to the story; everyone points out, reminds, or discovers something Sennett finds interesting. The pluralism and graciousness are estimable but also costly. Sennett nods to and compliments everyone he encounters. The warm collegiality that flows through his books douses the spark of ideas."

Such "warm collegiality" may have found its perfect expression in the New York Institute of Humanities, which Sennett co-founded and ran from the late 70s. He describes the institute as "an effort to create a 'town-gown' intellectual centre in new York, combining academia, the worlds of publishing and writing, musicians, diplomats, journalists, politicians, painters... a kind of All Souls with lousy food and lots of good talk".

Sennett ran the institute with the writer Edmund White, and its first fellows included Susan Sontag, Joseph Brodsky, Thomas Kuhn and Michel Foucault. White later wrote the experience up in his book Caracole as the "chat shop". Sennett says, "We did chat but we also supported a lot of starving intellectuals." It was in the mid to late 80s that Sennett also published three novels, The Frog That Dared To Croak, An Evening With Brahms, and Palais Royal, which were undertaken partly as a way "of recovering my word craft".

City life, with its promise of anonymity and community, is one of the great loves of Sennett's life. In The Uses Of Disorder he observes that "the city alone can make us conscious of a kind of equilibrium of disorder... the enemies lose their clear image, because every day one sees so many people who are alien but are all alien in the same way". Much of his later work, such as The Conscience Of The Eye, (1990) and Flesh And Stone, (1994) are attempts to trace the history between humans and the built environment.

The architect Richard Rogers, who has known Sennett for 15 years, says, "We are very much on the same intellectual wavelength. Richard believes in the importance of the public domain, that people should have direct involvement in relation to public space and buildings. We are both interested in sustainable development and the role of cities in a civil society."

City life also fosters the kind of intense but unclaustrophobic friendships that Sennett thrives on. "He has a near genius for contacts and friendship," says Victoria Glendinning. LSE director Anthony Giddens describes Sennett as "very lively, well-connected, good at talking to people. He has always had a wider coverage than the rest of us." Such friends describe Sennett as full of plans and curiosity, "always building castles in the air... some of which he will make happen" and as a good cook and generous host.

"Richard has the most astonishing ability to re-invent himself. He must be in about his fifth life by now," says the writer and old friend Marina Warner. However, on his private life, Sennett is guarded to a point of gracious stubbornness. He first married in 1968, the marriage being annulled later that year. He says only "I married very young and I divorced young." He was married again between 1974-78. He is more forthcoming on his present marriage to Saskia Sassen, 53, a formidable academic in her own right whom he met in New York in the early 80s and to whom he has been married for 14 years. Sassen, a specialist on the global economy, holds chairs in sociology at the University of Chicago and in political economy at the LSE. Sennett says "Saskia and I write about many of the same things. People imagine our pillow talk is all about the global economy. Well it isn't, well not much." Richard Rogers describes the couple as a "very interesting twosome, overlapping in their interests, but specialising in different areas. They are a powerhouse, but a very nice, humanist powerhouse."

Glendinning tells a story about the couple staying at a mutual friend's country house. The host told her that after everyone had gone to bed, peals of laughter were heard coming from their bedroom. Glendinning thinks that "for a couple who are apart an awful lot of the time, it works very well when they are together". Sennett, who has no children of his own, is by all accounts a devoted stepfather to Saskia's only son, Hilary, 25, a sculptor in New York.

Sennett's alliance with Sassen may have prompted him to the more international and economic emphasis of The Corrosion Of Character, published in 1998, a lucid study of the insecurities of the new economy and the ways in which it has warped the qualities of loyalty, trust, commitment and self-discipline. It is vintage Sennett, moving easily between 19th century political theory and 20th century interview and reportage. There is a masterly if somewhat ambiguous account of a visit to Davos, the Swiss resort that hosts the annual meeting of world business and political leaders. Here, one can almost feel Sennett torn between his sympathy and admiration for the skills of global leaders and an emotion bordering on contempt fortheir "ethical neutrality".

But if he is rarely critical of individuals, he holds nothing back in his criticism of the new economy in which "to make it you really have to plunge into much more superficial social relations. It is dysfunctional to feel loyalty to an organisation. The notion of accumulating a life history with an institution or a person doesn't work in this economy. The boom gave people the impression that the class divide was going to end - that there would be no losers. In fact, it has made it worse."

He is currently overseeing a research project in New York which involves interviewing young people in their 20s, who have gone into financial services, IT and the new media. They are confused, he says: "Everyone thinks they are going to be the next Martha Lane Fox but they are learning very quickly that all these fantasy worlds just aren't going to happen. Don't commit, don't be dependent, stay loose. Loyalty is very low on this list. But if you think dependence is bad, what you produce is a damaged human being."

Ruth Levitas of the University of Bristol describes The Corrosion Of Character as a "wonderful description of the way in which insecure work has taken away the basics for a certain kind of character". But she also thinks there's something about the thesis "that doesn't work in relation to women, something that's not quite right. Ultimately, I felt the book doesn't address gender".

Sennett has, he says "a complicated relationship with my country, an incredible ambivalence. I am uneasy when I am outside New York. The United States is very rich, but not very realistic. All the good things in US life are hidden while what is on the surface is stupid. America probably has the most sustained set of voluntary social relationships, charitable groups and citizen participation. Yet most small-town Americans have political attitudes to the right of Atilla the Hun. It's a real conundrum." The Corrosion Of Character was a bestseller in Germany, which may contribute to a feeling in some quarters that Sennett is "an American read by Europeans".

In his work in progress, Socialism: An Essay On Honour And Dishonour, he attempts to find a place for socialism after communism, "in particular to understand what notions of dependence and mutuality mean in the context of capitalism which is really focused on issues of individual competence". Even New Labour, which he broadly supports, "fosters this impossible image of a kind of New Labour superman".

In middle age, Sennett says he has returned to his political roots. "I started out in the 60s when it was pretty fevered on the left. And then I moved right in reaction to all the bullshit of the counter- culture. I got fed up with that anti intellectualism, the rejection of serious ideas, of serious art and the measurement of reality by psychological categories of the moment, an emphasis on immediate gratification."

The Fall Of Public Man was anti-psychological, an anti-touchy-feely book and in American terms, that was anti-radical. But the error he made, he says, was to draw political consequences from his rejection of the counter-culture... a trajectory that has finally brought him back to the left. "This genetic socialism reasserted itself and I've returned to overtly writing about socialism. In America, I voted Green at the last election for the simple reason that it has become a party with a single overarching ideal - electoral reform, which means ending the private funding of politics in the US.

"Even when I had this period of disillusion with the cultural left, I still voted Socialist Worker. I voted for the party not in one of its Trotskyist phases, which I hated, but in one of its Green, multicultural, pluralist phases, which I like." He talks about meeting President Clinton, who said to him"It's always good to meet an intelligent Democrat." "When I told him I voted Socialist Worker the famous Clinton smile froze."

Sennett lives most of the year in London, returning to the States for three months. Sassen similarly divides her time between the two countries. Although Sennett describes London as "our emotional base" he appears genuinely outraged at "the degree of bureaucratic micro-management in [British] academia. My colleagues, particularly the younger ones, are very depressed by it. Academics are constantly filling out forms, their emails can be looked at by the government. In America, there is far more appreciation of academics than in official Britain. Here there is an institutionalised contempt which makes it hard to do good work."

At the same time he describes his students here, "as the best I've ever had". Sennett claims he has written enough. He would like to end his days as he began them, as a professional performer or possibly running a music festival, maybe somewhere like the Wigmore Hall in London. When he has finished the current book on socialism, "I have probably only one book left in me. I would like to do something on the sociology of performing."

Music remains his great love and he has returned to playing the cello after several operations on his hand. "The ability to play again is one of the greatest gifts middle age has brought me." He plays in a small chamber group, with, among others, the Guardian's editor, Alan Rusbridger, on clarinet. But the popular reception for a work like The Corrosion Of Character suggests there is a hunger out there for the informed, exploratory, and in some ways gentle anti-capitalism that Sennett represents. With his grasp of history, his sympathy for the radical cause, his understanding of city life and his own professional success, he is one of the few writers who can puncture the pretensions and false hopes of the New Economy with some authority.

He was also one of the first writers to predict, again with admirable restraint, the economic and political turbulence that may lie ahead. For, as the chilling last line of the Corrosion Of Character observes, a regime "which provides human beings no deep reasons to care about one another cannot long preserve its legitimacy".

Life at a glance: Richard Sennett

Born: January 1 1943, Chicago.

Educated: Breck School; University of Chicago; Juilliard Conservatory New York (external student); Harvard University.

Married: First married 1968 (annulled 68); Caroline Rand Herron 74-78; Saskia Sassen 87.

Career: Yale University, lecturer 68-70; Brandeis University, asst. professor 70-72; New York University, professor 72-98. London School of Economics 99-.

Some books: Nineteenth Century Cities: Essays In The New Urban History (co-author) 69; Classic Essays On The Culture Of Cities (editor) 69; The Uses Of Disorder, Personal Identity And City Life, 70; The Hidden Injuries Of Class, (with Jonathan Cobb) 72; The Fall Of Public Man, 74; Authority 80; Flesh And Stone: The Body And The City In Western Civilisation 94; The Corrosion Of Character, The Personal Consequences Of Work In the New Capitalism, 98.

Novels: The Frog Who Dared to Croak 82; An Evening of Brahms 84; Palais Royal 86.

But it is often people talking out their subjectivity. In The Hidden Injuries Of Class, people are ashamed that they're not middle class, even though they have contempt for that class. "In The Corrosion Of Character, published in 1998, the class issue is somewhat effaced and it is more about the long term organisation of one's activity, the narrative of one's own life, rather than one's relation to others. In both cases, though, the issue is lack of mastery over one's life." The Hidden Injuries Of Class still makes fascinating reading, largely because of its sensitive and subtle exploration of working-class lives. It dissects the ways in which doctrines of equality may work against most people in the modern world; with inherited social distinctions now apparently erased, "social difference can now appear as a question of character, of moral resolve, will and competence". It is an argument which has as much resonance in the age of so-called depressed affluence as it had 30 years ago. It was clear from these early books that Sennett was a skillful writer. At its best, his sociology reads like a subtle, psychological novel, an absorbing biography or a piece of really good journalism. It amply fulfils his claim to be "a report on the act of thinking". His aim, he says, is to make sociology a form of literature, "as it was in the 19th century. This question of style is a huge issue in sociology," he says. "There's a great gap between politics and expression. So many academics are closed, anxious about performance and status. Foucault wrote in clear evocative French, but his followers have a possessive obscurity. Roland Barthes was a wonderful writer but there is a paralysis about his acolytes." In 1974 Sennett published what was to become probably his best known book, The Fall Of Public Man, a study of changing forms of public and city life which was also a powerful argument for a more formal public culture and a swipe against the rise of a self-indulgent counter-culture. "Masses of people are concerned with their single life histories and particular emotion as never before; this concern has proved to be a trap rather than a liberation," he wrote. Given that each self is "in some measure a cabinet of horrors, civilised relations between selves can only proceed to the extent that nasty little secrets of desire, greed or envy are kept locked up". Homi Bhabha, professor of sociology at the University of Chicago, first met Sennett only a few years ago, but as early as 1980 or 1981, he says, "a colleague had urged me to read The Fall Of Public Man. It was a book I'd flirted with but never really read. I realised that it brought in a whole range of social and intellectual interests and experience. It was completely different from the evaluative, numerical view of experience of his number-crunching contemporaries. If I had to sum up Richard's work, I would say he is always interested in the relation between authority and experience." But the book was not without its critics. The radical commentator Russell Jacoby described it as "diffuse, vague, uncritical. Few pages attain clarity; few seem crafted." In Sennett's intellectual world, says Jacoby, "everyone adds a little piece to the story; everyone points out, reminds, or discovers something Sennett finds interesting. The pluralism and graciousness are estimable but also costly. Sennett nods to and compliments everyone he encounters. The warm collegiality that flows through his books douses the spark of ideas." Such "warm collegiality" may have found its perfect expression in the New York Institute of Humanities, which Sennett co-founded and ran from the late 70s. He describes the institute as "an effort to create a 'town-gown' intellectual centre in new York, combining academia, the worlds of publishing and writing, musicians, diplomats, journalists, politicians, painters... a kind of All Souls with lousy food and lots of good talk". Sennett ran the institute with the writer Edmund White, and its first fellows included Susan Sontag, Joseph Brodsky, Thomas Kuhn and Michel Foucault. White later wrote the experience up in his book Caracole as the "chat shop". Sennett says, "We did chat but we also supported a lot of starving intellectuals." It was in the mid to late 80s that Sennett also published three novels, The Frog That Dared To Croak, An Evening With Brahms, and Palais Royal, which were undertaken partly as a way "of recovering my word craft". City life, with its promise of anonymity and community, is one of the great loves of Sennett's life. In The Uses Of Disorder he observes that "the city alone can make us conscious of a kind of equilibrium of disorder... the enemies lose their clear image, because every day one sees so many people who are alien but are all alien in the same way". Much of his later work, such as The Conscience Of The Eye, (1990) and Flesh And Stone, (1994) are attempts to trace the history between humans and the built environment. The architect Richard Rogers, who has known Sennett for 15 years, says, "We are very much on the same intellectual wavelength. Richard believes in the importance of the public domain, that people should have direct involvement in relation to public space and buildings. We are both interested in sustainable development and the role of cities in a civil society." City life also fosters the kind of intense but unclaustrophobic friendships that Sennett thrives on. "He has a near genius for contacts and friendship," says Victoria Glendinning. LSE director Anthony Giddens describes Sennett as "very lively, well-connected, good at talking to people. He has always had a wider coverage than the rest of us." Such friends describe Sennett as full of plans and curiosity, "always building castles in the air... some of which he will make happen" and as a good cook and generous host. "Richard has the most astonishing ability to re-invent himself. He must be in about his fifth life by now," says the writer and old friend Marina Warner. However, on his private life, Sennett is guarded to a point of gracious stubbornness. He first married in 1968, the marriage being annulled later that year. He says only "I married very young and I divorced young." He was married again between 1974-78. He is more forthcoming on his present marriage to Saskia Sassen, 53, a formidable academic in her own right whom he met in New York in the early 80s and to whom he has been married for 14 years. Sassen, a specialist on the global economy, holds chairs in sociology at the University of Chicago and in political economy at the LSE. Sennett says "Saskia and I write about many of the same things. People imagine our pillow talk is all about the global economy. Well it isn't, well not much." Richard Rogers describes the couple as a "very interesting twosome, overlapping in their interests, but specialising in different areas. They are a powerhouse, but a very nice, humanist powerhouse." Glendinning tells a story about the couple staying at a mutual friend's country house. The host told her that after everyone had gone to bed, peals of laughter were heard coming from their bedroom. Glendinning thinks that "for a couple who are apart an awful lot of the time, it works very well when they are together". Sennett, who has no children of his own, is by all accounts a devoted stepfather to Saskia's only son, Hilary, 25, a sculptor in New York. Sennett's alliance with Sassen may have prompted him to the more international and economic emphasis of The Corrosion Of Character, published in 1998, a lucid study of the insecurities of the new economy and the ways in which it has warped the qualities of loyalty, trust, commitment and self-discipline. It is vintage Sennett, moving easily between 19th century political theory and 20th century interview and reportage. There is a masterly if somewhat ambiguous account of a visit to Davos, the Swiss resort that hosts the annual meeting of world business and political leaders. Here, one can almost feel Sennett torn between his sympathy and admiration for the skills of global leaders and an emotion bordering on contempt fortheir "ethical neutrality". But if he is rarely critical of individuals, he holds nothing back in his criticism of the new economy in which "to make it you really have to plunge into much more superficial social relations. It is dysfunctional to feel loyalty to an organisation. The notion of accumulating a life history with an institution or a person doesn't work in this economy. The boom gave people the impression that the class divide was going to end - that there would be no losers. In fact, it has made it worse." He is currently overseeing a research project in New York which involves interviewing young people in their 20s, who have gone into financial services, IT and the new media. They are confused, he says: "Everyone thinks they are going to be the next Martha Lane Fox but they are learning very quickly that all these fantasy worlds just aren't going to happen. Don't commit, don't be dependent, stay loose. Loyalty is very low on this list. But if you think dependence is bad, what you produce is a damaged human being." Ruth Levitas of the University of Bristol describes The Corrosion Of Character as a "wonderful description of the way in which insecure work has taken away the basics for a certain kind of character". But she also thinks there's something about the thesis "that doesn't work in relation to women, something that's not quite right. Ultimately, I felt the book doesn't address gender". Sennett has, he says "a complicated relationship with my country, an incredible ambivalence. I am uneasy when I am outside New York. The United States is very rich, but not very realistic. All the good things in US life are hidden while what is on the surface is stupid. America probably has the most sustained set of voluntary social relationships, charitable groups and citizen participation. Yet most small-town Americans have political attitudes to the right of Atilla the Hun. It's a real conundrum." The Corrosion Of Character was a bestseller in Germany, which may contribute to a feeling in some quarters that Sennett is "an American read by Europeans". In his work in progress, Socialism: An Essay On Honour And Dishonour, he attempts to find a place for socialism after communism, "in particular to understand what notions of dependence and mutuality mean in the context of capitalism which is really focused on issues of individual competence". Even New Labour, which he broadly supports, "fosters this impossible image of a kind of New Labour superman". In middle age, Sennett says he has returned to his political roots. "I started out in the 60s when it was pretty fevered on the left. And then I moved right in reaction to all the bullshit of the counter- culture. I got fed up with that anti intellectualism, the rejection of serious ideas, of serious art and the measurement of reality by psychological categories of the moment, an emphasis on immediate gratification." The Fall Of Public Man was anti-psychological, an anti-touchy-feely book and in American terms, that was anti-radical. But the error he made, he says, was to draw political consequences from his rejection of the counter-culture... a trajectory that has finally brought him back to the left. "This genetic socialism reasserted itself and I've returned to overtly writing about socialism. In America, I voted Green at the last election for the simple reason that it has become a party with a single overarching ideal - electoral reform, which means ending the private funding of politics in the US. "Even when I had this period of disillusion with the cultural left, I still voted Socialist Worker. I voted for the party not in one of its Trotskyist phases, which I hated, but in one of its Green, multicultural, pluralist phases, which I like." He talks about meeting President Clinton, who said to him"It's always good to meet an intelligent Democrat." "When I told him I voted Socialist Worker the famous Clinton smile froze." Sennett lives most of the year in London, returning to the States for three months. Sassen similarly divides her time between the two countries. Although Sennett describes London as "our emotional base" he appears genuinely outraged at "the degree of bureaucratic micro-management in [British] academia. My colleagues, particularly the younger ones, are very depressed by it. Academics are constantly filling out forms, their emails can be looked at by the government. In America, there is far more appreciation of academics than in official Britain. Here there is an institutionalised contempt which makes it hard to do good work." At the same time he describes his students here, "as the best I've ever had". Sennett claims he has written enough. He would like to end his days as he began them, as a professional performer or possibly running a music festival, maybe somewhere like the Wigmore Hall in London. When he has finished the current book on socialism, "I have probably only one book left in me. I would like to do something on the sociology of performing." Music remains his great love and he has returned to playing the cello after several operations on his hand. "The ability to play again is one of the greatest gifts middle age has brought me." He plays in a small chamber group, with, among others, the Guardian's editor, Alan Rusbridger, on clarinet. But the popular reception for a work like The Corrosion Of Character suggests there is a hunger out there for the informed, exploratory, and in some ways gentle anti-capitalism that Sennett represents. With his grasp of history, his sympathy for the radical cause, his understanding of city life and his own professional success, he is one of the few writers who can puncture the pretensions and false hopes of the New Economy with some authority. He was also one of the first writers to predict, again with admirable restraint, the economic and political turbulence that may lie ahead. For, as the chilling last line of the Corrosion Of Character observes, a regime "which provides human beings no deep reasons to care about one another cannot long preserve its legitimacy". Life at a glance: Richard Sennett Born: January 1 1943, Chicago. Educated: Breck School; University of Chicago; Juilliard Conservatory New York (external student); Harvard University. Married: First married 1968 (annulled 68); Caroline Rand Herron 74-78; Saskia Sassen 87. Career: Yale University, lecturer 68-70; Brandeis University, asst. professor 70-72; New York University, professor 72-98. London School of Economics 99-. Some books: Nineteenth Century Cities: Essays In The New Urban History (co-author) 69; Classic Essays On The Culture Of Cities (editor) 69; The Uses Of Disorder, Personal Identity And City Life, 70; The Hidden Injuries Of Class, (with Jonathan Cobb) 72; The Fall Of Public Man, 74; Authority 80; Flesh And Stone: The Body And The City In Western Civilisation 94; The Corrosion Of Character, The Personal Consequences Of Work In the New Capitalism, 98. Novels: The Frog Who Dared to Croak 82; An Evening of Brahms 84; Palais Royal 86.

fields.headline: Mr Fixit and chums
fields.standfirst: Counter-intelligence agent, presidential speech-writer, Broadway producer, newspaper owner and friend of the stars... Donald Seawell, saviour of the Trojan epic Tantalus, talks to  Michael Billington
fields.trailText: Counter-intelligence agent, presidential speech-writer, Broadway producer, newspaper owner and friend of the stars... Donald Seawell, saviour of the Trojan epic Tantalus, talks to Michael Billington
fields.body:
When John Barton's Trojan war cycle Tantalus gets its British premiere tonight in a marathon 12-hour stint at the Lowry in Salford, it will be largely because of the iron determination of the 88-year-old Donald Seawell. In a long life, Seawell has played many parts: lawyer, Broadway producer, newspaper proprietor and presidential speechwriter. But it was as chairman of the Denver Center for the Performing Arts that he personally authorised the spending of $8m that turned Tantalus from a tantalising dream into a theatrical reality. Talking to him at London's Connaught Hotel, I was struck by Seawell's old-world courtesy and passionate liberalism; but there is something in his piercing gaze that persuades me he is a man who also likes to get his way.

As an RSC governor, Seawell has known John Barton - and Peter Hall - for 40 years and was well aware of the prolonged gestation of Barton's Trojan epic. "As soon as I read the manuscript," he says, "I knew this was something I wanted to be involved in. When it started out there were six potential backers, but one by one they all fell out. Finally, there was only the Denver Center left so I had to gulp and say, 'OK, we'll do it.' The money actually comes from a foundation that was set up in 1981 when I sold the Denver Post to the Times-Mirror group. Backing Tantalus was entirely a personal decision, which my board happily went along with."

A classic case of enlightened patronage. But given Tantalus's well-documented rehearsal problems, did Seawell ever have doubts? "Oh, many," he says. "But I have only one regret, and that is the rift it has caused between John Barton and Peter Hall, which I hope can be patched up. John's complaint basically is that Peter has cut one of his plays and that he wasn't notified in advance of the textual changes. Peter's argument was that there was too much exposition and no proper ending. Having been a Broadway producer, I can sympathise with both sides. I think what John wants is for Peter to say, 'I went too far and I'm sorry.' But I doubt that Peter will say that and I'm not even sure he feels it."

Whatever Tantalus's internal tensions, Seawell was thrilled with the result, especially by the fact that at one of Denver's packed- out performances there were people from 14 countries. But while Tantalus may be the crowning example of Seawell's gift for backing the right horse - even a Trojan one - what is extraordinary is his lifelong ability to move between different worlds. For instance, how did he, as a New York lawyer, become adviser and producer to such showbiz icons as Noël Coward, Tallulah Bankhead and the celebrated acting duo Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne?

"They were all friends of my wife, Eugenia Rawls, who was an actress, and they all asked me to represent them. I was especially close to the Lunts, who often referred to me as the son they never had. Alfred used to write to me every day. But, after I'd moved to Denver to publish the Post, one of the partners in my New York office cleaned out all the files - something lawyers do every six years - and so all the letters were lost. That broke my heart."

Slightly more surprising is Seawell's closeness to Tallulah. She had a famous gift for outrage that once led her to remark that she favoured the conventional position for love-making because the alternatives gave her either claustrophobia or lockjaw. "Sex to Tallulah," Seawell suggests, "was no more important than shaking hands. Once that was out of the way, she was the most caring and devoted person. She was also a remarkable, if undisciplined, actress: when she played Blanche in Streetcar, Tennessee Williams, who had written the part for her, went backstage, got down on his knees and said she was the greatest Blanche he ever expected to see."

On another occasion, Williams also told her, given their shared appetites and religious upbringing: "Tallulah, you and I are the only two constantly high High Episcopalians I know." But what Seawell prefers to remember is her active endorsement of civil liberties and universal justice.

Seawell's own life has also been devoted to liberal causes. Everything from the National Endowment for the Arts to Family Health International. He was also a speechwriter for Roosevelt and Truman and was asked by Kennedy to start a performance series for his cabinet, which led to him bringing Barton's the Hollow Crown to the State Department. But did he get on equally well with Republican incumbents?

"Well, I worked in counter- intelligence with Eisenhower during the war, and as a general he was wonderful. But I remember Ike circulating a memorandum to his staff in which he said he'd been approached to run for president. He said, 'I want you to know that under no circumstances will I accept the nomination. No military man should because his training has been too narrow.' He certainly turned out to be a hands-off president: he played golf more than 600 times during his eight years but the economy was booming so it didn't matter too much.

"Nixon was altogether different. In fact, I made his enemies-list. I was chairman of the American National Theatre and Academy and we'd been commissioned to send plays abroad, one of which Nixon vetoed on political grounds. I wrote to him to protest. At the time I was also publishing the Denver Post and we didn't support Nixon. So when my name was submitted as a trustee for the Kennedy Center, he struck it out, wrote 'This man is against me' and inserted Trisha Nixon's name instead."

Seawell's liberalism, however, is balanced by strong convictions. As publisher of the Denver Post he encouraged columns expressing every shade of political opinion. But, in a crucial presidential election, his editorial board came to him and said they'd voted 16 to nil for one particular candidate. "I said to them, 'You're now outvoted one to 16.' The candidate they had chosen was Ronald Reagan, who was a personal friend of mine, but I didn't let that stand in my way."

But Seawell's lasting memorial will be the Denver Center for Performing Arts. When he first proposed the idea of an arts centre back in the early 1970s, the local mayor told him that it was an impossible dream because fewer than 3,000 people in the metropolitan area had ever been to a live performance.

Now the centre is a vast, booming complex that houses eight performance spaces, boasts its own resident theatre company and has sundry offshoots including a media studio and an acting academy. "Last year," says Seawell, "a million and a half people in Denver came to see theatre alone, and that's not including ballet, symphony and opera. For a city of under two million that's not bad."

Seawell embodies a kind of plutocratic liberalism that is peculiarly American: one based on private wealth and public service, and the notion that it's everyone's duty to leave the world a little better than they found it. I suspect there is a good deal of toughness under the silvery charm and that, having encouraged plurality of opinon, he enjoys having the final say. But as he takes his seat in Salford tonight, he can congratulate himself on the fact that, but for his swiftly unilateral action, Tantalus would have remained nothing more than a deskbound Attic dream.

 At the Lowry, Salford (0161-876 2000), tonight then touring.

webTitle: Getting big ideas in my umbel abode

fields.headline: Getting big ideas in my umbel abode
fields.trailText: A garden from a hundred packets of seeds
fields.body:
Flowers for their Size

"I love flowers," says a friend, "but I don't like plants." I can easily understand the distinction. Plants involve mess and responsibility and edaphic ("of or pertaining to the soil") requirements. They perhaps expect a commitment of us that we are not, at this stage in our lives, prepared to give. Flowers can seem to come out of nowhere. Bought, arranged, admired, chucked out - they are given no chance to reproach us. Arum lilies are like this: spotless, exotic, unreal. One can tell from his photographs that Robert Mapplethorpe loved flowers. One hardly expects him to have liked plants.

Among the plants for people who don't really like plants is the recently popular category called "architectural"? What is an architectural plant? It is something big, and possibly expensive, and of a bold shape - above all something that promises to make an immediate and permanent impact on the space we are filling - but its resemblance to actual architecture may be minimal. A stand of bamboo does not remind me of any architecture I know, even though I have lived in countries where much of the architecture uses bamboo. And what building looks like a phormium?

If I gaze up at a giant hogweed ( Heracleum mantegazzianum , a plant which we may not grow - an irresponsible plant), I may indeed be reminded of gothic fan vaulting. But a giant hogweed is not an architectural plant in the popular sense, because by the end of the year it is going to let us down: this beautiful structure will die back. I might add that if the giant hogweed looks architectural in its structure, then so do many umbellifers of different scale: cow-parsley, dill, and (a crop failure for us last year) Ammi majus , known in one of my books as false bishop's weed. (False bishops! When have you ever met a bishop who wasn't false?)

Still, if we are to be thwarted in our ambitions to have the giant hogweed romping around the periphery, the angelicas are there as our reward, the grand old sentinels of vegetable gardens. I would choose (no 11) the oriental Angelica gigas , purple stemmed and purple flowered, although we have found it to be monocarpic (that is, it dies after flowering).

In general, experimenting with various angelicas, we have found them easiest to keep going by shaking the seeds out of the ripe seedheads and allowing them to grow where they fall (they do not remain viable long). A plant, then, which may take a couple of years to reach full size. There follows one summer of glory, before it goes over. Such a habit cannot easily be accommodated in the kind of garden in which every scrap of space is supposed to be maximally active, year in, year out.

All those umbels, all those umbellules. My garden is the subject of crazes, but with an underlying tendency towards the encyclopedic. So the umbellifer craze makes an investment of time and space in (no 12) the Giant Fennel, Ferula communis , obligatory, given the prospect of an eventual (they say) five-metre flower-spike (only likely under Mediterranean conditions). I am warned that it may be advisable to remove this spike before large amounts of seed are set, to keep the plant perennial. But what we want from such plants is the spectacle they offer as they go, so we must pay for this.

With anything that grows really, really fast and large in a temperate climate, there is likely to be a price to pay. A ceanothus will romp up a wall, but its wood and its roots will be vulnerable to wind. The wonderfully obliging (no 13) Abutilon vitifolium , which is a 10-foot tall woody mallow, coming with white or lavender flowers, similarly produces a wood which needs the protection of a wall. After a few years, although the stem is thick at the base, the whole becomes overdeveloped and ungainly. If something puts on six foot of growth in a year, one cannot expect that growth to be of the quality of, say, teak. The abutilon makes a bargain with us: it grows fast, and can easily be replaced from its own seed. But it does need replacing - it is not "architectural".

fields.bodyText: Flowers for their Size "I love flowers," says a friend, "but I don't like plants." I can easily understand the distinction. Plants involve mess and responsibility and edaphic ("of or pertaining to the soil") requirements. They perhaps expect a commitment of us that we are not, at this stage in our lives, prepared to give. Flowers can seem to come out of nowhere. Bought, arranged, admired, chucked out - they are given no chance to reproach us. Arum lilies are like this: spotless, exotic, unreal. One can tell from his photographs that Robert Mapplethorpe loved flowers. One hardly expects him to have liked plants. Among the plants for people who don't really like plants is the recently popular category called "architectural"? What is an architectural plant? It is something big, and possibly expensive, and of a bold shape - above all something that promises to make an immediate and permanent impact on the space we are filling - but its resemblance to actual architecture may be minimal. A stand of bamboo does not remind me of any architecture I know, even though I have lived in countries where much of the architecture uses bamboo. And what building looks like a phormium?
