fields.headline: The last word on   Nature
fields.standfirst: Nature is no spendthrift, but takes the shortest way to her ends. -  Emerson
fields.trailText: Nature is no spendthrift, but takes the shortest way to her ends. - Emerson
fields.body:
Fragile human life often finds itself confronting nature's larger gestures - earthquakes, volcanoes, hurricanes, floods, droughts, pestilences and plagues, even fiery meteors from space. Nevertheless we choose to assume that, generally speaking, nature's ordered and law-like ways are benign. The power of a natural disaster is an abrupt reminder that they are not - a fact sadly manifest in the Gujarat earthquake, whose effects have daily grown more appalling as its true dimensions emerge, evoking profound sympathy for those whose lives are for ever marked by a few mighty and remorseless seconds of geophysics.

The reason for the earthquake's occurrence is the same as the reason for the Himalayas' height. Those stupendous mountains mark the meeting point of the Indian and Eurasian tectonic plates, two of the giant scales constituting the earth's surface. The Indian plate is moving slowly northwards, at a few inches a year - the same speed as one's fingernails grow - converging with the southern edge of the Eurasian plate and lifting it. Everest is therefore the index of a monumental collision taking place more slowly than human senses can register - until, that is, stresses in the crust beneath our feet are released, and plate tectonics is revealed as a Samson bringing the temple of our certainties down around our ears.

Millions of tiny earthquakes happen daily, almost all of them too minor to detect. Newcomers to Japan are disconcerted to notice palpable tremors every few hours, until habituation makes them fade away. While one is still aware of them one recognises the frailty of human tenancy among nature's indifferent forces. Even then one does not really believe that a disaster might suddenly strike: there are things to do, people to meet, tasks to fulfil: how could things not go according to reasonable plan - which includes nature behaving itself?

Such is the frame of mind of many who live along the San Andreas Fault, or in the hurricane belt of the southern United States, or along the low banks of Bangladesh's rivers. But as Turgenev wrote, "Nature cares nothing for our human logic; she has her own, which we do not acknowledge until we are crushed under her wheel."

At the same time, nature is as unyielding in defending itself as it is in exploding our expectations. A man is frail when a mountain falls on him; but give him the slimmest chance of survival, a fissure to crawl into as an escape from the engulfing rock, and he will survive. People have been pulled from the rubble of Bhuj and Ahmedabad in Gujarat days after the earthquake struck, among them an eight-month-old baby. They illustrate the tenacity of life, which Schopenhauer described as an instance of the general metaphysical will underlying all things - the determined struggle for continuation.

Schopenhauer thought that the will to exist is a bad thing, because it pointlessly perpetuates suffering. But others are not so pessimistic, and redescribe nature's neutrality as even-handedness. "Why should we fear to be crushed by savage elements," Emerson asked, "we who are made up of the same elements?"

People who enjoy opportunities for reflection - for which leisure is a condition; and a condition for leisure, in turn, is wealth, or at least freedom from necessity - tend to occupy areas of the world with temperate climates, fertile soil, and low frequencies of natural disasters. For them, nature is an amenity and an enjoyment: blossom-filled woods in spring, sandy beaches in summer, sparkling snows at Christmas, are not matters of life and death, but aesthetic delights instead.

Nature in these guises elicits poems and songs, watercolour paintings and afternoon walks. No one writes an ode to a tsunami, or strolls in storm - though they might, like Turner, paint one. It was a Romantic affectation to seek out the sublime and awful in nature; poets took pains to be overwhelmed by Alpine chasms and brooding forests. Such is the mental mark of urban civilisation; the shepherds who grazed their sheep there found them much less amazing than a city street. For them, nature - earthquakess and all - was merely natural.

fields.headline: Mole in a hole
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
You can tell a lot about a sitcom by its theme tune. Thus, the Ronnie Hazelhurst-style synthesized salsa that heralded the arrival of Office Gossip (BBC1) may have had you tuning away in droves. With shades of Sorry! and hints of Are You Being Served?, the tune could have had you thinking that Office Gossip was a pile of old pants. You wouldn't have been far wrong.

Happily, Adrian Mole: The Cappuccino Years (BBC1) is only half an hour long. That there are another five parts to come isn't quite so positive. With an able cast - Alison Steadman, Alun Armstrong and Helen Baxendale (Zoë Wanamaker doesn't count since she blotted her copy book with My Family) - and a talented writer, you may have been hoping for better things.

Alas, the writing is unsophisticated and lazy. Pauline Mole cooks a fried breakfast to Hot Chocolate singing You Sexy Thing, Adrian utters banalities ("Am I addicted to jelly babies, especially the green ones?") and there is even a jar of piccalilli in an old person's house. Did Townsend stumble upon a time capsule buried some 15 years ago by Victoria Wood? The only reason to continue watching is to see whether William asks for two garibaldi biscuits and a carton of Um Bongo.

And then there's the acting, which is as over-the-top as Helen Baxendale's wig (which was surely stolen from Coronation Street's Liz McDonald). As Adrian, Stephen Mangan seems to have mistaken gurning for acting, and Keith Allen being mean is hardly a brave casting choice. And let's not even start on the theme tune.

Between them, Holby City and Casualty (BBC1) must have exhausted every possible cliche to do with the heart in their search for episode titles. So, soon after the former used Anyone Who Had a Heart, along comes the latter's Something From the Heart. Meanwhile, Casualty scriptwriters should perhaps become a bit more anatomically adventurous in their choice of episode titles. In doing so, they could introduce more variety to the show's Guess The Imminent Horrific Injury formula. Hence, Cock of the North could be about a Geordie pre-op transsexual who lops his bits off early with a pair of sewing scissors; Ears Looking At You, Kid could star a Humphrey Bogart lookalike who stands too close to a plane propellor; and Heads, Shoulders, Knees and Toes could feature a gardener on a motorised lawnmower who gets shampoo in his eyes and accidentally runs down a bus queue. The Straight Story, but curvier. And with more blood. Still, that theme tune is a cracker.

webTitle: Jonathan Romney on the Rotterdam film festival

fields.headline: OK, kids - shoot!
fields.standfirst: Murderous schoolchildren, babies for sale and a log that eats people - it’s all part of the fun at Rotterdam film festival, says Jonathan Romney
fields.trailText: Murderous schoolchildren, babies for sale and a log that eats people - it’s all part of the fun at Rotterdam film festival, says Jonathan Romney
fields.body:
Rotterdam film festival has always had a reputation for being leftfield, but this year it leapt straight into the realm of the conceptual. It didn’t have an opening film - it had 18, screening simultaneously in all of the festival’s various venues. The catch was that punters had no idea what they were going to get. So, on a strictly lucky-dip policy, you could have ended up with Memento, or Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, or In the Mood For Love. Or, like your correspondent, you could have got the short straw - a downbeat German comedy about go-kart racing. Rotterdam’s sprawling programme means that you can usually be sure of finding something to set your teeth on edge; this year it was Le Rat, a film touted as the French answer to Eraserhead, but in reality a morbid serial-killer fantasy.

But you are equally sure to find a gem or two. One hot topic this year was the rediscovery of the small but fascinating back catalogue of the Swedish director Roy Andersson, whose apocalyptic Songs From the Second Floor - soon to be released in Britain - came 25 years after his last feature, the bizarre Giliap. And there was the Iranian film Smell of Camphor, Fragrance of Jasmine, the toast of Tehran’s festival last year. Its director, Bahman Farmanara, didn’t make films for two decades because he was prevented from working by the Iranian authorities. He has now made a subtle, sometimes bitterly comic and angry fictionalised self-portrait. He himself plays an elderly film-maker pondering on mortality, loss and the peculiar inner death that faces an artist who is not allowed to work.

At the other end of the spectrum, Rotterdam is also good on seedy cult thrills. This year’s undisputed hot ticket was Battle Royale, the new feature by veteran yakuza-thriller specialist Kinji Fukasaku, who had a retrospective here in the last festival. Currently doing massive box office in Japan, Battle Royale is about a game in which the country’s worst-behaved class of high-school kids are sent to an isolated island, given weapons and ordered to kill each other until only one is left standing. All this under the watchful eye of their teacher, played by Takeshi Kitano. It’s hard to tell whether Battle Royale really is the youth-hating authoritarian fantasy that it seems, or whether there’s any more subversive intent. I suspect not, and that it’s just the gloating, mean-spirited shoot-up game that it seems. But it feels like the sort of cheap and cheerfully vicious exploiter that used to come out of the Roger Corman stable in the 1970s. Thoroughly tawdry, Battle Royale is impossible not to enjoy. And the Hollywood remake would be even better - perhaps directed by Paul Verhoeven, with Britney and Eminem getting to shoot it out at last?

No less grisly was the latest from the Czech maestro Jan Švankmajer. He unveiled not only his new feature Otesanek, but an exhibition of paintings, sculptures and other work by him and his wife and collaborator Eva Švankmajerova. Otesanek is a blend of animation and live action, in a similar vein to the Švankmajer versions of Alice and Faust. Based on a fairy tale, it’s the story of a childless couple who adopt a chunk of wood and watch it grow into a writhing, neighbour-devouring monster. Thoroughly unsavoury in places, like a sort of gorefest Pinocchio, Otesanek is a wry piece of storytelling, mixing the wildly grotesque with a Bunuel-style detachment. Perhaps only card-carrying old-school surrealists, like the Švankmajers would dare to use paedophilia as the basis for a running visual gag, but there is astonishing material in here - such as the sight of real human babies fished out of a market trader’s barrel and wrapped in newspaper. Meanwhile, at the Chabot Museum, the couple’s exhibition gives further insight into their extraordinarily fertile folie à deux - including a fully functioning masturbation machine from the film Conspirators of Pleasure (not that punters are encouraged to try it out for themselves).

Probably the single most startling new discovery of the first few days was a 12-minute short by young Austrian director Virgil Windrich. A man wakes up, goes to work at a photocopying shop, and copies a series of pictures - of a man who wakes up and goes to work at a photocopying shop. By the end of the film, the man has turned himself into a multitude of clones. A slender concept, but the execution lifts it into the realms of dizzying nightmare. The film consists of 18,000 photocopied frames, making it neither strictly live action nor animation, and the blurry black-and-white makes it look like a lost Murnau film.

I have one regret - missing New Rose Hotel, the “lost” film from 1998 by wayward director Abel Ferrara. Even hardcore Ferrara fans roll their eyes in horror when it’s mentioned, but it is hard to resist a film described in the catalogue note (by French critic Frédéric Bonnaud) as “an endless loop, an abyss into which we must leap, a film phantom all the more haunting for being incomplete, fragmented, still to be rounded off.” And if that doesn’t make your mouth water, then you’d probably better stick to German go-karting comedy.

• The Jan and Eva Švankmajer exhibition Anima, Animus, Animation is at the Chabot Museum, Rotterdam (00 31 10 436 3713), until March 25.

fields.headline: It's 'innocent stuff now'
fields.standfirst: More than 30 years ago a film of James Joyce's Ulysses was banned in Ireland. Next week it finally opens in Dublin.  Tanya Sillem  reports
fields.trailText: More than 30 years ago a film of James Joyce's Ulysses was banned in Ireland. Next week it finally opens in Dublin. Tanya Sillem reports
fields.body:
In 1967, when the American director Joseph Strick was filming Ulysses in Dublin, a notice appeared in a reputable bookshop: "There are over 8,000 books banned in Ireland. If by chance we have one on display, please inform us and it will be destroyed ."

"The funny thing," says Strick, now 77 and living in Paris, "is that James Joyce's novel was not one of them. As it had never been published in Ireland, it had never been censored, and under-the-counter copies were available." But when Strick's film was submitted to the Irish film censor's office the following year, it was rejected outright.

The script was lifted straight from the book, and its reception mirrored the response to Ulysses in 1922 when the Dublin press howled that it was "written by a perverted lunatic who has made a speciality of the literature of the latrine". In 1968, a civil servant considering Ulysses on behalf of the then prime minister Jack Lynch reported that if the film was cleared for showing to "any class" of Irish audience, it would bring "discredit" on the government.

The fortunes of Strick's film, which has now finally been passed for release in Ireland with a 15 certificate, are a measure of the enormous distance that Ireland has travelled in the last 30 years from what Brian Moore called "a nation of masturbators under priestly instruction".

True to the book, the film records a series of episodes that take place in Dublin on June 16 1904. Much of the action is related through the consciousness of the three principal characters: Stephen Dedalus (Maurice Roeves), Leopold Bloom (Milo O'Shea) and Molly Bloom (Barbara Jefford). The script, like the text, switches between the spoken word and soliloquy. Strick says he always regarded Joyce as a great cinematic writer, and attributes much of the modern cinema to his inventions in Ulysses. Joyce had worked with the Russian cinematographer Sergei Eisenstein (maker of Ivan the Terrible) and founded the Volta cinema in Dublin.

Despite the radical politics that swept the campuses of Europe and America in the 60s, Ireland remained immune to the ensuing social changes. Rosaleen Lenihan, who plays the dominatrix whore-mistress in the film's Circe episode, says she remembers the police forcing a small Dublin theatre to close after a contraceptive was dropped on stage during a performance of Tennessee Williams's The Rose Tattoo.

Certainly Ireland, where women had even fewer rights than their European counterparts, was not judged to be ready for what Strick calls "the pure magic: the mental pyrotechnics" of Molly Bloom, languishing in bed and falling out of her nightdress. There is no surviving explanation of the film censor's decision, but the ban reflected the official reception it received in other countries. If it was rejected in Australia, and only shown to audiences segregated by sex in New Zealand, Ulysses was not going to be welcomed with open arms in a tiny theocratic backwater such as Ireland, where dancing was deemed to be the cause of bastards.

If Dublin was not ready for Ulysses on film, neither was Cannes. Robert Favre Le Bret, the director of the 1967 film festival, obliterated 29 subtitles, proclaiming: "There are certain things that can be read but not heard!" Lady Dartmouth (later Raine Spencer, stepmother of Princess Diana), then a city councillor for London, stated - without having seen the film - that if someone did not protest, "you'll have people making love in the streets".

The British Board of Film Censors demanded 29 cuts. Almost all were from Molly's monologue, which takes up a fifth of the film's running time. One can surmise what Lady Dartmouth's reaction would have been to Molly's musings amid the sex-stained sheets hours after cuckolding her husband: "Never in all my life felt one so full up he must have eaten a whole sheep after what's the idea making us like that with a big hole in the middle of us like a stallion driving it up into you..." Strick's response was to insert in lieu of the removed sections 29 blank screens backed by a high-pitched shriek. The British censor relented.

Sheamus Smith, the current censor in Dublin, says Strick's film is "innocent stuff now". He says the reason the ban has had to wait until now to be lifted is that "nobody thought to bring it back before. I'm sure that if it had been resubmitted to me 14 years ago, when I first became censor, I would have made the same decision."

Strick says he is "over the moon" that Ulysses has finally been passed, but is scathing of the censor's office: "That is like saying that a prisoner could have been released from an unjust sentence if they'd only had the courtesy to ask to be let out of the hoosegow. They are craven. They pretend to be buffs when they're buffoons. They don't care about anything but the box office. They have combined to create a self-censoring industry."

After the ban Strick made two appeals to the censor before giving up, then left Ireland for 25 years. In the meantime the film censor's office evolved from an institution that, in 1968 alone, banned over 100 films, to one that in the past 15 years has rejected only seven (including Natural Born Killers). The office owes its existence to 1923 legislation which judged films by "subversive content" and "threat to public morality". Now, however, it is principally a classification body.

Strick finally returned to Ireland last year, to direct a bawdy comedy by Aristophanes in Cork, and says he found the country "transformed". He decided it was time to resubmit Ulysses. Women he had encountered in pre-Mary Robinson Ireland, he says, were "fearful. When I returned I saw that they were barristers and doctors." While filming Ulysses, Strick had seen Dubliners "foraging on corporation rubbish tips not yards from the beach. Nowadays unemployment is 4%!"

After 33 years Joyce's own nation will finally cease to be the only one in Europe where audiences are not allowed to see the sole film of Ulysses made in English. Many will be introduced to the work for the first time. Smith, passing the film uncut, told Strick: "We owe you one."

 Ulysses opens in Dublin next Friday. Tanya Sillem's TV report on Ulysses will be shown on Channel 4 News at 7pm next Thursday.

fields.headline: South Yorkshire
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
Badgers, like many wild mammals, are fastidious creatures. They like to keep their underground homes clean; the bedding fresh and well aired. However, in the midst of winter, it can be something of a wrench to drag yourself out of a warm and snug sett in order to answer a call of nature. It is not surprising therefore, that, at the two setts we- examined this week, the fresh dung pits which help to signify badger activity were about as close to the tunnel entrances as could be decently allowed. Given the harsh, freezing cold nights we have experienced over the past few days you would expect the badgers to spend as little time above ground as possible.

On warmer nights the badgers have been out and about. At each of the two setts it was clear which tunnels are currently in use from the trail of dead leaves and moss leading into them. Unused entrances are also full of dead leaves, but they lie differently, having been blown in by the wind rather than gathered, bundled and dragged.

All along the network of interlocking badger paths which dissect the woods like a lattice, clumps of moss lay discarded, roots and bulbs of woodland flowers lay exposed, some part-eaten and dead branches lying across the path, crushed by heavy jaws. Some Lords and ladies bulbs lay scattered, their early leaves lying limp. We pushed them back into the soil, happy they would recover. In areas of thick moss, snuffle holes reveal where badgers had been nosing deep into the soft cushions in search of worms and other invertebrates.

Although January is one of the months of least activity, both setts showed signs of recent excavations. Here the earth was still loose, as opposed to the hard-packed mounds of orange clay outside the more undisturbed tunnels. Sow badgers will be fully pregnant now, their eggs, fertilised perhaps as early as February last year, not implanted into the uterus wall until December. This allows badgers to mate at any time of year but still give birth in early spring, giving cubs the maximum opportunity to develop and grow before facing the rigours of their first winter.

webTitle: A people skating on thin ice

fields.headline: A people skating on thin ice
fields.standfirst: Once it was a thriving fishing port, now it's a ghost town where only the old, the young and the sick are left. John O'Mahony visits a city whose harrowing decline reflects a country in crisis
fields.trailText: Once it was a thriving fishing port, now it's a ghost town where only the old, the young and the sick are left. John O'Mahony visits a city whose harrowing decline reflects a country in crisis
fields.body:
Just when it seems that the solitary, snow-bound highway might really lead nowhere, the ghost town of Oktyabrskiy peers over the permafrost, its skyline a grim, gap-toothed leer. As we approach, a hammer-and-sickle-encrusted sign by the roadside announces what was once one of the busiest fishing ports in the Russian far east, a model soviet enterprise bustling with life.

Stretching away behind, however, Oktyabrskiy's main Lenin Street now looks little more than a sliver of wasteland, lined on both sides by abandoned apartment blocks, their sunken windows staring blankly, their facades in the advanced stages of decay. Dilapidated wooden cottages, stripped to timber skeletons, clutter the moul dering side-streets. Everywhere, tatty scraps of open ground appear to have been seeded with trash and twisted metal. And all along the pier, the rotting shells of trawlers lie entombed in ice.

Only occasionally do the last sad remnants of Oktyabrskiy's population stumble into this desolate scene, some of them sullen teenagers who pass without expression, but the majority hunched and elderly, the human detritus of an unprecedented decade of decline: "It's difficult to believe this place was once crammed with people," says Lidia Ivanovna, the town's current governor, and our guide through the ruins. "All we have left are the very young, the very old and the sick - the people who couldn't leave. We're trapped between the tundra on one side and the sea on the other. Oktyabrskiy has been condemned to a gradual death."

Over the past 10 years, Russia has been haemorrhaging humanity at a rate unprecedented for a modern, industrialised nation, except during times of famine or war. At the fall of communism, the population stood at 148.3m, a number that has been steadily sinking by between 300,000 a year, in 1993, and almost 800,000 in 1999, the most dramatic 12-month slump to date, a net loss of 0.5 % of Russia's total inhabitants. In an atmosphere of deep pessimism about the country's future, the traditionally high birth rate has plummeted to 1.3 children per woman, the lowest in Russia's history. At the same time, the death rate has soared; average life expectancy for the Russian male is now just 59, some 10-15 years less than in any western country, while women can expect to live to 72, six to eight years less than their European sisters. In yet another symptom of the Russian demographic malaise, this male/female discrepancy is the largest in the world.

Other indicators are equally alarming: infant mortality is on the rise, 15.8 per 1,000 births in 1999 as against 6.9 in the US that year; Russia has become one of the world's TB hot spots, and Aids is said to threaten an epidemic of sub-Saharan proportions; meanwhile, migration is depleting the human resources of the far-flung regions. As the scale of the situation was becoming clear in 1998 and '99, the Russian Duma included genocide among the charges in an impeachment drive against the then president Boris Yeltsin, regarded as the architect of the debilitating reforms widely seen as the catalyst for the population collapse. However, if the projections of Russia's state statistics department, GosKomStat, are correct, the mammoth scale of the demographic catastrophe has yet to unfold. By the year 2016, they predict that Russia will lose another 8-10m, making the total loss for the post-soviet period more than the combined victims of Stalin's purges.

Even in relatively thriving Moscow, which serves as a magnet for impoverished migrants from all over the former Soviet Union, there is still foreboding evidence of demographic subsidence: a precipitous 27% drop in the numbers of pre- and primary school infants has forced the closure of scores of the city's kindergartens and junior classes. Just a few hundred kilometres south of the capital, there are already dwindling villages, each one home to a meagre handful of pensioners.

However, it is at the exposed and vulnerable extremities of the vast Russian territories that the atrophy of the population has been most acute. Perhaps the most startling example is Chukotka, a massive chunk of the far east three times the size of Britain, where the population has withered by a staggering 60%, from 180,000 in 1990 to just 65,000 today, a figure that is expected to slump to just 20,000 within the next five years, making the region's infrastructure unsustainable. Others include the Taimyr region in the far north, which enjoys 10 months of arctic winter and two of "polar night", which has bled more than 20% of its inhabitants and may now be in considerable danger of being evacuated by central government, and Kamchatka, an isolated peninsula, and the region where Oktyabrskiy is located.

The final approach into Kamchatka after a nine-hour Aeroflot flight affords a view that might pass for an aerial vision of the edge of the earth. Its capital, Petropavlovsk-Kamchatskiy, is surrounded by a crescent of gently smouldering volcanoes, just a few of the 800 scattered throughout the peninsula, including Asia's largest and most lethal, the Klyuchevskaya Sopka. The ground beneath hides a mesh of grinding fault lines; we had barely stepped from the plane when an earthquake struck, jolting the ground for a few unnerving seconds.

Since the fall of communism, almost a quarter of the overall population has seeped away. Unemployment in the grubby, low-lying capital is running at about 30%; 40% of its people live below Russia's already low poverty line, healthcare is nonexistent and fuel shortages have meant that until recently, heating and electricity were routinely shut down for as much as 17 hours a day.

However, as we venture outside Petropavlovsk in the company of a Red Cross contingent, the situation worsens exponentially. Mountain-locked microclimates send the temperatures crashing to -30F. For hours, we encounter no other vehicles, just the occasional group of fishermen trudging through the snow. And then, at the end of one of the world's bleakest stretches of roadway, a desolate strip of asphalt separating the heaving lead-coloured waters of the Okhotsk Sea on one side and a huge frozen lake on the other, we finally encounter Oktyabrskiy.

Perhaps fittingly, governor Lidia Ivanovna begins not with the physical wreckage of the town, but with a virtual tour of how it once was: "Right here there used to be two rows of houses." She gestures towards sawn-off foundations in a completely deserted district known as Basa II. "That was once a small port, where supplies were delivered before the road was built..."

The decay began, she explains, in the early 90s, with the liquidation of the fish-processing plant and cannery; in the new, market-driven environment, harsher even than the merciless natural climate the town had survived for decades, no one could justify the ballooning costs of transporting canned fish across the vastness of Russia. Since then almost 60% of the population of 4,500 has evaporated, and the spirit of the town with them. A heavy-set woman in her 50s who brooks little sentimentality, Lidia Ivanovna finds herself continually fighting back tears: "People once lived well in Oktyabrskiy," she says. "People once lived very well..."

By anyone's estimation, however, many of the remaining inhabitants of Oktyabrskiy now endure an almost bestial existence. One filthy apartment we visited, home of an alcoholic and his retarded son, was the most sordid imaginable, strewn with vodka bottles, stinking mattresses and the guts of ancient televisions. Across the stairwell, we find a woman of Koryak origin in a dark and sooty living room with her two youngest children, a mischievous boy and pretty moon-faced girl called Veronika, both suffering from tuberculosis. Ironically, because of spells in the TB hospital in Petropavlovsk receiving proper nutrition, they look infinitely healthier than the three emaciated older boys.

Most of these pitiable human beings pray for escape - in any form - from their grimy purgatory. In the first block we visit, pen sioner Maria Riabchenko shows us round her two almost entirely bare, unheated rooms. Aged 72 and virtually blind, she has carefully stacked all of her possessions in one corner, in preparation for a journey she was almost certainly never going to make: "I want to get out of this prison," she hisses. "Many people have already fled but the rest of us would also get out if we could. I have everything packed. I'd have left long ago, except that I don't have any money." With tears streaming, she adds, bitterly: "But I can wait. I'm very patient..." In the next stairwell, we call on Valintin Igulayev, an amiable old man who arrived in Oktyabrskiy in the 50s, brimming with idealism: "A friend of mine said one day: 'Let's go to Kamchatka' and I immediately answered, 'Why not?'. I was up for some romance and adventure." His elderly wife, Lilia, has just been diagnosed with cancer of the colon; but with their combined pensions totalling about $70 (£45) a month, she has no hope of getting adequate treatment. Physically shaking and with tears welling up in her eyes, she explains that her only option is to sit at home and wait for the tumour to consume her: "The doctor says that I must pay 15,000 roubles for the treatment, but I don't even have 40 roubles for fish in the market..."

Oktyabrskiy's clean but impossibly spartan hospital, which is forced to rely on the Red Cross for basic commodities such as soap and washing powder, has almost given up trying to help the seriously ill. Instead, certain wards serve as a rest home for the most chronically destitute.

In one upstairs room, Alexei, who has lost all coordination because of the devastation wrought by alcohol on his nervous system and looks 25 years older than his actual age of 48, shares a room with Vladimir, whose binge drinking caused a cerebral haemorrhage that deprived him of the use of one arm and his legs. "We don't hope to cure them," Oktyabrskiy's head doctor, Nikolai Kuznetsov, tells me, "but if we let them out now, they wouldn't survive long. The only option is to look after them here until we find a place for them in the old people's home in Petropavovsk or until they die..."

Our final stop is Oktyabrskiy's modest, two-storey school, which has seen numbers fall from 680 students 10 years ago to 240 today. This will sink further as every one of the children intends to flee the ailing town immediately on graduation: "Oktyabrskiy is just a long street with the sea on both sides of it," says Oksana, a forthright 16-year-old who intends to move to Petropavlovsk, "It's boring here. There are no sports facilities or anything. I want to study psychology and there are no higher education facilities. And I won't come back - there is no work and nothing to do." Another 16-year-old, Spartak, hopes to move either to England or Greece: "Of course I'll miss Oktyabrskiy. It's my home," he says. "But I have to survive and, for that reason, I have to move. I know that without us, Oktyabrskiy will die, but what can I do? Not a single one of my friends wants to stay..."

"Russia has been shunted back a century," says Sergei Kaleshnikov of the statistics committee, GosKomStat. "A contemporary man who is 50 can, according to statistics, live for another four to 10 years It's almost the same as it was 100 years ago." As is obvious from the situation in Oktyabrskiy, the primary causes of the demographic catastrophe are brutally simple: poverty, bad diet, poor living conditions and, in more industrialised parts of Russia, a polluted environment.

This has been fatally compounded by an almost total implosion of the healthcare system, even in the more populous cities. The TB hospital in Petropavlovsk-Kamchatskiy relies entirely on a 50-year-old fleurography machine, a hulking piece of apparatus that produces tiny imprints of lungs the size of postage stamps. In St Petersburg and Moscow, very few hospitals have the resources to perform what have become routine operations in the west such as heart bypasses; the leading TB hospital in St Petersburg can only afford to spend about 55p per day on its patients, much less than is required to cure many of them. Contemporary Russia is also an ideal breeding ground for infectious diseases such as TB which, incubated in the labyrinthine prison system, are now raging through the population.

"We are now on the verge of an epidemic," says Tatyana Suprun, one of St Petersburg's leading TB doctors. "It's a consequence of the way we live now in Russia, often three generations in a tiny flat. If one person gets sick, everyone does." Aids too is rumbling beneath the surface, due to a potent combination of rising intravenous drug use, the post-soviet sexual revolution and an almost total lack of safe-sex education.

However, the Russian populace is not only being corroded by disease, but also by its own self-destructive social reflexes. Alcohol consumption in Russia is the highest in the world, and deaths from alcohol poisoning far outstrips those in any other country: about 50,000 cases in 1999 as opposed to just 350 in the US, mostly as a result of a national predilection for binge drinking and the nature of the alcohol itself: "Since about 1990 there has been no control of alcohol production," says Viktor Petrovich, head of Petropavlosk's addiction clinic. "This has led to the availability of very low-grade spirits. People also started to brew their own, low-quality home brews that led to a lot of poisoning. In some cases, people even drank technical spirits."

Finally, there is the issue of violent death: the Russian murder rate per capita, which has doubled since 1990, is the highest in the world, three times more than the US and four times more than France. And in the atmosphere of social gloom, suicides are also rising, up by a third from their 1990 levels.

Russia and its long-suffering people have, throughout most of the country's demographic history, had a complicated, almost intimate relationship with the mechanics of death. As Catherine Merridale reported in her recent book on the death culture of Russia, Night of Stone (Granta £25), crude death rates in Russia in the 1870s were far higher than for any European country: 38 deaths per 1,000 members of the population per year, compared to the corresponding rate in France and England of just over 22 per 1,000.

If the situation continues to deteriorate today, Russia's accelerating population decline could become the most important challenge to the country's already unstable economic and political status in the world: "If this trend does not change in 15 to 20 years," claims Valentin Pokrovsky, of the Russian Academy of Medical Science, "for each working person, there will be one or two people who cannot work. It will be very difficult for the country." However, despite an insulating fatalism nurtured by Russians over centuries, the ultimate toll is a very human and individual one.

The cemetery in Petropavlovsk-Kamchatskiy is probably one of the most beautiful spots in the city, a sweeping, steep, snow-covered hill framed by the icy peaks of volcanoes. On one of the most picturesque slopes, a small army of youthful gravediggers is opening the frozen earth with picks, working simultaneously on three or four graves at once. All around, small picnic tables are piled with food, sustenance for the dead on their journey, while ravens, believed by Russians to be celestial pallbearers, circle hungrily overhead. One funeral (pictured above) is already in progress, the deceased an unemployed man of 44 who died suddenly from a heart attack, leaving behind a wife and young daughter. "It was totally unexpected," said his brother, "He was so young, still relatively healthy. Life killed him."

As soon as it ends, another gets underway, this time of a 21-year-old man who had been kicked to death by a group of soldiers: "He was just coming home and they beat him up. Five or six of them just set upon him," says his father. "They beat him up and took his clothes. He was just left there lying naked in the snow; people just walked around him, nobody helped him. They only found him in the morning lying there dead - he didn't have a chance because of the cold."

Once the body has been laid in the ground, the entire mountainside, as bleak and depleted a stretch of wilderness as any we have encountered during our journey to Kamchatka's depopulated margins, seems to fill up with the keening of his mother as she is led away.

Stretching away behind, however, Oktyabrskiy's main Lenin Street now looks little more than a sliver of wasteland, lined on both sides by abandoned apartment blocks, their sunken windows staring blankly, their facades in the advanced stages of decay. Dilapidated wooden cottages, stripped to timber skeletons, clutter the moul dering side-streets. Everywhere, tatty scraps of open ground appear to have been seeded with trash and twisted metal. And all along the pier, the rotting shells of trawlers lie entombed in ice. Only occasionally do the last sad remnants of Oktyabrskiy's population stumble into this desolate scene, some of them sullen teenagers who pass without expression, but the majority hunched and elderly, the human detritus of an unprecedented decade of decline: "It's difficult to believe this place was once crammed with people," says Lidia Ivanovna, the town's current governor, and our guide through the ruins. "All we have left are the very young, the very old and the sick - the people who couldn't leave. We're trapped between the tundra on one side and the sea on the other. Oktyabrskiy has been condemned to a gradual death." Over the past 10 years, Russia has been haemorrhaging humanity at a rate unprecedented for a modern, industrialised nation, except during times of famine or war. At the fall of communism, the population stood at 148.3m, a number that has been steadily sinking by between 300,000 a year, in 1993, and almost 800,000 in 1999, the most dramatic 12-month slump to date, a net loss of 0.5 % of Russia's total inhabitants. In an atmosphere of deep pessimism about the country's future, the traditionally high birth rate has plummeted to 1.3 children per woman, the lowest in Russia's history. At the same time, the death rate has soared; average life expectancy for the Russian male is now just 59, some 10-15 years less than in any western country, while women can expect to live to 72, six to eight years less than their European sisters. In yet another symptom of the Russian demographic malaise, this male/female discrepancy is the largest in the world. Other indicators are equally alarming: infant mortality is on the rise, 15.8 per 1,000 births in 1999 as against 6.9 in the US that year; Russia has become one of the world's TB hot spots, and Aids is said to threaten an epidemic of sub-Saharan proportions; meanwhile, migration is depleting the human resources of the far-flung regions. As the scale of the situation was becoming clear in 1998 and '99, the Russian Duma included genocide among the charges in an impeachment drive against the then president Boris Yeltsin, regarded as the architect of the debilitating reforms widely seen as the catalyst for the population collapse. However, if the projections of Russia's state statistics department, GosKomStat, are correct, the mammoth scale of the demographic catastrophe has yet to unfold. By the year 2016, they predict that Russia will lose another 8-10m, making the total loss for the post-soviet period more than the combined victims of Stalin's purges. Even in relatively thriving Moscow, which serves as a magnet for impoverished migrants from all over the former Soviet Union, there is still foreboding evidence of demographic subsidence: a precipitous 27% drop in the numbers of pre- and primary school infants has forced the closure of scores of the city's kindergartens and junior classes. Just a few hundred kilometres south of the capital, there are already dwindling villages, each one home to a meagre handful of pensioners. However, it is at the exposed and vulnerable extremities of the vast Russian territories that the atrophy of the population has been most acute. Perhaps the most startling example is Chukotka, a massive chunk of the far east three times the size of Britain, where the population has withered by a staggering 60%, from 180,000 in 1990 to just 65,000 today, a figure that is expected to slump to just 20,000 within the next five years, making the region's infrastructure unsustainable. Others include the Taimyr region in the far north, which enjoys 10 months of arctic winter and two of "polar night", which has bled more than 20% of its inhabitants and may now be in considerable danger of being evacuated by central government, and Kamchatka, an isolated peninsula, and the region where Oktyabrskiy is located. The final approach into Kamchatka after a nine-hour Aeroflot flight affords a view that might pass for an aerial vision of the edge of the earth. Its capital, Petropavlovsk-Kamchatskiy, is surrounded by a crescent of gently smouldering volcanoes, just a few of the 800 scattered throughout the peninsula, including Asia's largest and most lethal, the Klyuchevskaya Sopka. The ground beneath hides a mesh of grinding fault lines; we had barely stepped from the plane when an earthquake struck, jolting the ground for a few unnerving seconds. Since the fall of communism, almost a quarter of the overall population has seeped away. Unemployment in the grubby, low-lying capital is running at about 30%; 40% of its people live below Russia's already low poverty line, healthcare is nonexistent and fuel shortages have meant that until recently, heating and electricity were routinely shut down for as much as 17 hours a day. However, as we venture outside Petropavlovsk in the company of a Red Cross contingent, the situation worsens exponentially. Mountain-locked microclimates send the temperatures crashing to -30F. For hours, we encounter no other vehicles, just the occasional group of fishermen trudging through the snow. And then, at the end of one of the world's bleakest stretches of roadway, a desolate strip of asphalt separating the heaving lead-coloured waters of the Okhotsk Sea on one side and a huge frozen lake on the other, we finally encounter Oktyabrskiy. Perhaps fittingly, governor Lidia Ivanovna begins not with the physical wreckage of the town, but with a virtual tour of how it once was: "Right here there used to be two rows of houses." She gestures towards sawn-off foundations in a completely deserted district known as Basa II. "That was once a small port, where supplies were delivered before the road was built..." The decay began, she explains, in the early 90s, with the liquidation of the fish-processing plant and cannery; in the new, market-driven environment, harsher even than the merciless natural climate the town had survived for decades, no one could justify the ballooning costs of transporting canned fish across the vastness of Russia. Since then almost 60% of the population of 4,500 has evaporated, and the spirit of the town with them. A heavy-set woman in her 50s who brooks little sentimentality, Lidia Ivanovna finds herself continually fighting back tears: "People once lived well in Oktyabrskiy," she says. "People once lived very well..." By anyone's estimation, however, many of the remaining inhabitants of Oktyabrskiy now endure an almost bestial existence. One filthy apartment we visited, home of an alcoholic and his retarded son, was the most sordid imaginable, strewn with vodka bottles, stinking mattresses and the guts of ancient televisions. Across the stairwell, we find a woman of Koryak origin in a dark and sooty living room with her two youngest children, a mischievous boy and pretty moon-faced girl called Veronika, both suffering from tuberculosis. Ironically, because of spells in the TB hospital in Petropavlovsk receiving proper nutrition, they look infinitely healthier than the three emaciated older boys. Most of these pitiable human beings pray for escape - in any form - from their grimy purgatory. In the first block we visit, pen sioner Maria Riabchenko shows us round her two almost entirely bare, unheated rooms. Aged 72 and virtually blind, she has carefully stacked all of her possessions in one corner, in preparation for a journey she was almost certainly never going to make: "I want to get out of this prison," she hisses. "Many people have already fled but the rest of us would also get out if we could. I have everything packed. I'd have left long ago, except that I don't have any money." With tears streaming, she adds, bitterly: "But I can wait. I'm very patient..." In the next stairwell, we call on Valintin Igulayev, an amiable old man who arrived in Oktyabrskiy in the 50s, brimming with idealism: "A friend of mine said one day: 'Let's go to Kamchatka' and I immediately answered, 'Why not?'. I was up for some romance and adventure." His elderly wife, Lilia, has just been diagnosed with cancer of the colon; but with their combined pensions totalling about $70 (£45) a month, she has no hope of getting adequate treatment. Physically shaking and with tears welling up in her eyes, she explains that her only option is to sit at home and wait for the tumour to consume her: "The doctor says that I must pay 15,000 roubles for the treatment, but I don't even have 40 roubles for fish in the market..." Oktyabrskiy's clean but impossibly spartan hospital, which is forced to rely on the Red Cross for basic commodities such as soap and washing powder, has almost given up trying to help the seriously ill. Instead, certain wards serve as a rest home for the most chronically destitute. In one upstairs room, Alexei, who has lost all coordination because of the devastation wrought by alcohol on his nervous system and looks 25 years older than his actual age of 48, shares a room with Vladimir, whose binge drinking caused a cerebral haemorrhage that deprived him of the use of one arm and his legs. "We don't hope to cure them," Oktyabrskiy's head doctor, Nikolai Kuznetsov, tells me, "but if we let them out now, they wouldn't survive long. The only option is to look after them here until we find a place for them in the old people's home in Petropavovsk or until they die..." Our final stop is Oktyabrskiy's modest, two-storey school, which has seen numbers fall from 680 students 10 years ago to 240 today. This will sink further as every one of the children intends to flee the ailing town immediately on graduation: "Oktyabrskiy is just a long street with the sea on both sides of it," says Oksana, a forthright 16-year-old who intends to move to Petropavlovsk, "It's boring here. There are no sports facilities or anything. I want to study psychology and there are no higher education facilities. And I won't come back - there is no work and nothing to do." Another 16-year-old, Spartak, hopes to move either to England or Greece: "Of course I'll miss Oktyabrskiy. It's my home," he says. "But I have to survive and, for that reason, I have to move. I know that without us, Oktyabrskiy will die, but what can I do? Not a single one of my friends wants to stay..." "Russia has been shunted back a century," says Sergei Kaleshnikov of the statistics committee, GosKomStat. "A contemporary man who is 50 can, according to statistics, live for another four to 10 years It's almost the same as it was 100 years ago." As is obvious from the situation in Oktyabrskiy, the primary causes of the demographic catastrophe are brutally simple: poverty, bad diet, poor living conditions and, in more industrialised parts of Russia, a polluted environment. This has been fatally compounded by an almost total implosion of the healthcare system, even in the more populous cities. The TB hospital in Petropavlovsk-Kamchatskiy relies entirely on a 50-year-old fleurography machine, a hulking piece of apparatus that produces tiny imprints of lungs the size of postage stamps. In St Petersburg and Moscow, very few hospitals have the resources to perform what have become routine operations in the west such as heart bypasses; the leading TB hospital in St Petersburg can only afford to spend about 55p per day on its patients, much less than is required to cure many of them. Contemporary Russia is also an ideal breeding ground for infectious diseases such as TB which, incubated in the labyrinthine prison system, are now raging through the population. "We are now on the verge of an epidemic," says Tatyana Suprun, one of St Petersburg's leading TB doctors. "It's a consequence of the way we live now in Russia, often three generations in a tiny flat. If one person gets sick, everyone does." Aids too is rumbling beneath the surface, due to a potent combination of rising intravenous drug use, the post-soviet sexual revolution and an almost total lack of safe-sex education. However, the Russian populace is not only being corroded by disease, but also by its own self-destructive social reflexes. Alcohol consumption in Russia is the highest in the world, and deaths from alcohol poisoning far outstrips those in any other country: about 50,000 cases in 1999 as opposed to just 350 in the US, mostly as a result of a national predilection for binge drinking and the nature of the alcohol itself: "Since about 1990 there has been no control of alcohol production," says Viktor Petrovich, head of Petropavlosk's addiction clinic. "This has led to the availability of very low-grade spirits. People also started to brew their own, low-quality home brews that led to a lot of poisoning. In some cases, people even drank technical spirits." Finally, there is the issue of violent death: the Russian murder rate per capita, which has doubled since 1990, is the highest in the world, three times more than the US and four times more than France. And in the atmosphere of social gloom, suicides are also rising, up by a third from their 1990 levels. Russia and its long-suffering people have, throughout most of the country's demographic history, had a complicated, almost intimate relationship with the mechanics of death. As Catherine Merridale reported in her recent book on the death culture of Russia, Night of Stone (Granta £25), crude death rates in Russia in the 1870s were far higher than for any European country: 38 deaths per 1,000 members of the population per year, compared to the corresponding rate in France and England of just over 22 per 1,000. If the situation continues to deteriorate today, Russia's accelerating population decline could become the most important challenge to the country's already unstable economic and political status in the world: "If this trend does not change in 15 to 20 years," claims Valentin Pokrovsky, of the Russian Academy of Medical Science, "for each working person, there will be one or two people who cannot work. It will be very difficult for the country." However, despite an insulating fatalism nurtured by Russians over centuries, the ultimate toll is a very human and individual one. The cemetery in Petropavlovsk-Kamchatskiy is probably one of the most beautiful spots in the city, a sweeping, steep, snow-covered hill framed by the icy peaks of volcanoes. On one of the most picturesque slopes, a small army of youthful gravediggers is opening the frozen earth with picks, working simultaneously on three or four graves at once. All around, small picnic tables are piled with food, sustenance for the dead on their journey, while ravens, believed by Russians to be celestial pallbearers, circle hungrily overhead. One funeral (pictured above) is already in progress, the deceased an unemployed man of 44 who died suddenly from a heart attack, leaving behind a wife and young daughter. "It was totally unexpected," said his brother, "He was so young, still relatively healthy. Life killed him." As soon as it ends, another gets underway, this time of a 21-year-old man who had been kicked to death by a group of soldiers: "He was just coming home and they beat him up. Five or six of them just set upon him," says his father. "They beat him up and took his clothes. He was just left there lying naked in the snow; people just walked around him, nobody helped him. They only found him in the morning lying there dead - he didn't have a chance because of the cold." Once the body has been laid in the ground, the entire mountainside, as bleak and depleted a stretch of wilderness as any we have encountered during our journey to Kamchatka's depopulated margins, seems to fill up with the keening of his mother as she is led away.

fields.headline: Dull tortoises win profit race
fields.standfirst: Less flamboyant funds are often best at producing the goods, writes David Hunt
fields.trailText: Less flamboyant funds are often best at producing the goods, writes David Hunt.
fields.body:
Most people have heard the fable of the hare and the tortoise. Having decided to settle their differences by racing, the hare storms off and builds up a huge advantage.

Supremely confident, he decides he can afford to take a nap by the roadside and allows the tortoise to catch up a bit. The plodding tortoise duly overtakes the sleeping hare and wins the race.

The moral of the tale: slow and steady does it.

Isa investors, considering where to place their equity allowance, can draw a few lessons from that tale.

For when it comes to investment, slow and steady can often be a much better bet than the flashy performer which promises much then fizzles out.

Just like the health warnings on packets of cigarettes, the messages that "equity investment should be considered as long term" are ignored by investors at their peril, yet, large numbers seem to find the latest bandwagon almost impossible to resist.

At this stage last year, technology was all the rage. Billions were pushed into technology funds over January and February, just in time to witness the bottom fall out of the market in mid-March.

Amateur investors are renowned for bad timing but investment is a cyclical business. Hanging in there for the long term means you might just catch the next cycle when it comes around.

Last year's technology Isa investor is currently looking at a loss averaging around 25%, but the technology investor of three years ago is still banking a healthy gain of around 170%. Who can say what last year's technology investment will be worth in a few years time?

Some areas last the test of time, others don't. Biotech funds did exceptionally well over 2000, and are being tipped in some quarters as the place to be this year, but how many investors remember the biotech bandwagon of the mid-80s when the market darling Genentech hit $65 a share only to fall back to $18 a year later.

It is not just the specialist areas of the stock market that rise and fall. The far east, Latin America and even Japan have all had their time in the sun, only to go into the doldrums for long periods.

In many ways, the investment race, like that of the hare and the tortoise, is a marathon rather than a sprint. Investors should be looking for the fund that will do well over five, 10 or 20 years, rather than just the next 12 months. If you believe in the long-term technology story, fine; but you have to accept that in the short- to medium-term you could be in for a bumpy ride.

It is significant perhaps, that while at any one time it may be the sexy funds that head the one-year performance tables, over longer terms it is quite often the less flamboyant funds (the steady tortoises of the fund world) that produce the goods.

Statistics from the performance analyst S&P Micropal show that seven of the top 10 funds over the past 20 years come from the staid UK income and growth sectors.

For investors unsure about where to put their Isa money this year, we asked independent financial advisers to nominate funds suitable for a hare (a higher risk bet) and one for a tortoise (a good steady fund for, say, a 10-year period).

Mark Robinson of Berry Asset Management reckons that, given the fall, technology is a much better buy this year than last. For the hares, he goes for Henderson Global Technology. Under the tortoise heading, he selects HSBC Income Growth.

Anna Bowes of Chase de Vere picks last year's top performer, the Framlington Health Fund (hare) and the Chase Fleming Extra Income (tortoise), while Tim Cockerill of Chartwell chooses Artemis UK Smaller Companies (hare) and Fidelity International (tortoise).

Among investment trusts, Mr Cockerill goes for Fleming Chinese and the capital shares of the Schroder Split Capital trust (hare) and the Foreign & Colonial Trust as his long-term performer.

webTitle: John O'Farrell: third world poverty and the world bank

fields.headline: Don't bank on it
fields.standfirst:
Whoever thought of solving third world poverty with western capitalism must be nuts

Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: Whoever thought of solving third world poverty with western capitalism must be nuts.
fields.body:
Every day all over the third world, the same scene is played out time and time again. Some poor embattled finance minister puts his card in the World Bank cash dispenser and the machine beeps and whirrs menacingly before telling him that it's retaining his card. "Sorry, you have exceeded your withdrawal limit. You are currently $89 trillion overdrawn. Please refer to branch." And he turns to the beggar sitting besides the cashpoint and says: "Spare any change please?"

It's been a miserable few days for James Wolfensohn, president of the World Bank. As if it's not enough to be reviled by all the world's anti-capitalists gathered at Davos, a leaked memo this week also revealed that he is feared and despised by his own staff as well. That move into telephone banking was a big mistake.

"Good morning Sudan, thank you for calling the World Bank, my name is James; from your password today may I take letter number four please?"

"Er, well we don't use the Roman alphabet. We are an Arabic nation."

"Okay, squiggly bit number four then, please?"

"Is that going from left or right?"

Wolfensohn's job is much like being the manager of any other bank, really. You lend money to people who have much less than you do and then tell them they shouldn't be so extravagant. You write to third world leaders reminding them that they're massively overdrawn and then charge them £15 for the letter. Except that the World Bank was conceived as an organisation to assist third world development. Perhaps this is why the leaked memo revealed such disenchantment within the organisation. Staff know that the projects funded by their bank are causing massive ecological damage, the displacement of indigenous populations and increased poverty for millions. What with that and the bank having to be open on Saturday, it's no wonder they're fed up.

It has to be said that if you are hoping to avoid the wrath of campaigners against global capitalism you might come up with a slightly less provocative name than World Bank. It doesn't put you in mind of a council funded drop-in centre with creche facilities and a kettle. What about something like the Community Development Resource Project Co-operative? Their inescapable problem is that applying the ethos of international banking to third world development is as likely to work as your local Oxfam shop attempting a hostile takeover of the HSBC. You don't get the Red Cross handing out medical supplies on condition that the local regime builds an enormous dam which will displace thousands of people.

Christian Aid doesn't hold back emergency relief until it is sure that a toxic power plant is going to be built with the money. Much of the criticism that has been laid at the door of the World Bank has been prompted by its insistence on what are called Structural Adjustment Policies (ie economic policies that countries are forced to adopt in order to qualify for a World Bank loan). And I thought it was bad enough having to wear a tie when I went in about a mortgage.

Yet for an impoverished regime, the glossy brochure from Washington must have looked so appealing when it came through the post. "Problems with famine? Planning a small war? Whatever your financial needs, you'll find a flexible loan from the World Bank will help you and your subjects relax and enjoy the good things in life like sun, fresh air and er ... well that's all you'll have left. Call Free-phone 'Shark' and speak to one of our financial advisers.*

Third world governments are expected to devalue their currency against the dollar, lift import and export restrictions, bring in privatisation and slash government spending, which inevitably results in deep cuts in areas such as education, health and social care, prompting political unrest, rioting and repressive action on behalf of the state. Still, on the plus side, the Junior Savers Plus account does come with a smart leatherette folder and a plastic piggy bank.

It seems completely bizarre that anyone could imagine that western style capitalism could ever be the solution to third world poverty. It would be like the World Health Organisation saying: "Your country has a malaria epidemic. What you need is more mosquitoes." Perhaps James Wolfensohn should abandon any pretence of greater ideals and ballot the bank's shareholders with the promise of a windfall cheque if they vote for conversion into a normal high street bank. Then he could sack all his staff and sell off the bank's premises for conversion into a trendy restaurant. That seems to be the way everything else is going - why should we expect third world aid to be any different? That's the trouble with global capitalism these days. It's just got so commercial.

* Loans subject to status. Your right to decide economic policy may have to be surrendered to secure loan.

webTitle: Income investing is back in vogue

fields.headline: Income investing is back in vogue
fields.trailText: Equity income unit trusts were once top of the pops - their combination of capital growth and good income payments added up to a best-sector package.
fields.body:
Equity income unit trusts were once top of the pops - their combination of capital growth and good income payments added up to a best-sector package.

Now the fall-off in dividend payments and the cut in the tax credit (from 20% to 10% when Isas were introduced) has taken some of the shine off the concept. But millions have holdings, and the hi-tech bubble deflation could convince many more of their merits.

Independent financial adviser Principal Premier certainly thinks so. But it warns there is a big gap between quality and mediocrity in the sector.

webTitle: Unearthing treasure from a golden age

fields.headline: Unearthing treasure from a golden age
fields.standfirst: Auctions of the contents of country houses often contain bizarre and rare antiques in excellent condition, reports Stewart Dalby
fields.trailText: Auctions of the contents of country houses often contain bizarre and rare antiques in excellent condition, reports Stewart Dalby.
fields.body:
January is often a month of clear-outs and two of the main London auction houses, Phillips and Christie's, have just held sales of the contents of country houses. These sales are not held as frequently as they once were, but are always extremely popular and well attended when they do occur. They are the antiques and collectibles trades version of finding buried treasure.

Really valuable pieces have been locked away for ages, and because they have not chopped and changed hands are often in very good condition. These auctions contain not just rare and beautiful pieces but also bizarre oddities reflecting the diverse interests of different generations of families rich enough to buy fine things.

Part one of the Phillips sale of the contents of Elm Hill a country house in Worcestershire, held at Knowle in the Midlands on January 10, al most doubled expectations to realise nearly £467,000.

Elm Hill was the home of the Gibbons family, archetypal Victoria industrialists whose wealth came from banking and mining. The contents on offer ranged from toys and nursery items to expensive paintings. One highlight was The Shell, a family portrait by Charles Robert Leslie (1794-1849) and commissioned by John Gibbons who was a noted collector. The painting made £31,050, against an estimate of £7,000 to £10,000.

The Christie's, South Kensington, sale on January 24 comprised collections from three country houses in Buckinghamshire, Scotland and the Cotswolds and covered Georgian and Regency furniture, pictures, silver, ceramics and works of arts, as well as collectibles liking sewing boxes and Tunbridgeware pieces with estimates ranging from £200 to £15,000.

The first collection consisted of mainly fine Georgian and Regency furniture, removed from Cairness House in the north-east of Scotland. Built in 1791 by the noted Scottish architect James Playfair, the house was said to be one of the finest examples of neo classical architecture in Scotland. Until ill health forced a return south, Phillip Miller, an architect and design historian, together with wife Pat, a decorator specialising in period house design, spent six years restoring the house to its former glory.

Highlights of the sale included a three pillar mahogany dining table estimated at £8,000 to £12,000, and a William IV drum top library table which fetched £17,625. At the lower end a collection of four various Tunbridgeware souvenir boxes sold in line with the estimate of £700 to £1,100 and a late George III specimen wood and parquetry inlaid sewing box sold for £450, against an estimate of £300 to £500.

The second was called Property From the Collection of Mr and Mrs Geoffrey Gomme, built up during the 1960s and 1970s and sourced almost entirely from auctions at the time. There was again an array of regency furniture including a pair of gilt wood eagle console tables carved with plumage estimated at £10,000 to £15,000.

The third sale - The Property of a Clergyman - consisted of the contents of a house in Gloucestershire. This also included some Regency furniture and a number of curiosities. There was a George III mahogany chamber barrel organ by Longman and Broderip, one of the best-known 18th century London barrel organ builders known today as Chappells, the piano manufacturers. It was thought this piece would make £3,000 to £5,000. In the event it realised five times the estimate selling for £27,025.

This reflects the fact that the Georgian and Regency periods were the golden age of British furniture making; the time of Hepplewhite and Chippendale. The top 10 was dominated by furniture. Eight of the ten were Georgian pieces and mostly mahogany. By contrast the Edward Seaga painting did not sell at all.

The William IV (just about Georgian) mahogany drum top library bookcase, estimated at £5,000 to £8,000, realised £17,525. A George III mahogany tallboy chest, estimated at £4,000 to £6,000, fetched £16,450. Nicholas Orchard, a specialist at Christie's, says: "It was the wood - the mahogany - which sold these pieces. It was so rich, so textured. The dealers lapped up these pieces."

For further information telephone Christie's South Kensington 020 7581 7611 or visit www.christies.com. Phillips 020 7 629 6602 or visit www.phillips-auctions.com

fields.headline: Water pistol squabble hurts Weston
fields.trailText: Weston Medical suffered a setback yesterday following the collapse of a lucrative development deal with US healthcare group Johnson & Johnson.
fields.body:
Weston Medical suffered a setback yesterday following the collapse of a lucrative development deal with US healthcare group Johnson & Johnson.

Weston has invented a high-speed water pistol, Intraject, which fires medicine through the skin. Johnson & Johnson wanted to use it for an unspecified product, which insiders have identified as a version of erythroproietin - a drug for cancer and kidney failure.

The two companies yesterday agreed to end their tie-up by mutual consent. Weston's shares plunged 62.5p to 184p, wiping £77m off the Peterborough-based company's market value.

Its chief executive Christopher Samler said Johnson & Johnson's requirements had changed at a late stage in negotiations. He added: "We did not feel comfortable focusing significant resources on a new device that may only have been suitable for one licensee."

A source said Johnson & Johnson had demanded a different sized instrument at the last minute, provoking a squabble with the British company.

The Intraject device is considered promising for people with needle phobias and for patients with infectious diseases.

Johnson & Johnson's drug, known as EPO, is expected to command annual sales of $2bn (£1.3bn). Erythroproietin made headlines as a medicine abused by professional cyclists, because of its use in boosting blood circulation when the body is under pressure.

Weston's devices have attracted interest from other drug companies, including Roche and GlaxoSmithKline. However, Mr Samler described the Johnson & Johnson agreement last year as "more valuable than any other deal we've signed".

Weston floated on the stock market last spring, with an initial share price of 170p valuing the business at £210m. Analysts at Weston's house broker, Goldman Sachs, played down the importance of yesterday's disappointment, saying the Johnson & Johnson deal accounted for only 8% of Weston's market value.

Weston has several competitors in needle-free syringes, including Oxford-based Powderject, which blasts powdered drugs through the skin.

webTitle: The inside view: A question of confidentiality

fields.headline: A question of confidentiality
fields.standfirst: Most market players suspect others of insider dealing but cases rarely reach court, yet alone conviction
fields.trailText: Most market players suspect others of insider dealing but cases rarely reach court, yet alone conviction.
fields.body:
While I am delighted that my email address stands at the foot of this column as an invitation to feedback, I am always faintly embarrassed to find communication in my inbox on a Monday morning. I just cannot understand why strangers should feel drawn to their keyboards by this amateur's market musings.

The answer, I've concluded, lies in the teasy subtitle: The inside view. When the Guardian's financial editor, Paul Murphy, first sat down with me to discuss the column's format, we spent as much time lingering over these three words as everything else combined. I now understand why. The mystique of the insider holds a compelling fascination for the outsider.

The UK market's regulators, principally the London Stock Exchange and the financial services authority, are engaged in a permanent battle to control the power that derives from privileged access to information. This was brought into focus again this week with the resignation of Iceland's executive chairman Malcolm Walker.

Mr Walker sold a slug of stock in the frozen food retailer in mid-December at 339p a share. Only five weeks later the company issued a warning of poor trading either side of the new year. Its shares have since slumped to 152p.

The board of Iceland may or may not have known that its trading was well adrift of analysts' expectations when it authorised its chairman's sale. Either way it stands accused of negligence. If it didn't know, what was wrong with its management information? If it did, what was wrong with its corporate governance?

The issue of directors' share dealings is a vexed one. Senior executives are always in receipt of inside information that is unavailable to outside investors. Constraints are imposed upon the timing of executive dealings to ensure that they do not take place in the run-up to results announcements or while a company is engaged in or contemplating material transactions.

In extreme circumstances, these constraints can result in directors being tied into their existing shareholdings for very long periods of time. This is especially true of fast-growing, acquisitive businesses moving from takeover to takeover.

The investment community can be ac cused of letting a rightfully puritanical approach to directors' dealings spill over into an unfairly retributive attitude. Entrepreneurs often have nearly all of their net worth tied up in shares in the companies they run. Investors preach diversification for the portfolios they manage. They should not be surprised if company executives seek to spread their personal risk.

Equity participation for employees is widely accepted to be an effective means of incentivisation. However, inside share holders must be able to crystallise their gains. In the United States a mini-industry has developed in which banks lend money to executives who use the unrealised value in their share options as collateral.

This development is a sinister one, for it loosens the tie between a company's economic performance and the financial worth of its management - without outside investors being informed. I've yet to stumble across similar practices in the UK, but would be interested to hear from anyone who has. Information in the stock market is like an onion. Peel away each layer and you get closer and closer to a core that is far smaller than the onion as a whole. The quantum of true facts, and the number of people in full possession of those facts, are both far fewer than might appear from the outside.

Most information exchange in the market takes place in a barely orderly fashion between the outer layers of the onion. The release of core facts from the centre is usually carefully orchestrated and regulated.

Unfortunately for the regulators, human nature tends to intervene. As a covert takeover bid nears announcement, for example, dozens of people will be in the know and sworn to secrecy. Protagonists, advisers, secretaries, couriers, printers, chauffeurs - there are a lot of lips to seal. And many may have completely unpredictable personal reasons for the deal to leak or even to fail.

The UK has a woeful record of identifying, capturing and then prosecuting insider dealers. Cases rarely come to court, more rarely result in convictions, reflecting the difficulties in tracking information flows, establishing exactly what constitutes inside knowledge, and then proving intent.

Most market players will tell you that they regularly suspect others of trading on inside information but that there is a gulf between suspicion and certainty.

I'd like to see the UK introduce the American standard of quarterly reporting of company results, replacing the British standard of half-year announcements. The US clampdown on selective briefing of analysts by companies - in lieu of formal statements via the exchange - would also help level the informational playing field. The integrity of the market must be protected. If, as a consequence, The inside view is revealed for what it is - one man's sifting of the onion's discarded outer layers - then so be it.

Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities
