webTitle: Business: TotalFina guzzles BP's oil stake

fields.headline: TotalFina guzzles BP's oilfield stake
fields.trailText: BP Amoco is pulling out of the consortium developing Kazakhstan's huge Kashagan oil field because its 9.5% stake does not give it enough influence.
fields.body:
BP Amoco is pulling out of the consortium developing Kazakhstan's huge Kashagan oil field because its 9.5% stake does not give it enough influence.

The British oil company said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to sell the stake to France's TotalFinaElf for an undisclosed sum.

Industry sources said that BP had invested less than $10m in the venture and would probably get about $400m for its stake.

The Kashagan field, under the Caspian Sea, is thought to be one of the world's largest untapped petroleum reserves. Even though it is at an early stage of development, with just seismic tests and one well completed, its recoverable reserves could top 30bn barrels of oil. However analysts believe that it may be at least five years before oil starts to flow from the field.

TotalFina have been attracted by the size of the discovery. Thierry Desmarest, chief executive of the French company, told the Wall St Journal earlier this week that the distance between the first and second oil strikes was 40km. "That should give you an idea [of the size of the field]," said Mr Desmarest. TotalFina shares rose 1.23% as investors cheered the deal. BP shares inched up 8p to 587p.

A BP spokesman said that the Kashagan consortium, set up in 1997, was a large one with a number of members, including TotalFina, with stakes of more than 14%.

"We looked at the possibility of increasing our stake, to become a bigger player and to have more influence over the development, but were unable to do so," he said.

He added that BP still had other interests in Kazakhstan, including a stake in the Tengiz oil field and in the CPC pipeline from Tengiz into Russia. The group recently sold its 7% stake in Lukoil, Russia's largest crude oil producer. It acquired the stake when it took over the US oil major, Atlantic Richfield.

TotalFinaElf, which has a 14.3% stake in the Kashagan consortium, will become the largest shareholder when it completes the deal with BP, possibly this month. If the $400m figure - the price essentially of at least one billion barrels - is correct, it would value the Kashagan field at $4bn.

Kazakhstan's president, Nursultan Nazarbayev is determined to ensure that his country will become an oil superpower - even boasting that it will rival Saudi Arabia as the world's largest oil producer by 2015.

Towns and villages on the Caspian Sea such as Atyrau have been touted as a future Aberdeen or Houston. Already "American suburbs" of large US-style executive homes and hotels have sprung up there.

 US-owned utility TXU Europe said yesterday that it has sold its UK North Sea gas business, including assets and licences, to British company Consort Resources for $201m. Consort will also take over the operation of the Johnston gas field and an energy trading company linked to Consort will become the buyer under the life-of-field Johnston gas purchase agreement.

fields.headline: Salvesen loses director as it warns on profits
fields.trailText: Christian Salvesen, the logistics group, yesterday issued a profits warning and parted with one of its three executive directors.
fields.body:
Christian Salvesen, the logistics group, yesterday issued a profits warning and parted with one of its three executive directors.

Paul Carvell, the director responsible for the group's European industrial logistics operations, resigned with immediate effect. A company spokesman said Mr Carvell, who joined Salvesen only a year ago, was moving to another job.

He denied that Mr Carvell was taking the rap for the disappointing performance of the European industrial logistics business, which was the main cause for the profit revision.

He said Salvesen had had difficulty in passing on higher fuel costs to customers in Spain and Germany whereas in Britain it was able to recover the extra cost on about 80% of its contracts.

"Fuel prices have remained high in Spain and Germany, and the group is experiencing increased resistance from industrial customers to accepting the higher prices," said the company.

The group last year earned £40.3m before goodwill amortisation and exceptional items, and analysts had been expecting up to £42m this year. Forecasts have been downgraded to about £39m following the company's warning.

Mr Carvell, who was on a two year rolling contract, technically had to give Salvesen a year's notice. The spokesman said he would not be receiving any compensation.

webTitle: Rail chaos drives passengers into BAA's arms

fields.headline: Rail chaos drives passengers into BAA's arms
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: BAA benefited from the rail crisis with a 6.5% increase in passengers at seven British airports and a 50% rise in profits, the airports operator announced yesterday.
fields.body:
BAA benefited from the rail crisis with a 6.5% increase in passengers at seven British airports and a 50% rise in profits, the airports operator announced yesterday.

The number of people using its airports including Heathrow (above), Gatwick and Stansted increased from 92.4m to 98.4m in the nine months to the end of 2000.

Pretax profits in the same period rose to £467m, com pared with £311m at the same point last year.

BAA also published normalised pretax profit figures for the nine months, showing an increase of 14.4% to £452m.

This includes the share of trading profits from its joint venture with the US company, McArthurGlen, to develop designer clothing outlets.

Operating profits at the seven airports increased by 8% to £473m and revenue from airport charges increased by 10% to £493m.

Income from shops in its British airports for the last three months of 2000 grew by 13% to £119m, demonstrating that the company has shaken off the effects of the abolition of duty-free shopping within the EU.

BAA also made a £6m operating profit on its Heathrow Express rail link into London on revenues of £47m.

BAA negotiated an end to its contract with Eurotunnel after sales and profits from the operation collapsed with the end of the European duty-free market.

fields.headline: Phone companies warm to pay-as-you-go
fields.standfirst: Auction turns into French farce
fields.trailText:
Auction turns into French farce
Down the Tube
fields.body:
Ken Binmore, a 59 year-old professor of economics at London's University College, has lot to answer for. He was head of the Treasury team that designed the auction for third-generation mobile licences. The wheeze might have netted the British government £22bn, but the ramifications for the telecoms industry as a whole could not have been more severe.

As governments across Europe raced to replicate Binmore's money-making formula, investors and bankers balked at the rising price tag attached to participation in the promised mobile internet era. Telco market valuations plummeted, business plans were shredded and financial regulators across the world went into spasm over the monster size of telecom debt.

Now the destruction is spreading to various governments themselves. The French, arriving at the auction party late, have found themselves in the acutely embarrassing position of having more licences on offer than there are bidders.

The situation in France is self-inflicted, with the authorities there imposing a €5bn (£3.2bn) entry fee for would-be licence winners. Only France Telecom, with Orange, and the Vodafone-backed Vivendi remain in the contest. Hong Kong's Hutchison Whampoa, Deutsche Telecom and the Franco-German-Italian venture Bouygues Telecom have all balked at the size of the initial price tag. So the French have been left flaying around, trying to get bidders back into the contest with promises of reviewing the entry fee and all the other parameters of the new mobile licences, such as the duration and the payment schedule.

At the same time, the French experience has fuelled speculation that Belgium, whose spectrum auction is due to begin on March 7, will run into similar problems. With just a week to go to the deadline for applications, the only applicants for the four licences on offer are the three incumbent mobile phone groups. Belgium is not a strategic market as far as the telcos are concerned, and so even those companies who bother to bid are unlikely to be digging very deep.

It is all quite farcical and rather entertaining. But it is worth remembering that this is great news for the industry and could well prove beneficial for mobile users across the continent.

Telecoms firms have already stumped up £70bn for licences in Europe and, until this week, the assumption was that they might have to come up with another £30bn.

At the same time, across the new economy as a whole, a sense of crisis has been growing over delays in the rollout of the technological infrastructure. Aside from the mobile internet, broadband access in the UK is just not happening. And even at the gizmo end of the business, this week saw the worrying collapse of Psion's plans to produce the first decent phone and personal organiser in-one.

It may be tough on French taxpayers, but the effective cash injection - which the collapse of the licence auction there amounts to - is just what the industry needs right now.

Down the Tube

Ken Livingstone has brought the government's plans to part-privatise the London Underground to a grinding halt. London's mayor, with the active support of his new no-nonsense American transport lieutenant, Bob Kiley, yesterday forced John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, into a straightfoward climbdown on the idea.

With an election almost upon us, nothing could be designed to infuriate eight million London voters more than continuing uncertainty over the future of their crumbling Tube system.

In effect, Mr Prescott has told Mr Kiley to come up with suggestions on how the public-private partnership might be rescued without a loss of face for the government.

The private sector will still be involved in the long term maintenance and refurbishing of the tunnels and tracks, but Mr Kiley will be in charge of the operation.

The difference is that under Kiley's likely plan, the companies will come under a new direct London Underground management system. They will get long leases but will be tightly monitored and controlled to ensure that they provide an effective service for the passenger.

You have to ask why Mr Prescott has wasted almost four years on a project which looked half-baked when it was produced.

And it does not say much for Mr Blair's third way. First the plan for private-public partnership for British Nuclear Fuels had to be scrapped, now the Tube faces a similar fate. That only leaves air traffic control. This scheme, too, is hanging by a thread with financial backers for two of the three bidders pulling out at the last moment.

fields.headline: Danka faces trouble in loan repayment
fields.trailText: Danka, the troubled photocopier company, yesterday said that it was unlikely to meet bank loan agreements as sales continue to be hit by changing technology and increasing competition.
fields.body:
Danka, the troubled photocopier company, yesterday said that it was unlikely to meet bank loan agreements as sales continue to be hit by changing technology and increasing competition.

The company posted operating profits of £2.9m in the three months to January. This compares with £29.7m for the same period the previous year.

An exceptional charge of £7.5m related to redundancy payments after 1,200 job losses. A further charge of £10.9m was expected when the company posts full-year results.

Chief financial officer Mark Wolfinger said the poor performance was due to a slowdown in sales as customers switched from analogue copiers to faster, more reliable digital machines. Danka has also suffered from competition from computer hardware companies moving into the market.

Danka, which took on considerable debt after it acquired Kodak's Eastman photocopier division in 1996, said in a statement to the stock exchange that it hopes to amend a $550m (£375m) credit agreement with a group of banks for the tenth time. The agreement expires in March 2002 and requires the company to achieve a minimum net worth.

Shares in Danka, which could face collapse if the banks foreclose on their loan, yesterday fell 1.75p to close at 11.5p.

Danka's problems were exacerbated two years ago when discontented US investors brought a class action suit.

fields.headline: Cooking up the perfect recipe
fields.standfirst: SMEs give better investment opportunities than many giant manufacturers today, suggests Robin Stoddart
fields.trailText: SMEs give better investment opportunities than many giant manufacturers today, suggests Robin Stoddart
fields.body:
Most investors depend on others to manage their funds. Many wonder whether they could do better themselves. Pension schemes apart, portfolios are often erratic accumulations. Saving in unit trusts is the most popular and trouble-free method, though expensive. Next come investment trust shares with a quoted life of their own, or, increasingly, the Open Ended Investment Companies (Oeics) that hope to combine the best features of both.

Yet direct investment was boosted by privatisations and once enthusiasm is aroused it may be the preferred course for the growing army of active retirees.

Such basic goods as food and drink might be expected to provide sound investment prospects. In fact, returns have often been less than wholesome. The biggest and often best investment in the sector in recent years has been the Swiss giant Nestlé. For years Mars set the pace, but it remains in US family ownership. Pet food is a fruitful area for both, as another multi-billion acquisition in the US falls to the Swiss multinational. All fare has not been poor, however, as Greggs, the bakery chain, goes from strength to strength and a newer northern winner, Inter Link Foods, grows apace. It goes to show how much can be made, or saved, on home cooking. In drinks, where most of the beerage lost the plot, particularly in pub management, Diageo may be a premium brand winner, but regional groups are now showing their worth. Meals are an essential ingredient, along with low prices that still give high returns. Restaurants alone are a dicey business.

Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have provided better opportunities for investment than the giants over the last two years. Previously it was very different as heavy expenditure on research paid off for multinationals and sterling's gyrations made life difficult for home manufacturers and exporters.

The large-scale reorganisation, first of American companies and lately of European conglomerates and state- or family-controlled businesses, increased their power. Meanwhile UK management lost its way, first overseas and then on the home patch. Now that inventiveness is seen to be highly rewarding and entrepreneurialism is encour aged, the hope is that more small companies will flourish. Risks are high, but the last year or so has shown that the value of survivors that multiply can be much greater than fallers that become a total loss. The rise in employment when old industry is in almost terminal decline bears this out. Last year smaller companies showed a small rise in average valuation, while falls close to 10% were recorded by the large company indices.

Recently there have been some setbacks in the valuations of small and medium-sized companies that enjoyed the support of leading fund managers in the sector. Iceland, the food retailer, has fallen from grace after a spectacular near tenfold rise over a few years following financial engineering that geared up the reduced share capital. Old English Inns, a favourite with some of the top performing trusts, has warned that growth has been hit by bad weather.

Other leisure firms, including a handful listed on the Alternative Investment Market, have also suffered. Computer games are being shown to be a high-risk area and media issues generally require a selective approach as the advertising boom tails off. Cammell Laird is low in the water again after lifting some SME trusts.

From the performance of smaller company unit and investment trusts over the last three eventful years it is apparent that smaller fund managers, including stockbrokers, are better at managing smaller company funds than insurance groups or larger international fund managers, at least in the UK.

Those unit trusts that have achieved a near 200% increase for holders are also mostly funds of well under £100m. Close Beacon, Duncan Lawrie, Marlborough Special Situations and Edinburgh UK head the list, followed by Murray with appreciation of 150% in three years. More recently, Standard Life has made a good start and a strong early performance is often achieved by newcomers.

Among small company investment trusts, the battle for supremacy between AIM Trust and Eaglet goes on with the latter in pole position now that technology is a less potent element. Again, Murray Enterprise is leader of the rest, though well short of the fourfold appreciation achieved over three years by friends Ivory & Sime's AIM and Eaglet's 250% rise. Demand has lifted both shares to a premium over underlying holdings. Eaglet has large stakes in some companies.

Medical equipment supplier Ferraris and a couple of electronics engineers have performed brilliantly for it. Successful fund managers provide ideas that private investors might follow on their own account.

webTitle: Business: George Davies takes on M&S

fields.headline: St George to the rescue
fields.standfirst: Designer who built £600m fashion business for Asda takes on M&S challenge
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer has signed up George Davies - the man who created the Next brand and built a £600m clothing business for Asda - in its latest effort to win back shoppers who have deserted the ailing chain.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer has signed up George Davies - the man who created the Next brand and built a £600m clothing business for Asda - in its latest effort to win back shoppers who have deserted the ailing chain.

Mr Davies is to design, manufacture and supply a range of fashion clothes and accessories which will go into 100 stores in the autumn. They will be displayed in specially refitted areas within the stores and will target fashion-conscious younger women.

The clothes will have a new brand name, which will be revealed in the summer and which will be advertised separately from the main M&S range. "It will be my responsibility to market the brand," said Mr Davies yesterday, "Because it is my brand."

Marks & Spencer surged 16.5p to 240p as the City applauded the move. Ten times the normal volume of shares changed hands.

The deal with Mr Davies marks an about-turn in strategy for M&S, which always spurned the idea of selling any brand apart from its own. But in the past 12 months its has largely ditched the outmoded St Michael label and said that it would start using the names of the top designers behind its up-market Autograph range, including Hussein Chalayan and Katherine Hamnett.

The George Davies range will occupy 2,500sq ft in each of the stores selected to stock the merchandise. It will account for 10% of the womenswear on offer and be aimed at 20 to 35-year-olds. The main M&S range will now refocus on "core, classically stylish" merchandise.

Two years ago M&S said it had become too expensive and too fashionable, but yesterday Mr Davies said it was essential to get new customers into the stores and that he would focus on quality.

"This country has become too concerned with price, not value. "You've got to trust me", he added. "I've got it reasonably right over the past 20 years. But now I want to be an independent designer brand with all the qualities of DKNY, but at an affordable price".

He will source his range from the UK, Far East and Turkey and promised to "react like lightning" to fashion demands.

The arrangement with Mr Davies is the second high profile move in a week by Marks & Spencer's new chief operating officer Roger Holmes. He has also appoinmted Yasmin Yusuf, from Warehouse, as M&S's new creative director.

He approached Mr Davies before Christmas, just after he quit Asda amid suggestions that he did not want to work for Wal-Mart, the pile-it-high, sell-it-cheap American discounter which now owns Asda. At the time of his departure he said he would not work for M&S because it was "too corporate".

But yesterday he said: "I made a mistake" and insisted that M&S had changed under new chairman Luc Vandevelde.

Marks & Spencer refused to reveal the financial details of any agreement with Mr Davies, but some City sources estimated that he could generate £10m a year.

Analysts broadly welcomed the move, although some said it would not solve M&S's problems with its basic, bulk ranges.

Mr Holmes said the George Davies connection would pay dividends throughout M&S. "I've rarely seen such passion and commitment", he said. "We can learn lessons for the whole of our business that will hasten our path to recovery".

fields.headline: What women want
fields.trailText: George Davies has been dressing British women for 20 years, twice generating retailing phenomena that captured the zeitgeist.
fields.body:
George Davies has been dressing British women for 20 years, twice generating retailing phenomena that captured the zeitgeist.

At Next in the 1980s, he threatened to become as ubiquitous as M&S. Created out of the fusty Hepworths tailoring business, Next offered designer-look goods at chainstore prices. It grew rapidly - 60 stores in the first three months alone - and branched out into menswear, homeware, restaurants and florists. He revolutionised mail order - taking the waiting out of wanting by offering delivery within two days - and even dabbled with garden centres.

It was a near-suicidal pace. The company overstretched itself, went to the brink of bankruptcy and in 1988 Mr Davies was ousted in a boardroom coup.

Undaunted, he started over and two years later was drafted in to revamp the Asda clothing range under his own George at Asda label. It was the decade of value retailers and supermarket chic and under his guidance sales of "affordable quality" clothing at Asda mushroomed from £70m to £630m. He was rewarded with a rumoured £1m-a-year package and Asda's then chief executive, Allan Leighton, branded him a genius.

Mr Davies, now 59, has a kingsize ego and boundless energy. "I am the expert," he said yesterday, "or near to it... I've studied the pyschology of a woman."

Three times married - once to his design director - and with five daughters among his seven offspring, he has certainly had the opportunity.

Born in Liverpool, George Davies spent his formative years there. In the 1960s it was a swinging, fashionable city, and he was a regular at the Cavern Club.

He trained as a dentist for two years but gave up to join Littlewoods as a stock controller in charge of ankle stocks. It was the beginning of a lifetime in retail fashion.

He is now the epitome of a creative, international businessman. Yesterday he was vague about where his new company to do business with M&S will be based. "Offshore," he said. "I live in France and Turkey, and have a house in London. I fly my own plane, a Citation 1, and I am in and out all the time."

Born in Liverpool, George Davies spent his formative years there. In the 1960s it was a swinging, fashionable city, and he was a regular at the Cavern Club. He trained as a dentist for two years but gave up to join Littlewoods as a stock controller in charge of ankle stocks. It was the beginning of a lifetime in retail fashion. He is now the epitome of a creative, international businessman. Yesterday he was vague about where his new company to do business with M&S will be based. "Offshore," he said. "I live in France and Turkey, and have a house in London. I fly my own plane, a Citation 1, and I am in and out all the time."

webTitle: Business: gameplay quits the high street

fields.headline: Gameplay quits the high street
fields.standfirst: 275 jobs to go as listed company pushes for early profit
fields.trailText: 275 jobs to go as listed company pushes for early profit
fields.body:
Gameplay yesterday took the axe to its cost base in devastating fashion by sacking one third of its workforce and shutting all of its UK stores.

The online games retailer's actions, which will result in the loss of 275 jobs and closure of several operations in Europe, underlines the stock market's increasing intolerance of loss-making dot.coms.

The chief executive, Mark Bernstein, said he was confident that Gameplay could now reach a profit without having to raise more money, but admitted it could be forced to sell further assets to reach its goal. It retains 475 staff.

Market conditions have changed considerably since Gameplay floated on AIM in August 1999. Listed internet companies were then a rarity and optimistic investors were happy to give firms like Gameplay five years to turn a profit.

"Shareholders and the City in general want to see profits much sooner now," Mr Bernstein said. "The decision to restructure was a tough one but will pull it all back together. We have done what we said we would by building a real business with revenues and buying technologies that people want to use."

Gameplay's reorganisation will cut around £12.5m out of its annual costs and split it into two operating units. One will be a boxed games division selling games mainly through mail order.

The other will be a technology division, representing most of the group's growth prospects. The majority of computer games are still sold in boxes through shops but analysts predict they will eventually be squirted down telephone lines direct to users' computers or television sets. Sales margins and profits are expected to be much higher when that happens.

Gameplay, thanks largely to a strategic investment from BSkyB, has developed an interactive digital television strategy that allows customers to play games through their TV sets. Analysts point out however that Gameplay is dependent on factors outside its control as it attempts to deliver games digitally to PC and mobile phone users.

The rich graphics and sound used in computer games needs to be piped down fat or broadband telephone lines and the roll out of those new networks has been delayed.

Similarly, the next generation of mobile phones will be far better equipped to handle games than the current hand sets but they are not likely to be in mass use for at least another year.

Shares closed down 2.5p at 102.5p.

webTitle: Business: Scotsman group cut paper's price

fields.headline: Paper's price cut cost £5m
fields.trailText: Andrew Neil, publisher of the Scotsman and Sunday Business, has admitted that the audacious price-cutting strategy at the Scotsman has cost the newspaper group up to £5m.
fields.body:
Andrew Neil, publisher of the Scotsman and Sunday Business, has admitted that the audacious price-cutting strategy at the Scotsman has cost the newspaper group up to £5m.

Mr Neil said that, while sales of the Barclay brothers' daily broadsheet grew by 33% between July and December last year, when the price was slashed from 42p to 20p, there had been a significant financial cost. But he promised that the new price of 30p - falling to 15p on Mondays - would be retained.

At a reception held in London to celebrate the sales increase, Mr Neil, a former editor of the Sunday Times, said the risky strategy had been essential. "We had to blow the paper up and start again or someone else would have blown us up," he said.

Mr Neil said he is planning changes at Sunday Business. The paper's circulation has fallen since the cover price was doubled to £1. The Barclay brothers, who own the titles, want to give the paper a "younger feel".

The Guardian has learned that plans are being considered for a Sunday Business website. The site would challenge the Financial Times, which dominates the online business sector with its hugely successful FT.com.

webTitle: Making it work when the children are home

fields.headline: Making it work when the children are home
fields.trailText: Working parents, and parents who would like to work if only they could locate some decent, affordable care for their children, must be welcoming the fact that childcare is currently a hot topic in government circles.
fields.body:
Working parents, and parents who would like to work if only they could locate some decent, affordable care for their children, must be welcoming the fact that childcare is currently a hot topic in government circles.

Three years on from the launch of the government's National Childcare Strategy, Britain's "childcare gap" is steadily closing. There is now one childcare place for every 6.9 children under eight, down from one in nine three years ago, and a number of initiatives are now under way to expand and improve the provision of childcare to accommodate the needs of working parents.

But there is still a long way to go before all parents will have the choice of quality, affordable and accessible childcare, which is what the campaigners want.

To start with, British par ents' childcare bills have reached record heights, according to a survey from national childcare charity Daycare Trust to be published on Monday.

A typical full-time nursery place for a two-year-old now costs more than £110 a week - more than £5,700 a year and more than the average family with two children spends on housing or food.

Regional variations (see table) mean that in some regions, notably London and the south-east, the cost of a typical nursery place rises to £135 a week, with some parents paying much more than this. And the typical cost of a childminder looking after a two-year-old full-time, which is often seen by parents as a more affordable and flexible option than using a nursery, is almost £90 a week nationally, in other words, still more than £4,500 a year.

A serious gap in childcare provision is the continuing dearth of affordable places for children aged under three. According to Daycare Trust there are currently only 42,740 free or subsidised places for the 600,000 under-threes living in poverty.

Also worrying is the fact that, while 124,000 families are getting help with childcare costs through the new Childcare Tax Credit (CTC) - three times the number getting help under the previous system - four out of five lone parents who could get help through the CTC for childcare costs are still not claiming it.

"Part of the reason for the lack of take-up is that parents are simply not aware of what they could be claiming, so there is a need to raise awareness and promote the availability of CTC," says Stephen Burke, director of Daycare Trust. CTC is available to parents on lower incomes (up to £22,000 for one child and £30,000 for two children) and contributes a maximum of £70 for one child and £105 for two children per week towards childcare costs.

But another major barrier is that parents are only eligible for CTC if they are using "registered" childcare, which includes childminders and nurseries registered and inspected by local authorities. The many parents who pay relatives to look after their children, unless the relative registers as a childminder, are ineligible for CTC.

So too are parents who employ nannies to care for children in their own homes because, despite calls for a change in legislation, nannies remain unregistered at present.

Average salaries for a daily nanny are now £22,000 in central London, £17,750 in Greater London and the home counties, £15,000 in urban areas elsewhere in Britain and £14,000 in rural areas, according to a recent survey in the magazine Nursery World.

"The ceilings in CTC also need to be reviewed," Mr Burke says. "It is critical that parents on lower incomes can afford the cost of a typical nursery which clearly now exceeds the CTC ceiling. The geographical lottery in childcare prices means parents in London, and the south-east particularly, benefit least from CTC and the ceiling should be raised or removed completely."

Other major gaps in existing childcare provision include the lack of formal childcare services for children with special needs, for black and minority ethnic children, for shiftwork ing parents who need childcare outside the pattern of the traditional nine-to-five working day, and for student parents, who often struggle to find affordable care at or near their college.

Mr Burke says: "We are seeing real change. The childcare revolution we are now witnessing can be compared to the 1880s, when schools became available to all. But we are only at the beginning.

"The childcare revolution is still invisible to most parents in the country. Every day parents call our helpline searching for financial help or simply saying no childcare is available where they live."

So what is being done so far and what more could be done to further the provision of quality, affordable childcare for all?

The government has now met its target of providing free nursery places, guaranteeing five two-and-a-half hour sessions per week for all four-year-olds and has recently pledged to extend this provision to all three-year-olds by September 2004.

Announcing the provision of a further 80,000 free nursery places for three-year-olds this year, education secretary David Blunkett said that many of these places will be integrated with childcare so that children can be looked after on one site throughout the day, allowing parents the chance to return to work, education or training.

Five "wrap-around care" pilot schemes to test the benefits of providing early education and childcare on one site will begin later this year and run until March 2003 in Cornwall, Ealing, Kirklees, Lancashire and York.

Recognising that parents who live in the most deprived areas have particular problems finding affordable childcare, the government has committed £203m over the next three years to fund some 900 new Neighbourhood Nurseries, which will create a minimum of 45,000 childcare places in disadvantaged communities.

Mr Blunkett confirmed last Friday that a further £155m from the New Opportunities Fund, a National Lottery distributor, will be used to provide capital support for the new nurseries and start-up funds for around 50,000 out of school childcare places in disadvantaged areas.

Mr Blunkett said: "By March 2004, the government's ambition is for every lone parent living in a disadvantaged area to have a childcare place when they enter work."

Pioneers of the neighbourhood nursery approach include centres like the Robert Owen Early Years Centre in Greenwich, London, which combines childcare with a nursery school in all-year-round provision and provides a range of family support services.

Behind these initiatives, aimed at developing different types of childcare to suit different needs, is the government's stated objective to offer parents diversity and choice in childcare.

Finding out what parents and children really want and need from childcare was the primary aim of the independent Childcare Commission, a one-year-old body set up by Kids' Clubs Network at the beginning of 2000, which reported its findings and recommendations this week.

The commission is now proposing building a fairly radical "integrated childcare system" on the foundations of the government's existing childcare initiatives, including a children's centre in every area, tax relief on childcare outlay and financial support for families in the first three years of a child's life.

Daycare Trust runs a childcare helpline for parents on 020 7739 2866, open for calls Monday to Friday, 10am-5pm. Parents can also visit www.daycaretrust.org.uk for advice on paying for childcare.

The government's ChildcareLink service, which parents can contact for details of facilities in their area, is on freephone 0800 096 0296 or online at www.childcarelink.gov.uk. Copies of the Childcare Commission's full report (price £15) are available from Kids' Clubs Network. Email orders to publications.sales@kidsclubs.co.uk or fax to 020 7512 2010.

fields.headline: Emap 'break-up' turns heads
fields.trailText: It all used to be so different. For much of the 1990's publishing group Emap was one of the media sector's biggest stars.
fields.body:
It all used to be so different. For much of the 1990's publishing group Emap was one of the media sector's biggest stars. Attracted by its stable of youth-focused magazines like FHM and Smash Hits, City institutions could not get enough of the company.

In the past year it has all gone sour. Institutions have deserted the firm and its share price has halved. Problems with the $1.5bn (£1bn) acquisition of US magazine group Petersen (now called Emap USA) and the perception that its consumer magazines division has gone ex-growth have been behind the decline.

It looks as if things may have gone too far. According to usually well informed market sources, Emap's chief executive, Kevin Hand, has decided radical measures are needed to halt the decline.

One theory being put for ward by Patrick Wellington, Schroder Salomon Smith Barney's respected media analyst, is that Mr Hand is considering a decisive reshaping of the group.

He thinks it likely that Emap is considering the sale of its business communications division (EBC) and Emap USA so that it can reinvest the proceeds in radio and consumer magazines. Alternatively, he says, Emap might be thinking about selling its radio operations as well as EBC to concentrate on being a pure consumer magazine group.

Either way, he believes a break-up would highlight release value, reduce Emap's high level of debt, and free up resources to invest in the remaining businesses. Emap closed 1p higher at 811p.

Elsewhere, the FTSE 100 index finished 4.6 points higher at 6,256.4, after key employment data offered a mixed picture about the state of the US economy.

Dealers said institutions were treading cautiously, nervous of moving into the market ahead of the Bank of England meeting next week.

The FTSE TechMark 100 index closed 38.81 points lower at 2,732.22.

In the telecoms sector, Energis eased 27p to 526p as dealers latched on to speculation that the company is planning to tap its shareholders for more cash via a discounted rights issue. Back in September Energis raised £400m through a placing of 77.7m new shares.

In the meantime, telecoms equipment maker Marconi slipped 28p to 668p after traders heard whispers that a profits warning is on the way.

But troubled retailer Kingfisher proved a strong performer, advancing 17.75p to 480p, as a trip for City analysts to its operations in the north-west got started.

The reaction of Marks & Spencer's share price to news that fashion guru George Davies will be designing an exclusive women's fashion collection raised a few eyebrows. Puzzled traders could not figure what was in the news that merited a gain of 16.5p to 240p. After all, Mr Davies is not joining M&S; he is simply designing and selling them a collection.

Senior market men pinned the share price reaction to the closing of short positions.

According to one tale doing the rounds, the proprietary trading desk at Merrill Lynch has got itself into a terrible position shorting M&S shares and has been told by management to close the position. It should be noted that M&S is Merrill's retail "bear" stock of the year.

Lower down the corporate ladder, market professionals were taking a look at a tiny water company called Mid Kent Water , off 1.5p to 450p, on the grounds that an offer for the company is expected to be made next week.

The gossips believe Mid Kent is discussing a complex four-way way merger with rivals Sutton & East Surrey Water , 2p higher at 185p, Brockhampton Holdings , off 10p to 260p and Bournemouth and West Hampshire Water.

A "buy" recommendation and a £16.60p target price from Merrill Lynch lifted flat speaker specialist NXT 70p to 675p.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
E-comsport buys TMG
Bridge faces bankruptcy
Four years for card forgers
Express staff win payout
Accountancy merger off
fields.body:
E-comsport buys TMG

British online sports firm E-comsport group has bought TMG Worldwide, a commercial sports rights firm that has done extensive work for motor racing teams, for £2.8m.

TMG has worked for British American Racing as well as US Cart teams, including Jordan Grand Prix, Benetton Formula One and Mo Nunn Racing.

TMG made a pre-tax loss of £560,000 on £6.7m in sales in the 16 months to end-1999. E-comsport will pay for TMG with new shares and a loan note as part of a wider strategy to secure international content across all major sports through third-party relationships.

Bridge faces bankruptcy

A bankruptcy petition is threatening an eleventh-hour attempt to rescue one of the world's largest financial news agencies.

The decision by a creditor to press harder for recouping $26m (£18m) in debts is jeopardising a plan to inject $100m into ailing news company Bridge Information Systems.

Bridge, which claims to be the largest financial information provider in the US, and to rank number two in the world, has struggled to repay a bank loan.

Four years for card forgers

Two Russians who set up Britain's first credit card cloning, making state of the art fakes were jailed for four years each yesterday. Vladimir Stroguine, 44, and Alexander Tanov, 33, employed a network of eastern European cronies in top hotels and restaurants with card-swiping machines hidden in their belts. The judge also jailed Stroguine for six months concurrent for two counts of misusing trademarks and said he would be recommending the men be deported upon their release.

Express staff win payout

Former staff of the now defunct Express Newspaper websites have dropped the threat of legal action after agreeing terms for compensation.

The 46 staff were left to wait in line with creditors when the websites were put into liquidation a month after being sold by Richard Desmond to SP Investments, a subsidiary of his financial adviser. Failure to pay for notice periods or even salaries for January prompted an angry response.

Meanwhile, the office of fair trading yesterday submitted its report on Mr Desmond's takeover of Express Newspapers to trade secretary Stephen Byers.

Mr Byers could decide to order an investigation by the competition commission for public interest reasons and has until mid-April to make a decision.

Accountancy merger off

A merger between Grant Thornton and HLB Kidsons has collapsed, ending plans to create the country's sixth largest accountancy firm.

A joint statement said the "range and complexity of issues" in the deal had proved difficult to resolve. Recent reports have suggested some of Kidsons' regional partners were opposed to the tie-up, citing concerns about differing fees and the closure of overlapping offices.

The combined company would have had 70 offices, nearly 4,000 staff and annual fee income of £230m.

Bridge, which claims to be the largest financial information provider in the US, and to rank number two in the world, has struggled to repay a bank loan. Four years for card forgers Two Russians who set up Britain's first credit card cloning, making state of the art fakes were jailed for four years each yesterday. Vladimir Stroguine, 44, and Alexander Tanov, 33, employed a network of eastern European cronies in top hotels and restaurants with card-swiping machines hidden in their belts. The judge also jailed Stroguine for six months concurrent for two counts of misusing trademarks and said he would be recommending the men be deported upon their release. Express staff win payout Former staff of the now defunct Express Newspaper websites have dropped the threat of legal action after agreeing terms for compensation. The 46 staff were left to wait in line with creditors when the websites were put into liquidation a month after being sold by Richard Desmond to SP Investments, a subsidiary of his financial adviser. Failure to pay for notice periods or even salaries for January prompted an angry response. Meanwhile, the office of fair trading yesterday submitted its report on Mr Desmond's takeover of Express Newspapers to trade secretary Stephen Byers. Mr Byers could decide to order an investigation by the competition commission for public interest reasons and has until mid-April to make a decision. Accountancy merger off A merger between Grant Thornton and HLB Kidsons has collapsed, ending plans to create the country's sixth largest accountancy firm. A joint statement said the "range and complexity of issues" in the deal had proved difficult to resolve. Recent reports have suggested some of Kidsons' regional partners were opposed to the tie-up, citing concerns about differing fees and the closure of overlapping offices. The combined company would have had 70 offices, nearly 4,000 staff and annual fee income of £230m.

fields.headline: £6bn bill for junk email
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Junk email carries a huge hidden cost to the consumer which direct marketing firms keep quiet about but which is costing internet users £6bn a year worldwide, a study carried out for the European Commission has concluded.
fields.body:
Junk email carries a huge hidden cost to the consumer which direct marketing firms keep quiet about but which is costing internet users £6bn a year worldwide, a study carried out for the European Commission has concluded.

Junk mail pushed through the letterbox costs the householder nothing, its electronic equivalent forces the recipient to open it up or delete it and that, Brussels says, carries a connection cost.

The EC will, later this year, review its rules on data privacy. At the moment consumers in Austria, Denmark, Finland, Italy and Germany are required to opt in and make a conscious choice to receive junk email, while the rest of Europe, including the UK, has an opt-out system.

"A cyber-marketing company can send half a billion personalised ad mails via the worldwide web every day," the EU's internal market commissioner Frits Bolkestein disclosed yesterday. "Consumer information from individual web transactions can be sold for large sums of money, yet many individual subscribers are unaware of this."

The EC is worried that lax data protection rules could hit consumer confidence in electronic commerce and hold back the development of online services.

fields.headline: Lessons in appreciation
fields.trailText: I am glad that teachers are to get an above-inflation pay rise - they deserve it. However, it would be nice if, just once, the government, the media and employers acknowledged that up to 25% of staff working in schools are not teachers.
fields.body:
I am glad that teachers are to get an above-inflation pay rise - they deserve it. However, it would be nice if, just once, the government, the media and employers acknowledged that up to 25% of staff working in schools are not teachers. There are also lab technicians, librarians, admin and IT staff. I am a lab technician in a London school and I have not had a pay rise for two years, nor a London weighting rise for nine years.

Most teachers would agree that our work directly affects the quality of education, yet it is rarely even mentioned in Ofsted reports. We work just as hard as teachers, yet we get only a fraction of their salaries and certainly do not get three months' paid annual leave.
David Reggiori
London
dreggiori@freeuk.com

I trained as a teacher in 1997, and am caught in-between the pay reforms that others are (rightly) benefiting from: those who trained earlier than me can access the threshold payments, while those who trained later are being paid to train. I cannot help but feel hard done by, as I am still paying off student loans taken out while training.

Perhaps Gordon Brown could introduce a moratorium on student loan repayments taken out while doing teacher training? He should certainly think carefully about taking other measures to help retain those who have recently entered the profession. It is this group who, still in the youth of their careers, are most tempted by other professions.
Mr K Brewin
London
kbrewin@elliott-school.org.uk

webTitle: Letters: Out of tune with students

fields.headline: Out of tune with students
fields.trailText: So, the aim of the Sheffield University's students' union is "to create a culture of tolerance, equality and respect" for all their members (Students revolt as union bans Eminem, February 2).
fields.body:
So, the aim of the Sheffield University's students' union is "to create a culture of tolerance, equality and respect" for all their members (Students revolt as union bans Eminem, February 2).

Laudable sentiments, but if this culture is threatened by a few tunes by a soon-to-be-forgotten rap artiste, it must be a very fragile culture indeed.
Ian Payn
London
Ian.Payn@dga.co.uk

Of course I find the lyrics of Eminem both offensive and pathetic. I also despise those who use the term "political correctness" as if it were an insult so that they can excuse their own offensive language and behaviour.

That said, it is very difficult to summon any support for the well-meaning but misguided ban on Eminem's records and T-shirts by Sheffield students. There are hundreds of songs by hip hop, reggae and rap acts that actively rejoice in violence, homophobia and misogyny. Which of these are subject to similar censorship on the Sheffield campus?
Jon Harrison
London

Many of the Conservative party's policies are decidedly anti-gay. Will Mr Nowakowski and friends be banning Tories from the union as well? We can only hope.
Alex Marklew
(Co-head of the University of Sheffield Alternative Music Society, 1999-2000)
Hitchin, Herts
alex.markiew@itp.net

webTitle: Letters: Red in tooth and claw, but helpful

fields.headline: Red in tooth and claw, but helpful
fields.trailText: Your leader (Belling the cat, February 1) has cost you your entire feline readership. How would you like to jingle every time you eat, walk or scratch for fleas? Talk about cruel and degrading treatment.
fields.body:
Your leader (Belling the cat, February 1) has cost you your entire feline readership. How would you like to jingle every time you eat, walk or scratch for fleas? Talk about cruel and degrading treatment.
David Steele
Dorking, Surrey
d_steele@lineone.net

The amazing news that cats are hunter killers prompts two thoughts. The first is that cats will take over the animal kingdom. The second is that cats are an integral part of the ecosystem and without them we would be afflicted by hordes of rodents carrying diseases. As cats have been domesticated for thousands of years, I think that is more likely.

One thing is certain. If cats could live safely in Trafalgar Square we would be rid of the pigeon invasion.
David Smith
Boston, Lincs
smith.boston@btinternet.com

News of the death toll inflicted by the country's lovable pussycats reminded me immediately of lines in the song And the Mouse Police Never Sleeps by Ian Anderson of Jethro Tull. "With claws that rake a furrow red, licensed to mutilate,/ From warm milk on a lazy day, to dawn patrol on hungry hate".
Michael Smethurst
Winchester, Hants
msmeth@waitrose.com

Experience with my own Siamese cat (now deceased), suggests a number of additions to your list of a cat's victims. He also dealt with rabbits, moles and stoats. At least he ate the rabbits.
Alan Bradley
Dobcross, Oldham
alan@54sandy.fsnet.co.uk

fields.headline: Jobs and the euro
fields.trailText: Polly Toynbee (Steel yourselves, February 2) sees the closure of the Corus steel works as a direct result of Britain not joining the euro.
fields.body:
Polly Toynbee (Steel yourselves, February 2) sees the closure of the Corus steel works as a direct result of Britain not joining the euro. Yet the fact that a transnational company can close production facilities at will while our government is forced to stand by is a direct result of our joining the EU. The basis of that commitment is that we forgo the right to take action to protect jobs and industries. Overcapacity has nothing to do with the euro and nor does shareholder pressure on transnational corporations to downsize.
John Green
Cnwch Coch, Aberystwyth

Corus has plants in Holland, inside the eurozone, where they are taking on extra staff; and in Britain, outside the eurozone, where thousands are to be made redundant. The "sacred" pound is devastating our manufacturing industries. The British opt-out was a disaster. If we had joined the single European currency this would not be happening. How many more jobs must be lost before we get real?
David G Sawtell
Luton, Bedford
david.sawtell@ukonline.co.uk

Please tell Simon Hoggart (Sketch, February 2) that redundant workers at Corus can't even find jobs at the Berlei bra factory: it's in the process of being closed.
David Bellis
Kings Newton, Derby

Stephen Moss surmises that few shoppers know who John Frost was (Return to Llanwern, February 2). There is a more potent symbol of change - the Westgate Hotel, scene of the chartist uprising, is being converted into a theme pub, record store and offices for recruitment consultants.
Ian Grutchfield
Newport

fields.headline: Elitism on the terraces
fields.trailText: As it now costs more than £40 to see Arsenal live in far less edifying surroundings (Highbury hits the pocket hardest, February 2), can anyone explain why opera is considered a more elitist leisure activity?
fields.body:
On Thursday I attended a performance at the Royal Opera House. The combined cost of my night out, including a front-row seat, a substantial programme, smoked salmon sandwiches, a glass of wine and my bus fare, came to considerably less than £50. As it now costs more than £40 to see Arsenal live in far less edifying surroundings (Highbury hits the pocket hardest, February 2), can anyone explain why opera is considered a more elitist leisure activity?
Paul Lay
London

I am a regular at Highbury and have never paid more than £25 for a ticket.
Ian Canadine
London

Why do you always use the same picture of a spliff with any article involving cannabis, and a poorly rolled spliff at that (Scientists list mental risks from smoking cannabis, February 1)?
Nick Wiltsher
Bristol

Rosie "Rizla" Boycott can't be tailor-made for any job (Letters, February 2).
Jerry Stiles
London

I note from a search of the Guardian archive that the word "Tarantinoesque" hasn't appeared in your arts pages since June. Come on reviewers - get a grip.
Andrew Nickolds
Cambridge

Fatboy Slim needs to diet a bit more (Letters, January 31). We are still waiting for him to fit through our letter box.
David Short
Ashwell, Herts

I was beginning to think Norman Cook was losing his edge. The fact that your correspondents were driven to Ibuprofen and using their free CDs as birdscarers confirms he still has what it takes.
Adrian Brown
Southampton

fields.headline: Eminem of the people
fields.standfirst: Bad publicity just means more sales
fields.trailText: Bad publicity just means more sales
fields.body:
Follow me and do exactly what the song says

Smoke weed, take pills, drop outta school, kill people and drink.

These are the kind of lyrics currently selling millions of CDs for Eminem, the 26-year-old Detroit rapper. He claims songs such as the above quoted Role Model are ironic; his critics claim he is a malevolent influence on youth because he advocates violence - particularly against "bitches", as he describes women, and homosexuals. His lyrics are loaded with fantasies of murder and violence - against his wife, his mother and himself.

This is pretty unpalatable stuff. But we've been here before; the outrage of elders over youth culture has been a stock in trade ever since Frank Sinatra described Elvis Presley's pelvic thrusts as "the most brutal, ugly, desperate, vicious form of expression". Breaking taboos, has been the rationale for youth culture from punk to rap. But the rebelliousness has become more brutal. Does it matter? It does to some marginalised young men who see in Eminem legitimisation of their misogyny and homophobia. For most of his fans, Eminem resonates with the often inarticulate violent emotions and hormones of adolescence and they will grow out of it, unscarred.

But Sheffield University students' union decided to take a stand and implemented a ban two months ago. It caused little comment until the Daily Telegraph picked it up as a wonderful example of the loony left wing. It rapidly became a national talking point: is this a story of politically correct censorship or a pernicious youth culture? It's a bit of both. But the union's stand is futile. The reason such well-intentioned gesture politics was petering out by the late 90s was that it was counterproductive. Eminem starts a UK tour next week and given that his unique selling point is his notoriety, the union has simply given acres of free promotions to the press ahead of his arrival.

webTitle: Indonesian students demand cleanup as president tries to cling on

fields.headline: Indonesian students demand cleanup as president tries to cling on
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: President Abdurrahman Wahid of Indonesia tried to secure a political future for himself yesterday by appealing to the people while trying to ignore the parliamentary accusers who claim he is corrupt.
fields.body:
President Abdurrahman Wahid of Indonesia tried to secure a political future for himself yesterday by appealing to the people while trying to ignore the parliamentary accusers who claim he is corrupt.

One day after parliament decided to send Mr Wahid a formal warning, which could lead to his dismissal if MPs are dissatisfied with his response, the half-blind Muslim cleric insisted that he would not resign.

"I will not step down," he said during a meeting with worshippers at a Jakarta mosque. "I will complete my presidential term." It ends in 2004.

He was also bullish at a press conference at the presidential palace, saying MPs had acted improperly in censuring him based on their interpretation of events in two corruption scandals, rather than on the facts.

"There are people who talk about public lies and words which are not ethical, but they are still being used by those who consider themselves to be the people's representatives," he said.

The presidential spokesman, Wimar Witolar, said that Mr Wahid would reply to parliament's memorandum of warning "as soon as possible" but would focus on responding "to what's a very clear call for acceleration of reform, so he will accelerate action against corruption and violators of the law".

He was speaking in reference to the fact that among several thousand demonstrators on Jakarta's streets in the past two days, a number have been calling for an end to corruption, rather than an end to this presidency.

But in a society where corruption is endemic and so many influential people want him out, it is unlikely Mr Wahid will be able to make much headway in the three months he has before parliament can issue its second and final warning.

Mr Wahid would then have 30 days to appease parliament before it could initiate impeachment proceedings.

Even if the president did prove successful in fighting corruption, it might not save him because a majority of legislators have decided they want him out.

webTitle: Pardon sought for Billy the Kid

fields.headline: Long shot
fields.standfirst: Pardon sought for Billy the Kid
fields.trailText: Richard Nixon got one. Bill Clinton's brother Roger has just received one. And now New Mexico's state legislature is considering whether to give a pardon to Billy the Kid.
fields.body:
Richard Nixon got one. Bill Clinton's brother Roger has just received one. And now New Mexico's state legislature is considering whether to give a pardon to Billy the Kid.

On the face of it, a pardon for a man who boasted of committing 21 killings, one for each year of his nasty, brutish and short life, looks like a bit of a long shot in a nation that has just acquired a president who vigorously defends the death penalty.

But, ever since William Bonney was gunned down by Sheriff Pat Garrett outside Fort Sumner, New Mexico, in July 1881, the legend of Billy the Kid has never stopped growing. In more than 50 movies, he has been played by the likes of Paul Newman, Kris Kristofferson and Emilio Estevez, and his defiant, brazen image has grown more seductive to admirers as the years have passed.

Now local Democratic politician Ben Rios has put up a non-binding proposal to ask New Mexico's governor, Gary Johnson, to issue a posthumous pardon to the man who was sentenced to hang for the murder of Sheriff William Brady in Lincoln, New Mexico, in 1878, but who then busted out of jail by killing two deputies.

Mr Rios says the then governor of New Mexico, Lew Wallace, who was just finishing writing his novel Ben-Hur at the time, had led the Kid to expect he would get a pardon.

Mr Rios made his move after being approached by constituents in Las Cruces claiming to be direct descendants of Billy the Kid.

"They just wanted to see if Billy could be pardoned, for the peace of mind of whoever is left whose family knew Billy," Mr Rios said this week. "The passing of more than 100 years should have healed many of the wounds left in his wake."

Unsurprisingly, Mr Rios's proposal has caused consternation among descendants of Sheriff Brady, who was shot 16 times in the back by Billy and his gang.

"Oh boy," said Bennett Brady, of Roswell. "Whoever said something like that has got to be crazy. As far as I'm concerned that's wrong." A spokeswoman for Mr Johnson said a pardon would be "very, very unlikely".

webTitle: Police dog's bite fails to live up to its bark

fields.headline: Police dog's bite fails to live up to its bark
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Once the scourge of football hooligans and rioters, the German shepherd dog has been dropped by police as too soft.
fields.body:
Once the scourge of football hooligans and rioters, the German shepherd dog has been dropped by police as too soft.

Officers say breeders trying to rid the breed of epilepsy and hip problems have, over the years, accidently bred out some of the dog's suitability for police work.

"Dog shows have meant the dogs have had the suspicion and boldness bred out," PC Phil Tyson, of the dog section of West Yorkshire police, told Police Review magazine. "Shows don't look for aggression but for dogs which look nice and are subdued. Working dogs need to be alert."

Graham Armitage, head of West Yorkshire's dog training school, said rottweilers, dobermans and Rhodesian ridgebacks had been considered. Collies had not been ruled out but Japanese akitas had. Officers had visited Belgium to buy malinois dogs, a form of Belgian shepherd, three-quarters the size of German shepherds but with a more "wolfish" appearance and a stronger work ethic.

"Twenty years ago if a dog went to a football match and arrested someone by biting them, or found a person in a building and barked, they would probably get the job," Mr Armitage said.

"But standards have gone up. We need scent detectors and confident dogs. The German shepherds we have now are fine, but we may have problems finding intelligent ones in the future."

A spokesman for the Association of Chief Police officers said some German shepherds were alert enough for the job, but the situation was under review.

Phil Buckley of the Kennel Club breeders association said breeders should bear in mind the guidelines for the breed: "Steady of nerve, self-assured, courageous and tractable; never nervous, overly aggressive or shy."

webTitle: Calf reprieved from German bse herd cull

fields.headline: German beef cull meets its match in a calf called Joan
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: She is reddish-brown, with soft, melting eyes and an unsteady gait. By last night, she had become a symbol of German farmers' resistance to the mass slaughter of their cattle because of the growing crisis over mad cow disease.
fields.body:
She is reddish-brown, with soft, melting eyes and an unsteady gait. By last night, she had become a symbol of German farmers' resistance to the mass slaughter of their cattle because of the growing crisis over mad cow disease.

Joan of Arc, as the farmers of Schleswig-Holstein have nicknamed her, is a new-born calf. Earlier this week, and in breach of all the rules, the regional agriculture minister, Rüdiger von Plüskow, gave in to a local farmer's entreaties and commuted her death sentence. Joan of Arc comes from a BSE-infected herd.

The minister seems not to have realised that the reprieve could invalidate measures being taken to combat BSE and cost it a ban on the export of its beef. By the time the implications became clear, however, Joan of Arc had been spirited away.

Last night, a nationwide calf hunt was under way and the authorities were threatening to cut off compensation for slaughtered animals unless Joan of Arc turned up.

The German government announced on Wednesday that it would slaughter an estimated 400,000 cattle in an attempt to curb mad cow disease. It was the most dramatic step in the fight against BSE since the first case was discovered in Germany last November.

The agriculture minister, Renate Künast, said it would cost some DM362m (£120m) to buy the cattle from farmers, slaughter them and dispose of the carcasses.

But in a departure from the guidelines, Mr von Plüskow said that Joan of Arc could be allowed to live as long as her mother did not test positive for the disease.

fields.headline: All at sea
fields.standfirst: Yachtswoman hit by mishap
fields.trailText: Ellen MacArthur's bid to become the first woman to win a solo round-the-world yacht race took a back seat to self-preservation when her boat collided with a submerged object in the mid-Atlantic.
fields.body:
Ellen MacArthur's bid to become the first woman to win a solo round-the-world yacht race took a back seat to self-preservation when her boat collided with a submerged object in the mid-Atlantic.

Ms MacArthur, at 24 the youngest competitor in the Vendée Globe race, battled for 24 hours and in 20 knot winds to repair a gash in the rudder of her 60ft yacht, Kingfisher, after it hit a submerged container on the race's 83rd day. She was in second place.

Ms MacArthur, who is 5ft2in, struggled with loads of one and a half times her body weight as she tried to fix the yacht without losing her place. She is currently 80 miles behind the leader, Michel Desjoyeaux, and has a 300-mile lead on her nearest pursuer.

At sunset on Tuesday, the yachtswoman was thrown forward as the boat slammed to a halt and emitted a sound which she took to be that of the hull being ripped apart.

"There was the most almighty crunching and the boat felt like she'd hit land," Ms MacArthur said. "I looked back and saw part of the rudder and daggerboard in the water.

"My immediate reaction was 'are we going to sink?'. I imagined I might have ripped the bottom of the boat out, the noise was so loud."

The boat's daggerboard, an adjustable keel twice the height of Ms MacArthur, had been damaged below the waterline on the port side and part of it had become lodged in the deck.

After 12 hours and in increasingly rough seas, she succeeded in hauling the undamaged rudder on deck. It took a further six hours for her to install it on the port side.

A spokeswoman for the team said: "The result of 24 hours' hard labour was that Ellen brought Kingfisher back to almost 100% performance. She collapsed, exhausted, struggling even to speak."

Ms MacArthur has surrendered her record-breaking lead to Desjoyeaux, a Frenchman. There are 2,500 miles left to go before the race ends in Sables D'Olonne, France, next week.

webTitle: Catholic Church compensates victims of paedophile priests

fields.headline: Catholic Church pays damages to victims of paedophile priest
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: The Roman Catholic Church faced another embarrassment over paedophilia in the priesthood yesterday after admitting paying undisclosed damages to the families of three boys abused by Adrian McLeish, a priest in Durham who was jailed for six years in 1996 after admitting 12 charges of abuse.
fields.body:
The Roman Catholic Church faced another embarrassment over paedophilia in the priesthood yesterday after admitting paying undisclosed damages to the families of three boys abused by Adrian McLeish, a priest in Durham who was jailed for six years in 1996 after admitting 12 charges of abuse.

The diocese of Hexham and Newcastle issued a statement that said: "The bishop and the diocese have always expressed sorrow and regret for the great suffering and harm caused by the actions of Adrian McLeish ... The diocese denies any legal liability .. and in respect of themselves none has been established. Nothing can make up for past damage, but by consent of all parties a settlement has been accepted to help the young people move on."

Police recovered 5,000 computer disks containing 9,000 pictures, mostly relating to child pornography, at McLeish's presbytery at the time of his arrest. The parents claimed that he had been moved from his parish in Tyneside five years earlier to escape previous complaints.

He served two years of his sentence and was suspended as a priest. He is being stripped of his priesthood.

The church has been undermined by a series of convictions in recent years and payment of compensation to victims.

Last year the Most Rev Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, Archbishop of Westminster, admitted that he had moved Michael Hill, subsequently convicted of indecency, and that compensation had been paid to his victims in Arundel and Brighton diocese.

The Most Rev John Ward, Archbishop of Cardiff, has admitted ordaining Joe Jordan, subsequently convicted of abusing boys, despite warnings that he was a risk to children.

Father Dennis Tindall, Hexham and Newcastle diocese's child protection officer, said: "We are doing everything we can to stop any repetition of this. I would stress that the church did not know of this particular problem."

The church has set up a committee under Lord Nolan to investigate its procedures for dealing with sex abuse by clergy.

webTitle: As the police closed in, jailed accomplice started talking

fields.headline: As the police closed in, jailed accomplice started talking
fields.standfirst: Investigation Confession and DNA advances led to second culprit
fields.trailText: When psychologist Jennie Cutler first sat down with John Duffy in November 1997 she thought it would be the start of possibly harrowing but essentially routine counselling.
fields.body:
When psychologist Jennie Cutler first sat down with John Duffy in November 1997 she thought it would be the start of possibly harrowing but essentially routine counselling.

Instead Dr Cutler sat spellbound as in a series of highly charged sessions Duffy confessed to the brutal crimes he had always insisted he could not remember - then named his childhood friend, David Mulcahy, as his accomplice.

These sessions led to one of Britain's biggest and most complex police investigations, culminating in Duffy facing his old friend across a courtroom to lay bare their horrific crimes.

Dr Cutler, head of forensic psychology at Whitemoor prison in Cambridgeshire, saw Duffy when a prison officer suggested he needed individual counselling. He had nightmares, including one in which a girl ran along a canal towpath - the circumstances of one of the murders.

In the first interview Duffy mentioned that the "other kid's a friend". Dr Cutler, who had little knowledge of Duffy, assumed he was talking about a partner who had stood trial. She asked him which prison his co-defendant was in, and was astonished when told he was still at large.

As the interviews progressed, Duffy recalled his offences. The first attack he spoke about was when he and Mulcahy raped two au pairs on Hampstead Heath in north London. The memories, Dr Cutler said, flowed. Duffy clearly trusted her, and some believe he became infatuated with her. He finally admitted to 16 rapes and three murders, conceding there may have been others he had forgotten.

His attitude to Mulcahy, which emerged during the interviews, is fascinating. Dr Cutler recorded in her notes: "Has mixed feelings about David. It worries him he might still be offending, thinks he should pay for what he's done."

But he also expressed concern over the welfare of Mulcahy's family, whom he had sworn to protect if Mulcahy had been caught instead of him.

By the time Duffy's confession began, police had already turned their attention back to Mulcahy. They had long believed he was Duffy's partner, but in 1988 did not have enough evidence to prosecute.

Operation Hart, the original inquiry that resulted in the conviction of Duffy, had been the largest since the Yorkshire Ripper investigation.

Hart examined 68 offences in south-east England between 1982 and 1986 which detectives believed could be linked. Sometimes the offences were committed by two men, sometimes by one. Often they were near railway stations, leading to Duffy being called the Railway Rapist.

As in the Ripper investigation, the sheer scale troubled the police. To their credit, they were prepared to innovate. The Hart inquiry was the first to call upon a psychologist, David Canter, then of Surrey University, to draw up a "criminal profile" of a suspect.

But the detectives did not get close to Duffy and Mulcahy until the former came to their attention after an attack on his wife in July 1985. The police dug into Duffy's background and found that Mulcahy was his sole friend. Both were arrested but released pending inquiries.

Within months they had murdered for the first time, perhaps because they now realised how vital it was not to leave witnesses, and were not rearrested until November 1986. Duffy was charged; but though Mulcahy was arrested three times, there was insufficient evidence to proceed against him.

There were mistakes, possibly inevitable in an investigation of this size. After the pair had killed Alison Day, a woman recognised a photofit of Duffy and reported her suspicions three times; twice her message went unheeded, the third time it was lost.

And while Duffy was on bail for the attack on his wife he was caught with a "butterfly knife". Though such a weapon had been used in some of the Hart attacks the link was not made. It is hardly surprising. At the start of the investigation officers had to document information manually and only towards the end had pilot computer systems. The foren sic scientists could not provide a breakthrough. DNA science, today a decisive tool, was then in its infancy. Police made do with trying to find links through blood grouping. In Duffy's case this was possible, as he had a rare blood type; in Mulcahy's it gave no conclusive help.

Again, towards the end of Hart, some primitive DNA testing was done, but nor did this link Mulcahy with the crimes. In addition, seven victims failed to pick him out at identity parades.

Mulcahy remained free. The police say there is no evidence that he went on to attack women alone after Duffy was jailed. But, disturbingly, they have said Mulcahy will be questioned about at least five other rapes. Professor Canter believes that Mulcahy's mindset makes it likely that he would have continued to offend after his friend's conviction.

At least one woman, the Guardian has learned, who has come forward to allege she was a victim of Mulcahy alone, is considering bringing a complaint because she feels police did not do enough. She was attacked in 1983 when Duffy was free, but this shows that Mulcahy seems to have been prepared to operate alone. Duffy certainly carried out attacks by himself.

One of the problems for the Hart team was their premise that Duffy had murdered alone. They knew that if they suggested that two men had been present at the killings, it would be much more difficult to convict the single man they had charged.

At least they had some sort of result. Duffy was convicted of five rapes and two murders in 1988. He was acquitted of Anne Lock's murder on the judge's direction but now concedes he and Mulcahy did kill her.

Then, between June 1996 and September 1998, there was a new series of sex attacks in Hampstead, near where Duffy used to live and Mulcahy was still based.

Operation Loudwater was launched and found striking similarities with the Hart crimes. To see if the attacks were linked fresh DNA tests using improved techniques were carried out on evidence from the earlier inquiry, and compared with those of the Loudwater investigation. There was no link.

But Mulcahy was also arrested in connection with Loudwater and a sample of his DNA taken. It ruled him out of the Loudwater series - but on a detective's hunch a "speculative search" of the DNA database was carried out and finally matched him with traces of semen found on the clothing of one of the Hart victims. At last, the evidence that had been missing in 1986 was there.

By this time, the police discovered, Duffy was talking.

In December 1998 Operation Marford, which ended with Mulcahy's conviction, was launched, the first "cold case" inquiry into serial murder undertaken in Britain.

The team were determined not to let Mulcahy escape. They debriefed Duffy, corroborating every piece of evidence possible. His evidence proved "chillingly accurate". But why did Duffy come clean? He claims it was to salve his conscience, saying: "I feel a lot of guilt and want to make a clean slate of it and own up. I am also worried I had a co-defendant who is still at large."

His avowals have to be treated with caution. Though Duffy has been told he will spend the rest of his life in prison, it is possible his confession may lead to his category A status eventually being reassessed.

Whatever his motive, his decision allows police to draw a line under one of the most horrific series of offences in history.
