fields.headline: Vicious attacks shattered lives
fields.trailText: For the many victims of David Mulcahy and John Duffy and for the women's relatives, the impact of their crimes will be felt forever.
fields.body:
For the many victims of David Mulcahy and John Duffy and for the women's relatives, the impact of their crimes will be felt forever.

Before sentencing Mulcahy, the recorder of London, Judge Michael Hyam, spelled out some of the horrendous consequences of their attacks, which he said had destroyed "all things in life which we take for granted".

One rape victim has been plagued by nightmares and constant anxiety. She has been off work and received medication. Another has spoken of how she could not comprehend how another human being could inflict such fear and terror in another. Yet another said she "ran away even now from the good things in life".

Three victims hugged each other as the verdicts were returned. Others were too upset to attend.

A young German au pair, raped at knifepoint, was so devastated she kept her ordeal a secret from her husband and family for 15 years. Even now she refuses to speak English or visit Britain.

From her home in Germany she said: "It happened in England and it will stay there. I did not wish to have the experience here with me. When I was not busy, I thought constantly of it. I never had any medical treatment and told no one, but repressed the experience."

The au pair was 20 and a virgin when she became the eighth victim in the catalogue of attacks. They ambushed her at knifepoint in Brent Cross, north London, as she returned from an evening out with a friend in January 1985.

She was dragged into bushes and gagged with her scarf, and a knife was held against her throat.

"I was very frightened and did what they told me. I tried to reason with them but they told me to shut up."

Though now a policeman's wife, the mother of two refused to travel to Britain to give evidence in Mulcahy's trial, fearing she would have a mental breakdown if she had to give evidence.

Police tried to reinterview every victim of the attacks. Many had undergone counselling, were married or in relationships and had children. Some had not told their husbands or partners they had been raped. Several were trying to rebuild their lives abroad.

Detectives paid tribute to the survivors of Mulcahy and Duffy, and to the families of murder victims Alison Day, Maartje Tamboezer and Anne Lock. The latter's husband Laurence said: "I don't have any clear memory of the night she disappeared but I have memories of her smile. I remember that vividly."

Detective Superintendent Andy Murphy said of the bereaved families: "They lived through the emotional anguish of one trial to learn many years later they had to face a second one. They had buried their children and moved on. We asked them to support a new investigation which opened old and painful wounds."

I never had any medical treatment and told no one, but repressed the experience." The au pair was 20 and a virgin when she became the eighth victim in the catalogue of attacks. They ambushed her at knifepoint in Brent Cross, north London, as she returned from an evening out with a friend in January 1985. She was dragged into bushes and gagged with her scarf, and a knife was held against her throat. "I was very frightened and did what they told me. I tried to reason with them but they told me to shut up." Though now a policeman's wife, the mother of two refused to travel to Britain to give evidence in Mulcahy's trial, fearing she would have a mental breakdown if she had to give evidence. Police tried to reinterview every victim of the attacks. Many had undergone counselling, were married or in relationships and had children. Some had not told their husbands or partners they had been raped. Several were trying to rebuild their lives abroad. Detectives paid tribute to the survivors of Mulcahy and Duffy, and to the families of murder victims Alison Day, Maartje Tamboezer and Anne Lock. The latter's husband Laurence said: "I don't have any clear memory of the night she disappeared but I have memories of her smile. I remember that vividly." Detective Superintendent Andy Murphy said of the bereaved families: "They lived through the emotional anguish of one trial to learn many years later they had to face a second one. They had buried their children and moved on. We asked them to support a new investigation which opened old and painful wounds."

fields.headline: Love of 'hunting' united rapists
fields.standfirst: Friends' fascination with violence began as schoolboys
fields.trailText: One day in the mid-1970s - it may have been during the long hot summer of 1976 - two oddball teenage friends who had met at school plotted a sex attack.
fields.body:
One day in the mid-1970s - it may have been during the long hot summer of 1976 - two oddball teenage friends who had met at school plotted a sex attack.

The taller and bolder of the pair, David Mulcahy, had fallen out with a woman while doing building work at her flat. Mulcahy suggested to his friend John Duffy, a seemingly meek man who was remarkable only for his piercing stare, that they "teach her a lesson" by breaking into her home and raping her.

The teenagers planned the crime carefully. They got in, lay in wait and were foiled only because she did not return that night. But they were not disheartened. A short time later they planned a second attack on another woman, again spotted by Mulcahy. This one seemed "stuck-up".

On this occasion the plot failed because she returned with a man. They only just managed to escape. But as they caught their breath, they realised that they had loved the hunt. That they were almost caught added to the excitement.

Bond

Over the next decade they changed and refined their tactics and became one of Britain's most prolific pair of sex attackers. Their friendship developed into what was characterised in court as a "unique but wicked" bond.

They raped together at least seven times and were foiled a further five. They called it "hunting" and liked to psych themselves up by playing Michael Jackson's track Thriller.

At first their territory was the streets around their north London homes. Then they looked further afield and became ever more violent. Eventually they began to kill. They murdered three times before Duffy - who came to be nicknamed "the Railway Rapist" because so many of the attacks happened near railway lines - was caught.

The police always suspected that Mulcahy was Duffy's partner, and indeed was the more dominant, but until now lacked the evidence to charge him.

Mulcahy and Duffy may never etch themselves in the public consciousness in the same way as Hindley and Brady, or the Wests, but those who have come into contact with them do not doubt that they are among the most depraved and dangerous criminals of 20th century Britain.

They met in September 1970 on their first day at Haverstock secondary school in Chalk Farm, north London, both aged 11. Quickly they became, in Duffy's words: "best of friends - like brothers."

At school the pair attracted the attention of the bullies, Mulcahy because he was small for his age - barely 4ft tall -and Duffy because of his bright red hair.

They felt alienated and took solace in each other, finding they had much in common, not least a fascination with violence. When they were 13, Mulcahy was caught torturing and killing a hedgehog in the playground as Duffy watched.

Often they played truant together on nearby Hampstead Heath. They enjoyed creeping up on courting couples and leaping out to frighten them. After they left school they would prowl the heath.

They also became fascinated with martial arts and both had a treasured collection of knives. Duffy, for one, studied Zen Budo, a form of martial arts with the motto "Leave no witnesses".

A copy of the notorious manual The Anarchist's Cookbook, which instructs on how to kill with bare hands, was found in Duffy's home. There is no reason to believe Mulcahy did not also learn such skills.

The pair left school in 1975 with no qualifications. Mulcahy did building work and helped out in his father's pubs while Duffy went on to work for British Rail. This gave him the intimate knowledge of the railway system which the pair were to use to find secluded places for their attacks.

In 1976 they were convicted of assault after taking shots with an airgun at passersby from the balcony of a pub in west London. And then there were those first two botched attempts at rape.

Their motive - according to Duffy - was to get back at the two intended victims. This supports the idea that their bond stemmed from their feelings of alienation.

Marriage

By their next attack both had married. Mulcahy met Sandra in 1976. They married in 1978 and went on to have five sons. Duffy married Margaret in 1980 but they could not have children because of his low sperm count, which put great pressure on the relationship.

The first rape took place in October 1982. Margaret was away and they planned to abduct a woman and rape her in Duffy's flat. They pounced on a woman in nearby Kilburn High Road but decided against taking her back. Instead they raped her in a building site.

Back at the flat, according to Duffy: "We were both very excited and said we should do it again." They got away with it despite Margaret returning unexpectedly and believed they would never get caught because they were cleverer than the police.

The pair began to plan the attacks in detail. They plotted where to take their victims, what they should call each other and arranged escape routes.

Duffy explained: "We normally travelled by car. We called it hunting. Part of it was looking for a victim, finding her and tracking her. David had a tape of Michael Jackson's Thriller. We used to put that on and sing along to it as part of the build-up."

They armed themselves with knives and on at least one occasion a replica gun, and wore dark clothes and balaclavas or hooded tops. They carried tape to cover the victims' mouths and eyes and terrified them by threatening to slash them.

But how could Mulcahy and Duffy leave their wives at night and do what they did?

Psychologists agree that in almost all cases where sex offenders are married, their wives are victims of an abusive relationship.

Duffy's definitely was. He once forced a handkerchief down Margaret's throat. He claimed that problems with his marriage led to his offending: "I think I just wanted to strike back at my wife by raping women."

Mulcahy told a work colleague his wife was "completely submissive" but there is little evidence he treated her badly. Last night she continued to insist he was innocent.

It is unusual, but not unique, for two men to rape together. The pattern of offending, however, beginning with childish high jinks before progressing to minor offences then on to serious crimes, is common.

Forensic psychologist Dan Wilcox, who has a consultancy role with the West Midlands probation service, said it was likely the pair had started fantasising about rape as early as the age of 12.

Mr Wilcox said each would have justified the other's actions in much the same way as sex offenders would do in paedophile rings. "They change what normality is and justify each other's actions," he said.

Excitement

The excitement level grew. Duffy said: "We used to compare the attacks. We would feed off each other's emotions." They also became proficient at hiding their tracks, trying to cover up evidence they might have left behind.

Between October 1982 and March 1985, by which time they were working together at Westminster council, they raped or conspired to rape 12 times. The youngest of the victims was just 16.

The attacks bound them ever closer. One victim said they were like "two bodies with one brain, soulmates".

The pair's hunger for excitement led them to grow ever more violent until killing seemed a logical next step. Duffy said Mulcahy had liked the idea of "playing God" with their victims and considered himself an "immortal warrior".

In December 1985 they killed for the first time. The victim, 19-year-old Alison Day, infuriated Mulcahy by trying to flee after she had been raped by the pair, who this time had not bothered to cover their faces. They strangled her with a strip of her clothing and dumped her body in a canal.

The following April they ambushed Maartje Tamboezer as she rode her bicycle. Duffy raped her and Mulcahy put her belt around her neck and ordered Duffy to twist it. They murdered for the final time in May 1986, this time killing 29-year-old Anne Lock. Duffy raped her and then went and sat in the car. When Mulcahy returned he said she would not be identifying them.

Now the police were closing in on Duffy. He raped once more - alone this time - in October 1986 at a time when he knew the police were watching him.

The pair had vowed to protect each other if one got caught. For a decade Duffy kept his side of the bargain.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Hopes high for heart drugs
fields.body:
Hopes high for heart drugs

Clot-busting drugs that promise to improve the chances of recovery for heart attack victims could soon become more widely available. Ministers hope the thrombolytic treatments will cut deaths among the 250,000 people who suffer heart attacks each year and have asked advisers to review success rates and value for money.

Dummy slows down drivers

A dummy policeman is slowing traffic in a village plagued by speeding drivers. The shop dummy dressed in an imitation uniform with a desk lamp in place of a radar gun has been placed beside the busy A429 in Corston, Wiltshire, by a local man, who claims it has encouraged drivers to keep to the 30mph limit.

£30m to fight rogue traders

Trading standards officers are getting a £30m boost over the next three years to tackle rogue traders. Part of the money will fund "stop now" orders, to be introduced in the spring, which will slap instant bans on illegal traders.

Chicken firm axes GM feed

Grampian Country Food Group, which supplies about a third of Britain's chickens for the dinner table, is to rear all its poultry on animal feed without genetically modified ingredients. All GM soya will be removed by June, the company said yesterday. Several supermarkets have said they will soon not sell livestock raised on GM ingredients. Grampian produces 3.8m chickens and 24,500 pigs a week.

Frogs' eggs give cancer clue

Frogs' eggs have given scientists a vital clue to what happens when cells turn cancerous. Researchers at the University of Dundee found a mechanism that may normally prevent cancer from developing, and could lead to new kinds of treatment in the future.

Sarah Payne arrest expected

Police are to arrest a 41-year-old man in connection with the murder of eight-year-old Sarah Payne following examination of new evidence. Sources have revealed that Roy Whiting, formerly of Littlehampton, East Sussex, will be arrested early next week. He has been arrested twice previously by detectives investigating the case.

fields.headline: Church sued over 'undue influence'
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: A controversial charismatic church admitted yesterday that it is being sued by a former member over allegations that its leader exercised undue influence over her.
fields.body:
A controversial charismatic church admitted yesterday that it is being sued by a former member over allegations that its leader exercised undue influence over her.

The Peniel Church of Brentwood, Essex, promised to fight allegations that its leader, "Bishop" Michael Reid, a former insurance salesman, had used his personal magnetism to force a member of the congregation to do his bidding financially.

Caroline Green, 33 now divorced and living in Wales, is alleging that Mr Reid overrode her parents' wishes concerning her education and ordered guests at her wedding to tithe a 10th of their gross income to the church.

Ann Brown, a spokeswoman for the church, said: "The claims she is making are bizarre. We are anxious that the matter should be brought before a judge so that we can contest it vigorously."

This is not the first time the church has found itself at the centre of controversy. The local parliamentary constituency of Brentwood and Ongar has been riven by claims that church members have signed up en masse for the local Conservative association.

The independent MP Martin Bell has promised to contest the seat at the general election in response to calls from independent Conservatives that the church's influence should be challenged. It is known that 119 members of the church joined the local Conservative association on the same day.

webTitle: Wanted: family to live on Muck

fields.headline: Wanted: family to live on Muck
fields.trailText: Residents of the Scottish island of Muck are advertising in newspapers for a family to join them, after 10 members of the community of 30 left to live on the mainland.
fields.body:
The name may not be appealing, but the lifestyle has its advantages.

Residents of the Scottish island of Muck are advertising in newspapers for a family to join them, after 10 members of the community of 30 left to live on the mainland.

They got the idea from a BBC series, Two Thousand Acres of Sky, in which the former EastEnders star Michelle Collins, responding to a newspaper advert, quits the London rat race and moves with her family to a remote community.

Ewen MacEwen, 54, who has lived on Muck all his life and has a share in his brother Lawrence's ownership of the island, said: "It's a family of children of primary school age or just under we are looking for, ideally."

The island, part of the group that includes Eigg, is virtually crime-free, has plenty of open space and has no bad crowd for children to fall in with.

"There is virtually no traffic, none of the problems you get on housing estates, with drugs and gangs," Mr MacEwen said.

It has a one-and-a-half-hour ferry service to Mallaig on the mainland. In summer a tourist boat operates from Arisaig.

Mr MacEwen said the absence of a secondary school was the main reason families left; otherwise pupils had to stay in lodgings on Mallaig.

The island's name is thought to derive from the Gaelic word for porpoise.

fields.headline: Hinduja deal that became a scandal primed to explode
fields.standfirst:
Bofors backlash: It is a tale of arms dealing and allegations of multi-million pound kickbacks. But why should a national scandal in India have set Labour's alarm bells ringing? David Pallister investigates
Special report: Peter Mandelson
Slow Burn - the scandal
fields.trailText: Bofors backlash:  It is a tale of arms dealing and allegations of multi-million pound kickbacks. But why should a national scandal in India have set Labour's alarm bells ringing?
fields.body:
The two charismatic prime ministers were good friends and political allies. The highlight of their public collaboration came in January 1985 with the Delhi Declaration, a manifesto for peace calling for control of nuclear weapons. But Sweden's third world champion, Olof Palme, and India's glamorous new moderniser, Rajiv Gandhi, then just 41, had more on their agenda than making the world a safer place. Their collaboration on what became known as L'affaire Bofors has mesmerised Indian political life to this day.

With the Indian judicial system continuing its tortuous grind to get at the truth, the Bofors scandal and the extraordinary attempts to cover it up still has the potential to damage, not only Britain's richest Asian family, the Hinduja brothers, but also Gandhi's Italian-born widow Sonia, now president of the ailing opposition Congress party. It all began in 1980 when India became worried about the build-up of Pakistan's defence forces with hi-tech equipment from the United States. Prodded by the generals, the defence ministry decided it needed some new, powerful artillery, the 155mm howitzer. Army delegations travelled the world and by late 1982 there were four countries on the shortlist, with a French system the favourite. Second best was the Swedish company Bofors, acquired by the inventor of dynamite, Alfred Nobel, in the late 19th century. Bofors badly needed new orders and according to the police chief who investigated Palme's assassination, the Swedish prime minister personally helped swing the deal.

But until February 1986 the French were still the preferred bidder. Then suddenly the Indian army HQ drew up a new technical evaluation and, to everyone's surprise, decided that the Swedish gun had the edge over the French, both on the grounds of performance and cost. It was a decision which the Indian auditor general would later call "deficient" and "flawed" on almost every level.

In just over a month the contract for 400 guns was signed with the personal approval of Rajiv Gandhi. The first advance payment of 20% of the £715m total was made on May 2.

Behind the scenes, however, there had been some fancy financial footwork going on in Switzerland, in Panama and in the English home counties.

Preparations were in hand for what the Indian criminal bureau of investigation (CBI) charge sheet would later allege was a criminal conspiracy.

On February 14, 1986, a company called McIntyre Corporation was registered in the off-shore banking centre of Panama. By the end of May the corporation had three Swiss bank accounts with the code names Mont Blanc, Tulip and Lotus.

Swiss banking records show that Mont Blanc was opened at the request of Prakash P Hinduja, who lives in Switzerland. Prakash confirmed that "we are the beneficial owner of MacIntire Corp (sic)" and added that the account was to receive more than 11m Swedish kroners sent by AB Bofors.

Two further accounts linked to the Hinduja family and the McIntyre Corporation were opened by May 30.

Between May and December, £21m in Swedish kroners flowed into the accounts.

The Hindujas were not the only players on the scene. In the autumn of 1985 the British director of a shell company in Guildford, Surrey, A E Services, had been approached by an Italian businessman, Ottavio Quattrocchi, a family friend of Sonia and Rajiv Gandhi. In November, a contract was signed between the company and Bofors and an account was opened in Zurich, which in September 1986 received more than $7m from Bofors. This then migrated via Panama, Geneva, Guernsey and Austria to accounts controlled by Quattrocchi and his wife Maria.

The first whiff of a scandal came within a year when Swedish public radio alleged that commissions had been paid on the deal and that the Hindujas were recipients. The brothers immediately issued a denial saying "there is a clear-cut conspiracy to malign the name of the family." Rajiv Gandhi described the allegations as "false, baseless and mischievious." Bofors insisted that no bribes or commissions had been made.

Reluctantly, "to set the controversy at rest" as he put it, Gandhi asked Sweden to investigate and a report was drawn up by the national audit office but never published in full. An Indian joint parliamentary committee started investigations and senior Bofors executives gave evidence.

According to the CBI, they lied. Yes, a consultancy agreement had been entered into with three companies for advice about banking and counter trade, but this had been cancelled in January 1986 before the Bofors deal was signed.

The committee exonerated the government of wrongdoing and Rajiv was able to claim: "To the best of my belief the Swedish audit report upholds the government of India position and does not contradict it."

There the matter may have been fallen off the political radar screens were it not for some tenacious digging by the Madras-based Hindu newspaper. Over two years, the Hindu published Swiss banking documents and sensational parts of the audit report. The documents linked the Hindujas to the commissions but the brothers immediately claimed they were false and fabricated. "Baseless and malicious lies," said Gopichand (GP) Hinduja, who with his brother Srichand (SP) had by then established the headquarters of their multimillion business empire in London.

But the audit report was devastating. It had found "entirely proven commission payments to companies/accounts in Switzerland in relation to the Bofors deal." It went on: "[That] these payments unquestionably relate to this deal is based on the fact that this has been communicated in writing by A B Bofors to the Bank of Sweden."

The details of the three Hinduja accounts identified by the Swedes and the money transferred coincided exactly with the Swiss documents that eventually would be released in Geneva 10 years later.

The Hindu also published extracts from the personal diary of Martin Ardbo, the former president of Bofors, in which Rajiv Gandhi was personally implicated. The sleaze was too much for the Indian electorate and in the elections of 1989 Gandhi and the Congress party were decisively defeated.

Faced with such prima facia evidence, the Indian central bureau of investigaton began to show its mettle. On February 7 1990, it requested banking documents from the Swiss authorities. Two weeks later both G P and SP Hinduja, then assiduously courting Tory politicians, made their first unsuccessful applications for British passports.

The police described their explanations as "evasive" and the court refused them permission to leave the country.

webTitle: Maharajah's palace in search of a saviour

fields.headline: Maharajah's palace in search of a saviour
fields.standfirst: Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: With its ornate balconies and air of eccentric majesty, the old palace in Bhuj used to be the town's star tourist attraction.
fields.body:
With its ornate balconies and air of eccentric majesty, the old palace in Bhuj used to be the town's star tourist attraction.

Built in the early 18th century by a formidable princely ruler, Maharajah Lakhpatji, Bhuj's palace delighted in an architectural style unique in India, and showed the influence of the Moorish traders who came to Bhuj from far across the sea. But last week the palace suffered a terrible blow. The earthquake that flattened the town in Gujarat state saved its worst destruction for the old quarter, for its narrow alleys, tightly packed shops and the palace itself.

"One has to face reality," the current maharajah's now homeless cousin, Raghurajsinh Jabeja, said yesterday, sitting on a chair in a palace courtyard strewn with rubble.

"As much as one would like to see it restored, it is a Herculean task. We are trying to save as much as we can but so much has fallen down."

The palace's ceremonial arch to his right, 50 yards away, had half collapsed. Its dome lies upside down in a mountain of old masonry and dust. "The entire arch may have to be partly demolished, " Mr Jabeja said.

Many of the palace's lovely balconies - from where the womenfolk would have watched the world through wooden shutters - have survived. But the colonnaded square where Mr Jabeja used to play as a boy is filled with shattered teak beams.

"I was born here. So were my father and grandfather," he said.

The eunuchs' quarters have been destroyed. The last eunuch belonging to the court died as late as 1965. "We used eunuchs to guard the treasury along with local staff and Arab mercenary soldiers. Eunuchs were considered loyal because they did not have families." Mr Jabeja said.

The large ceiling tiles in the palace's subterranean passageways are now perilously loose. Mr Jabeja and the maharajah's brother, Ghanysham Singh, have not yet ventured into the palace's museum which used to attract 75 to 100 foreign tourists a day. The curator who has the keys has been busy, tending to his daughter who was injured in the quake.

The museum included the old maharajah's personal living quarters walled with dozens of decaying gilt mirrors, together with a collection of armour, turbans, coins, clocks and bad European art. "We suspect the 18th century collection of European glassware may have been totally damaged," Mr Singh said.

The music room with its ornamental fountain, where Lakhpatji used to compose poetry surrounded by dancing girls, is also in poor shape.

The two brothers were the only people inside the palace a week ago when the tremors started. "I had taken a bath. I knew immediately it was an earthquake. I ran outside and stood under the doorframe. I could hear the girders come crashing down around me. I was saved by the will of God," Mr Singh said.

The present maharajah, who lives his life mostly in Bombay and London, was in Bhuj but not in the palace at the time of the quake. He survived the destruction in the town. An elderly man, he has no children.

The history of the palace - the only building of architectural significance damaged in the catastrophic earthquake that took at least 20,000 lives in western India when it struck on January 26 - is also the history of Kutch, the barren and alluring desert region in Gujarat. During the monsoon season Kutch becomes an island fiefdom, encircled by water.

The palace has long been associated with intrigue. An early maharajah, Raydhanji II, who converted to Islam under the influence of an Arab holy man, was imprisoned by courtiers for his whole 75-year reign, Mr Jabeja said. Raydhanji is said to have roamed the building at night, sword drawn and holding a candle, shouting "Hail be to Allah!".

Another boy prince who joked that a tubby local chieftain might be hanged from the palace's elm tree was swiftly deposed in a coup. This experience of civil strife led, inevitably, to the arrival of the British.

The first British adventurer to reach Kutch, Captain MacMurdo, came disguised as a sadhu or holy man. But in 1819 an army regiment blasted through the walls and Kutch followed other areas of Gujarat in being brought under the administration of the British East India Company.

That same year the last great earthquake hit Bhuj, destroying 7,000 houses and killing 1,000 people. The maharajahs survived but when India became independent in 1947 they were divested of their powers.

Last night it was not clear who, if anybody, would take on the bill for restoration of the palace, estimated off the cuff at £3.5m.

"We don't want the money for ourselves. And we don't particularly want it from the Indian government. But we would like it with no strings attached, " Mr Singh said.

One suspects that unless a generous benefactor comes forward to rescue the beautiful but broken palace, the maharajahs of Bhuj have, after 500 turbulent years, reached the end of the line.

fields.headline: Sub-postmaster sued by PO after armed robbery
fields.trailText: The Post Office is suing a sub-postmaster from whom £54,000 was stolen in an armed robbery, saying he had inadequate security.
fields.body:
The Post Office is suing a sub-postmaster from whom £54,000 was stolen in an armed robbery, saying he had inadequate security.

A £4,241 claim for negligence has been lodged against Nicholas Beech at Grimsby county court on Humberside. He says there is no case to answer, and has issued a counter-claim to the court. The Post Office says he broke his contract by failing to follow specified precautions.

In September 1999 three men armed with handguns and wearing balaclavas burst into the flat above Mr Beech's sub-post office in Grimsby, and took captive an 18-year-old tenant living there. During the night they drilled through the floor.

The following day they lay in wait for Mr Beech's wife, Susan, and two staff to close for the evening. They then smashed through a ceiling, threatened the three women, and tied up them with plastic cords. The men stole money from the safes and made off in a waiting car.

Speaking yesterday, Mr Beech, who is also a senior lecturer at Leeds Metropolitan University, said his wife was still traumatised by the raid and claimed the Post Office had not done enough to help staff recover from it. Seventeen months on she suffers from nightmares and does not like going out in the dark.

"The Post Office says that if we had done certain things, they wouldn't have got away with so much money; but I believe it wouldn't have made a difference," he said. "The criminals concerned had plenty of time, and planned it with military precision.

"They say I should have had different proportions of cash in the different safes to make it more difficult for the robbers. But I believe they would have got in anyway, as they had already shown they were quite prepared to wait."

He added: "My wife and I have been through a considerable amount of harassment, and it is not helping her get over this. It is no wonder that people like me are getting disillusioned with the whole business and want to get out."

Mr Beech also claimed the Post Office used cheap security equipment - even though the average turnover of a town post office is between £100,000 and £200,000 a week.

After the raid the police put a sensor alarm at the back of the office for protection - the Post Office had refused to do so because of the cost, said Mr Beech. He handed in his resignation as sub-postmaster three months ago, although his wife still works there.

Colin Baker, general secretary of the National Federation of Sub-postmasters, said: "There's been far too much violence against post office staff in recent years. I can't imagine why the Post Office would consider a sub-postmaster negligent in this kind of case. The Post Office only asks sub-postmasters to contribute to losses if there has been some negligence."

A spokesman for the Post Office said the armed robbery had been very traumatic for everyone concerned, but it had done all it could to support the staff at the office.

"However we do have security procedures in place, and our sub-postmasters are under contract to adhere to them," he said.

"What we are saying is that he was in breach of that agreement. That is why we are pursuing a claim for negligence."

Four men have been charged with conspiracy to commit robbery and will appear before Hull crown court later in the year.

webTitle: Fears of insurance no-go zones as global warming claims rise

fields.headline: Fears of insurance no-go zones as global warming claims rise
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: The insurance bill for extreme weather events and rising sea levels is set to increase tenfold - from £20bn a year to £200bn a year by 2050 - making parts of the world uninsurable, the world's leading insurers have warned.
fields.body:
The insurance bill for extreme weather events and rising sea levels is set to increase tenfold - from £20bn a year to £200bn a year by 2050 - making parts of the world uninsurable, the world's leading insurers have warned.

"Climatic changes could trigger worldwide losses totalling many hundreds of billions of dollars a year," Dr Gerhard Berz, head of research for the largest re-insurance company in the world, Munich Re, told the United Nations' Environment Programme (Unep) in Nairobi. "The burden of claims resulting from so-called natural catastrophes has already taken on dramatic dimensions.

"There is mounting evidence of increasing frequency and intensity of natural catastrophes. Major windstorms set new loss records almost annually, while innumerable flood, tempest, drought and forest fire emergencies now seem to occur more frequently than ever before."

Losses caused by the weather in the 1960s totalled £30bn (in today's prices); in the 1990s that figure rose to £250bn. But as greenhouse gas pollution increases, the bill is set to rise more dramatically, to £200bn per year by 2050.

More than 100 environment ministers, including Britain's Michael Meacher, are meeting in Nairobi on Monday to discuss climate change.

Dr Berz fears the losses will bankrupt parts of the industry and wants government action to halt climate change. "There is reason to fear that climatic change in nearly all regions of the Earth will lead to natural catastrophes of hitherto unknown force and frequency," he said. "Assessing these developments could jeopardise the future of entire industries in some regions."

Before 1987, only one hurricane - Alicia in Texas in 1983 - cost £1bn in claims. Since then, 29 have cost that much.

Munich Re's estimates are based on predictions by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) that carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere will double by 2050.

The IPCC's previous report in 1996 saw no link between global warming and the increased frequency and intensity of extreme atmospheric events, Dr Berz said, but studies and simulations since have provided new evidence.

Dr Berz is particularly concerned about the effect on Europe where he says the pattern of insurance losses shows that climate change has already begun. Flooding on the Rhine in December 1993 and January 1995, and in England in 2000 are examples. Ever more frequent and heavier downpours are predicted.

"These milder winters have also reduced the extent of snow-covered areas above which stable, high-pressure zones of cold used to form, creating a barrier against low-pressure storm fronts approaching from the Atlantic," said Dr Berz. "So this barrier is often weak or has shifted far to the east. German wind records indicate a marked increase in the number of windstorm days in recent decades."

He says annual losses from a rise in sea level and flooding in low-level islands such as the Maldives, the Marshall Islands and the Federated States of Micronesia in the Pacific would exceed 10% of their GDP by 2050.

Klaus Toepfer, executive director of Unep, said the report was of great concern. Unep is working on a vulnerability index to warn governments which of their countries are most likely to be hit by extreme events, causing loss of life and property.

"The time to act is now," Mr Toepfer said. "The world has already signed up to a certain level of human induced climate change as a result of over a century of industrial emissions. We must help vulnerable areas of the world, primarily in the developing world, to adapt to the consequences of global warming."

Countries such as the US would lose £5bn a year because of damage to agriculture, while the EU would stand to lose up to £6bn.

The cost of premature death due to rising numbers of heatwaves is put at £14bn a year within the EU and £11bn in the US. Worldwide, the cost of premature death caused by heatwaves is put at £50bn.

But as greenhouse gas pollution increases, the bill is set to rise more dramatically, to £200bn per year by 2050. More than 100 environment ministers, including Britain's Michael Meacher, are meeting in Nairobi on Monday to discuss climate change. Dr Berz fears the losses will bankrupt parts of the industry and wants government action to halt climate change. "There is reason to fear that climatic change in nearly all regions of the Earth will lead to natural catastrophes of hitherto unknown force and frequency," he said. "Assessing these developments could jeopardise the future of entire industries in some regions." Before 1987, only one hurricane - Alicia in Texas in 1983 - cost £1bn in claims. Since then, 29 have cost that much. Munich Re's estimates are based on predictions by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) that carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere will double by 2050. The IPCC's previous report in 1996 saw no link between global warming and the increased frequency and intensity of extreme atmospheric events, Dr Berz said, but studies and simulations since have provided new evidence. Dr Berz is particularly concerned about the effect on Europe where he says the pattern of insurance losses shows that climate change has already begun. Flooding on the Rhine in December 1993 and January 1995, and in England in 2000 are examples. Ever more frequent and heavier downpours are predicted. "These milder winters have also reduced the extent of snow-covered areas above which stable, high-pressure zones of cold used to form, creating a barrier against low-pressure storm fronts approaching from the Atlantic," said Dr Berz. "So this barrier is often weak or has shifted far to the east. German wind records indicate a marked increase in the number of windstorm days in recent decades." He says annual losses from a rise in sea level and flooding in low-level islands such as the Maldives, the Marshall Islands and the Federated States of Micronesia in the Pacific would exceed 10% of their GDP by 2050. Unep is working on a vulnerability index to warn governments which of their countries are most likely to be hit by extreme events, causing loss of life and property. "The time to act is now," Mr Toepfer said. "The world has already signed up to a certain level of human induced climate change as a result of over a century of industrial emissions. We must help vulnerable areas of the world, primarily in the developing world, to adapt to the consequences of global warming." Countries such as the US would lose £5bn a year because of damage to agriculture, while the EU would stand to lose up to £6bn. The cost of premature death due to rising numbers of heatwaves is put at £14bn a year within the EU and £11bn in the US. Worldwide, the cost of premature death caused by heatwaves is put at £50bn.

fields.headline: Bush funds Iraqi opposition
fields.trailText: President George Bush has taken the first step towards making the overthrow of Saddam Hussein an explicit goal of US policy on Iraq, a move which could cause a significant split within his new team.
fields.body:
President George Bush has taken the first step towards making the overthrow of Saddam Hussein an explicit goal of US policy on Iraq, a move which could cause a significant split within his new team.

The Bush administration has issued an order permitting Iraqi opposition groups to begin limited moves inside Iraq using US government funding. The decision followed a meeting on Iraq policy at the White House on Tuesday, chaired by Mr Bush.

The moves are limited to a programme described as the "collection of informational materials", but they signal further steps in the same direction and cross a line in the sand which the Clinton administration was exceptionally reluctant to pass.

The new order allows the Iraqi National Congress (INC) - the main umbrella opposition group in the north of the country - to draw on $4m (£2.7m) which was authorised by the US Congress late last year, to compile information inside Iraq relating to Baghdad's war crimes, military operations and other internal developments.

It marks the first time since 1996 that the US has directly funded Iraqi opposition activities inside Iraq itself.

Further orders not yet authorised would permit the INC to use US funds to open a permanent centre of operations in northern Iraq, where overt activities would include the publication of a newspaper and other propaganda.

The INC then wants to tap into a further $12m to establish a distribution system for food, medicine and other humanitarian relief efforts inside parts of Iraq still under the control of President Saddam.

The new order is a clear sign that the Bush administration intends to push US policy towards Iraq in a different direction from the containment policy followed by President Clinton and US allies including Britain.

But first the new administration must resolve an internal power struggle between the secretary of state, Colin Powell, who favours caution and containment, and the Pentagon chief, Donald Rumsfeld, who is a supporter of active engagement in support of the Iraqi opposition.

Asked this week about Iraq policy, Mr Powell said: "Iraq is a problem for its own people," and described the situation in the region as "an arms control problem" involving weapons of mass destruction.

"They made a commitment to do away with those weapons and I think the international community and the United Nations has to hold them to that commitment," Mr Powell said.

However, that view is not necessarily shared so strongly by the Bush administration's more hawkish members and advisers, including Mr Rumsfeld and the vice president, Dick Cheney.

An INC official was reported yesterday to have said that the new money would enable it to extend its operations within as little as two weeks. The US funds could pay for some 40 INC agents to develop their networks within Iraq, linking up with thousands of sympathisers, the official said.

webTitle: Israel divided by an image to die for

fields.headline: Divided by an image to die for
fields.standfirst:
As neighbours grow fearful of a Likud victory, four men reflect on the appropriation of their historic picture

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: As neighbours grow fearful of a Likud victory, four men reflect on the appropriation of their historic picture.
fields.body:
It was an Israeli icon: three young paratroopers gazing in awe at the great stone slabs of the Wailing Wall, photographed in the first heady moments after the capture of East Jerusalem and its holy places in the 1967 war.

But what was once a symbol for all Jews has been appropriated by the Israeli right. The photograph has become a dominant image in the hardline Likud leader Ariel Sharon's campaign to defeat the incumbent Ehud Barak in Tuesday's prime ministerial election.

"Only Sharon will protect Jerusalem," the slogan says. Mr Barak's reply: "A big Jewish Jerusalem for ever and ever."

The photograph was used to advertise the rally outside the ramparts of Old Jerusalem at which tens of thousands of rightwing and religious Jews protested at Mr Barak's proposal to exchange parts of East Jerusalem for peace with the Palestinians.

Its appropriation has divided the four men whose lives collided on June 7 1967: the paratroopers Isack Ifat, Haim Oshri, and Zion "Tsiggy" Karasente, and David Rubinger, the photographer who gave them a place in history.

Today Mr Oshri, 55, works for the school system in the coastal town of Netanya. Dr Ifat, 57, is a gynaecologist in Rishon LeTzion near Tel Aviv, and Mr Karasente, 56, owns a pizza restaurant near the town of Afula in Galilee. Mr Rubinger, 76,a Time magazine photographer for 27 years, still lives in Jerusalem.

Of the four, Mr Rubinger is the most liberal, supporting Mr Barak's proposals for a Palestinian state and willing to go further by relinquishing Israeli sovereignty over the Biblical temple site, of which only the Wailing Wall remains.

Mr Oshri is a committed supporter of Likud and says Israel must keep all the Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

They are divided on whether the photograph should be used in the campaign.

Last month Dr Ifat, who stands, battle helmet clasped in his hands, at the centre of the photograph, took the rally organisers to the election commission, arguing they had no right to use his face without his permission.

He is uncomfortable with the celebrity and was livid when his likeness was used beneath a slogan he rejects: "We pledge an undivided Jerusalem will remain Jewish forever".

"You see many Arabs living there and you can't throw them away," he said. "Jerusalem is divided, so why do we talk about a united Jerusalem?"

His former comrades from the 55th paratrooper brigade hold a different view.

Mr Karasente said: "No matter if we are secular or religious, there is only one thing that can unite us: it is the Temple Mount, and the Western Wall and Jerusalem which are in our hands, and must stay with us until the end of time."

Although he counts himself a supporter of the peace camp, he balked when Mr Barak proposed to share the site with the Palestinians.

Mr Oshri believes Jerusalem is the heart of the Jewish people, and that the Arabs lack "the mentality" to make peace.

He says he no longer owns the likeness in the photograph, and that any soldier would have worn the same look of reverence on seeing the Wall for the first time.

The election commission agreed, ruling that the photograph had become "an asset of the entire nation".

Oz Almog, a sociologist, disagrees. The image has been used to sell cigarettes, wine and chocolates, and has been reproduced in a Tel Aviv waxworks museum. But having made the journey from icon to kitsch it has travelled back again, he says, becoming this time a symbol of the right.

Mr Sharon, he says, embodies the spirit of the paratroopers at the Wall because he looks back to a time when Israelis believed they could solve their conflict by military might.

Mr Rubinger - who gave the copyright to the army - is unhappy to see it being imbued with messianic feeling.

"Stones have become holy. Temples have become holy. Mountains become holy, and now pictures. The trouble is that people die because something becomes holy."

webTitle: Ivy League killing of perfect couple

fields.headline: Ivy League killing of a perfect couple
fields.standfirst: Victims friends ask who would want to murder two Dartmouth academics and question low-key police tactics
fields.trailText: Victims friends ask who would want to murder two Dartmouth academics and question low-key police tactics.
fields.body:
When Roxana Verona arrived at her friends' home for dinner she thought she knew what to expect there: strong margaritas mixed to a special recipe and conversation bridging the shores of academia and popular culture.

But she was wrong. What she found in the secluded house three miles from one of the leading universities in the United States were the bodies of Susanne and Half Zantop, lying in their own blood.

The couple, advocates of liberal causes at Dartmouth College, which has a reputation as one of the more Waspish conservative Ivy League schools, had been killed for, well, what? If the police know, they are not saying.

The two professors seem to have been well liked, loved even, by the friends, colleagues and students who will be at their memorial service in Hanover, New Hampshire, today. They had a large social circle, helped and counselled those in need, and performed quiet acts of charity from their home, set among barns and stone walls in the village of Etna.

Hanover is a close-knit community of 9,600 where everybody knows everybody else, most have some connection with the campus, and people take pride in not having to lock their doors. At least, that was the case until the Zantops, German immigrants born during the second world war, were killed. Sadly, the couple were among those who did make a habit of locking up when they were home.

"These are the two most remarkable people we knew," said Phil Pochoda, an associate director of the University Press of New England.

"How can they be the only two people that fate would obliterate? The thought that we would go on without them is now inconceivable."

Zantop, 62 and his wife, 55, arrived separately in the US in pursuit of opportunities not available in Germany to people of their generation, friends said. He wanted more than his father's box-making business; she wanted an academic career.

They met at Stanford University in California and Zantop's work as a geologist for mining companies took them to Central America, Argentina and Spain before they settled in Hanover 25 years ago, where he took a job in the earth sciences department.

She was a late starter who did not earn her Harvard doctorate until 1984, the year she took a post at Dartmouth. She began in the Spanish department, changed to German, and became chairwoman of that department five years ago. She was considered one of the leading German studies scholars in the US. In addition, she taught women's studies and comparative literature.

"It's pretty extraordinary for someone who got her PhD at a later age to have such a stellar career," Susannah Heschel, head of Jewish studies at Dartmouth, said.

This is by no means the only aspect of the lives and deaths of the Zantops considered extraordinary.

Jourdan Abel, a second-year Dartmouth student from Miami, said: "I'm from a big city where tons of people get killed every week and no one really cares. But there's this feeling that this is the perfect school, the perfect town. It's like something has disturbed our perfectness.

"Yesterday my room-mates and I locked the door while we were in our room. That's definitely a new thing."

Murder, if not a new thing in Hanover, is rare. There have been only two cases in the past 50 years, and local people are finding the authorities' refusal to give much away about the Zantop case frustrating.

It was five days after their death before the New Hampshire attorney general, Philip McLaughlin, was prepared to concede that they had been stabbed, and even then he would not speculate on the weapon.

"It's probable that the person or persons who entered their home were probably let into their home," he said. "We are also told that the Zantops were very generous and might have let a stranger into the home."

Earlier had said little more than that there was no need to panic, and that he did not want to disclose too much for fear of prejudicing a trial.

Some were surprised that the police did not interviewed the couple's friends sooner. Audrey McCollum, their next- door neighbour, said: "Let's say they're not Sherlock Holmes, but I know they're working diligently and being careful not to release anything that would start a wave of rumours."

This was not an entirely successful approach. First, a bloody handprint found in a kitchen on the campus was ruled irrelevant. Then undergraduates reported that a suspicious man had been seen in a hall of residence on the night of the murders, asking if anyone had heard sirens and whether there was a telephone nearby.

The suspicious man came forward: he was the editor of the student newspaper.

Veronika Zantop, 29, and her sister Mariana, 27, will be at today's memorial service, a week after their parents performed one of their final characteristic acts: they emailed friends asking them to oppose John Ashcroft, President Bush's nominee for US attorney general and a bete noir of the left. Mr Ashcroft's appointment has just been confirmed.

fields.headline: Arabs braced for 'rabid' Sharon
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Ariel Sharon's seemingly invincible lead in opinion polls is causing shivers of unease among Arab leaders contemplating the prospect of their greatest villain being crowned Israel's prime minister after next Tuesday's elections.
fields.body:
Ariel Sharon's seemingly invincible lead in opinion polls is causing shivers of unease among Arab leaders contemplating the prospect of their greatest villain being crowned Israel's prime minister after next Tuesday's elections.

Despite the efforts of his minders to repackage him as a peacemaker by restricting interviews and banning a debate with the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, Mr Sharon raised hackles this week in Egypt and Jordan, the two countries which have peace agreements with the Jewish state.

Mr Sharon's soft new image has also been undermined by pronouncements from extreme rightwing allies - potential cabinet ministers in the next government - that he would be prepared to bomb Tehran and Cairo.

After engaging in a spat with the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, Mr Sharon compounded his blunder by claiming that Jordanian officials had confessed to him their secret fears that their country would be swallowed up by a Palestinian state stretching from the edges of Tel Aviv to Iraq.

The Palestinians, too, appear unnerved by the implications of a Sharon victory. Despite the deaths of more than 320 Palestinians during the four-month uprising, Mr Sharon has repeatedly criticised Mr Barak for not cracking down hard enough on protesters.

Earlier this week, the Palestinian information minister, Yasser Abd Rabbo, called Mr Sharon a "rabid and dangerous" man with "hostile intentions to reopen a wider conflict".

Leading Mr Barak by 17 to 21 percentage points in yesterday's opinion polls, Mr Sharon does not want to see a near certain victory snatched from his grasp by Israeli fears of a regional war.

On Thursday, he told a Likud youth rally in Tel Aviv: "I know Arabs and they know me. They take me at my word; they know my yes is yes, and my no is no, and they know I say exactly what I think. I can lead negotiations with the Arabs. I have started contacts."

Several men in the audience yelled out: "Talk to who? They are all terrorists."

Such popular pressure, and the demands of coalition partners, could sway a Sharon government and lead to a further deterioration in relations with Cairo and Amman. Egypt, the first Arab country to sign a separate peace with Israel 20 years ago, recalled its ambassador from Tel Aviv last November in protest at an Israeli bombardment of the Gaza strip.

Arab leaders began venting their loathing for Mr Sharon on Monday when Mr Mubarak told Israeli television he had no intention of meeting the Likud leader unless he was serious about getting a peace agreement with the Palestinians.

"I have a peace treaty with you [Israel]. Do I have to speak with Sharon? If he needs something and comes to me, he is welcome," he said. "But if he needs nothing, leave him where he is, I don't need anything from him."

Mr Sharon shot back that he was not interested in speaking to Mr Mubarak either.

A day later, Mr Sharon muddied the waters with Jordan, long suspicious of the man who famously said that Jordan was Palestine, provoking fears of a mass expulsion from the West Bank. Mr Sharon, who opposed the 1994 peace agreement with Jordan, told the largest circulation Hebrew newspaper, Yediot Aharonot, that a Palestinian state could threaten Jordan's monarchy.

Jordan's prime minister, Ali Abu Ragheb, was furious. "These statements are nonsense and are aimed at sowing discord between Jordanians and Palestinians," he said.

 The Israeli army said yesterday that it was tightening restrictions on movement in the West Bank by further limiting access to Palestinian-ruled cities "because of the escalation in the security situation".

webTitle: Wave on wave of Afghans flee homeland

fields.headline: Wave on wave of Afghans flee homeland
fields.standfirst: War and drought drive people to barren camps
fields.trailText: In the biggest exodus from Afghanistan for four years, 150,000 people have poured into northern Pakistan in the past five months to escape drought and war.
fields.body:
In the biggest exodus from Afghanistan for four years, 150,000 people have poured into northern Pakistan in the past five months to escape drought and war.

Most of these refugees now live in grim and freezing conditions in camps around Peshawar, where aid agencies are struggling to cope. In one crowded camp nine children died from exposure in just one week in January, the agencies say.

The impact of Afghanistan's worst drought for 30 years has been made worse by fighting across a swath of the north between the hardline Taliban militia and the forces of the government it ousted. This mountainous area is the last sizeable chunk of the country holding out against the regime.

"The conditions in Afghanistan are worse than they are here," said Mohammed Abdi Adar, who works at the Peshawar office of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees.

"There are areas which the aid agencies cannot reach or do not have the resources to deal with. The ones who made it here are the lucky ones."

In the far west of Afghanistan, up to 500 refugeees have died in camps in Herat since heavy snowfalls in late January drove temperatures at night down to -30C (-22F), according to the UN. Its staff believe at least 80,000 others who have flocked to the city are at risk.

International aid donations for Afghanistan have slowed to a trickle in the past year. The UN has launched an urgent appeal for £2.3m to feed and clothe the Herat refugees. So far just £130,000 has arrived.

"We have to come to terms with the fact that we will see many people die in Afghanistan this year," said Erick de Mul, the UN coordinator for Afghanistan.

In Pakistan thousands of refugees have been moved to a new camp at Shamshatu, a mud-brown wasteland 20 miles south of Peshawar.

Most of Shamshatu's 60,000 Afghans live in canvas tents and survive on handouts of wheat flour, cooking oil and lentils. But the World Food Programme says supplies will last only two months more.

Clutching their red and green "verification cards" hundreds of men stood in a circle waiting to collect a ticket to exchange for food.

Crouched on the floor in the centre of the ring in a roped-off block sat dozens of women covered from head to foot by their burqas. Most of them were widows.

Qudsia Ghafar was waiting for a food ticket for her family. Her husband lost both his feet in a landmine blast but made the week-long journey with his family from their home in the Panjsher valley in northern Afghanistan a month ago.

"We had nothing to eat, there was no food," she said. "Our house was burned when the Russians came and now it has been destroyed again by the Taliban. They put my husband and my father in jail. My father is still in our village. We didn't have the money to bring him with us."

Pakistan officially closed the border crossing at Torkham in the Khyber pass in November, saying it could not cope with the influx of refugees. More than 2m Afghans, most of whom fled their homes during the Soviet occupation in the 1980s, already live in Pakistan.

But up to 600 people are still crossing every day, by bribing the guards or evading checkpoints. It is the largest wave, officials say, since September 1996 when Taliban fighters seized the capital, Kabul.

From Bagram, in central Afghanistan, Ahmad Shah and his wife travelled for five days with their five children.

"Now we want to learn a trade and work because Afghans don't want assistance, they want to work."

When the fighting is finished, "we will go back and rebuild our houses," said Mr Shah, who worked in Bagram as a nurse and English teacher. "I am always thinking about my house and the grapevines I had. Now there is nothing."

fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: When Tony Blair faced the Peter Mandelson crisis he was tackling a problem that is emerging to dominate organisations - how to manage talent. Even Mandelson's enemies acknowledge his role in turning Labour from an unelectable political relic to   the dominant force in modern UK politics. His achievements can be compared with any industrialist who has transformed a fading enterprise.
fields.body:
When Tony Blair faced the Peter Mandelson crisis he was tackling a problem that is emerging to dominate organisations - how to manage talent. Even Mandelson's enemies acknowledge his role in turning Labour from an unelectable political relic to the dominant force in modern UK politics. His achievements can be compared with any industrialist who has transformed a fading enterprise.

The modern economy is not the e-conomy, even the knowledge economy but the talent or T-conomy. The formula for success is R(KxT)=S, where R is resources, K is knowledge, T is talent and S is success. The link between knowledge and talent decides the returns from any given amount of resource.

Competition for talent is a battleground for all types of organisations. Leaders are judged by their ability to spot and get the best from talent. This is especially true in knowledge-based organisations where most of the value is generated by talent not cap ital equipment. Managing talent is different to managing other resources. Highly talented people do not operate by the same rules. Typically they change or reject rules. This willingness to rethink ideas, challenge convention or rewrite the rules is central to their appeal.

The talent paradox is that managers recruit gifted people for these capabilities, but strive to impose rules and structures upon people whose greatest value may lie in challenging rules, systems and structures. Little wonder that control oriented managers and bureaucrats find them awkward and difficult.

Traditionally, the balance of power lay with managers and organisations. Switching jobs was hard. The security of a pension could make the most creative person sit tight.

The dot.com revolution changed this. New companies offered capital gains that compensated for lost pension rights. The pattern set among internet firms spread rapidly. Banks, consultants, retailers, the leisure industries, media companies, other service businesses and ambitious manufacturers saw the link between knowledge, talent and success.

New management strategies are needed, underpinned by strong and supportive relationships. Equally important are mutually agreed boundaries and effective mentoring. These can only be built on negotiated outcomes, not imposed processes.

These systems are crucial in overcoming the Icarus effect after the character in Greek legend who built wings that enabled him and his son to fly, but in flying too close to the sun was destroyed.

Talent can behave in the same way. Gifted people can believe they are inviolable, take too many risks or simply ignore warning signs. Organisations that want their abilities need systems to handle these risks.

Many of these systems are surprisingly easy to design and develop. The three Rs of talent management are Recognition, Resources and Reinforcement.

There are two aspects of recognition. First, recognise that managing talent is different and rethink approaches to accommodate this. Second, recognise and acknowledge individual contributions - constantly.

Adequate resources are vital in retaining the enthusiasm and commitment of talent. A sense of worth and control can reinforce the feeling of value that helps people to realise their potential.

Reinforcing the importance and value of talent becomes a key leadership role. Tony Blair claimed that the New Labour project would not be completed until the party learned to love Peter Mandelson. The pleasure in so many quarters at his fall suggests that the Prime Minister failed in this, with unknown costs to his government.

Professor Tom Cannon is chief executive of RespectLondon

webTitle: An open and shut case for judges

fields.headline: An open and shut case for judges
fields.standfirst: The work done by Cap Gemini Ernst & Young on behalf of interactive TV caught the eye in the Management Consultancies Association's annual awards. Will White explains why
fields.trailText: The work done by Cap Gemini Ernst & Young on behalf of interactive TV caught the eye in the Management Consultancies Association's annual awards. Will White explains why
fields.body:
The Management Consultancies Association represents leading consulting organisations in the UK. Despite our attempts and those of our members, for reasons of client confidentiality it is difficult for consulting firms to talk freely about their work. So the Association launched the MCA Best Management Practice Awards which boast a larger and a more sophisticated collection of case studies each year.

At a ceremony earlier this week the winners of the year 2000 awards were announced in front of an audience of consultants, clients and other interested parties at the Great Eastern Hotel in the City. The judges, including civil servants, journalists and executives with hands-on experience of managing, were unanimous in deciding that the overall winner was the entry from Cap Gemini Ernst & Young and Open Interactive TV.

The project is a good example of how management consulting continues to develop as an industry. Open Interactive is a digital television service that allows viewers to browse for products, services and information in the comfort of their armchair rather than hunched over a PC.

In late 1999 CGEY were asked to provide support and advice to Open to enable viewers to get a first-class service. Part of the reason this project so impressed the judges was that the UK really is leading the world in Interactive Television (iTV). Television is seen by many industry experts as the key breakthrough application to boost e-commerce access for the many, rather than a small, tech-literate elite.

It is seen as the best way of bridging the so-called digital divide. Open is already avail able to 4m UK homes and the number is growing daily.

The two barriers holding back the development of electronic commerce over the internet are security and ease of use. Research by the MCA and others, including a recent Guardian/ICM poll, reveals that while around 50% of the UK population has the potential to engage in e-commerce, only around 2-3% actually make regular weekly purchases online. Open, with the support of CGEY, can now start to plug that gap via iTV.

The project and the demands made of CGEY, were breaking new ground, as Alan Glover, director, Cap Gemini Ernst & Young explained. "We were all very aware that here was something totally new. There had been one-man-one-dog experiments in iTV in the USA, but Open was going to be the first serious attack on interactive TV in the world. And we both realised there were risks, both commercial and technical. Would people want it? Would it work?"

CGEY had to cope with a particularly demanding set of project criteria. Research had already shown that iTV users expected a far higher standard of service than PC online browsers. They were also more sceptical about the security aspects of using an interactive service. It was vital that CGEY should put in place the right back-up systems that would ensure a smooth, efficient and pleasurable experience for the iTV subscriber. The systems had to work all day, everyday. Disaster recovery procedures that could cope with almost any eventuality had to be tested before the project went live.

CGEY continues to research the latest technological developments in iTV and trains and advises Open staff in their implications. CGEY also had to cope with the organisation of a variety of sub-contractors working on the project to ensure that they too understood the demands. The project represents the largest IT outsourcing contract ever agreed in the UK media industry

The MCA stresses that the best consulting projects are those that demonstrate a true partnership ethos, with consultancy and client working together. Relations between CGEY and Open are cordial, constructive and most of all interactive. With people bouncing ideas off each other the client can really benefit from using a consulting firm like CGEY.

One concern with using consultants is that it is often hard to measure demonstrable benefits. The speed of success of this project is certainly fairly convincing evidence. Open Interactive management has been able to focus on strategy and marketing secure in the knowledge that CGEY are there to pick up the pieces if there are problems with the technology or support systems. The rapid rise in demand for Open from nil to more than 4m in little over 12 months posed some serious questions about the reliability of CGEY as a partner, which were more than adequately met.

The success of Open is in no small way due to the consulting skills and experience of Cap Gemini Ernst & Young which was instrumental in turning a good idea into a real success. As Mr Glover says: "The results have more than justified our confidence, with Open pulling ahead of the internet as an easy way into e-commerce for millions of ordinary people."

 Will White is deputy director of the MCA. For further information log on to www.mca.org.uk or ring Will White on 020 7235 3897

fields.headline: Talking heads
fields.standfirst: Ruth Spellman Chief executive, Investors in People
fields.trailText: Ruth Spellman Chief executive, Investors in People
fields.body:
What was your first career aspiration?

To become Britain's first woman prime minister.

What has been your best moment in management?

Implementing a major culture change at NSPCC, then seeing the impact on services, fundraising and families.

And your greatest mistake?

One of the biggest was prob-ably recruiting the wrong person into a key position.

How would you describe your management style?

Open, participative, supportive but not always consensual.

Which deal would you most like to have done?

British Airways committing to Investors in People!

What do you find most annoying in your staff?

When they take on too much and are almost too loyal in not raising the point when they are overloaded.

What management wisdom is most overrated?

That there is only ever one right solution to every problem.

What is the biggest challenge facing your industry?

SMEs who do not see the relationship between people and profit, yet they have the most to gain from Investors in People.

What single lesson would you pass on to budding managers?

Don't presume you know everything; listen and learn, and don't be afraid to appoint people who are cleverer than you.

Which management guru do you believe in?

None, although the person I have read and read again is Charles Handy.

Who is your management hero?

Sir Tom Farmer. He gets things done and he can inspire others to achieve more than they thought they could.

Who is your favourite politician?

Denis Healey. I spoke with him in my first debate at the Cambridge Union when he was Minister of Defence.

If you could change one aspect of British business, what would it be?

Yet more acknowledgement of the people factor in business.

Do you have a view on UK membership of the EMU?

This has got to be the best option for us in the long term: the best route to linking us with other currencies in Europe so that we can develop a truly European economy.

What phrase or saying do you most overuse?

"This isn't rocket science."

Apart from quality time with your family, what else makes you happiest in life?

Seeing my children grow up into warm and generous human beings and my continuing contact with charities as chair of the Voluntary Sector NTO.

What annoys you most?

Having my time wasted or feeling that other good people's time is being wasted.

How do you relax?

Listening to music, walking or swimming. Occasional sauna and massage therapy. A long lunch with friends.

What was your last cultural experience?

The Turner Exhibition at the Royal Academy.

What is your favourite city?

Florence.

What would you really like to have been?

A truly great opera diva.

fields.headline: Travellers' checks curb Russian rovers
fields.trailText: Relishing a recent break to sample the little-known architectural delights of Russia's far north, a friend of mine boarded a train at Moscow's Yaroslavsky station.
fields.body:
Relishing a recent break to sample the little-known architectural delights of Russia's far north, a friend of mine boarded a train at Moscow's Yaroslavsky station.

For the first time in his 45-year-old life, he was stopped by a policeman demanding to see his passport and that of his wife and 15-year-old son. Just checking. Making sure that the three born-and-bred Muscovites were entitled to be in Moscow at all.

You can tell a lot from a Russian's passport - every address they've lived at since birth, whether (if male) they've done their military service, nationality and criminal record if any, as well as the usual stuff on marital status, children, etc.

In most cases the document is still the old passport, replete with communist star, and hammer and sickle on the cover under the large initials CCCP (USSR) - the personal ID eulogised by the revolutionary Vladimir Mayakovsky in his ode, My Soviet Passport.

Back then, in 1929, the Soviet passport enabled Russians to travel abroad. These days you need another special "foreign passport", while the main document that all Russians carry with them at all times is essentially an instrument of police and social control, making life easier for the bureaucrats sorting citizens and deciding where they are entitled to live.

Formally, of course, this is not the case. Freedom of travel inside Russia and the right to live where you like were enshrined in the declaration of rights and freedoms at democracy's dawn in 1991. But Mayor Yuri Luzhkov's regime in Moscow makes a mockery of such fundamental rights. Living in Moscow is seen as a prize while banishment from the 11m-strong metropolis has always been a rather blunt weapon wielded by the authorities to punish undesirables.

This helps explain the thriving underworld trade in the buying and selling of Moscow residence permits.

"For many Russians the words 'Moscow residence permit' still embody the pinnacle of their desires even though residence permits were abolished years ago," explains Alexander Borisov, a law professor at a Moscow police academy.

'Twas always so in Russia. After Peter the Great introduced the first rudimentary passport system in 1724, the tsars refined the system into a key instrument of domestic police control.

Lenin denounced the system as repressive and bourgeois after the revolution, but Stalin re-established and tightened the regime.

All these curbs on freedom of movement mean that provincial Russians are forever pining for Moscow while exile from the city is a perennial penalty. Anton Chekhov's three sisters famously sigh "Moscow, Moscow" in their desperation to escape the crushing boredom of the Russian provinces.

Things have changed hugely. Russians can travel abroad at will, provided they can afford it, and the host country grants a visa. But the police checkpoints examining documents on the roads around Luzhkov's Moscow and the random checks at Yaroslavsky railway station show that old habits die hard.

fields.headline: ANC crisis meeting on kickbacks claim
fields.trailText: South Africa's ruling African National Congress is meeting this weekend to scrutinise the party's performance as President Thabo Mbeki battles to fend off another crisis of public confidence.
fields.body:
South Africa's ruling African National Congress is meeting this weekend to scrutinise the party's performance as President Thabo Mbeki battles to fend off another crisis of public confidence - this time over charges that his government is blocking an investigation of corruption in a controversial £4bn weapons deal.

At issue is the purchase of planes, ships and submarines from European countries, including Britain. The investigation was ordered after the auditor general said there may have been kickbacks and nepotism in the awarding of contracts, and raised questions about the skyrocketing cost of the huge deal.
