webTitle: Tanzanian rap breaks free of past

fields.headline: Tanzanian rap breaks free of past
fields.standfirst: Songs reflect Africa's reality
fields.trailText: Conceived after her mother was kidnapped and raped, 18-year-old Witness Mwaijaga wants a loving relationship for herself. Losing her virginity, she raps in Kiswahili, was just "letting a man crack open my beer". She needs "a man who'll take me to the Planet of Love".
fields.byline: James Astill in Dar es Salaam
fields.body:
Conceived after her mother was kidnapped and raped, 18-year-old Witness Mwaijaga wants a loving relationship for herself. Losing her virginity, she raps in Kiswahili, was just "letting a man crack open my beer". She needs "a man who'll take me to the Planet of Love".

Witness, aka Bad Gear, is plump and purposeful, with swept-back hair and a "B" tattooed in her cleavage. She is the latest star of Tanzania's burgeoning hiphop scene. After decades of paternalistic socialism under independence leader Julius Nyerere, the east African country is awakening to freedoms of enterprise and expression, and one result is rap.

"Socialism institutionalised Tanzanian music - every company had its band. But the musicians were just paid lackeys. It created a very lethargic musical state," says Michel Tyabji, a musicologist.

Hiphop, he says, is the antithesis of that. "It's all about creative individualism, and it's producing an extremely talented, vocal breed of young Tanzanian."

When Witness was 15 she chose hiphop over traditional Ngomas drum music played by her mother. "Rap is the music in which you talk about hardcore things - and I've been through them," she says.

When her mother threw her out aged 15, she moved into the slums of Dar es Salaam and found her calling. Rapping in beer-shacks for a few Tanzanian shillings, her career began.

"It was very hard with no money," she says. "If I had not been strong I could have sold myself; been a bitch. But I dislike that. There's blood under my skin like everybody else. I can't be doing that."

Tanzania's rappers may have chosen an American musical style, but the substance is African. "We're telling Tanzanian stories, we're talking about the hard life we've been through," says Witness.

Sam Stigillydaa, her co-writer and fellow rapper, agrees. "We're singing about African life, about surviving," he says. "I'm talking about love, about how we can help out the women, about how we deal with HIV."

Sitting in the shade in Sam's mother's yard, a calf nibbling at her shoe and Sam's Down's syndrome younger brother pulling at her hair, Witness runs through her current hit, Unanisuuza ("You are cleaning me up").

Chopping out the beat with her hand, she raps first in Kiswahili, then Kinyakyusa, the language of her ethnic group, and sings the chorus in both.

The song says there are three kinds of man - those who love you; those who beat you; and those who only "open your beer" - and it has struck a chord with the women who come to hear her rap in the city's smarter bars.

Tanzanian rappers in general see their work as a force for the good, says Mr Tyabji, the musicologist. "There's very little negativity: they believe hiphop can help educate the kids who are flocking to the city with nothing to do."

Witness's Aids rap, Demo Akijileta ("Women are coming on") is another example. "If she's coming on, but she don't want to eat sugar in a plastic bag, you'd better put your pants on, because the disease is the bad one," giggles Witness, rapping in English as she translates from Kiswahili.

Since starting to write lyrics, Witness says she has lost interest in other rappers - Tanzanian or American. "I used to like Snoopy," she says, renaming American rapper Snoop Doggy Dogg. "But it's different for us here, we're in another world - the third world, I guess. I'm on my own, just me and a microphone."

To record the lyrics, Tanzanian rappers must pay a studio around £10 for a backing tape. To record a song for radio costs nearer £50 but even with Unanisuuza blaring out of radios across Dar es Salaam Witness cannot afford to record an album. Even if she gets the money, she will have to queue with other hiphop acts, such as Hard Blasters, Too Proud and Biggy Doggy Paws, for recording time at Dr J's - the only studio in town. There was another, but it burned down.

Despite the lack of facilities, fellow rapper Sam does not envy his wealthier American counterparts. "American rappers talk about crazy things - drinking, drugs, violence against women, American blacks killing blacks," says Sam. "I hope African rap stays African and doesn't turn crazy."

webTitle: Giant airship is no flight of fancy

fields.headline: Giant airship is no flight of fancy
fields.trailText: It is so big it can be seen from the tops of tall buildings in Berlin, 45 miles to the north. You could stand the Statue of Liberty inside it and lay the Eiffel Tower alongside with room to spare.
fields.byline: John Hooper in Brand, eastern Germany
fields.body:
It is so big it can be seen from the tops of tall buildings in Berlin, 45 miles to the north. You could stand the Statue of Liberty inside it and lay the Eiffel Tower alongside with room to spare.

It rears up on an abandoned Soviet military airfield set amid pine and larch woods near the town of Brand, the tangible evidence of a venture seemingly designed to strain credibility and invite scepticism, but which has now begun in earnest.

The plan is to use this immense structure as a construction hangar for the production of airships several times as big as any built in the past. They are intended to drift around the globe carrying loads heavier than anything that can be transported at present.

CargoLifter, the firm set up to turn this dream into reality, was listed on the Frankfurt stock exchange last year and has since become one of Germany's 100 largest companies by market value.

At his desk in an office on one side of the giant hangar, Christoph von Kessel, CargoLifter's production director, summoned an image on to the screen of his laptop. It showed one of the huge machines that crawl across opencast mines, tearing coal from the earth.

"This was built in Germany and sent to Kazakhstan," he said. "It had to be manufactured, separated into seven parts, transported, then reassembled and retested. Each of the bits was a heavy load that required bridges to be taken down along the route. We could have transported the entire thing in one piece."

To move a monster like that, though, you need first to build a vastly bigger monster, and everything about the CargoLifter's activities is on the grand scale.

Some of the workers in the hangar at Brand have taken to using micro-scooters to cross it. It is so enormous that Mr von Kessel keeps a pair of binoculars in his office to see what is going on up at the top.

The airships he plans to make there would be as big as cruise liners and carry a crew of between eight and 12. It is envisaged that, powered by helicopter engines, they could cover distances of more than 6,000 miles at speeds of between 50 and 75 miles an hour.

The standard production model, the CL160, would be three times the size of the Hindenburg, the passenger airship that exploded while mooring in New York in 1937.

That spectacularly horrific disaster seared itself into humanity's collective subsconscious to the extent that it prevented rational assessment of airship transport for half a century.

The engineers behind the CargoLifter project maintain that a Hindenburg-style disaster would be impossible with the CL160 since the gas keeping it aloft would be helium, which is non-flammable.

"The Hindenburg was a rigid structure with bags inside filled with hydrogen. It was covered with cotton mate rial and painted with aluminium paint. What caused the explosion was an interaction between the carbon in the cotton, the hydrogen in the bags, the aluminium in the paint and the oxygen in the air. It's exactly what you have in an Ariane rocket," said Mr von Kessel.

The CL160 will have a semi-rigid construction. Inside, there will be two giant airbags, pumped up and down by computer-run blowers to compensate for the expansion and contraction of the helium as pressure changes with altitude and temperature. However, the CL160 will be unable to fly above 2,000 metres.

It remains to be seen whether air traffic authorities will welcome such a vast craft floating around at low altitude. There may also be objections to its carrying vast loads over densely populated areas.

But the key technical challenge is in the area of unload ing. If an airship filled with lighter-than-air helium were simply detached from its cargo, it would shoot up into the sky. So the designers of the CL160 have devised a "load exchange" system whereby the cargo is replaced with water before the airship takes off again.

"It hasn't been done before, so we have to prove it is possible," said Mr von Kessel.

Behind him on the floor of the hangar, something that looked like an outsize gob of ectoplasm was wobbling and billowing in slow motion as, almost imperceptibly, it grew in size.

To test load exchange and many of the other features of the CL160, CargoLifter has built a test tool in the form of a balloon known as the TowTech that Mr von Kessel was fairly sure was the biggest ever made - 60 metres across. It had arrived from the firm's US plant the day before and was being inflated for the first time.

After experiments with the TowTech, the plan is to begin work on a prototype CL160 in September. The first flight is scheduled for the end of 2002 or the beginning of 2003. An academy has already been built among the abandoned runways and decaying MiG shelters on the air base in which to train pilots. Provided everything goes to plan, a lot of pilots are going to be needed.

"If we get only 10% of the existing market for heavy loads, we will need 200 CL160s", said Mr von Kessel.

fields.headline: A man of substance
fields.standfirst: My big break
fields.trailText: Adrian Sington, co-founder of online publisher eSubstance, first made his mark with the kind of success only the world of publishing would consider a failure.
fields.body:
Adrian Sington, co-founder of online publisher eSubstance, first made his mark with the kind of success only the world of publishing would consider a failure.

He edited a book about a pop group - the slick 80s boy band Bros - that went on to become the best-selling book of the year for his company. Despite its success, depicting the rise and fall of Matt and Luke Goss was frowned on and did nothing to enhance his prospects.

At some publishers Mr Sington would have been hailed as a commercial hero. But he was working for Penguin, a company more used to publishing the works of DH Lawrence and George Eliot than books on glossy stars.

Mr Sington, who worked at Penguin for three years until 1990, realised his chances of managerial advancement were slim.

Yet, he says: "My big break without question was joining Penguin. It was there that I saw what the power of working for a huge brand could do." Until then Mr Sington had spent all his working life in mainstream publishing, after studying philosophy and art history at University College London and later at the Courtauld Institute.

It was, however, the insight about brands - even pop brands such as Bros - and his knowledge of publishing that formed the template for his later career. If a single strand can be traced from his Penguin departure to his most recent project it is a theory that success can be found in a strong brand can be taken from one media and translated into a book.

It led to him co-founding two companies - one offline, Box Tree, and the most recent, eSubstance, online.

Box Tree turns strong television brands into popular books for both ITV and Channel 4. One of the most successful was Mr Bean's Diary, which sold more than 1m copies.

The company was sold to Macmillan in 1996, where Mr Sington stayed as managing director until last year. He left, 10 years to the day after the formation of Box Tree, to help set up eSubstance, a company that uses the internet to distribute the information in books to corporate customers.

A restless character, Mr Sington likes new challenges and thought he had achieved everything he could with Box Tree. It was profitable, with a turnover of £11m, but it would never be the source of riches and success that he sought. "I was watching people passing me on either flank making millions on the internet," he says.

Then he ran into Jeffrey O'Rourke, a Californian acquaintance, at the Frankfurt Book Fair in 1999. Mr O'Rourke asked Mr Sington if he was interested in joining him in starting an internet company.

Mr Sington's response was immediate: "Yes, what is it?"

It turned out to be eSubstance, which negotiates rights to distribute mainly factual information in books to corporate customers.

If, for example, a company is in health care, eSubstance can provide information from relevant journals and books for use on their web sites. Athough there is no book as an end product with eSubstance, Mr Sington insists his expertise remains the same -identifying brands and finding a way to exploit them in a different medium.

"For me the really attractive part of this was that I would be able to put into practice everything I had learned over the past 25 years about how to run a business and how not to run a business," Mr Sington says.

eSubstance, Mr Sington emphasises, has a traditional business model. Not for him the struggle of retailing online like Lastminute.com. Instead he pays publishers advances of between £3,000 and £150,000 for content which his web operation then sells to business customers.

Books are split into small pieces and then eSubstance searches for the bits that are relevant to an individual customer. The information is passed straight to the customer's website.

Unlike most dot.com outfits, his company has seen an initial valuation remain steady, he says, at a time when most valuations are tumbling. The company started with £7.5m in cash, and the team of 22 staff hope to be profitable by the end of 2002.

As for the technology sector, Mr Sington's views are clear: "The year 2000 was a year of over excess and I think that 2001 is going to be a year of over restraint by the people that are lobbing money into this space."

He is determined to be one of the survivors.

Everyone else in financial services has been doing the same, for once this year's opportunity to get tax relief on £7,000 worth of new investment is gone, the allowance will go to waste.

But investment trusts have an advantage. The industry's "its" advertising campaign, designed to demystify the business, has proved a controversial, success in its first incarnation, doubling sales to private investors in the six months to the end of the present tax year. Now the campaign has come out of cold storage, as the trusts spend £8m on press and television advertising.

Many have even started paying commission to independent financial advisers at the same rates as on unit trusts.

The "its" campaign may be wacky but many people are wary of the trusts, partly because they are complex and, more importantly, can involve higher risks than unit trusts.

Unit trust mechanics are easy: the value of your holding rises and falls in line with the underlying assets the trust happens to hold.

In contrast, putting money into an investment trust means buying its shares, and there is no direct link between the share price and the value of the assets the trust hold. Only supply and demand shifts in the share price decide what your holding is worth.

Investment trust shares are almost always traded at a discount to their net asset value - their shares are worth less than the value of their portfolio. The swings in that discount can be crucial. At the end of 1999, the average discount was 13%. By the end of 2000, it had fallen to 10%. But as share prices slipped by some 10% during the year, the end result was a fall in trust prices.

"There are more than 350 trusts, so the choice is enormous," says the personal financial adviser Penny O'Nions. "But you have to pick the risk level you want."

Some relatively broad-based funds investing overseas can provide you with an extra tier of opportunity or risk in the form of currency gains or losses.

Many IFAs shun investment trusts because they generally do not pay commission, but those who do not suggest using this year's Isa allowance to buy one widely based trust and then using the 2001-02 ration to buy a more specialised vehicle.

"A general growth trust investing round the world with a good long-term record is a starting point," says Ellisa Beyer of Gerrard, the London brokers."Foreign and Colonial Investment Trust fits the bill. TR's European fund is one step up the risk ladder, but prospects look attractive. Europe's stock markets had their dose of gloom earlier than we did and have come out the other side. What's more the euro looks like becoming stronger, which could provide some currency gains."

Mark Dampier at Hargreaves Lansdowne recommends the same general split and maintains that shares on the small Irish stock market are much cheaper than those elsewhere.

Most investment trusts can be purchased directly from their management groups through low-cost savings plans either on a regular monthly payments play or one one-off lump sum basis. The Association of Investment Trust Companies has free information on Isas and other investment trust issues on 020-7431 5222.

webTitle: Dream themes are all the rage

fields.headline: Dream themes are all the rage
fields.trailText: Themed funds, which invest in an idea rather than an geographical area, are taking the UK market by storm.
fields.body:
Themed funds, which invest in an idea rather than an geographical area, are taking the UK market by storm.

But financial advisers warn that these specialist trusts should be used as a diversification tool rather than a one-stop-shop to meet all investment needs.

There are two main breeds: One focuses on a single theme, such as technology or biotechnology. These can be risky due to their concentration in a given sector - witness last year's hi-tech fallout.

The second, newer variant is the global thematic fund, which has evolved with globalisation. Fund managers identify major trends in the marketplace, such as demographic change or developments in wireless communication, then construct the portfolio around companies and sectors likely to benefit from these trends.

Research by Citigate Dewe Rogerson shows that 87% of professional financial advisers now prefer funds carrying a number of sectors to single-themed portfolios.

Neil Birrell, manager of the Framlington New Leaders fund, says managers of global multi-theme funds are active in shifting money into areas where they anticipate the strongest growth, and avoid sectors likely to disappoint.

"If, for example, the biotech sector was to move out of favour, then we wouldn't have to hold exposure in this area, unlike a pure healthcare fund," Mr Birrell says. "Instead, we would channel the money into other areas that had stronger growth prospects: for example we would focus on the financials sector if that looked more promising at the time."

Although these funds can be volatile, investors can gain exposure to some of the biggest, best and fastest growing companies in the world, so long as they are prepared to hang on for at least five years.

But this does not mean they should be fooled into putting all their eggs in the one basket of multi-themed funds. Vivienne Starkey, at the London-based IFA Equal Partners, says themed funds should only be used as a diversification tool for investors who already have adequate exposure to more mainstream markets.

"Thematic funds have become the new buzzword and there is a real danger that people who don't have any other investments are being tempted to follow the fashion and splurge their full investment into these new types of products," she says.

Global thematic funds, which by their nature are dominated by US companies, could prove particularly useful for investors who had utilised their Pep (personal equity plan) allowance over many years and are heavily exposed to the UK.

Prior to the Isa's introduction in April 1999, the Pep was largely restricted to investment within the UK and EU. But from April 2001, there will be no geographic Pep restrictions, making the global thematic portfolio a viable option.

Thematic investing may have taken off last year but it is nothing new. The pioneer was Sarasin, which launched its EquiSar fund in 1994, followed by Invesco GT, which launched its Global Dynamic Themes fund in 1997.

Mike Jennings, fund manager of EquiSar, said his company took the view back in 1994 that when investing in multinationals, increasing globalisation and the rising use of technology rendered geographic boundaries irrelevant. He uses the example of Vodafone, Brtain's largest company, which is expecting to derive 84% of its earnings from outside the UK in 2001. Over the past year Merrill Lynch has launched its Global Titans fund, Framlington has come up with New Leaders, Newton launched Global Innovations and Aberdeen Asset Management set up Global Champions.

webTitle: Is the time right for a new bond?

fields.headline: Is the time right for a new bond?
fields.standfirst: Gail Moss checks out the current standing of corporate funds
fields.trailText: Gail Moss checks out the current standing of corporate funds.
fields.body:
When, back in 1995, corporate bonds were finally allowed into the Pep fold, they proved immensely popular, mainly because of the high tax-free yield they offered.

Six years on, investors holding corporate bond funds within Isas can still save 40% of yields currently averaging 7.5% if they are higher rate taxpayers.

But those same funds spent most of last year in the doldrums. So do corporate bond Isas still represent good value? Or are savers being lured by the tax breaks into a poor investment?

The answer needs an understanding of how corporate bonds are measured. As with equities, their performance is ranked in terms of total return - the change in capital value plus all income received. Bondholders generally expect to get most of the return in the form of income.

And while the level of income a bond pays out should be stable, its capital value fluctuates according to market views on inflation, interest rates, and how well the company itself is doing.

"Last year was a year of two halves," says John Hatherly, head of global analysis at M&G. "Until August bonds were not doing very well, because investors were buying government-issued gilts.

"But then in August the government announced that pension funds were allowed to buy corporate bonds in order to satisfy minimum funding requirements. That was enough to raise corporate bond prices."

That led to a strong rally and by the year's end the total return on M&G's corporate bond fund was 7%. Of this, 6.1% came in the second half. The average bond fund returned 4.7%. This compares with a total return for the average unit trust of -6.9%.

But the story was different for junk bonds with their lower credit rating, based on a higher chance of default on loan interest and capital. Junk weakened last summer as the British economy slowed down and the market feared increased defaults.

Over the year, the M&G high yield bond fund (which holds 60% sub-investment grade bonds, such as Orange and Colt Telecom) returned -1.9%. Advisers say investors need to understand what they're buying, and to pitch their choice according to their risk profile.

"There are some very safe corporate bond funds, and some aggressive funds,"says John Pattullo, corporate bond manager with Henderson Global Investors. "There is a myth that corporate bonds are risky, but they are generally safer than equities, as they rank before them in any payout to creditors. They are fine for people who are retired, and don't need capital growth, but a safe and reliable income flow."

Mark Bolland of independent financial adviser Chamberlain de Broe says: "I suspect a lot of people have corporate bonds in their port folio when they shouldn't have. The real reason they're there is to provide income. We've got clients who have built up their Pep portfolios to £130,000. With a yield just over 6%, they get £8,000, so higher rate taxpayers are saving £3,200."

Mr Bolland also points out that non-taxpayers with equity and fixed interest investments may be better off choosing to hold the equity funds in an Isa, and the fixed interest investments outside.

"As a non-taxpayer, you can reclaim the tax on income from fixed interest investments, but you can't reclaim the tax credit from equities unless they're in an Isa."

But he warns that investors should always do their investment calculations first, and work out the tax implications afterwards. "The tax aspect should be a side-effect, not the main reason for investing."

But even if all the fundamental reasons are there, is now the right time to be getting into corporate bonds?

"There is a strong possibility that interest rates will be cut after the next Bank of England meeting," says Mr Hatherly. "This makes deposit-based investments less attractive, and we might see switches to alternative sources of income, such as corporate bond funds."

fields.headline: White's week
fields.standfirst: A dollar stockpile awaits the slam-dunker from Stockport
fields.trailText: An £8m payday awaits a slam-dunker from Stockport
fields.body:
Hardly a day goes by without speculation in the papers on the size to which David Beckham's wad will swell when he signs a new Old Trafford contract this summer. But whatever engorgement it undergoes, the Beckham retainer will be nothing compared to the money being earned by a former Manchester United player from Stockport now plying his trade in America.

"How much is Beckham meant to be getting next year?" John Amaechi asked me when I met him in Florida this week. "£100,000 a week? Well, when my new contract kicks in, I'll be on £160,000."

At &£8m a year, this will allow Amaechi to elbow aside commercial lightweights such as Tim Henman, Eddie Irvine and the pathetically under-remunerated Beckham to become the second-highest-paid British sportsman in the world, after Lennox Lewis. The fact that you may not have heard of him is because he plays basketball, for the Orlando Magic (the United on his CV was not the football club, but Martin Edwards's ill-fated venture into basketball back in the late 80s). Now 30, after a decade on the American circuit, Amaechi is at last joining the sport's elite earners.

"Of course you could say I'm being overpaid, but for 10 years I've very definitely been underpaid," he said. "And I'm by no means the top earner, even on our team. There's one guy here who wears $m worth of jewellery. Imagine that, it's the value of a house round your neck."

The ever-articulate Amaechi has developed a reputation in America for speaking his mind on any number of subjects. Guns, abortion, sex education: he has an opinion on everything, though he says he's not much interested in basketball. His fondness for using his position in the game as a political platform earned him hundreds of death threats recently when he took on the gun lobby. But he insists his frankness on the subject of money - which contrasts with the shuffling embarrass ment of English footballers when asked publicly to embrace the subject - is more a matter of circumstance.

"Over here everything is open," he explained. "You can just go to the search engine on your laptop, tap in 'NBA salaries' and you'd get every detail, right down to bonuses and penalty clauses. Everyone's contract is posted there for scrutiny, so there's really no point being coy about it."

Though we might never discover whether Fabrizio Ravanelli really did have a clause in his contract which obliged Middlesbrough to pick up his wife's hairdressing tab, Amaechi's experience has telling pointers for the future of sport over here. The fact, for instance, that he and his colleagues can be paid so much is, in part, because his sport long ago sold its soul to television. In exchange for altering playing rules to provide convenient breaks in play for commercials to be shown, the cheques have just kept coming. And that's not all.

"Match days are entirely corporate now," Amaechi said. "What pays for the stadium upkeep are the big sponsors, the sky boxes, the hospitality. The real fan up in the nosebleed seats, paying maybe $15, really doesn't cut it in terms of finances."

Indeed when I went to see the Magic in action, it was clear that the prawn-sandwich lovers were in complete command. Unlike in college basketball, where the crowd plays a huge part in the game, here they sat back and waited to be entertained. And entertained they were. Even if the actual play followed the staccato rhythm dictated by television, there was a non-stop, all-singing, all-dancing parade which featured not only a mini airship dropping discount vouchers to a local electrical store on spectators' heads but also the local slimmer of the year firing fat-free sandwiches into the crowd through a bazooka. The irony of all this is that the arena where the Magic play is found in the most depressed part of Orlando, the deprived, decayed and exclusively black ghetto of Passmore. Thus, in the sport of choice of the urban poor, these days the locals have a better chance of getting into the arena to play the game than to watch it.

Huge salaries, television dictating the pattern of the game, the grass roots priced out: it all has a familiar ring. And if we are to follow every aspect of the American sporting way, Amaechi has a warning for his compatriots in England.

"I try to go out there as often as possible and engage with the fans," he told me. "But whenever I do, I see kids brushed aside by a new type of professional autograph hunter looking to sell my signature on [the internet auction site] ebay. I find that very sad."

But it does provide a fine definition of commercialised modern sport in which we know the price of everything and the value of nothing.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: Raquel's words of passion
fields.trailText: One of international football's true unsung heroines is Raquel Busto, the indefatigable translator of Noticias, the magazine of the South American confederation. Noticias, written in both Spanish and English, is a triumph of banality, typically featuring endless photographs of suited worthies congratulating each other on the opening of new office suites in downtown La Paz. Raquel's rendering of the text, however, is an art form. Highlights in the latest issue include the use of the word "fructiferous" and a feature on Boca Juniors' Toyota Cup triumph, headlined "Good weed, the ball!" After Boca's win, she writes, "the caravan of happiness spread like fire". As indeed it does whenever she approaches the keyboard.

Highlights in the latest issue include the use of the word "fructiferous" and a feature on Boca Juniors' Toyota Cup triumph, headlined "Good weed, the ball!" After Boca's win, she writes, "the caravan of happiness spread like fire". As indeed it does whenever she approaches the keyboard.

Easy as it is to laugh at the advertisement in Fulham's programme for the Domaine La Dona Tigana vintage ("its floral aroma is as beautiful as a John Collins free-kick") you can't help wondering if the description of this wine "as full-bodied as Chris Coleman" is that funny any more. Coleman's recent car accident almost resulted in his leg being amputated and it remains in doubt whether he will play again.

On the letters page of the invaluable Non-League Paper, an ideological dispute has broken out that threatens to make the divisions in the old Communist Party of Great Britain look like a mild tiff. Should they print the results of league matches or not? "To use the phrase 'bitterly disappointed' is a little dramatic," writes one NLP reader, John Davies, in response to complaints in the previous week's issue about the first signs of league coverage. Maybe so, but "bitterly disappointed" is likely to be the start of a long and vicious guerrilla campaign.

The news that some bookies have stopped taking bets on Manchester United to win the title has been greeted with grim resolve at the Oxford United website, Rageonline (www. rageon.freeserve.co.uk/ rageonline). They have started taking bets on which match will ensure the U's relegation.

More betting news. After picking two out of five winners (thank you Vitesse Arnhem and Oberhausen) in last week's gambling extravaganza, we were dismayed to discover that the company offering us £100 of free wagers had registered them as defeats. If that sort of thing continues we'll have to name them after all. Undaunted, we offer you this week's fabulous five, all at 3-1 or better: Genk, Metz, Sporting Braga, Athletic Bilbao and Bristol Rovers.

Was it a dream, or did Mark Lawrenson really refer on the radio last weekend to Ryan Giggs's "sleight of body"?

Heard the one about the Man City players and the planks of wood? Supply your own punchline if you prefer, but it emerged yesterday that Joe Royle hauled his reluctant squad in at 9am on Wednesday to prepare for their match against Liverpool. Under the guidance of a sports psychologist, they were instructed to chop through a plank each, with their bare hands. The defender Richard Dunne said afterwards: "I just thought, 'Yeah, right', but two hours later we'd all done it. The trick was not to look at the wood and to believe there were no objects in our way and that nothing can stop us." Yeah, right.

Highlights in the latest issue include the use of the word "fructiferous" and a feature on Boca Juniors' Toyota Cup triumph, headlined "Good weed, the ball!" After Boca's win, she writes, "the caravan of happiness spread like fire". As indeed it does whenever she approaches the keyboard. Easy as it is to laugh at the advertisement in Fulham's programme for the Domaine La Dona Tigana vintage ("its floral aroma is as beautiful as a John Collins free-kick") you can't help wondering if the description of this wine "as full-bodied as Chris Coleman" is that funny any more. Coleman's recent car accident almost resulted in his leg being amputated and it remains in doubt whether he will play again. On the letters page of the invaluable Non-League Paper, an ideological dispute has broken out that threatens to make the divisions in the old Communist Party of Great Britain look like a mild tiff. Should they print the results of league matches or not? "To use the phrase 'bitterly disappointed' is a little dramatic," writes one NLP reader, John Davies, in response to complaints in the previous week's issue about the first signs of league coverage. Maybe so, but "bitterly disappointed" is likely to be the start of a long and vicious guerrilla campaign. The news that some bookies have stopped taking bets on Manchester United to win the title has been greeted with grim resolve at the Oxford United website, Rageonline (www. rageon.freeserve.co.uk/ rageonline). They have started taking bets on which match will ensure the U's relegation. More betting news. After picking two out of five winners (thank you Vitesse Arnhem and Oberhausen) in last week's gambling extravaganza, we were dismayed to discover that the company offering us £100 of free wagers had registered them as defeats. If that sort of thing continues we'll have to name them after all. Undaunted, we offer you this week's fabulous five, all at 3-1 or better: Genk, Metz, Sporting Braga, Athletic Bilbao and Bristol Rovers. Was it a dream, or did Mark Lawrenson really refer on the radio last weekend to Ryan Giggs's "sleight of body"? Heard the one about the Man City players and the planks of wood? Supply your own punchline if you prefer, but it emerged yesterday that Joe Royle hauled his reluctant squad in at 9am on Wednesday to prepare for their match against Liverpool. Under the guidance of a sports psychologist, they were instructed to chop through a plank each, with their bare hands. The defender Richard Dunne said afterwards: "I just thought, 'Yeah, right', but two hours later we'd all done it. The trick was not to look at the wood and to believe there were no objects in our way and that nothing can stop us." Yeah, right. mike.ticher@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Karembeu's spice makes Boro sizzle
fields.standfirst: World Cup winner tells of his voyage from New Caledonia to Teesside.
fields.trailText: World Cup winner tells of his voyage from New Caledonia to Teesside.
fields.body:
Christian Karembeu strides out of the changing room, talking in French on a mobile phone and tricked out in a sharp suit smacking of catwalk couture. His team-mates are long gone but, as one of Europe's most decorated footballers, the Middlesbrough midfielder naturally needs extra time to spruce himself up.

"I go home to New Caledonia every three years, but I'm in constant touch with my family," the 30-year-old says, glancing towards reception at Boro's Hurworth training ground before joking: "Mr Venables pays the mobile bill."

Karembeu's mane of dreadlocked hair gives him the air of Ruud Gullit in his prime and recently his performances have justified the comparison. Yet this afternoon Boro welcome Manchester City, three points below them, to the Riverside for Teesside's latest relegation battle.

Such a predicament is alien to a player who has won league titles in Spain and France, two European Cups with Real Madrid, and the World Cup and European Championship with France. In Boro's trophy cabinet, by contrast, the 1976 Anglo-Scottish Cup continues its lonely wait for some meaningful company.

Karembeu, admittedly, was hardly an integral part of either the Real Madrid or France teams that won their most recent trophies, although he has 46 caps. However, he stresses other reasons for his move to the north-east. "I had everything I could ever have wanted in Madrid, apart from a challenge. It is easy to win the title at Real. You can swap the players around but the machine is always working and winning. They have a special word for their culture of victory: madridismo . Coming here was a totally different experience.

"But the first steps have already been taken - Boro have the players, the stadium, the training ground - and I want to be a part of the second stage. We could win the title. Why not?"

Such talk passes over Karembeu's torturous introduction to the Premiership after his £2.3m move, which could serve as a microcosm of Boro's season. Despite a rousing opening-day success at Coventry, the Teessiders quickly nose-dived towards the foot of the table. The Frenchman, groping blindly around midfield, looked alarmingly out of his depth.

"It's very hard to adapt," he admits. "There's less time on the ball; basically it's another sport. At Nantes I learned technique, how to move and create space; in Italy it was more tactical and every player has a quick-thinking, tactical brain. In Spain you got more open games, but here they hit you in the first second."

From early October there were eight defeats in nine games under Bryan Robson. Karembeu's personal nadir came in the first match of that losing streak. Against Newcastle at the Riverside he cut a forlorn figure, his passing consistently abysmal as he laboured in a spineless formation - "I worked myself up, didn't sleep a wink the night before and was awful on the day" - but his display was symptomatic of Boro's malaise.

"It was a mental thing," he says. "We kept losing our concentration. Sometimes two players would go for one ball; other times nobody would go for it at all. When you keep losing every week you steadily forget what it is you are actually good at.

"We were too frightened to play and towards the end of that sequence we had often lost even before the kick-off. Outsiders found it easy to criticise, but we were working, talking and trying to change things with Bryan. Perhaps he trusted us too much, but it is very difficult to manage and one of Bryan's strongest ideas was to bring Mr Venables here."

The transformation since Terry Venables arrived as coach in December has been staggering. Since a 1-0 defeat at Sunderland grounded them at rock bottom, Boro have been unbeaten in nine matches. Everton's first goal in Wednesday's 2-2 draw was only the third conceded in that period, and the other two were a penalty and an own goal respectively. Karembeu, too, has rediscovered his sparkle, forging a close relationship with the side's other big-name performer, Alen Boksic. It was the Frenchman's sweeping cross, headed back by Boksic, which enabled Hamilton Ricard to open the scoring at Goodison Park.

"Terry is strong and thorough at repeating details," he says. "We're professionals, but sometimes you need to be reminded of how to approach games. He spoke to every player, telling us what each of our strengths was, and suddenly we can run, we can pass, we can do anything. The defence is more organised and with those foundations in place the game is so much simpler. We have generated a positive energy. Now we believe that we are winners. A manager must be a good psychologist to encourage all his players to play well."

Karembeu should know. Since arriving at Nantes as a 17-year-old he has been coached by Sven-Goran Eriksson - "He's so philosophical and positive, under him I truly hope that England win something" - Gerard Houllier, Aime Jacquet, Jupp Heynckes and John Toshack. Under them he gorged himself on success, prompting raised eyebrows when he and his wife, the model Adriana Sklenarikova, decamped from Castile to Teesside.

But Karembeu has never been conven tional. As a student in New Caledonia, he protested against French nuclear testing in the Pacific. He is currently learning his sixth language, Slovak, so that he can communicate with his mother-in-law, and he is crusading on environmental issues.

"I've lived the life of a nomad and picked up philosophies from across Europe and I want to open people's eyes," he says. "My home and the traditions of my people are very dear to me. We have our own culture and identity which teach us to respect nature. We have destroyed so much, we have to give something back.

"I talk to the younger players here to educate them about the environment, just as we try and teach them the will to win. I wanted to come here and be a good ambassador. There are many talented players who never win anything; success is a mentality, and if you are strong-willed it can make up for a lot of other things."

fields.headline: Wenger wins appeal
fields.trailText: Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger has had his 12-match ban for violent and threatening behaviour overturned by the FA.
fields.body:
Arsene Wenger left the Football Association's headquarters with a reprimand and a £10,000 fine last night but his 12-match touchline ban was overturned.

The Arsenal manager was cleared by an FA appeal board of using violent or threatening behaviour towards the fourth official Paul Taylor at Sunderland in August. But the board decided after a two-day hearing that he was guilty of the less serious charge of misconduct for his behaviour in the tunnel after his team's defeat at the Stadium of Light.

The decision represents a serious blow to Taylor, who gave evidence to the board at Soho Square on Thursday, but whose version of events was unanimously dismissed.

The official arrived in London having been subsequently charged with misconduct by the FA since the initial hearing for comments he allegedly made to a Notts County player during a match in October. He faces a disciplinary commission in Birmingham on Tuesday and may be removed from the national list if found guilty.

Wenger, who employed two barristers for the hearing, presented new evidence to the board. He spent two hours giving evidence yesterday after three of his players - Thierry Henry, David Seaman and Robert Pires - had appeared as witnesses on Thursday.

The board concluded that although contact was made between Wenger and Taylor, it was minimal and that the Arsenal manager had not been threatening or violent in intent. "I feel I got a fair hearing and that I could defend my case well," Wenger said. "It's very important to me that the charge of threatening behaviour and violent conduct has been dismissed. The fact that I was charged with improper misconduct means my reaction was may be a bit big.

"But the fact that I got only a reprimand means the FA recognise my intention was clear and right, and that is important for me. I just wanted to avoid any violence in the tunnel."

Wenger has insisted that he he was merely trying to prevent a far worse incident occuring between Henry and Darren Williams, the Sunderland midfielder who also gave evidence on Thursday.

"The sad thing is that my record is not clean any more even if I was cleared of the main charges," said Wenger, who must also pay the costs of the appeal board.

John Hartson's proposed£5m move to Coventry and a meeting this afternoon with one of his former clubs, Arsenal, has been called off and remains a Wimbledon player. The striker had previously failed medicals at Spurs and Rangers.

"Unfortunately the deal will not be completed for a purely technical reason," said Bryan Richardson, the Coventry chairman. "For historical reasons, and nothing to do with John Hartson's current situation, we have been unable to secure the necessary insurance cover."

Birmingham City have completed the £1m signing of the England Under-21 midfielder Curtis Woodhouse from Sheffield United. The 20-year-old has signed a 4-year deal and is included in the squad for this afternoon's match with Norwich City at St Andrews. Peter Ndlovu, 27, moved in the opposite direction.

fields.headline: Walks in a Sven wonderland
fields.standfirst: Ron's in the dugout
fields.trailText: Ron's in the dugout
fields.body:
'@ *#*'in' Handbags!" ... ho ho! it's that man again! ... Peace-loving Peter Reid smoothing things over as tempers flare at the Stadium of Light ... hmm? And when two titans of the Premiership lock horns ... expect fireworks!

Andy Cole and Alex Rae like two rutting stags ... Monarchs of the Glen in their pomp! ... Imagine the pair of them mounted! ... powerful image isn't it? ... er above the banqueting table in the great hall ... marvellous!

But ... Ho ho ... there's only one United! ... er, no hang on there's two isn't there ... what? ... oh yes ... all right ... there's loads of them isn't there ... and one's dumped another one out of the cup!

Mighty Manchester beaten by their own bobbly pitch! ... dreams of the treble shattered by rugby-playing oafs neglecting to replace their divots in their rush to hurl themselves into the communal bath ... two months ago!

Ho ho! No characters left in the English game? ... Guff!

Barthez! ... Di Canio! ... a war of wits or a pair of twits? ... was Fabien "trying to make Paolo's brain a bit confused" ... Fat chance! ... Di Canio's cool as a cucumber! ... nickname "Zucchini" ... Plucked from the obscurity of a clothes shop in Milan by Our 'Arry! ... Footballers have always fancied themselves as dandies ... memories of Big Norm's boutique at the height of disco fever ... "Big Strides" ... regular customer John Travolta teaching us the latest routines ... Bianca Jagger's grand entrance, riding on a donkey!

Well Di Canio's settled at West Ham ... "The only way I will leave is if the chairman or manager kick my ass away" - er, sheepish recollections of Bianca Jagger's rather undignified exit from "Big Strides" ... swinging a leg astride a bolting Neddy who'd just taken a glancing blow from my platform shoe ... Blame it on the Boogie! ... ho ho the 70s ... happy days! ... Play School! - the square window? ... the round window? ...

Ron takes a peek through the Transfer Window!..

Oh! ... look its Stan! ... Collymore's on his travels again! ... he's signed for Real Oviedo!... Why?... Ask Miguel Solis ... the Spanish club's head ... er ... honcho? ... "We need a striker because one of ours has a broken leg"! ... ho ho wait till Stan gets there! ... Expect lots of fun next week! ... and not looking through the barred window ... hopefully!

Let's move on ... "The Case of the Fourth Official" ... "Elementary my dear Watson" isn't it? ... No! ... it's Monsieur Wenger! ... up before the disciplinary panel! ... Said he'd "fight like a real Arsenal man!" ... What! ... an 11-man brawl? ... ho ho!

Time for ... Ron's Tales from the Tunnel

Yes! ... let me put it straight ... here's the "inside dope!" ... "There was an incident ... deep in the shadowy recesses ... something's gone off? ... a fracas? ... handbags? ... much ado about nothing? ... hmm? er ... I didn't really have a clear view ... let's move on to ...

Ron's Tales from the Training Ground

You've heard the rumours ... a "committed" session at Arsenal? ... hmm? ... Bergkamp? _... Kanu? ... did things get a bit heated? ... dunno.

Performance of the week ? ... giant-killers Charlton Athletic defeat mighty Essex titans Dagenham and Redbridge ... how did they draw two at once? ... bit unfair! ... hmm? ... But Charlton continue dreaming! ... Me too! ... I find myself following a trail of hand-written signs bearing the legend "Svens" ... which leads me to a lock-up garage in Docklands ... filled with life-size effigies of Mr Eriksson ... perfect in every detail except ... no eyes and no ears ... and beside them a small wooden crate ... enigmatically labelled "Tords" ... just a strange recurring dream ... but how do those lads manage to turn up at every game? ... hmm?

...And a reader's letter ! Chelsea fan Mark Pitts of Chiswick writes: "Ron, I've always thought our loyal defender was called Frank leBoof, but a friend of mine says you say leBiff. Can you sort this out for us. People are laughing at me Ron."

Ho ho! .. it's French, Mark! ... just pucker the mouth ... jut out the lower lip ... drop it away to one side ... then ... er ... "le Boof!" ... isn't it? ... and Mark ... sticks and stones isn't it? ... practise a gallic shrug and walk away ... er reeking of garlic! ... marvellous!

Cheer up! ... here's one of Ron's Funnies ! ...Believe 'em or not ... they're all true!

In the world club championship in 1970, Van Daele of Feyenoord played "blind" ... the Argentine Pachame had broken his specs! ... ho ho! ... priceless!

... And a reader's letter! from a Mr Crozier of Scotland! "Ron here's one for your collection of 'Funnies!': Traditional cheats Germany were beaten 4-2 by England in 1966 - the third English goal didn't even cross the line! ... er ... ho ho.

webTitle: How to... combat bullying at work

fields.headline: How to... combat bullying at work
fields.standfirst: Old schoolyardhabits die hard
fields.trailText: Old schoolyardhabits die hard
fields.body:
Bullying is something we like to laugh off as a childhood rite of passage, but according to recent figures, there's a high probability you've seen bullying at close range in more recent years. A study of 5,500 employees by Manchester university UMIST found that almost half had witnessed bullying at work, and one in four had been bullied in the last five years. In three out of four cases, the boss was to blame.

"Bullying is endemic in the workplace, and it's getting worse," says Val Wallace, general manager of anti-bullying charity The Andrea Adams Trust.

The effects of bullying can be particularly damaging for recent graduates, who have less experience of workplace politics and may be more vulnerable as a result. "When graduates enter the workplace they need guidance and mentoring," says Cary Cooper, Bupa professor of organisational psychology and health at UMIST. "If they get management by punishment instead, it will totally undermine their self-confidence."

This was certainly true for Charles, a graphic designer. "My first boss was a self-made man who hated the fact I'd been to university," Charles says. "He yelled at me in front of other people, told me my work was useless and ignored me in meetings. The awful thing was, I started to believe I wasn't up to the job. In the end I left to go travelling. It took ages to get my confidence back."

Val Wallace believes jealousy is the core reason for bullying. "I'd say 98% of bullying is born out of envy or jealousy. Perpetrators often perceive their target as a threat to their professional position."

The Andrea Adams Trust defines bullying as "persistent, negative, malicious attacks on personal or professional performance that are often unpredictable, unfair or irrational".

So, what can you do about it? The first step is to recognise what's happening and remember it's not your fault.

To bolster your self-confidence, go to Tim Field's Success Unlimited site and discover that bullies usually pick on people who are good at their job, popular and have a high degree of integrity.

The next stage is to get support from friends and family, trustworthy colleagues, your union, a doctor or an occupational health counsellor. Don't try to deal with the problem alone. Talk informally to your line manager or, if your manager is the bully, to personnel.

Wallace recommends keeping a diary of events, covering dates, times, places and any witnesses. "But keep it at home, not at work," she advises. Also keep copies of relevant memos or emails.

Confronting a bully might seem like a risky option but it can be effective. "Bullies are devious, manipulative people who hate to be found out," says Wallace.

To tackle a bully face-to-face, it's best to act when you're feeling calm, rather than in the heat of the moment. Use assertiveness techniques and mention specific examples of inappropriate behaviour.

In their book "The Bully at Work", Gary and Ruth Namie say one option is to confront the bully behind closed doors, with a witness, citing his or her unprofessional and unacceptable conduct, and stating what you want to change. They claim this will make you less of an easy target for a bully, as well as reinforcing your self-esteem.

An alternative method is to get together with colleagues and confront the bully as a group. "Bullies thrive on lies, secrecy and imagined fear," say the authors. "Displays of fearless, public solidarity deprive the bully of all her weapons."

However, you need to trust your gut instinct about whether it's safe to confront a bully. "Some bullies are psychopathic," says Professor Cooper. "And if you're frightened to give feedback, you should report the person to personnel instead."

If your company is one of the 6% in the UK that has an anti-bullying policy, this should speed up the process. Other options are using the internal complaints procedure or - in extreme cases - taking legal action.

If you don't remember anything else...

You could just cut your losses and leave. "If the organisation has an autocratic culture of bullying, you should consider going," says Professor Cooper.

And Tim Field adds: "You might be better off finding a new employer who genuinely values you and your skills."

webTitle: MBAs? Oh baby, there's never a right time

fields.headline: MBAs? Oh baby, there's never a right time
fields.trailText: You know you want to do an MBA at some point. The only question is, when will you get most out of it?
fields.body:
You know you want to do an MBA at some point. The only question is, when will you get most out of it?

In many ways, doing an MBA is like having children - there's never a good time. They can be very expensive yet it's one of those things you think you might regret not doing in the future.

Leaving the finding of time, money and energy aside, when is the best time to embark on an MBA? Certainlyif you graduated in your early twenties and are just two years into a career, you're probably not ready. However, leave it too long and plenty of other distractions start coming along and a return to college looks increasingly unlikely.

If you talk to Professor Leo Murray, the man who runs one of the UK's most respected MBA programmes at CranfieldUniversity, he'll tell you not to consider it until you have some decent work experience under your belt.

"We don't let anyone enrol on an MBA course unless they have three years' experience of the working environment. The greater and more diverse the experience the graduate brings with them, so much the better. Besides, I think anyone with less than three years of experience wouldn't be getting what they wanted out of the course," he says.

Professor Murray places much emphasis on the interaction between students doing an MBA and describes a full-time course over a year as an "intense experience". While he probably wouldn't ever use the phrase, the underlying message is that he wants people that have "seen a bit of life" and have something to bring with them.

According to Peter Calladine, educational services manager at the Association of MBAs, most schools look for a minimum of two years' relevant work experience at an appropriate level of responsibility.

He says, that in practice, this usually means three years, so the minimum age is 24. However, far from the media perception that MBAs are done by bright young things fresh out of college, he reports the average age for commencing a full-time MBA is around 27. And for those undertaking a part-time MBA, it is more likely to be 33 or 34.

Again he warns against going straight from college and says graduates should question the merits of an MBA gained from a school that will accept them without looking for relevant work-experience.

"In a worst-case scenario he or she may be over-qualified to be considered for the 'graduate intake' at blue-chip companies, while not having the kind of MBA that employers want. They would be better off going to a good school to study for a masters in management (sometimes referred to as the 'young manager's programme').

"The curriculum is similar but it does not rely on the intense input and knowledge that is available from the students themselves on the MBA programme," he says.

webTitle: Writing covering letters that don't get 'filed' in the bin

fields.headline: Writing covering letters that don't get 'filed' in the bin
fields.standfirst: Make your first impression a good one
fields.trailText: Make your first impression a good one
fields.body:
As Stephen Garside, managing director of a TV production company, says: "Forget CVs. When I'm looking for people, particularly for more junior positions like a runner, I'm far more swayed by the covering letter than the CV." Experience, he adds, isn't essential - but the ability to be original, informal and articulate is. "It might seem a tall order to get all that into a covering letter but it is perfectly possible. However, it's rare."

In the days of milk rounds, recruitment agencies and endless internet sites offering top jobs, it might seem that writing a good covering letter is no longer a necessary skill. But any job that doesn't come through an agency will need a letter. In many media industries, on-spec letters are the only way to get a foot in the door - the demand to be a runner, receptionist or production assistant is usually so high that advertisments aren't necessary.

"People often tend to strive for the wrong things in covering letters," believes Anne Miller, head of human resources for a London radio station. "Most people do one of two things. They either repeat everything that is in their CV, which is pointless, or they write an incredibly formal letter which gives no clue as to their personality or why we should give them an interview."

According to Miller, what catches her attention is a letter where the character of the individual comes through. "Any letter that starts with anything different from 'I'm writing in response to your advertisment,' instantly grabs my interest. I like honesty - if someone admits that they've no experience in radio, but talks about their enthusiasm and motivation to get into the industry, then I'm just as likely to give them an interview as someone who used to run their campus radio station."

"The point of a covering letter is to complement your CV," believes work consultant Rachel Weston. "It should flesh out and explain any points that the CV doesn't cover. For example, if you're looking to change industries, your letter should explain why you want to make the move, what is your motivation, and what you hope to achieve. If your CV shows that you don't have a relevant qualification that the job ad has specified - perhaps a degree or a vocational qualification - you need to explain why you should still be considered."

It's not easy, and often writing the letter can take twice as long as writing your CV. But to some extent that is how it should be - a CV is a formal, structured document that is there simply to impart factual information, a letter is your chance to make an impression.

"I always try to make my letters gently humorous," says Nita Bhaskar, a freelance set designer. "I'll make reference to the fact that I know most on-spec letters end up filed in the bin, or that I'm happy if making the tea is one of my duties. I've never believed in the terrible formal style - in TV, directors and producers receive probably twenty or thirty on spec letters a week, so you've got to have something that will make you stand out."

Humour, according to Rachel Weston, is an important factor but she believes it should be mixed in with an air of respect for the person you are writing to and an understanding of the industry you want to work in. "It might sound obvious, but always write to a person, not a position," she says.

"Find out who is head of the department you want to work in and write to them by name. Try to get an idea of their job and the role that they play, and clearly define the type of position you are interested in. Writing to production companies saying you are dying to work in TV will impress no-one. You have to show a knowledge of the industry and where, ideally, you would fit into it."

Finally, always make the letter open-ended. "If someone writes into me asking if there are any positions, it's terribly easy to write back a polite no," says Stephen Garside. "If they write and ask if I would see them for ten minutes for an advisory chat and a coffee, I'm more likely to say yes. I like that kind of flexibility and informality. If someone is confident enough to suggest coming in for a coffee, then I'm interested enough to meet them."

Covering letters are the first impression you make. Don't dash off a three-line formal response, take your time over it and make it enthusiastic, positive and friendly.

webTitle: Careers with an accent on Europe

fields.headline: Careers with an accent on Europe
fields.standfirst: Stepping stones to the corridors of power
fields.trailText: Stepping stones to the corridors of power
fields.body:
If you fancy a career in the corridors of power at Brussels or Strasbourg there is a unique opportunity to find out more about studying in Europe later this month - a special fair to promote European integration postgraduate study courses in universities is being held in Brussels on February 17.

Graduates who might want to work in the commission or who fancy a career in the private sector but with a strong European flavour will discover that a European intergration studies qualification can be an impressive addition to their CV.

And at the fair they can find out what is on offer from universities and academic institutions all over Europe, including the UK, with the knowledge that the courses have been identified by a unit of the European Commission itself

This is the second such fair - last year's event attracted 300 students - and it is expected to be even more popular.

European Voice, a Brussels-based newspaper which is dedicated entirely to the coverage of European affairs, has teamed up with the European Commission's Action Jean Monnet to organise the fair which is free to all students with an interest in European postgraduate study.

The Guardian, along with Belgian newspapers The Bulletin, La Libre Belgique and Le Soir , is sponsoring the event.

And to coincide with the Swedish presidency of the EU, Ericsson is a major sponsor along with the University Association for Contemporary European Studies.

Part of the role of the Action Jean Monnet unit is to support the promotion of European integration studies in member states and other countries around the world and it holds a database of more than 500 postgraduate study courses in the subject of European intergration.

Action Jean Monnet also provides start-up funds for new courses, chairs and modules as long as the academic institution promises to keep its teaching activities going for at least seven years.

In the ten years since the start of this project, some 491 Jean Monnet chairs have been established and more than 1,300 new courses have been set up. At least 250,000 students each year are now on Jean Monnet courses in member states as well as the United States, Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic.

"This is a unique opportunity for students and young professionals to find out exactly which EU study courses are available, to meet programme directors and to decide which courses would be most appropriate for them," says Adrian Scally, head of enterprise at the European Voice . "Our objective is to ensure that all interested parties have the opportunity to sample what is on offer academically and to prepare them for a career in EU- related professions.

The event also includes seminars and workshops to give graduates a more detailed understanding of what a European intergration course can achieve.

For example Christopher Burghardt from consulting firm Hill and Knowlton is organising a seminar aimed at giving people a better perspective on the kind of practical experiences they can expect after a course. "The most popular option is to do an internship in the European Commission," he says.

An internship or 'stage' in Brussels-speak is a six-month stint working on a specific subject in a directorate general, or with cabinets in the commission. It can often mean working with people at a very senior level.

With this experience to call on, European integration students can work directly for the commission or take their inside knowledge into the private sector, working for consultancy practices, law firms, chambers of commerce, think tanks and other companies.

Christopher Burghardt, for example progressed through a masters at the College of Europe in Brussels and served an internship at the commission's office in Washington. He is now an account director with Hill and Knowlton in Brussels, advising clients on how EU affairs affect their businesses, on how to promote their interests and how to lobby within the EU for a regulatory framework in which businesses can comfortably operate.

His job would have been almost impossible without his integration studies background, he says.

A workshop hosted by the University Association for Contemporary European Studies aims to help students understand the nature of European studies and will run twice a day at the fair.

There will be three speakers, one who works in the European Commission and also writes on the subject, an academic who teaches European studies in the UK and will giv a UK perspective on the discipline, and a student who has worked for an MEP and is continuing with their European studies.

The workshops will also show how European Studies courses have a practical application to careers.

www.european-voice.com/eustudy

webTitle: It's a jungle out there - and they could be coming for you

fields.headline: It's a jungle out there - and they could be coming for you
fields.standfirst: Headhunters stalking campuses
fields.trailText: Headhunters stalking campuses
fields.body:
There's a tap on your shoulder and a word in your ear. Out of nowhere, someone you've never heard of is saying you've been recommended for a job you hadn't even considered with an organisation you'd never thought of approaching. Within a few weeks you've accepted a job offer and your career worries are over.

This is headhunting student-style, and such is the pressure to find graduates, it is no longer anything unusual on higher-ranking campuses.

"People tend to think headhunting only happens at a very senior level," says Amanda Powell, head of graduate headhunting at Moloney Search, which claims to be the only organisation finding students in this way. "But what we have done is take the techniques used for the boardroom and apply them to the junior level.

"We work very closely with clients in defining the sort of person they're looking for, and once we've got the brief we go out and look for them. We're not an agency and we don't have a database of students. We approach tutors on relevant courses and ask them to recommend their most appropriate students, or we network through student unions, JCRs, and student societies, asking people for recommendations."

Being headhunted when you're still a student can be a shock. "I was really surprised," says Laura Cope, aged 24, who was studying for a BA in French and economics at the University of Durham when the call came.

"It had never occurred to me that headhunting happened to students. At the time, I was doing my finals so I had put jobs to one side in order to focus on my degree. I found out that a friend had recommended me, and although I was initially unsure that I had the right background for the job, which was with Tesco.com, I did pursue it. I'm glad I did because I am very pleased with the situation I am in.

"When you're in the throes of student life you don't really have a picture of what working life is like, and a lot of graduates rush to apply for companies without actually realising what they will be good at. In a way having someone else help with your decision can be very relaxing."

Apart from the obvious ego trip of being chased rather than having to do the chasing, there are other advantages to being headhunted.

"Because the search company does the first interview, you're much more relaxed because you know that they're not going to be your future employer," says Rachel Carr. "They can see who you really are, whereas with the employer, you are so aware that you're being interviewed that you never really relax. I could also say things - like how I had never considered accountancy - which you wouldn't dream of saying to a prospective employer."

Laura Cope says: "I wouldn't call it insider information, but it is definitely useful being able to chat things through with an intermediary. In an ordinary application you wouldn't get the opportunity to speak to people one-on-one until the interview stage. In headhunting you can do it straight away. The other big benefit is missing out on all the form filling at the primary application stage."

Of course, being approached by a headhunter does not mean that you are going to be offered a job. An initial chat over the phone will be followed by an informal interview, and only then will your name go forward to the company itself. Even then you may have tests to pass and there will always be other candidates to beat at the final interview.

However, once your name has gone forward, your chances of getting the job are probably about one in two so you know you are a serious contender.

The reason companies use headhunters is to ensure they get exactly the people they need. By gathering recommendations from tutors and leading students, and by interviewing informally over the phone, an experienced headhunter can quickly gauge whether someone has the right mix of personality, interests and abilities.

"We used a headhunter because we were looking for someone who had shown a very specific interest in treasury rather than just finance," says Andrew Kirby-Pugh, human resources manager at Tesco, "and we didn't think we would find them through our conventional recruitment methods. It looks expensive, but the results are so good it is actually cost effective."

So, if you do want to be headhunted what should you do? "Extracurricular activities are one of the most important factors," says Amanda Powell. "If you are active in the JCR, the student union, or in sports and social clubs we're much more likely to contact you. Companies want team-players and potential leaders, and extracurricular activities demonstrate this perfectly."
