fields.headline: Blackburn look to Berkovic
fields.trailText: Eyal Berkovic, Celtic's Israel international, was last night considering a loan move to join Blackburn Rovers in their attempt to win promotion to the Premiership.
fields.body:
Eyal Berkovic, Celtic's Israel international, was last night considering a loan move to join Blackburn Rovers in their attempt to win promotion to the Premiership.

The 28-year-old hopes to leave Celtic after being phased out of the first team since the arrival of Martin O'Neill as manager last June.

O'Neill is willing to let Berkovic move on, despite being heavily embroiled in a chase for the treble.

"The club have had a conversation with someone at Blackburn Rovers - John Williams [the chairman] - who telephoned this morning before we went training," said O'Neill.

"Nothing has gone through but there's a possibility that he will move on a three-month loan period soon."

The Blackburn manager Graeme Souness, who was Berkovic's manager at Southampton, said: "I spoke to Eyal's agent after hearing he was not happy at Celtic. It is no secret I am looking for another midfield player. In my opinion, he is the best in the business at delivering the killer pass."

Berkovic became Celtic's record signing when he moved from West Ham United for £5.75m in July 1999 but the striker has made only four league appearances this season, two as a substitute.

Airdrie were last night spared having to field a team of youngsters in their delayed third-round Scottish Cup tie at Queen of the South because of a registration blunder.

The First Division club failed to register 16 first-teamers in time and feared they would have to play on with the 14 remaining registered players on their books, most of whom are untried juniors.

An SFA spokesman said: "The decision was made in the interests of fair play, and taking into account the fact that the players had been registered continuously by the club since the start of the season."

Aberdeen's coach Ebbe Skovdahl goes into today's match against second-placed Hibernian believing his team will one day pose a serious threat to the Old Firm.

"We are trying to build a young side but it will take time until we will be able to compete against both Rangers and Celtic home and away," he said. "My main objective is to see that the young players are developing correctly. I think it is definitely going in the right direction."

fields.headline: QPR Chairman stands down
fields.trailText: Chris Wright's dream of returning QPR to the Premiership died yesterday when he announced his decision to resign as chairman.
fields.body:
Chris Wright's dream of returning QPR to the Premiership died yesterday when he announced his decision to resign as chairman.

Wright, founder and chairman of the media group Chrysalis, spent £13m uniting the west London side with Wasps rugby union club in August 1996, just months after their relegation from the Premiership.

At the time he had visions of a great sporting empire. "With the right attitude we can get back in the Premiership," he said. "If, for the sake of our fans, we can win the FA Cup one year or reach Europe, I would say we've achieved something."

By his own standards Wright has failed. Loftus Road plc, the company he created in 1996 to control the clubs, lost £5.3m last year. Its share price, which reached 56.13p in 1998, rose 1p yesterday when the news was announced - to 8p.

Wright decided to resign after fans' unrest following Wednesday's defeat against Fulham. "When I took over I made it quite clear that as soon as I felt I had lost the support of the fans I would immediately resign," he said. "It is abundantly clear that time has now arrived."

Talks with potential buyers have been ongoing for some time but, with Rangers one from bottom of the First Division and uncertainty clouding the future of the transfer system, it is difficult to see who would be willing to buy Wright's stake. He will continue to fund the club until a saviour is found.

Manchester United plan to appeal against Andy Cole's sending off for clashing with Sunderland's Alex Rae on Wednesday. "In my opinion it wasn't too bad," said the United manager Alex Ferguson. "We're considering asking the referee to look at it again."

Gary McAllister has agreed a one-year extension to his contract at Liverpool, which will now expire in the summer of 2002.

fields.headline: Banse/ Henschel
fields.standfirst:
Wigmore Hall
London
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
Wigmore Hall
London
Rating: *****
fields.body:
German soprano Juliane Banse and her compatriot, the baritone Dietrich Henschel, could be described as two of classical music's beautiful people. Stylish and glamorous, they joined forces with Graham Johnson for a concert to mark Schubert's birthday. Its ostensible purpose was a retrospective summary of songs from the last four years of his life - though the evening could have been dubbed "sex and Schubert" as the emphasis lay very much on his response to the vagaries of erotic experience and depictions of sexual sublimation.

Banse set the tone by kicking the proceedings off with Die Junge Nonne (The Young Nun), a performance that was anything but religious. Smoky toned, and with a suggestive fluency of line, she projects an ambivalent mixture of innocence and knowingness. The song's melodic lines curl upwards with a heady rapture. Her delivery of the line, "Come heavenly bridegroom, claim your bride", carried with it a whiff of indecency.

Thereafter, she presented us with a gallery of sensuous character portraits. Im Grünen hinted at other open-air pleasures than simply going for a walk. She turned Walter Scott's Lady of the Lake into a seductive figure closer to Keats's La Belle Dame Sans Merci; Raste Krieger is apparently a lullaby addressed to an exhausted soldier, though you got the impression that neither of them were actually going to get much sleep. The high point, however, came with her portrayal of Mignon, the androgynous, tragic heroine of Goethe's Wilhelm Meister, suggesting both waif-like fragility and irreparable emotional damage. Henschel joined her for Mignon Und Der Harfner, one of Schubert's rare duets, in which he played Mignon's demented father, abstractedly echoing the beautiful phrases in tones of deranged intensity.

Henschel is, first and foremost, an outstanding vocal actor, capable of transcending occasional limitations of tone and technique - a metallic quality when the voice is under pressure, moments of hollowness in the lower registers - with verbal and psychological projections of tremendous subtlety and power.

He tackled Im Freien with a hushed, rapt sensuality. Addressed to a sleeping male beloved, it's usually sung by a woman. The homoerotic implications of Henschel's performance asserted a universality of emotion that went beyond gender and sexual orientation. He closed the evening with the seven Rellstab settings from Schwanengesang, done so immaculately that you wanted the cycle in its entirety. The famous Serenade was full of seditious urgency. In Der Ferne encapsulated extremes of emotional exhaustion. The final Abschied (Farewell) combined wit with a tender nostalgia.

That Henschel and Banse have yet to achieve star status is perhaps surprising. The evening revealed both of them to be great artists, ranking among the finest Lieder singers of our times.

webTitle: Ask yourself: Is this the  brightest way to shop?

fields.headline: Ask yourself: Is this the  brightest way to shop?
fields.standfirst:
Liz Stuart trawls the high streets and finds that retail credit deals are expensive for the customer

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Liz Stuart trawls the high streets and finds that retail credit deals are expensive for the customer.
fields.body:
A brighter way to shop at Argos - that's what last month's press release launching Argos's first storecard said. But with an annual interest rate of 27% charged on sums which are not paid off at the end of the month, it might have been more accurate to dub it shopping for the dumb.

The store says, in its defence, that it is still in the top quartile for cheapest providers and that it has had to weigh up the risk it takes that customers will default. Argos is not alone. Most major department stores and retail chains promote an in-house card charging rates way in excess of those available on bank credit cards.

Jaeger's is 29.8%, Country Casuals charges 30.7%, all Creation cards, which can be used in shops such as Liberty, Millets and Selfridges, have a rate of 30.9%, while The Timecard, which can be used at Comet, B&Q, Woolworths, Superdrug and Next, charges customers who fail to pay off their total balance each month a massive 31.9%.

This is at a time when credit is coming down in price. All the major credit card providers have been forced to bring down their rates by competition from new entrants to the market, but store cards continue to charge more than double credit cards. Buy your £100 dress on your Egg card, for instance, and you would be subject to a rate of just 11.9%, following an introductory offer period of six months' free credit.

In-store credit is not only expensive, it is also very readily available, even pushed. In one morning of shopping I was offered £6,000 to spend in various shops. Sometimes I had to ask for it, but in other stores the offer was made without my initiating the conversation. In shops selling clothes aimed at the teenage market, advertisements scream: "It couldn't be easier to apply - do it now! " and: "Up to £500 to spend instantly."

And in the week when the government is slapping down banks and other credit card providers for not making their interest rates prominent, I found that the annual percentage rate (APR) did not appear in the majority of store card leaflets. When questioned on the mechanics of the cards which their stores were selling in the same way as any other merchandise, the assistant often did not understand the most basic details of the card and, at other times, their information was either misleading or wrong. In Ted Baker, when asked about the annual percentage rate, I was given the monthly interest rate.

A spokeswoman for Arcardia, the group whose portfolio includes Warehouse and Miss Selfridge, insists: "All our staff are trained within two weeks of starting. They should know what the rates are and help the customer fill out the form." So, why do people continue to take out these cards? Why would you want to sign up for a card which can be used in a limited set of stores, with way above average interest rates for credit and which allows a shop to consider you as part of its "family" - giving it access to raid your details on its database for marketing needs?

For some people, this sense of belonging is, in fact, what persuades them to take a card in the first place, and in some cases, the emotional worth of card membership is echoed by its financial worth. For others, it is the range of special deals to which card membership gives access, although these are generally "feelgood" offers, such as invitations to exclusive shopping evenings, which are of low commercial value.

Lorraine Brannan, head of marketing at Marks & Spencer, which now accepts bank credit cards, admits that she is puzzled, adding that applications for the M&S card have been at the steady rate of around 4,000 a month for at least two years.

"The company is currently conducting research into quite why so many people do opt for the card," she says. Steve Worthington, professor of marketing of financial services at Staffordshire University, suggests that customers opt for these cards because they like to have a line of credit which is unknown to their bank.

Yet shops can afford to offer credit lines for less and one or two do John Lewis's card has a standard rate of just 13%, aping the main credit card providers. It goes to show that the 25%-30% rates charged by are store groups are little more than a rip-off.

M&S has cut its card rate to 18.9% (Barclaycard, the number one provider of credit cards, charges 19.4%). Ms Brannan says: "We took a decision to ensure that our card is in line with other means of payment ... that option is open to other retailers: it is a commercial decision that they take."

Professor Worthington adds that one reason why store cards are so expensive relative to credit cards is that the card administrators do not have the same range of alternative income streams available to them: "These finance companies do not have the benefit of the annual fee which is charged on some credit cards, nor do they have the merchant service charge (1%). Having said this, however, the charges are still very high."

The Arcadia spokeswoman says: "We have a long-standing relationship with our partner who provides the card. I don't want to be drawn into the rate itself." But she insists that the group sees itself as "value for money".

Warehouse
Credit limit:
I was offered up to £500 instantly. APR:
30.9% Provider:
Creation Financial Services. Perks:
10% off initial purchase; set of vouchers, for example, 15% at Wallis and £5 off at JJB Sports if you spend £50 or more or £50 next holiday from Holiday Club; cardholder evenings. Verdict :
The assistant did not know the rate and had to look it up. She was very vague about the precise nature of the card's perks: "You get invites to launches and offers and stuff."

Oasis
Credit limit:
Up to £500 instantly "yep, that means you can spend it today" boasts the brochure. APR :
29.9%
Provider:
Ikano Financial Services.
Perks:
A good range of significant perks: aside from the usual shopping evenings with goodie bags, each month there are special offers, such as 10% off all leatherware or two for one Eurostar tickets; three months' interest-free credit over Christmas.

The assistant was very helpful and understood all the rates and how the card works. fields.headline: The darker side of Schubert
fields.standfirst:
Alban Berg Quartet
Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
Alban Berg Quartet
Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating: *****
fields.body:
It's unusual enough for a string quartet to pack out a concert hall, let alone to receive the kind of ovation that greeted the Alban Berg Quartet after the final chord of this exhilarating concert. But the reputation of the Viennese ensemble is formidable - some claim they are the best quartet in the world - and their regular appearances here at the South Bank have earned them a demonstrative body of London supporters.

Most of the crowd were probably there to hear Schubert's sweeping and melodious Quintet in C. Yet the less obviously listenable work that preceded it, Bartok's Sixth Quartet, made an interesting companion piece. One perhaps expects something discomfiting from Bartok, especially from a work written, like this one, at the outbreak of war and during a time of great personal unhappiness. What was more surprising was the light, or rather the shade, that it threw on the deceptively sunny Quintet.

The members of the Alban Berg Quartet, who have been together now for more than a quarter of a century, sounded at home with both composers. Essentially they are a band of equals. Cellist Valentin Erben is a player of sensitivity blessed with a fabulous-sounding instrument. Violist Thomas Kakuska and second violinist Gerhard Schulz are both fine soloists in their own right. Yet the leader, Günter Pichler, often emerges as a dominant character, his playing physically strong and never merely decorative. Often at moments of greatest emphasis he actually leaves his seat.

It seemed that Bartok's Sixth Quartet could have been written for these players; they made short work of its considerable technical demands, cutting through them to its unsettling heart. Moments of extreme turbulence coalesced into phrases of almost pastoral lyricism without losing impact, and even in the monstrous Burlesque movement the players never compromised on tone. The resulting performance was one that strung out the nerves.

Schubert's Quintet is often thought of as comfortable; this performance, though, was something of a revelation. Joined by cellist Heinrich Schiff, the players drew out the elements of the work that jar with its mellifluous surface. While the melodies of the first movement were as sweet as ever, they found the same kind of turbulence within the Adagio as in the Bartok, and the bars before the return of that movement's theme took on a real sense of desolation.

Schubert was only two weeks from death when he completed this score; many composers in similar positions have believed themselves to be writing their own requiem. We were made to feel that he could have created himself no more eloquent a memorial than this.

webTitle: World music review: Afro-Cuban All Stars

fields.headline: Doing the Afro-Cuban stomp
fields.standfirst:
Afro-Cuban All Stars
Bridgewater Hall
Manchester
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Afro-Cuban All Stars
Bridgewater Hall
Manchester
Rating: ***
fields.body:
The release of the Buena Vista Social Club album in 1996 signalled a new dawn for Cuban music, catapulting long-forgotten musicians into the spotlight and making belated superstars out of pianist Ruben Gonzalez, singer Ibrahim Ferrer and band leader and World Circuit Records mainman Juan de Marcos Gonzalez. Next in line for the honour of cluttering up coffee tables throughout the land is vocalist Felix Baloy, whose new album is a collaboration with Gonzalez's commercially invulnerable Afro-Cuban All Stars, and who features as star vocalist in that group's latest stomping live extravaganza.

Strolling on stage in a sharp turquoise suit and panama hat, Baloy is clearly relishing his new found celebrity. While Juan de Marcos will shuffle funkily, conducting his band and occasionally knocking his knees together, Baloy strolls around the auditorium shaking hands with old men and flirting with young ladies. The All Stars look fantastic in their gold suits and enormous moustaches, and they rustle up their usual feast of clattering congas, razor-sharp brass stabs and summery piano motifs, all the time beaming at us as if we are their long-lost relatives.

As skilfully orchestrated as an Ellington big band, the ensemble is a veritable human engine, albeit one that has forgotten how to change gear. The energy and volume become overbearing after a while, particularly when you remember that you're supposed to be listening to a "featured" vocalist.

Baloy's voice is reputed to be a wonderful instrument, but here he is not so much supported by the other musicians as thrown into a pit with them and forced to slug it out. There are a couple of slower, sparser numbers where we realise that he is not simply bellowing mindlessly into his microphone, but these tunes have a tendency to sink into cloying sentimentality - again not really giving the vocalist a chance to communicate on an emotional level.

To be fair on the All Stars, the odds are somewhat stacked against them in this large, booming venue. The acoustics are woolly, blunting all the edges that Juan de Marcos has no doubt been sharpening recently, and the very act of sitting down to listen to what is essentially dance music feels all wrong. Most of what is played tonight is party music, pure and simple; yet the only people having a party are on the stage.

 At the Royal Festival Hall, London (020-7960 4242), tonight, and the Corn Exchange, Brighton (01273 709709), tomorrow.

fields.headline: 1m Britons own second homes
fields.standfirst:
Better mortgage deals fuel rise in demand for an extra property

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Better mortgage deals fuel rise in demand for an extra property.
fields.body:
Britain is becoming a nation of second home owners, with more than a million people owning another property for holidays or as an investment.

Better mortgage deals and a healthy economy have brought what was once a luxury purchase for the rich within reach of more households, according to the Council for Mortgage Lenders, the trade body representing banks and building societies.

Two thirds of buyers rent out their second home, while the rest use it as a holiday house or a long-term investment.

"Flats and terraced houses in highly desirable city and town centres, such as London, Edinburgh and Bristol, are being bought up effectively as a long-term pension fund," the CML said.

Second home ownership has risen from 250,000 10 years ago to 1.139m today - representing 5.6% of the population.

"Buying a second home usually requires a higher than average income, but it is no longer the preserve of the rich," said the CML's deputy director general, Peter Williams.

The increase is due partly to looser borrowing requirements. Mortgage lenders used to require hefty deposits for second homes but are now encouraging those with spare cash to consider property as an investment.

Competition in the mortgage market had forced lenders to relax their rules, said Peter Mounty, head of communications at Cheltenham and Gloucester.

They were "taking a more liberal approach to how people choose to spend their own money", he said. "The relaxation in the way industry views second homes has fuelled the rise in demand."

But the trend is pushing up prices in popular locations. Well-established holiday destinations such as Cornwall and Devon have already seen prices soar, so buyers are searching for cheaper seaside towns.

In Weymouth the estate agent Tony Gregson has seen an explosion in interest by second home buyers in the past 18 months. The new marina in the centre of town is the lure for many. "We have buyers who have a £500,000 boat in the harbour and are looking for a flat close by," he said.

A two-bedroom flat in a converted warehouse by the harbour fetches £200,000 - expensive by local standards but a snip for buyers used to stratospheric London prices.

Poor summer weather has attracted British buyers to warm spots throughout southern Europe, while the strong pound and cut-price air fares have made foreign property more affordable.

"The time to buy in Europe has probably never been better, with estate agents reporting large numbers of Britons seeking to buy cut-price second homes," the CML said.

"Wealthy Britons wanting to retire to the sun are heading to the Costa del Sol, rather than to Tuscany, Malta or the Algarve."

France, Italy, Spain and Portugal are the most popular locations for second homes abroad. Advertisements for houses for sale often refer to their proximity to Buzz, Go and EasyJet destinations.

Property in Europe is on average cheaper than in Britain. In France, the choice of most second home buyers, a rundown property in the north-east can go for as little as £25,000, according to the CML.

fields.headline: Into the Mystic
fields.standfirst:
Riverside Studios
London
Rating: *
fields.trailText:
Riverside Studios
London
Rating: *
fields.body:
The Harold Shipman affair and the children's organ scandal has had the medical profession tottering on its pedestal in recent months. Now Peter Wolf's play about DNA, genetic engineering and diseases of the mind paints a picture of doctors so incompetent, uncaring and arrogant that it adds to the idea that it might be safer to steer clear of hospitals.

Jade, however, adores hospitals. They are her favourite place. She loves them so much that she's there every Monday in Accident and Emergency, the wounds on her body being tended to by Chris, a doctor who knows that, although blood is pouring out of her self-inflicted cuts, it is her mind that really hurts. He wants her to get professional help, but help arrives in the form of religious nutter Robbie.

Will God or the doctors do for Jade first? It's a choice between the devil and the deep blue sea, particularly when Dr Chris is suspended from his job for negligence and starts to take a closer personal interest in Jade, who is by now displaying all the signs of stigmata. Her hands and feet weep blood and there is a wound in her side.

Into the Mystic was produced by the disabled theatre company Graeae, which has done some exceptionally fine work in the past couple of years that has seriously explored our relationship to our bodies in thought-provokingly theatrical ways. And it was developed through the Disabled Writers' Mentoring Scheme, which pairs disabled writers with established writers. Wolf's mentor was Mark Ravenhill. One might have guessed that from the style and thematic concerns of the piece, but you wonder why Ravenhill didn't do more to make the piece more coherent. I spent a lot of this 75 minutes both baffled and, I am sorry to say, bored.

My suspicion is that director Jenny Sealey has tried to paper over the cracks in the writing with a stylish production that makes particularly effective use of video to create the buzzy, edgy urban environment. But from Robbie's arrival into the action, Sealey pitches things so high that the combination of the production's increasingly creepy religious imagery and a script that is ever more incoherent creates a kind of sensory overload. It becomes like seeing a play in a foreign language: you understand odd words and sometimes seem to be getting the gist, but entire passages remain incomprehensible. I never found out - or even cared - why everyone was shouting a lot and taking their clothes off.

 Until February 10. Box office: 020-8237 1111. Then touring until the end of March.

He wants her to get professional help, but help arrives in the form of religious nutter Robbie. Will God or the doctors do for Jade first? It's a choice between the devil and the deep blue sea, particularly when Dr Chris is suspended from his job for negligence and starts to take a closer personal interest in Jade, who is by now displaying all the signs of stigmata. Her hands and feet weep blood and there is a wound in her side. Into the Mystic was produced by the disabled theatre company Graeae, which has done some exceptionally fine work in the past couple of years that has seriously explored our relationship to our bodies in thought-provokingly theatrical ways. And it was developed through the Disabled Writers' Mentoring Scheme, which pairs disabled writers with established writers. Wolf's mentor was Mark Ravenhill. One might have guessed that from the style and thematic concerns of the piece, but you wonder why Ravenhill didn't do more to make the piece more coherent. I spent a lot of this 75 minutes both baffled and, I am sorry to say, bored. My suspicion is that director Jenny Sealey has tried to paper over the cracks in the writing with a stylish production that makes particularly effective use of video to create the buzzy, edgy urban environment. But from Robbie's arrival into the action, Sealey pitches things so high that the combination of the production's increasingly creepy religious imagery and a script that is ever more incoherent creates a kind of sensory overload. It becomes like seeing a play in a foreign language: you understand odd words and sometimes seem to be getting the gist, but entire passages remain incomprehensible. I never found out - or even cared - why everyone was shouting a lot and taking their clothes off.  Until February 10. Box office: 020-8237 1111. Then touring until the end of March.

webTitle: Housebuilders offers - read the small print

fields.headline: Deals too good to be true?
fields.standfirst: Housebuilders are making all sorts of offers to attract buyers. But make sure you read the small print, advises Elizabeth Langton
fields.trailText: Housebuilders are making all sorts of offers to attract buyers. But make sure you read the small print, advises Elizabeth Langton.
fields.body:
In every high street retailers are urging consumers to "buy one and get one free" or snap up a once in a lifetime half-price purchase as the new year sales stumble into February. Housebuilders are now playing the same game. In many areas of the country the market is quiet and, in a bid to sell homes, builders are offering part-exchange, legal fees paid, even free fitted carpets.

As trading standards officers will confirm, offers that appear too good to be true usually are, and experts warn buyers against signing up to the deals without taking independent advice. According to Ray Boulger of mortgage brokers Charcol, builders include a margin in the asking price to cover the costs of buyer incentives.

One of the most popular incentives on offer is part-exchange, a gimmick that housebuilder Barratt claims to have pioneered in 1971. Since then about 75,000 homebuyers have taken advantage of it, says Barratt group chairman Frank Eaton.

After buyers have reserved their new home under a part-exchange offer, Barratt will arrange for their present property to be valued by an independent chartered surveyor or valuer. The company then makes the seller an offer on the property (subject to contract and any surveys) within seven days. The sale progresses as normal and the customer remains in their current home until the new one is ready.

In order to qualify, movers need to move upmarket and buy a home that is worth at least 30% more than the value of their current home. According to Barratt, the schemes save movers the hassle of selling their home, estate agent's fees, the possibility of getting stuck in a chain and last-minute price haggling.

Barratt is advertising part-exchange deals at Westfield Place, a development of houses and apartments in Feltham, west London. Fairclough Homes' part-exchange deals at Hartham Place in Hertford stipulate the new home must cost 30% more than buyers' current home and come from the Hertfordshire area. Here, small four-bedroom homes are on offer for £280,000.

Part-exchange offers usually only apply to specific properties on a development, often to the less appealing plots that the developer may have difficulty shifting. The most obvious benefit of part-exchange is that sellers don't have to worry about finding a buyer for their home or about getting stuck in a chain, says Mr Boulger.

But he advises movers thinking of taking this route to ensure they get a reasonable price from the builder for the property they're selling. Usually, developers will get a couple of estate agents or surveyors to value the property and take a price in the middle of the two valuations. The developer will offer the seller anything between 93-100% of the value of the property, says Mr Boulger.

Prudent sellers will check how much their home is worth with estate agents before they enter into a part-exchange contract. However, those selling an unusual property should proceed with caution.

On some developments Barratt offers a free agency selling service. This means buyers can reserve a Barratt home "off plan" or at an early stage of construction. Buyers secure their new home at a fixed price while Barratt sells their existing home following a valuation and after agreeing a "realistic" asking price with the owner.

Barratt says it then markets the property professionally - "using marketing skills and selective sales incentives to find a buyer". In the heady days of the 1980s the absence of savings to put down as a deposit on a house failed to prevent many first time buyers from securing their first home.

Housebuilders are targeting the same group of aspiring homeowners by offering to pay a 5% deposit to allow them to buy a new home. Fairview New Homes is offering to pay deposits on properties in Cricklewood, North Woolwich, Enfield and Greenwich. Wimpey Homes will pay a 5% deposit on selected homes at developments in Chessington, Hillingdon and Hounslow. Fairclough Homes North West is offering first-time buyer properties in Oswaldwhistle under similar schemes.

In theory the offers are very attractive. However, buyers may have problems when it comes to applying for a mortgage. If a property costs £100,000 and the builder says it will pay 5%, the buyer will apply for a £95,000 mortgage, says Mr Boulger. But what if the lenders' valuer says the property is only worth £95,000 because that is the final cost. Then the buyer will have to come up with 5% of the £95,000 as a deposit. The only way forward will be to get a 100% mortgage, generally with a higher interest rate.

Some builders will get particular lenders to agree to accept the 5% reduction as a deposit rather than as a reduction in purchase price. This means "on completion the builder gets 95% of the theoretical purchase price from the lender and the remaining 5% is written off", he says.

Mr Boulger urges buyers to haggle. "The sales consultant will have some leeway in terms of negotiating. Maybe 5%, maybe less. Whatever price the builders are quoting is a guide price."

Fairclough Homes
Barratt Homes
Wimpey Homes
Fairview Homes

webTitle: Watchdog offers hope of compensation deal

fields.headline: Watchdog offers hope of compensation deal
fields.standfirst:
More than 100,000 policyholders could be on their way to compensation payments from a second pensions scandal

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: More than 100,000 policyholders could be on their way to compensation payments from a second pensions scandal.
fields.body:
More than 100,000 policyholders could be on their way to compensation payments from pensions scandal No 2 - the first was personal pensions- according to figures released this week by the watchdog, the Financial Services Authority. But these figures are likely to be just the tip of the iceberg.

The payments to this group alone, likely to total £200m, are recompense for the mis-selling of free standing additional voluntary contributions - the top up retirement plans better known as FSAVCs.

These policies were sold mainly by commission-driven direct salesforces, but often by IFAs, to employees who would nearly always have been better off with a top-up AVC plan from their own employer where charges are far lower.

Because of the huge costs involved in FSAVCs, their values will be lower than AVCs invested in the same underlying fund. Some employers also added cash of their own to match workforce contributions - FSAVC holders lost out on these as well.

FSAVC sales started in April 1988. And 1.2m were sold before the FSA started to probe the plans for potential mis-selling in August 1999.

The mathematics involved in working out who lost out - and to what extent - are complicated. And it has, so far, been left to insurance companies to identify the worst hit victims. Their cases go to a review process ahead of possible compensation offers.

Up to this week, the insurers have found 109,800 policyholders who "will be invited to request a review" - a formality to set the ball rolling.

But there could be many more. The FSAVC review has ordered life companies to look at cases in phases with the biggest losers coming first.

This week's figures cover those who would otherwise have been in matched AVC schemes where the policyholder could have benefited from extra employer payments and other subsidised AVCs where companies would have enhanced contributions.

But hundreds of thousands of others could be drawn in later. The insurers have until June 2002 to complete their review - a process sure to throw up more losers.

FSAVCs were sold as monthly contracts based on no more than 15% of total earnings after other company pension payments. Many insurers will raid shareholder funds for the eventual compensation bills, although mutuals involved will have to find the compensation cash from their with-profits funds.

But there are no plans to ask salesforces or their directors to pay back the commission they earned.

FSAVC sellers claimed the plans offered wider investment choices and were more flexible for staff who switched jobs.

fields.headline: Miserly interest rates get the bird
fields.standfirst: Banks and building societies are shortchanging savers with absurdly low returns on some accounts. Rupert Jones reports
fields.trailText: Banks and building societies are shortchanging savers with absurdly low returns on some accounts. Rupert Jones reports.
fields.body:
Loyal savers are still being short-changed by major high street banks and building societies, some of which are getting round the code of practice designed to protect customers, Consumers' Association magazine Which? claimed this week.

It turned the spotlight on several leading institutions paying paltry rates to instant access-style account-holders, among them Abbey National, Alliance & Leicester, Northern Rock and the Woolwich.

Abbey National's Instant Saver account pays just 0.5% gross interest on balances of £500, or 1% gross if you have £2,500 stashed away. However, another of its recently launched easy-access accounts, Flexible Saver, pays 4% gross (3% gross if branches are used).

Alliance & Leicester's Instant Access account currently pays 1% gross on £500 and 1.15% gross on £2,500, while its newer EasySaver instant-access account pays 5.3% gross. The accounts work in a slightly different way but that is still a huge differential.

Northern Rock is also highlighted - its Instant Access account pays 0.15% gross on £1, and a tiny 0.55% gross on £10,000, though it will award you a 0.5% interest bonus if you make no withdrawals in a year. Woolwich pays just 0.5% gross on its Prime Gold instant-access account.

Compare these with Nationwide's instant-access InvestDirect account, which pays 5.3% gross on balances of between £1 and £10,000. It's a postal account, but a cash card is available. Standard Life Bank's no-notice Direct Access account, operated by phone, pays from 5.8% gross on £1.

Which? claims that a few of the accounts paying a pittance have effectively been discontinued and that the institutions concerned are "getting round" the banking code which is supposed to ensure consumers don't lose out. There are special rules in the banking industry's code of practice relating to so-called "superseded" accounts - those no longer available to new customers or which are no longer promoted.

Back in 1998 the industry came under fire over the way people with money in these accounts were being treated. There was an outcry about some banks launching new accounts paying table-topping rates while cutting rates on old accounts and not alerting savers that they could get a better deal by switching.

In response the banking code was tightened up and now states that if you have money in an account that's no longer available to new customers, or isn't being advertised, the bank must either keep the rate on that account at the same level as an account with similar features that is currently available, or it must switch you into an account with similar features. If the bank doesn't have a similar account it must help you to switch into another of its products.

Last summer Bristol & West was ordered to pay more interest to 4,000 savers with money in superseded accounts after it was discovered they were being paid just 0.1% on all balances, even if they had £100,000-plus invested. It now looks likely that a number of other banks will be ordered to do the same because the Banking Code Standards Board, the watchdog that checks banks are obeying the code, has been carrying out its own investigation into superseded accounts.

The BCSB is currently talking to several institutions about its findings and revealed this week it may take disciplinary action against some. This would involve naming and shaming.

Which? argues that the banking code needs to be tightened up again. The magazine claims Abbey National's Instant Saver and Woolwich's Prime Gold are not being actively marketed and so should have been classed as superseded, which arguably would have meant people with money in these would have got a better deal.

But the two banks reject the claims. Abbey says it is "whiter than white" as regards superseded accounts and always follows the rules laid down in the code. The Woolwich says Prime Gold is not superseded or obselete, is still available for sale and is the only passbook account it offers.

If you're looking for more information about savings rates, a new website called Moneyadder.com may be worth a look. Developed by two former senior bankers, Moneyadder says it will provide savers with up-to-date information on the best accounts in the market. It is even offering to email you if the rate changes on your account or a new product is launched that may offer a better deal.

fields.headline: Rates cut on the cards
fields.standfirst:
Ministers are considering bringing in new rules covering interest levels and other charges we pay on our plastic. Rupert Jones reports

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Ministers are considering bringing in new rules covering interest levels and other charges we pay on our plastic. Rupert Jones reports.
fields.body:
New rules to clean up the credit card industry, which could force down the interest rates millions of people pay, were unveiled by the government this week.

Ministers have decided to introduce minimum standards after concluding that many cardholders get a poor deal. They believe too many people are paying excessively high interest rates or are being clobbered with exorbitant small-print charges for paying just a day or two late or going over credit limits.

The new regime will be similar to the CAT-marking system already in force for Isas and mortgages. What prompted the most interest was the revelation that the Treasury is considering capping the interest rates people pay by insisting they are set at no more than a certain amount above the Bank of England base rate (currently 6%). But this idea is likely to face opposition from some of the industry's big players who will say the government shouldn't be meddling in the setting of rates.

However, where the government seems less likely to back down is on its proposal that, in order to win the CAT-mark of quality, a card would not be able to charge an annual fee.

One of the players which will come under pressure to shape up is Barclaycard, the UK's largest credit card issuer with 7.8m cardholders, whose annual percentage rate (APR) is 19.4% - more than three times the base rate - and which is one of the few providers which still impose an annual fee.

Unfortunately, the proposed rules are voluntary, so card issuers won't have to comply - but ministers will be hoping that a large proportion of the UK's issuers will adopt them, and there will clearly be pressure on firms to do this or risk losing customers to rivals.

Strictly speaking, the new rules don't apply to store cards, many of which are notorious for extremely high rates - typically around 29-30% APR. But some of the more responsible store card providers might decide to adopt them. Marks & Spencer, the UK's largest store card issuer with 6.1m cards and one of the lowest APRs (18.9%), said it would be studying the new rules "to see whether there are things we should be looking at".

Ministers say the new standards - which are likely to be in force by the end of the year - will help people to shop around for the best deal and ensure they are not hit by hidden charges. It spells good news for the UK's 25m credit card holders who between them have £24bn of outstanding debt attracting interest.

The Treasury says it has not yet made up its mind about whether it will insist interest rates are linked to the bank base rate. They could decide that a card's interest rate must be within X percentage points of the base rate (it hasn't yet said what the "X" might be).

Alternatively, it could insist that the interest rate must track any downward movement in the base rate within, say, 28 days, so people are not left stranded on high rates when interest rates are dropping. The other main requirements of the new regime are:

 All credit card statements must clearly state the annual percentage rate (APR); from what date interest is charged (some card issuers charge interest from the date the item is charged to the account, others charge from the date the goods are bought) and all other charges.

 No annual fee (aside from Barclaycard, those who still charge customers a fee include Abbey National, Clydesdale Bank) and Royal Bank of Scotland.

 No minimum spending limit.

 All information to be expressed in language that is fair, clear and not misleading.

 Any late payment penalty must be no higher than £20 and the fee for exceeding your credit limit can be no more than £5 (these two figures are provisional).

The second of these two could really sort the men from the boys, as many providers currently charge a fee for going over your credit limit well in excess of £5. In the case of NatWest, Lloyds TSB and RBS Advanta the fee is currently £15, while Egg charges a whopping £20

 For cash withdrawals, the fee must be no more than 1.5% (among those charging more than this are Tesco Personal Finance and Smile).

Broadly speaking, credit cards tend to fall into two different camps. There are those such as Barclaycard, which don't offer particularly competitive interest rates but don't impose any of the nasty small-print fees. Then there are others such as Egg's card, which offers a great rate but has lots of fees lurking around.

You should choose a card based on how you use plastic. If you pay off your credit card bill in full each month, thereby avoiding interest charges, the interest rate is pretty irrelevant. So look at the perks on offer. Cashback and air miles are both popular - the Alliance & Leicester MoneyBack card is one of several that gives you cash back depending on how much you spend.

If you don't usually pay off your balance at the end of each month your priority should be a low interest rate. Egg and Capital One Bank are both offering cards with zero per cent introductory APRs for the first six months - after that the rate rises to a not-bad 11.9% and 12.9% respectively.

Egg's card offers the added plus of a cashback scheme. RBS Advanta's card has an introductory APR of 1.9 that lasts longer - until January 1 next year - but after that date the rate jumps to 17.9%.

The other main requirements of the new regime are:  All credit card statements must clearly state the annual percentage rate (APR); from what date interest is charged (some card issuers charge interest from the date the item is charged to the account, others charge from the date the goods are bought) and all other charges.  No annual fee (aside from Barclaycard, those who still charge customers a fee include Abbey National, Clydesdale Bank) and Royal Bank of Scotland.  No minimum spending limit.  All information to be expressed in language that is fair, clear and not misleading.  Any late payment penalty must be no higher than £20 and the fee for exceeding your credit limit can be no more than £5 (these two figures are provisional). The second of these two could really sort the men from the boys, as many providers currently charge a fee for going over your credit limit well in excess of £5. In the case of NatWest, Lloyds TSB and RBS Advanta the fee is currently £15, while Egg charges a whopping £20  For cash withdrawals, the fee must be no more than 1.5% (among those charging more than this are Tesco Personal Finance and Smile). Broadly speaking, credit cards tend to fall into two different camps. There are those such as Barclaycard, which don't offer particularly competitive interest rates but don't impose any of the nasty small-print fees. Then there are others such as Egg's card, which offers a great rate but has lots of fees lurking around. You should choose a card based on how you use plastic. If you pay off your credit card bill in full each month, thereby avoiding interest charges, the interest rate is pretty irrelevant. So look at the perks on offer. Cashback and air miles are both popular - the Alliance & Leicester MoneyBack card is one of several that gives you cash back depending on how much you spend. If you don't usually pay off your balance at the end of each month your priority should be a low interest rate. Egg and Capital One Bank are both offering cards with zero per cent introductory APRs for the first six months - after that the rate rises to a not-bad 11.9% and 12.9% respectively. Egg's card offers the added plus of a cashback scheme. RBS Advanta's card has an introductory APR of 1.9 that lasts longer - until January 1 next year - but after that date the rate jumps to 17.9%.

webTitle: Friends Provident update on float and windfalls

fields.headline: Friends Provident update on float and windfalls
fields.standfirst: One mutual organisation this week gave out more details about the windfalls it will be dishing out while another disappointed carpetbaggers by slamming the door on potential payouts
fields.trailText: One mutual organisation this week gave out more details about the windfalls it will be dishing out while another disappointed carpetbaggers by slamming the door on potential payouts.
fields.body:
One mutual organisation this week gave out more details about the windfalls it will be dishing out while another disappointed carpetbaggers by slamming the door on potential payouts.

Insurer Friends Provident this week began mailing 1.7m policyholders to give them an update about its plans to float on the stock market later this year and pay windfalls which could run into several thousand pounds.

It surprised many observers last May when it revealed its plans to convert to a plc. This week it said the plans were still on track, and provided members give the go-ahead this summer it will float "by the end of the year". The letters going out include a questions and answers leaflet and a "validation form" showing your name, address and policy details, which must be completed and sent back.

Those wanting more information about how much the windfalls might be worth will be disappointed. Friends Provident says it cannot yet give any indications about the value of the free shares or even how many shares people will receive. Analysts have claimed the insurer could have a flotation value of £4bn-£4.5bn, which, divided between 1.7m policyholders, would suggest average payouts of around £2,500.

However, in reality, many of the 750,000 policyholders holding with-profits policies (such as some endowments and personal pensions) are likely to get more than this, while the 1m or so non-with-profits policyholders will probably only get a few hundred pounds each.

Every eligible policyholder will receive a fixed handout of shares, while the with-profits people will receive an additional variable handout of shares that will depend on the value of their policy. To qualify for a windfall you must have taken out your policy before May 4 2000, and it must remain in force until a future date yet to be announced.

Unfortunately, policies originally taken out with companies later taken over by Friends Provident, such as London & Manchester, do not confer membership. Investing in a unit trust also doesn't make you a member. There is good news for those with free-standing additional voluntary contribution (FSAVC) pension top-up policies, and those who bought a second-hand Friends Provident endowment policy before May 4. Provided members agree, they will qualify for windfalls. For the windfalls to go ahead, 75% of the members who vote this summer must approve the plans.

This week also saw Chelsea building society announce it has thrown out an attempt to force it to hold a vote on converting to a bank. It rejected as "invalid" the conversion resolution submitted by rebel member Andy Naughton-Doe.

fields.headline: Horace Walpole's skeletons come out in Glasgow
fields.standfirst:
Mysterious Mother
Citizens Theatre
Glasgow
Rating: *
fields.trailText:
Mysterious Mother
Citizens Theatre
Glasgow
Rating: *
fields.body:
It's as if Anne McKevitt has been called in to do a gothic makeover. The set is black on black, the floor strewn with grey confetti, a central seat like a giant, dark wedding cake by caterers from hell. The only lights are the stars in the blackest sky and huddles of candles dripping with foreboding.

You'd expect nothing less for a play by Horace Walpole, the fourth Earl of Orford and pioneer of the Gothic novel with The Castle of Otranto in 1765. Three years later he penned this tale of mother-son incest, never performed until now. The reason, we're told, is that its subject was too daring for its time, though the existence of earlier incest dramas ('Tis Pity She's a Whore springs to mind, as does Oedipus and his complex) suggests there might be other factors.

Maybe it's because the play is heavy, leaden and dramatically unsatisfying. The cast do their best to wade through Walpole's stultifying blank verse - and it's a shame this is all they have to work with, as there are some stunning performances, especially from Angela Chadfield as the Countess and Estelle Morgan as Adelisa, the child born of the incestuous relationship.

Walpole's target is not the mother and son's crime but clerical corruption, and this is one of the play's problems. The first hour is dominated by the relationship between the Countess and her priest, the sinister Benedict (Matthew Zajac), with the revelation of badness squashed into the last half hour. There is no easy relationship, or an especially convincing one, between these two aspects of the play. So when the full horror is revealed - Edmund, the son, has unknowingly married his own daughter and sister - its impact is sensational rather than emotional. Chadfield does a excellent messy suicide after much wailing, but we don't care. Adelisa gets sent to a nunnery, which will probably be more fun than this play.

Despite the strength of the performances and the evocative set, The Mysterious Mother is ultimately a bad advert for keeping it in the family, and a good one for leaving things undisturbed in the cupboard full of unperformed stinkers.

 Until February 24. Box office: 0141-429 0022.
